column7: Last Friday I handed over my responsibilities as the Chief Naval Logistics Officer (CNLO) to Rear Admiral Paul Murphy, after 5 years in the role. Remarkably I discovered that I am the longest serving CNLO since WW2. The Branch marked the occasion in the most remarkable way, not least by presenting me with a genuine copper rum measure cup which originated from the A Class WW2 destroyer HMS ACTIVE. The Type 21 frigate ACTIVE was one of my first ships and retains a special place in my heart. It has been an enormous privilege to lead the Logistics Branch over the past 5 years and I have been constantly amazed at the professionalism, sacrifice and dedication that our sailors exhibit, as they deliver global logistic support day in day out. They are a seriously talented and impressive cadre of men and women and I have been so proud of all they have achieved. #logistics#royalnavy

In Celebration of Women's History Month, AABE Atlanta Chapter hosted its Annual Hard Hat and Heels event. Theme: Leading with Purpose: Women's Role in Shaping a Diverse Enterprise. I had the opportunity to welcome Dr. Felicia Phillips as our Keynote Speaker and she left a lasting impact on each of us in that room. Some of her words; You are not your Title, You are your Purpose, Infuse your work with your Values. She challenged us all to determine, What truly matters to us? What kind of Impact do I want to make in the world? And How can my skills and talents be used to create positive change? Truly looking forward to her speaking at the AABE National Conference in Anaheim, California next month.  Congratulations Tiffany Callaway Ferrell for your Intentional Women's Award, so well deserved. #AABE #womenhistorymonth #burnsmaclife

column7: March Madness - Bracketology ChickYep. It's that time of year again. The frenzied 1st 4 days of the NCAA Men's College Basketball Tournament, when it's pretty-much wall-to-wall, simultaneous games on 4 TV channels, where 64 teams start going at it.It's a time when our quiet, serene home becomes a seeming war zone, with the TV, iPhones and iPads streaming every possible game, angle and commentary And printed / marked-up / crumpled-up brackets are strewn around the living room.It's a yearly moment in time when Renee (my wife and a very, very serious and knowledgeable sports fan) goes temporarily insane And the raging emotion, joy, anger, elation, screaming, referee conspiracy theories and thrill of victory during the best, nail biting completion of the year Demonically possesses her.It's a wonderful time that's been going-on for decades.  I always try to take-off the Thursday and Friday afternoons that make-up the 1st round.  To watch the non-stop action and more importantly, to enjoy Renee in rare form (which also happens during the Stanely Cup Playoffs).As we speak, one of her brackets is leading the group (and she won't shut-up about it) What's worse is she's really, really good at Fantasy Football (back-to-back league champion, etc., but that's another story, and she won't shut-up about that either).Here's a little video tribute to give you some perspective (turn-up the volume).

column7: Looking for motivation to write?  Stop scrolling and consider this: An act of creation is gloriously affirmative for ourselves and can be a gift to others. It's really good for a person. It doesn't have to be a masterpiece. It just has to be something that is our own truth. Maybe we even decide to put it out there for others. It might be a book, an idea for a new product or a loaf of bread. As long as creation is happening, we are really living. #writing #creativity

Celebrating #WorldWaterDay! Access to clean water and sanitation facilities is changing lives in rural Kenya”we see it every day on TKP's six campuses. As part of our commitment to creating high-quality schools that meet international WASH standards, TKP drills a freshwater well on each campus during the early years of campus development. Currently, five campuses have wells, with the sixth campus (Oloilalei) in the process of installation Clean water is a fundamental necessity”it has a far-reaching impact on health, education, nutrition, and overall quality of life.” Christine Hartter, VP of Communications and Development from the UN Sustainable Development Goal #6 essay Thank you for providing vital water sources across TKP schools for 2,100 students. Asante sana! Essay reference: https://lnkd.in/ezR4MQGF#water #cleanwater #worldwaterday #cleanwaterforall

column7: Now that the March Madness is underway, I have a question. When filling out your brackets “ do you pick your winners based on your head or your heart? I'll admit  for me, it's all heart. column7: "Let the generations know that women in uniform also guaranteed our freedom, that our resolve was just as great as the brave men who stood among us."General (Ret) Wilma L. Vaught Did you know Virginia boasts having the largest percentage of woman Veterans per population size of any state?While I wasn't born in the state of Virginia (or any state for that matter--Navy Brat), I do call Virginia my home.This week marks the seventh consecutive year that Virginia as designated an entire week to celebrate its women Veterans. The Commonwealth sets aside the third week of March during Women's History Month to recognize its more than 108,000 women Veterans.I have always felt at home here and recently the feeling was even more prevalent when I was chosen to be one of a handful of women Veteran stories highlighted by News anchor GeNienne Samuels, PMP of Richmond, Virginia's CBS News Channel 6. Ms. Samuels is such a gracious and professional journalist who along with her amazing photographer brought my journey to life in less than four minutes.  I have to admit my husband and I shed a few tears watching the video.Thank you GeNienne for all the wonderful stories you and your staff present day in and day out about our Veteran Brother and Sisters.Next month marks the closing ceremony for my Vietnam Veteran exhibit, can't believe it's been 15 months since the inception. Thank you Dr. Clay Mountcastle for the opportunity to contribute to the history of that generation.https://lnkd.in/eRGTEU7K#laurahatcherphotography #virginiaveteranwomen #veteransupportingveterans

column7: Poor leadership is building a great team and doing everything in your power to hold onto control. No one can develop and sustain a great company without genuine trust. Recruiting the best people and tying their hands by not giving them the freedom to perform makes no sense. Great leaders know that the soul of their business is their team, and they must allow and trust their team to produce their very best work; that's why you recruited them in the first place.If you want to be a leader, give your team the space to work, create an environment free from the impediments of toxicity and witness significant growth in your company but, more importantly, in your team.Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#leadership #management #leadershipdevelopment #employeeengagement #leaders #people #leadershipfirst #leadershipfirstquotes #executivesandmanagement #inspiration #giffordthomas #entrepeneurship

column7: USW backs Biden; Nippon shops for new Pittsburgh HQThe United Steelworkers (USW) labor union is formally backing incumbent President Joe Biden against former President Donald Trump for the 2024 presidential election just one week after President Biden decried the proposed $14.9 billion buy of US Steel by Japan's Nippon Steel, a deal the USW has railed against since it was announced in December.Meanwhile, Nippon may already be looking in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, for a new US headquarters, according to a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.Nippon “ and US Steel “ went unmentioned in the USW endorsement announcement. The union focused instead on the administration's infrastructure spending push and worker-centric trade policy.Workers and their families are more secure than they were four years ago, thanks to President Biden's leadership. From infrastructure to retirement security, international trade to safer workplaces, President Biden got the job done, USW International president David McCall said. We're honored to back him as he runs for re-election.The Nippon-US Steel deal has received hefty criticism from both the right and the left. Nippon has repeatedly said that it intends to follow US Steel's original plan of investment in its Big River mill in Arkansas. It has also said it does not intend to close any legacy assets in US Steel's heartland. In fact, the company intends to move its US headquarters to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, if the deal is completed. Visit www.fastmarkets.com to read more!United States Steel Corporation United Steelworkers (USW) Nippon Steel Corporation Fastmarkets Fastmarkets Metals and Mining The White House

column7: It was my honor today to participate in the Boys Scouts of America Court of Honor where my local Troop 500 celebrated four Boys Scouts who earned the highest rank in scouting. I read commendations from Federal, State, and Local leaders, including the President of the United States of America, Joe Biden.Eagle Scout is the highest rank attainable in the Scouts BSA program by the Boys Scouts of America. Since its inception in 1911, only four percent of Scouts have earned this rank after a lengthy review process. 65 Scouts have obtained the rank of Eagle Scout in my local Troop 500 since 1996.A big congratulations to the new Eagle Scouts, their family & friends, and the dedicated volunteers who ensure the next generation of leaders are being trained and equipped for service.

Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... Let's go!!Steve Canning Martti Nurminen Jane Broberg Perttu Nihti Katarina Paasi Henrik Smedberg Sam Mele Lars Madsen Christopher Blake Kevin Farrell Jethro Elvin James Welch Sean Delaney Sarah Salzman Bob Booth Simon Hurst Colin Reilly Dean Jacobson Gordon MacNeill Maurice H. column7: The magnitude of the volatility of hot-rolled coil is unique to the U.S. steelmaking industry. In the long term, that's not likely to change, writes Michael Cowden of Steel Market Update."How do steel consumers in the U.S. manage a business with a raw material price that whipsaws even in times of roughly stable demand? Yes, steel is a cyclical business, and it always will be. But the volatility of the last few years in sheet is something new."#steel #steelmaking #hotrolledcoil #sheetmetal #steelindustry #steelprices #fabrication #steelmanufacturing

column7: Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... Let's go!!Steve Canning Martti Nurminen Jane Broberg Perttu Nihti Katarina Paasi Henrik Smedberg Sam Mele Lars Madsen Christopher Blake Kevin Farrell Jethro Elvin James Welch Sean Delaney Sarah Salzman Bob Booth Simon Hurst Colin Reilly Dean Jacobson Gordon MacNeill Maurice H. column7: Stretnutie éfky eurokomisie Ursuly von der Leyen v závode BASF v Antverpách prinieslo dôleitú diskusiu o budúcnosti európskeho priemyslu v kontexte Európskej zelenej dohody. Priemyselné podniky zdôraznili, aby Európska zelená dohoda viac zohľadňovala investičné a legislatívne potreby priemyslu pri zniovaní emisií.  Antverpská deklarácia, ktorú predloili generálni riaditelia a priemyselné zdruenia, je 10-bodovým plánom, ktorý navrhuje novú európsku strategickú agendu pre priemysel v rokoch 2024 a 2029. Kľúčové body zahŕňajú postavenie priemyselnej dohody do centra európskej politiky, zameranie legislatívy na potreby priemyslu a podporu partnerstiev a inovácií v oblasti energetiky. Takéto diskusie sú kľúčové pre udrateľný rozvoj a konkurencieschopnosť európskeho priemyslu.  #industry #greendeal #sustainability

I'm happy to share that I've joined Global Holdings as Chief Administrative Officer.

We are excited to share the following leadership updates recently announced by Koch Industries' board of directors.  Cara Chennault-Reid has been elected by Koch Industries' board of directors to serve as Vice President of Human Resources. In this role, she will continue pursuing her passion for helping others learn and apply Principle Based Management„¢.  Our work continues to be focused on removing barriers for internal and external candidates and opening pathways for individuals who may not have the credentials but are motivated to contribute and have the necessary skills to make a meaningful contribution, Cara said.  Sheryl Corrigan has been elected to serve as Vice President of Environmental, Health and Safety. In this role, she will continue sharing our perspective on environmental stewardship, which has long been guided by our Vision to provide products customers prefer more than their alternatives while using fewer resources.  At Koch, our commitment to stewardship isn't new. The development and global implementation of Koch's Stewardship Framework has enabled Koch employees worldwide to consistently take a principled approach as they address the needs of customers, regulators, communities and other partners, Sheryl said.

column7: It's World Down Syndrome Day “ a moment of celebration and advocacy close to my heart as the Hilton Abilities Team Member Resource Group executive committee sponsor. Today, we join many across the globe in creating a single voice advocating for the rights, inclusion, and wellbeing of people with Down syndrome. Our diversity is one of our greatest strengths, and Hilton continues to invest in partnerships with organizations that break down barriers to workforce entry for those with learning disabilities, such as The Aurora-Group, Down's Syndrome Association WorkFit program, and SEDRA Foundation.  I encourage you to join our Hilton community in participating in the Lots of Socks campaign “ wear socks that are going to get noticed, and when they do, use the opportunity to raise awareness of Down syndrome. More here: https://lnkd.in/e5hmQHkc #HiltonForTheStay #travelwithpurpose

Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Today, on World Down Syndrome Day, we at Hilton celebrate our inclusive culture by recognizing people of all abilities. We're proud to partner with our Hilton Global Foundation grantees Down's Syndrome Association, The Aurora-Group, and SEDRA Foundation to provide career training and opportunities for people with Down syndrome at our hotels worldwide. Our incredible Team Members are breaking barriers and showing that inclusivity is our greatest strength! Let's continue to create a world where everyone has the opportunity to thrive and join across the globe in advocating for the rights, inclusion, and wellbeing of people with Down syndrome. #WorldDownSyndromeDay #LotsofSocks #HiltonForTheStay #TravelWithPurpose

column7: In the spirit of March Madness, let's end the "madness" and properly value women. The path to elite levels for women in any field is filled with roadblocks, speed bumps, and naysayers. I recently had the pleasure of spending time with my friend Nathalie Molina Ni±o, a brilliant #entrepreneur who has accomplished so much and hasn't stopped.¯ Nathalie is a co-founder of Known, an asset management and investment banking platform that deploys, structures, and shifts capital in ways thatare healthy for the planet and the people on it.¯ She has built an incredible team who will generate returns or structure your transactions which align with your values. You must get to know them. ¯ Pay women, value women, empower women, and #fundfemalefounders.¯ Follow Nathalie Molina Ni±o and Known, and let's #stopthemadness.#makesomenoise#inclusionpays#womenfounders#womeninassetmanagement#womeninfinance#womeninbanking

column7: Such an honor to moderate our inaugural SAP Beauty Advisory Council!  Thank you Est©e Lauder for hosting, Accenture for sponsoring and all of our participants for the great feedback, insight and dialogue!

Ellevest may have been the first by-women-for-women financial services company. But we have many, many women who came before us to thank for the work they did to kick down the industry's doors and trailblaze new paths.From as early as the founding of the US, women have been investing. Not just in themselves, but in their communities, their causes, and a better world for all of us. Over and over again, we see proof that when women have more money, nothing bad happens. Take a look for yourself ” the Ellevest team has put together a timeline of the brief (but very exciting) history of women investors:

column7: Leaders - 77% are burned out, here's how to help them:Everyone has a lot going on outside of work.We often envision work-life balance as an equalsplit between our careers and personal lives. Yet, the reality for many is a work-dominated life.Where personal time is squeezed in here and there.Leaders - use my action steps for successful balance:1¸£ Encourage Unplugging: ³ Remind your team to disconnect from work. ³ During their off-hours and time off. ³ Leaders - send email/messages during work hours.2¸£ Promote Flexibility: ³ Offer flexible work arrangements.³ Example: personal commitments and family needs.3¸£ Support Wellness: ³ Educate employees on available benefits for help.³ Encourage them to use them.4¸£ Regular Check-Ins: ³ Have open conversations with your team. ³ Discuss workload and stress levels for prevention.5¸£ Lead by Example: ³ Demonstrate work-life balance in your own life.³ Set a precedent for your team.Productivity thrives where balance lives.How are you helping others find balance?Inspired by: agrassoblog and Psb_dc__________________ Want a PDF of my top infographics? –¶¸ Go Here: https://lnkd.in/g2xbnwhpPlease repost to help others out there! ™»¸

column7: An Irish Blessing and 20 Years of Gratitude. Last Friday, much to my surprise, I was greeted by an office FULL of teammates and Dunkin' Donuts to recognize my combined 20th anniversary.  Together, they reminded me the importance of showing up, working hard and having fun along the way.  The videos messages, calls and notes from field partners, past and current home office associates was a special touch and made me grateful for those who I have had the privilege to work with.  Thank you to our team for being so thoughtful - yesterday's celebratory happy hour was the cherry on the sundae. A gift, pictured above, cites the first verse of an old Irish Blessing I have shared countless times at recognition events and meetings. column7: The Navy Seals only use 3 questions to review missions.Their breakthrough (& how it will radically improve your performance): AARs review projects, missions, training exercises or any other event you want to reflect on.There's a world of difference between an effective AAR and a post-mortem bitch session.The magic is in the phrasing of the questions.I adopted AARs for my portfolio of companies years ago, and they've been incredibly helpful.Here's how we do them:Step 1: What Went WellWe begin every AAR by asking this question:What replicable new learning did we gain from what went well?In any post-mortem, our brains can naturally focus on what went wrong. However, it is critical to get clear on what went RIGHT so the good can be repeated.”Step 2: What Didn't Go WellAfter reviewing what went well and the successes we can repeat in the future, we move on to constructive criticism.We frame the discussion with a similar question:What replicable new learning did we gain from what did not go well?Notice - the question isn't asking what went wrong... specifically what is the new LESSON we can incorporate for the future.”Step 3: New StandardsOnce we've dissected the lessons from what went well and what didn't, we turn our focus to the future.Combining the insights from the first two steps, we assess the following:Drawing upon questions 1 and 2, what changes can we make to our processes to systematically improve our consistent tactical excellence?This reinforces that the standard is excellence, clear process is how we get there, and asks what improvements to our process move us ahead?”Process note - each participant should complete these questions in writing 24 hours in advance.AAR sessions begin with reading all of the written feedback.Then the meeting owner leads the discussion of each question.“That's an AAR process at a high level.1. What went well (to be repeated)2. What lessons exist from what didn't go well3. How we'll modify our processes going forward (with excellence as the standard)Give it a shot.If this resonates, please share ™»¸ this post and follow Matt Schnuck for insights on inflections in life, entrepreneurship and 25 years in business.

column7: This weekend, I was compelled to reflect on the recent news from Princess Kate.  It felt oddly familiar, reminding me of another mom who had abdominal surgery, a life-altering cancer when very young, and a dad who had to keep working, sort out how to care for his family here, while coping with aging and ill parents there. These young, recent immigrants, and new parents who also needed time to manage shocking news, to figure out how to keep their little 3 year old girl steady and not scared.  (Photo below taken weeks before moms diagnosis)My dad courageously kept life moving, being a male caregiver of me and my mom.  Working hard to make sure if I was cared for by others, I'd come home every evening to be with him when mom was in the hospital.  All part of managing through my mom's first (of the 5 cancers she'd ultimately experience) that kept her away from us and a more normal life for several months at a time.  A time that also forced them to explain why there would be no more children - particularly tricky since the first was a girl . So much ahead for these two - early onset dementia 20 years later for him.  Decades of extreme grace and resilience for her ...These adults, still kids in their 20s/30s away from home, cautiously choosing words carefully to not alarm anyone back home by saying the C word. All while pushing down fear and appearing as if things were normal.It's not hard to remember my parents and our family this weekend.  So many of us can relate to the challenges faced by young families who manage through cancer.  It hits pretty darn close. These moments in the news remind us that every family responds in their own way, it's their own experience,  and they need support, culturally unique and defined, yet always wrapped with universal empathy. Check on the caregivers (and grievers )  in your life and look for more support at Rosalynn Carter Institute for Caregivers Caring Across Generations CaringBridge Empathy Wellthy #caregivers #cancer #immigrants

column7: We all get butterflies. The trick is how we think about them.I recently heard an interview with neuroscientist Lisa Feldman Barrett. She told a story about when her daughter was trying out for her blackbelt in karate.While her daughter was very anxious, the karate instructor didn't tell her daughter to dismiss or bury her fears. He encouraged her to reframe them”from a source of anxiety to a source of power.His advice: ¦‹Get your butterflies in formation.¦‹Instead of letting the energy of fear deter her, she could channel it toward her goal. I love this advice!I think about this advice in my role as an entrepreneur. Some elements of my work still make me nervous (public speaking is a good example). However, I see two choices: let the nerves get to me or use the nervous energy to make me better. I choose the latter.People sometimes assume you have to be fearless to be a founder. I disagree. It's about channeling the fear to help us keep going.We will always encounter our fears when we grow and challenge ourselves.We can see them as excuses to quit, or we can reframe them as fuel to push us forward.#leadership #courage #power #entrepreneurship

Still buzzing from last Friday's Innovation Day Immersive Learning Event, which was co-sponsored by our partners at University of North Carolina at Charlotte Charlotte. We hosted some of the best and brightest UNCC students Truist headquarters here in Charlotte where they learned how to use a no-code platform to develop payments solutions. I was honored to be invited to take part in the Lion's Den, where a panel of judges and I listened to pitches from the students on their innovation ideas. I also had the pleasure of speaking with several participants during happy hour, where we talked about how to solve business problems with simplicity, speed and safety. In all, it was a great event and I am proud to say the future of payments technology is in great hands! #truistimmersivelearning

column7: I am deeply grateful to all our guests at the event "BRING THEM HOME & BEARING WITNESS" in the beautiful Club Baur au Lac this week.We were honored with the presence of six members of the #SwissParliament, the President of the Canton of Zurich, other prominent Swiss politicians, 15 esteemed journalists, and numerous top leaders from the business world. It was an honour for me to host and moderate alongside distinguished co-hosts, Dr. Ellen Ringier and Anat Bar-Gera, as well as our esteemed presenters: Her Excellency Ambassador Ifat Reshef, Dr. Tatiana Kotlyarenko, Member of the Israeli Parliament #SharrenHaskel, Tal Hochman, and DALITH Steiger-Gablinger’». Thank you for sharing your experiences with us. We wanted to remind the world that there are still 134 innocent human beings, men, women, elderly, even babies being kept #hostage in Gaza. They need to be freed immediately and unconditionally! And we wanted to teach our audience about the atrocities that marked the October 7th attack by the #Hamas terror organization. May the 1200 souls that lost their lives never be forgotten. We also expressed the profound sorrow we feel for the Palestinian families in #Gaza, who find themselves trapped in an unfathomable situation. Civilians are caught in crossfires and are paying the price with their lives and their loved ones. An undeserved tragedy for too many! Yet, amidst these reflections, our hope for #peace remains undiminished. A long-term solution, one that fosters understanding and coexistence between both sides, is imperative. This event was a step towards reminding the world of these critical issues, and I am forever grateful to everyone who lent their voice, their time, and their commitment to this cause. Let us continue to strive for a world where #peace is not just a possibility but a reality for #ALL. #BringThemHome #BearingWitness #NeverAgainIsNow #Peace #october7 Ariel Rosenstein Dov Bar-Gera Shirona Partem Shir Landau-Blum Daniel Haymann Roland Gall Benjamin Fischer Dan Deutsch Guy Spier United Nations Ant³nio Guterres FDP.Die Liberalen Schweiz SP Schweiz Die Mitte - Le Centre SVP Schweiz Tages-Anzeiger NZZ Blick Tribune de Gen¨ve SRF - Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen Swiss Israel Chamber of Commerce StandWithUs UN Watch

Last Thursday, March 21, 2024, I found myself amidst a vibrant tapestry of innovation and collaboration at the Women in Data Science (WiDS) Conference. This event was a symphony of brilliant minds, groundbreaking ideas, and transformative discussions that left an indelible mark on me. One session that stood out was the fireside chat on "Leading Through Change “ A Rulebook for Navigating Through Uncertainties". Madlen Ivanova, Seemantini Godbole, and Sheila Jordan shared their personal journeys, painting a vivid picture of their rise in their fields, their triumph over internal fears, and their embrace of a 'let me be me' work culture. Sheila Jordan's concept of 'work-life integration' struck a chord with me, challenging the traditional notion of work-life balance and advocating for a more integrated approach.Seemantini Godbole's talk was a revelation. She challenged the conventional definition of 'work', arguing that networking, discussing deals, and solving problems are all part of the work process, even when we're away from our desks. This shift in perspective was a game-changer, promising to make a significant difference in both my personal and professional life.The conference was also a deep dive into the technical side of data science. Workshops by Kornelia Bastin, Chloe Pinkston, Ava Grossman, and Stephanie Radlick provided valuable insights into fine-tuning Large Language Models (LLMs) and exploring the world of Generative AI. These sessions were enlightening, offering practical tips and hands-on experience with these powerful AI tools.The networking opportunities were a highlight of the conference. I had the pleasure of interacting with inspiring individuals from Lowe's and Sia Partners. Their professional journeys were a testament to their dedication and passion for data science. A special mention to Megan Smith, Elizabeth Johnson, Jay Purcell, Duubar Villalobos Jimenez, jerome dormoy, Joseph Keating, Utwej Sai, Aida Miros, Connor Smith, Khalil K., Brianne Zavala, Haotian Feng, and many others for their valuable insights and shared experiences.A heartfelt thank you to the organizers from the School of Data Science: Doug Hague, Joshua Hertel, and Carly Mahedy. Your efforts made this enriching experience possible.Here's to applying these insights, pushing boundaries in data science, and continuing to learn and grow! #WomenInDataScience #WiDS2024 #DataScience #GenerativeAI

column7: I was invited by collaborators at Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School & Institutional Antiracism & Accountability Project (IARA) to moderate an important panel discussion on sports, media, and equity as part of their JFK Jr. Forum series.We heard from leaders on and off the court (Nneka Ogwumike, Rob Parker, Amber Goodwin) while being informed about the ways lives, communities, and policies can be shaped by the voices, messages, and creative platforms we use to elevate them. Lots of insights specifically around positioning athletes and institutional leaders closest to the challenges to be closest to the solutions, the importance of collective action, and the power of grace in difficult discussions.Thanks to everyone who made the exchange possible. Full video available here: https://lnkd.in/eMQtmzqF

Exciting News and Bittersweet Farewell!  After an incredible tenure at Lenovo, the time has come for me to start a new chapter in my career. It has not been easy to find the right words to say goodbye to a remarkable team and company. The well wishes (both in-person and online) from my teammates around the world were very touching.  I will always remember it!  It has certainly been an amazing ride at Lenovo. I am grateful for so many unforgettable experiences and countless opportunities for growth (too many to count!) But what has made the biggest imprint on my heart is the people who I worked with during my time at Lenovo. ¸ It has been an honor to be part of this exceptional team! To my team of outstanding Global Talent Acquisition leaders and professionals: thank you for the dedication, innovation, and teamwork you demonstrated as we achieved many milestones and overcame challenges. Working together, we helped shape the future of Lenovo. I know you will continue to do great things. Bill Opal, Chris Au, Eva Lv, Flora Wang, Marybeth Caulfield, Mike DeCellis, Monika Lubczak - Pufelska, Rohit Pratap Singh, Lesley Jones: I already miss you. ™ During my career in Human Resources at Lenovo, I have been truly fortunate to work for some world-class HR leaders. A special thank you to Yan Zhang, Jeanne Bauer-Hamlett, Yolanda Lee Conyers, Barbara Dower, Peter Haddad,  and many others who guided me and trusted in my abilities. You played a significant role in shaping my professional growth and success.  So, one chapter closes and an exciting new one begins. More details to follow soon as I settle in at my new company. ¨ Thank you for the unforgettable memories, opportunities, and friendships. Here's to new beginnings and adventures ahead!  #LenovoTalent

column7: I'm excited to announce my new role as the SVP of Cloud Platform Services at GM Financial.  Looking forward to this new opportunity and excited to be here. #GMFinancial

Excited to announce my new position as Head of Sales, North America at Nova Credit, where we're building a credit infrastructure and analytics company to enable businesses to grow responsibly by harnessing consumer credit data. Throughout my 20+ years in technology and financial services, I have always gravitated towards organizations with momentum, purpose and relentless focus.  Nova Credit is on a mission to give lenders the ability to underwrite anyone and empower consumers with thin or no file credit histories. Cash flow underwriting has arrived, and with the acceleration of our Cash Atlas solution, we are well positioned at Nova Credit to partner with lenders to implement a full suite of new credit data capabilities into their workflows - and use them compliantly.I'm thrilled to jump in this new role at Nova Credit to accelerate growth in partnership with this talented team, including Misha Esipov, Collin Galster, Nicole Newlin - and serve exceptional clients like American Express, Verizon, SoFi, Scotiabank, HSBC, MPOWER Financing and Yardi Systems among others.I will be at CBA Live in Washington DC this week representing Nova Credit, let me know if you are available to catch up.

column7: At TIAA we take professional development seriously. We believe taking action today to expand your skillset is like making a promise to your future self “ a promise that you'll be ready for whatever comes next in your career. That's why we celebrated DEAL Day recently to empower associates around the globe to Drop Everything And Learn. The agenda included a keynote from author and professor Hal Hershfield, as well as sessions on technology, products and the role of a people leader in supporting team development. Ensuring associates have what they need to grow their skills and delight our clients is another way #TIAATMRW is transforming the future of retirement.

Last night we played our 6th game of the baseball season. We are 0-6. As we left the field, my son was dejected and said, "Dad, we are terrible". I pondered what to say next and after I while, I offered him this:Sometimes the score of a game doesn't accurately reflect the effort of a team. I could see he was confused and I took him back to his last at bat where he struck out against what is likely the best pitcher in the league. He was fast to remind me he struck out. I acknowledged that yes, you did, and ultimately you failed to get on base. That said, I reminded him he fouled off several pitches straight back. I shared, you never gave up, you kept at it, you battled but came up short. That's going to happen but there's a lesson to be learned there. Still confused, he asked me what the lesson was.So I asked him if he knew what it means when a batter fouls a pitch straight back? He said, no, it's just a foul ball. I reminded him that foul balls hit straight back means, you've timed the pitcher. You're right on it. What that tells me is you were really close to getting on base. I bet the next time you face the same pitcher, you will get a hit. As we were putting our stuff away, he said to me "losing sucks". I laughed and said, oh it does buddy. However, do you remember what it felt like last year when your team went undefeated? It didn't take him too long to recall that and he smiled and said, "yeah, that was awesome". I reminded him that in life you will have successes, but you will also have times where you don't succeed. The times you succeed will remind you about all the hard work you put into your success. The times you don't will prompt you to appreciate the successes you had and also allow you to learn for the next time. Lastly, I reminded him that as you grow up, you will experience people that are better than you in the moment. When that happens, you tip your cap to them and and be gracious in defeat, then you turn the page and begin to learn from the past so you can guide your future. At that point, he was done with my motivational speech and just wanted to go home for ice cream. #leadershiplessons #learning #development #training #knowledge #icecream

column7: My message to aspiring leaders? Trust your #EmotionalIntelligence and dream BIG. If your dreams don't scare you, they are not big enough. I had a delightful time sharing #leadership insights with C©line Kajoulis on Radio Classique's ˜Secret de Dirigeants' #podcast.We started from one question: Is attending an elite school still the only way to become a CEO? No! From my humble childhood to eventually becoming a CEO, transforming multinational companies, I forged my own path through hard work and #meritocracy.BUTI don't want my story to remain anecdotal. To the next generation of #STEM leaders and beyond, I encourage you to not be afraid to dare AND show emotional intelligence, empathy, and humility. You need to create strong bonds with your people, especially in tough times. That is what authentic leadership is all about.AND it's even more important to accept your vulnerability and bring your whole self to work. That's what we strongly believe in at Syensqo. Doubts or hesitation are not a weakness, but also part of who we are.Never stop learning, unlearning, and relearning. Be always in continuous evolution, be inspiredand don't forget to have fun! If we all apply this, I have a tip for all companies out there: Look out for your #internsone day they CAN become your CEO!You can listen to the whole podcast episode here (in French): https://bit.ly/4cqBhyh#Syensqo #WeAreExplorers #AdvancingHumanity #talent #ThoughtLeadership #innovationweek

While hybrid work offers flexibility and freedom, nothing can replace the value of face-to-face human connections!In recent months, I've had the opportunity to travel and meet with some of our teams across the world, as well as partners, journalists, and suppliers. Beginning the year with CES was particularly exciting, immersing myself in the atmosphere of tech innovation and engaging in discussions with various industry stakeholders. Further visits to meet with our teams in Germany, India, and the US allowed me to delve deeper into understanding their local landscapes, while also experiencing the passion of Logi people, that makes Logitech so special ˜ I am grateful to our teams in India, Germany, and the US for their hospitality, insights, and kindness. Each exchange has been invaluable, reinforcing the importance of these personal connections. Thank you Craig Cahill, Wendy Spander, Joseph Mingori, Balajee Rajaram, Dhiraj Soni, Ashok Jangra, Moninder Jain, Sony Wahib, Antony Dick, Abirami Krishnamoorthy, Pooja Mukherjee, Yalcin Yilmaz, Carlos Monteiro, Lauren McRae, Anne-Sophie Bonnard, Boris Seibert, Crystal Ferreira, Rob Richardson, Flavio G.... After considering all the discussions and interactions of the past months, I'm genuinely inspired and energized as we enter the new fiscal year. So is my team! Our dedication to making access to the digital world more inclusive has never been stronger. The Tech industry can improve the lives of so many people: Increasing diversity to introduce different perspectives and foster dialogue will undoubtedly be beneficial to the future innovation and creativity!#humanconnection #innovation #diversity

Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... Looking for motivation to write?  Stop scrolling and consider this: An act of creation is gloriously affirmative for ourselves and can be a gift to others. It's really good for a person. It doesn't have to be a masterpiece. It just has to be something that is our own truth. Maybe we even decide to put it out there for others. It might be a book, an idea for a new product or a loaf of bread. As long as creation is happening, we are really living. #writing #creativity

I started my yoga and mindfulness journey 20 years ago to better balance the increasing pressures of my growing family, educational pursuits, and career elevation. Every day, I live my life aiming to optimize the union between my mind, body, and soul and I strive to help myself and everyone around me reach our greatest potential through loads of love and light. Throughout the years, I have weaved yoga and mindfulness principles in my roles as an executive, people leader, professor, mentor, speaker/panelist, mother, family woman, and friend. My wellness and the wellness of precious others is a non-negotiable #1 priority for me and I am so honored to be chosen to share my journey. Thank you Visionary League for including me on such a powerful panel. I have been having so much fun meeting new friends in Milwaukee Tech and am so excited for Women, Wine + Tech 5.0!

column7: At 101, Iris Apfel continued to captivate the fashion world with her fearless approach to her outfits and refusal to conform to societal norms regarding aging and fashion.She's known for her distinctive oversized glasses, layers of bold jewelry, and eclectic mix of textures and patterns; she carved out a unique space in the fashion industry that is entirely her own. Her approach to style is not just about clothing; but about self-expression, creativity, and embracing one's true identity without reservation.What sets Apfel apart is her flamboyant attire and her unwavering confidence in wearing whatever makes her feel empowered and alive. She had an infectious sense of liberation, inspiring people of all ages to embrace their eccentricities and the joy of fashion without limitations.In a world full of beige and neutrals (nothing wrong with those, by the way!), be an Iris Apfel! #IrisApfel #WomensHistoryMonth #Empowerment #Authenticity

column7: Today Smiths Group made two important announcements: First, that we posted yet another period of strong financial results, with 3.9% organic revenue growth, 16.5% order growth, and a 144% increase in free cash flow. Behind all this momentum, we launched a new £100M share buyback program and reaffirmed full year guidance of 4-6% organic growth with continued margin expansion. Second, we announced that I am stepping down as CEO of Smiths to assume leadership of a US-listed company. More to come on that soon.  The considerable momentum that makes it so hard to walk away from Smiths right now, also makes this an ideal time to pass the baton. For all we've accomplished over the past 3 years, Smiths' very best days are still ahead. I wish my successor, Roland Carter, and my 15,000 colleagues around the world every future success!

I don't often find myself without words; however, recently I was unable to form any response as I was awarded with the Navy Federal Credit Union Boss Award. To be considered for the nomination is an honor in itself- to win, truly unexpected. I owe many of my achievements to those around me, those that work alongside me everyday in many capacities. I am forever fortunate to have amazing people to work with. I celebrate with you all.

Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... Let's go!!Steve Canning Martti Nurminen Jane Broberg Perttu Nihti Katarina Paasi Henrik Smedberg Sam Mele Lars Madsen Christopher Blake Kevin Farrell Jethro Elvin James Welch Sean Delaney Sarah Salzman Bob Booth Simon Hurst Colin Reilly Dean Jacobson Gordon MacNeill Maurice H. The AGA DC Nominating Committee is proud to announce that we recently selected two new leaders for the upcoming program year! Crystal Wolf will be serving as the Chapter President-Elect beginning on July 1, 2024, and her presidency will begin on July 1, 2025. Crystal has provided services in finance optimization, governance, risk and control, and compliance for various Federal agencies, including the government's largest loan and grant programs to support families, students, and small businesses across the country. Crystal is a proud CGFM and has been a part of the DC Chapter since 2007 and has been serving as the Chair or Co-Chair of the Member Services Committee since then. Under Crystal's leadership, the DC Chapter consistently puts on sold-out networking events throughout the year as she's looking for new and creative ideas to bring Chapter members together and also connect with other local chapters. Crystal also actively participates in various national and local chapter activities, including participating and moderating training sessions, leading surveys and thought leadership development, and attending the AGA LEAD. We are excited for Crystal to bring her vast AGA experience to this important role!  Wendy Allen was selected to serve as the Treasurer-Elect, also beginning on July 1, 2024, and will support Mona Amatie when her term as Treasurer begins on July 1, 2024. Wendy is a Managing Director in KPMG's Federal Audit Practice. She has over 28 years of accounting experience, including 20 years providing professional audit services to the Federal government. Wendy has been a member of AGA DC Chapter for more than 16 years. As a CGFM herself, Wendy has served on the DC Chapter's CGFM Committee for four years to support our members to pursue the CGFM certification. Her leadership as the CGFM Committee Director led our Chapter to win the national CGFM Chapter awards for multiple years. Wendy has been serving on our Chapter's Strategic Direction Committee since 2020. Wendy leads the Chapter's various survey planning, execution, and analysis efforts, which are critical work for our Chapter to meet the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy (NASBA) requirements in providing CPEs for our luncheon program and to analyze our members' satisfaction with our Chapter's events and programs. Wendy also leads the Chapter's annual operating plan development efforts and currently serves as one of the appointed Chapter Directors.  Please join us in congratulating and welcome our new leaders! AGA DC Nominating Committee -Lal Harter, CICA, Chapter President -Paul Marshall, CPA, PMP, Chapter President-Elect (Nominating Committee Chair) -Caitlin Holmes, CPA, National Council of Chapters Representative and Past Chapter President (2022-23) -Paul Lionikis, Senior Advisor and Past Chapter President (2020-21) -Frank E. Petersen, III, Monthly Luncheon Program and National President-Elect -Thomas Chin, Newsletter and Chapter Director (Appointed)

column7: I am nice.People are nice back to me.It's not difficult to be nice.Some days, I don't feel like being nice.Just like you, I get tired, irritated, I am always overheated.So when someone in line in front of me anywhere is being an idiot, I sweat. Would like to roll my eyes or say "OMG, stop asking stupid questions and order a frigging coffee already."But I don't.We are adults. We don't let everything that passes through our brains come out our mouths.My husband and I stopped at a McDonald's on the NJ Parkway.He took the dog for a tinkle, and I ran in to grab a few burgers.I said "Hi, how are you?" to the gal taking my order. I said, "I love your glasses."  She had on a cool pair of purple readers.She smiled, "Thank you.  Your order will just be a few minutes."As I grabbed my cups to fill them up at the fountain, I asked the young man to throw some salt in my bag.He said, 'Do you need a drink carrier?"No, I'm good" I replied.The Manager walked over, I said "Great team you have here!"He did a doubletake, the widest grin spread across his face, and said "Thank you so much!"He asked me if I needed help out the door. "Nope, I am good!  You guys have a great day!"He opened the door for me anyway.He said, "Thanks for being so nice.  We work in fast food, so we get more complaints than compliments."We smiled at each other and said goodbye.When I got to the car, I thought a long time about what he said. Why are we all so entitled?Why do we think it's okay to be rude?How is it a 16 year old kids fault that you are having a bad day?Does yelling or demeaning someone really make it better?When I look at the world, I often think that maybe, we just need to revert back to the things we learned in kindergarten.¸ Follow directions¸Help each other out¸Listen when someone is speaking¸Respect others¸Take turns and share¸Be Kind¸Listen carefully¸Use kind words#resumewriting#bekind#thinkbeforeyouspeak

column7: I'm very pleased to share Rockwell Automation has been recognized by the #CIO100 Awards for the third consecutive year! This award is for Rockwell Automation's continuous efforts to meet our customers where they are in their digital transformation journey.Our IT #innovation teams at Rockwell Automation, in collaboration with colleagues across the company, applied AI to our industrial internet of things (IIoT) data collection platform and built a root cause analysis (RCA) capability within the batch performance analytics (BPA) solution. With BPA, customers can analyze vast amounts of real-time sensor data, identify anomalies and root cause errors, simulate, and prioritize, a corrective action plan, and predict future issues. This solution position companies to move from automation to autonomy - correcting manufacturing processes in real time and driving quality issues towards zero. Thank you to the Foundry CIO100 Awards for the recognition of the accomplishments and teamwork of our team at Rockwell!Link to the press release:https://lnkd.in/g-DRfr2q#lifeatrok #rockwellautomation #CIO100 #innovation #analytics #transformation Sabha, Patrick, Lance, Justin, Stephen, Eric, Chaya

column7: Last week we celebrated Spring Break (not to be confused with Easter Break which is in a couple of weeks). As any working parent knows, keeping your kids occupied while both parents are working from home can be a challenge. To that end, there was a disagreement in my home on Friday. That led to this small Mickey Mouse suitcase (pictured) to be placed by the front door. I asked mom, what's this all about? She said, Sam is running away. So I asked my son, where are you going? He defiantly said, I'm going to Hawaii. I thought, wow, at least he has good taste. So I asked him what he packed for his journey and he showed me the contents of his suit case. Inside were his beloved Pokemon cards, a stuffed animal and some snacks. Seems he was amply prepared.All of this got me thinking about someone close to me who is moving to another role within our great company. They are so very excited about the new role, but all the while making sure that we're prepared as they transition on. In what will likely be one of our final touch points, it is clear this person is running to something and not running from something. So for those of you who are curious about what became of Sam? Well it didn't work out for my wife and I. He decided to stay after all. I guess he realized it's not so bad here after all. ˜ #leadershiplessons #familyfirst #investinpeople

column7: My team and I are beyond ecstatic to welcome Mallory Lee as our new ¦. Many of you already know her because she's been a strong leader in the RevOps community for some time. We've also done some content together over the years, including our most attended RevOps Live event ever. Naturally, we tried to hire her a while ago. She turned us down. ˜But, we kept in touch. She continued leading and building. We did the same. Our team has been working incredibly hard to build and deliver the best Strategic Revenue Operations service we can, to align with CROs and help drive real results in the businesses we serve.We've racked up some wins, some amazing clients, and grown a lot, literally and metaphorically. As we pursue this vision, to drive revenue efficiency across the entire revenue engine, from marketing to sales to customer success, we needed help to take it to the next level. In addition to her wealth of experience across RevOps, Mallory grew up in marketing and MOPS, bringing critical skills and experience to make our team and our offering more well rounded and more holistic. As I said, I'm beyond ecstatic about what this means for our clients, for the next iteration of our service, and for the content we will continue to deliver to the RevOps and revenue leadership community.We will likely have many more announcements to come as we work on and roll out new offerings and new content for this amazing community we're so fortunate to work with!¸

column7: Tonight when I got home from work, my husband wasn't there.When I asked my oldest daughter where he was, she sheepishly told me that he went to the store to go get something.  Since it is not like him to run to the store without letting me know, I figured it was to run a quick errand, but as time passed by, I asked her if she knew where he went and she slowly told me that she had a terrible day, and her dad went to get”a pair of rollerblades.Apparently they were roller skating in gym class this week, and she kept falling and was embarrassed that she didn't know how to skate.As I heard the garage door going up, he walked in with not one”but two pairs of rollerblades (knowing my youngest wouldn't want to be left out)!I watched as he patiently listened to my daughter's fears and anxiety about falling, as she shared her humiliation of the day, and as she slowly gained confidence to stand in her rollerblades, hold onto her dad's hands, and skate on her own.Every time she doubted herself, he told her he believed in her.As I sat back thinking about what an amazing man he is, I also couldn't help but reflect on this moment.As a leader, having patience with your team and other colleagues is crucial for growth and understanding (I need to work on this).  Encouraging your team is important for building their confidence (I do a pretty good job at this).  Believing in your team is the foundation (This is why I lead).#lessonsfromlife #leadership #patience #encouragement #belief

A note to my belovedWhile busy with work, I feel guilty about staying away from my baby daughter during those hours. I have penned a short note for her.You were playful and kicking when you were inside your mother's womb.Even though the world was changing, you were safe and sound inside.You're out now but small enough to understand how messed up this world is.Whatever happens to this world, your dad will be there to ensure you're safe and secure.Feelings change, people change, time changes everything.Be assured that your dad is always going to be there for you.You will have everyone around you, but for your dad, you're the world and a reason to live.Your dad is your permanent armor that will shield you for the rest of your life.You're your daddy's girl. (You're PAPA KI PARI).

column7: A milestone moment for DPW. Today, we are launching our first US event: DPW NYC Summit ¸It was in New York in 2018 when the seeds of DPW were planted. Sitting in my Brooklyn apartment, I envisioned something revolutionary, something capable of harnessing the immense potential of digital procurement in unprecedented ways.Fast forward to today, DPW has evolved into the leading tech ecosystem for procurement and supply chain, with our annual event in Amsterdam drawing thousands of attendees and driving impactful change on a global scale.For years, I've been urged to bring DPW to the United States, and I am proud to say that day has finally arrived. Launching our event in the city where it all began is not only a milestone for DPW but a deeply personal achievement.The DPW NYC Summit is much more than just an event “ it's a testament to perseverance, innovation, and the power of a vision realized.Let's shape the future together!‘‰ Visit nyc.dpw.ai#DPWNYC #DigitalProcurement #DigitalSupplyChainPS: Please share this post ™

column7: Being wrong on the internet is the fastest way to learn. The amount of comments and DMs I received this week challenging me has been staggering, and a brilliant learning experience.Lessons?‘‰ I continue to get huge value from putting myself out there and being willing to be wrong‘‰ Please feel free to challenge any and everything I say, I love to learn.‘‰ On balance I stand by 90% of my initial takes on Robinhood, Visa and Chime, but the newsletter versions this week will look very different to the socials. So to those of you who say "I only read the Rant, I catch the other takes on social..." The newsletter version is much more nuanced with the benefit of all your comments.You're why Brainfood is good. I'm thankful for that.

column7: Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... column7: I have seen this happen enough, and sometimes it makes more sense "to let the house burn".

Unsolicited feedback or "thank you's" go a very long way ... it's not why we do what we do but when people send notes that highlight something you did or said a while back, and they share the impact that it had on their career / life ... it makes all of the work feel worth while ...."Thanks for the superpowers. Doug, I just wanted to reach out to express some gratitude.  A few years ago, a talk Amy Volas gave turned me onto your 4 Main Superpowers of Sales Leaders, and it's had a significant impact on my career. When I first encountered it as a manager, I used it to better understand my strengths and plan my professional development. It helped me advance my career from manager to director. Right now, I'm negotiating an offer with a new company, and your system has helped in two major ways: 1)  I referenced it early in the interview process and shared it with the hiring team to provide value and help influence how they were making the decision.  This had a big impact on getting the offer. 2) While planning my transition from my current org, I've been using it as a framework for de-siloing all of my skills, processes, and activities to ensure that I'm leaving them in the best place possible.Thanks again!"The link to the article this person refers to is in the comments!

As I am now in my 8th month of unemployment, Im reflecting on the process this far and it is quite sad.For the last 6 months, I have consistently put in around 6-8hrs a day searching for jobs, tailoring resumes and cover letters, and applying for jobs. I have learned and grown so much throughout the process, I have connected with a ton of helpful individuals, and despite it all I am no closer to employment.At the end of the day, what is my takeaway? I have wasted priceless hours of time and energy, catering documents to jobs I'm over qualified for, only for recruiters to spend 10-20 seconds looking at them and then kicking me to the side.Do I blame them? No, not all of them at least. The market is over saturated and with applicant pools being that large, it's the only way for them to do their job.My mental health is at the lowest point it's ever been in my life. The constant rejection, while not even necessarily about my skills, has left me feeling hopeless and unwanted.Unlike many, I am extremely fortunate to have someone by my side consistently pushing me forward and telling me to keep my chin up, that my time will come.Thank you Aubrey for being my daily cheerleader and reminding me that my experience is valuable, I am valuable, and that the right position is out there waiting for me to find it.Thank you Tim for continuing to provide advice, experience, and perspective. Your candor and humility are a refreshing reminder that there are people who help others for no other reason than because they are a good person.My LinkedIn network is small, but my community of unemployed veterans is huge. If you know someone that is also struggling, please share this with them so they know they're not alone in this fight.Sincerely,Joshua Hutcherson
Happy 90th birthday to trailblazer and icon #GloriaSteinem. Thank you for your lifelong commitment to advancing women's rights.

I know LinkedIn is about sharing business strategy and ideas, or some unique tips on how to manage your time, processes, people or relationships...but this post is a reminder to ensure people use their PTO.   I for one am as guilty as anyone for not taking enough time for myself, often driving myself to burnout and consequently impacting my own personal/mental health.Last week I took a few days off to recharge and spend some time with my brother chasing some fish around in Florida.  While not the extravagant resort vacation most would think of, I didn't realize how bad I needed some down time to recharge until I was floating around a lake and having good laughs and just being myself for a whileMorale of the story.... taking care of yourself is an important part of being a good employee, leader and co-worker.   PTO is a tool.... I for one will do better using it as well as celebrating those around me who do as well.....and for what it's worth, this is a pic of my paradise....

column7: Today marks the end of close to a decade and a half journey with EY / EY-Parthenon, as I'm embarking on a new path. In reflection, I want to extend my gratitude to...–¶  All the Financial Service and Fintech clients I've had the pleasure of advising on a broad range of strategic endeavors - your success in all facets is my focus–¶ The team members I've had the honor to lead and mentor - your growth has been my reward.–¶ The partners who have invested in people, sought to create insight, and collaborated to create better outcomes -you are the pulse that matters. –¶ The leaders and mentors who have amplified my potential, nurtured my growth, advised me in tough moments, and held your own values paramount - you have been a guiding light, and I appreciate you sharing your light with me. –¶ The broader firm that I've learned a tremendous amount from in both the best and worst of moments - remember, talent and culture are your most prized assets that make all else possible. Thanks to all who shared this journey with me. My next chapter starts May 2024, more to come then. #gratitude, #financialservices, #fintech

column7: Finally getting around to posting more about last weeks events!Last Friday and Saturday I had the pleasure of being one of 50 students selected to participate in the #TruistImmersiveLearningEvent. Together over the two days Green Team (Tharun Kumar Reddy Vattam, Deepthi Meher, Ayisha R., Fred Schuck, Riona Adela, Ruthvika Kosuri, Trinity Wells, and myself) participated in rapid prototyping and demoing a booking solution for IHG Hotels & Resorts utilizing Amazon Web Services (AWS), Verizon, Wicket, and Figma. The entire experience was unique, exciting, and a tad stressful (of course in a good way). I'm incredibly grateful for the chance and am hoping to participate again next year if Truist will have me!While we didn't come first in the pitch competition, all of the Green Team members came first in my heart; such an amazing experience to work with all of these skilled and hard-working individuals. It was also amazing to have real-time support from individuals from each of these companies as well as #TeamTruist staff. Special shoutout to Mike DeYoung, Brandon Castagna, Spencer Hawkins, Shannon Vanderhill, Michael Senuta, and David A. Lane for being our teams facilitators and guides through our rapid-prototyping journey.Another thank you to Eric Fender and Kourtney S. Peterson, MPA as well as the other UNC Charlotte Belk College of Business staff who helped organize the event and make it all possible. Thank you as well to, Edward Lopez, CCXP, Laura Smith, and again Shannon Vanderhill, MFA for introducing me to Design Thinking and inspiring me to seriously consider it as a career field I'd like to get into.Once again, thank you again to everyone I've tagged, getting to meet any of you is already a great joy for me, getting to meet all of you was beyond that, it was inspiring. I wish all of you good things to come!#InnovativeLeadership #RapidDevelopment #Charlotte #UNCCharlotte #BCOB

Tomorrow I start my final week with Accel-KKR, two years after my journey began. I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... column7: Solving consumer's everyday problems is what we do best at P&G. This is why we empower our employees since Day 1 in the company but also keep fueling them with opportunities, tools, platforms, technologies and more where they can bring their creativity, innovative thinking, and problem-solving skills to life. In the recent #CETechHUBHackathon the talented teams from the #CETechHub have recently demonstrated how they applied their unique capabilities combined with the latest digital technologies for a good cause. Working on an app helping the diagnose of rare neurological diseases not only was a great opportunity to learn, collaborate with external experts, but also make a difference for the communities we are part of. Congratulations for all the participants and project leaders, including Marcin Hajdenrajch, Paula Banach, Agnieszka Komorowska, Michal Wojtynski, Fabio Perfetti and our partners from the Warsaw Medical University to bringing this impactful project to life!

Excited to see our partnership with the Texas Rangers continue to grow with the addition of the Comerica Backyard experience! We are proud to work with the reigning World Champions as they seek to repeat the magic of 2023. Big thanks to Brad Ballard for this shout out and to Chad Wynn for his longtime support!

Last Friday and Saturday, Truist welcomed 50 students from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte to our Innovation & Technology Center for a 2-day Immersive Learning Experience. This was done through partnership with Amazon Web Services (AWS), IHG Hotels & Resorts, Verizon, and Wicket. The students had opportunities to meet with leadership from each company and get hands on guidance as they worked through building solutions and presentations on ideas to provide a frictionless payment process throughout a stay at a resort. With Shannon Vanderhill, MFA, Mike DeYoung and Spencer Hawkins I had the privilege of leading the 7 students on the UNCC Green Team: Ayisha R., Ruthvika Kosuri, Fred Schuck, Riona Adela, Cody Barry, Deepthi Meher, Trinity Wells and Tharun Kumar Reddy Vattam Reddy Vet. This was a rockstar team and took no time to start collaborating together, dividing and conquering the work. They listened to everyone's suggestion and prompts and factored it all into their solution and presentation.   Our team quickly envisioned and built a mock-up for a very innovative vacation planning/booking solution and estimated the cost to run it in the real world as well.  If we had had a few more hours they would have built a working prototype. All of this was accomplished in under 8 hours or working time on the project across two days. The innovation, courage, energy, and passion these students brought with them was inspiring, and made "working" on a Saturday worth every second.   Learning it was my birthday, the team even sang happy birthday to me at the conclusion of the event on Saturday.  I have no doubt everyone on this team will go on to great things. Perhaps some will come to work with us at Truist.  I look forward to seeing what these students choose to pursue.  If you get the opportunity to hire or work with them, do so.  You won't regret it. Thanks again to Eric Fender for masterminding the event and allowing me the opportunity again be part of these events and support university learning experiences where I can share my knowledge and experiences to help drive new ideas and solutions. #TruistImmersiveLearning
column16: Head of Innovation and Partnerships at Truist

FLOWERS DON'T TELL THEY SHOW:For the Women's History Month Edition of Client Segments KNOWLEDGE at WORK, I had the distinguished  delight to host Andrea Zaretsky, Chief Marketing Officer of Morgan Stanley Wealth Management and E*TRADE from Morgan Stanley in a fireside chat alongside the Global Chief Advertising Officer of The New York Times Company, Joy Robins. In alignment with this year's WHM theme, Women Who Advocate for Equity, Diversity and Inclusion and The New York Times' mission of helping people understand the world, the conversation centered on Inspiring and Supporting Others:· Advocating for women within and outside the industries· Embracing mentorship  and sponsorship from female leaders· Maintaining curiosity and driving innovation· Paying it forward to our future female leaders The room radiated with positive energy and meaningful career advice:·The HOW Matters·Leaders don't create Followers, they Inspire Other Leaders·Lessons not Losses· Lead by example and Role model being an Inclusive Leader·Share your Flowers A Wave of Engagement was created in partnership with Kate Butler , Ali Palazzetti, Mireia Naharro, Stephanie Herring , Wesley May, Isha Huston and WM Women in Wealth Leadership Julia Yue ,Riki Smith, Bernadette Davis, Jaclin Principato #DreamTeam Much #LoVe and Many Thanks to our  Viewing Party Location Leads:Alpharetta “ Nichole Humphrey , Sydney Griffin , Tasha SmithCalgary “ Jay Delesalle Jamie Philp, Honorine Hachey, CEP Chicago “ Leslie Delany Denver “ Alexa Magnino, CRPS, QPFC @Nancy BrooksNashville “ Molly Cloud , Nikiis Doherty, MSHRM Purchase “ Sara Cetron,  Alyson Gardner, Christie-Belle Garcia, Ph.D. San Francisco - Beth Scanlan  Sending a special shout out to Luisa Silva and Caroline Gundeck who amplified our event with her Thursday women's call and enabled us to add Chicago, Nashville and San Francisco #WomenSupportingWomen xoxoxo
