One thing that sets #TeamCignaGroup apart is our commitment to living our values and helping to improve the lives of those we serve and the community. Each year, we select several of our most passionate colleagues to become our Community Ambassador Fellows, supporting them as they spend a dedicated portion of their time giving back to a meaningful cause. As one of our Fellows, Jasmine Baten partnered with World-Wide Lighthouse Missions, strengthening partnerships with local businesses and other organizations to advance the non-profit's work in addressing hunger and those in need. During her fellowship, she helped provide life necessities for countless Connecticut residents, initiated a recycling program, and even assisted in establishing a corporate volunteer program to allow others the opportunity to make a positive impact. I'm thankful for Jasmine, as well as nearly 50 of our colleagues who have demonstrated remarkable leadership and commitment as part of our Community Ambassador Fellowship program over the years.

Books and bars and bars and books! There is something just really cool (and slightly nerdy) about sitting at a bar with a book, enjoying the white noise of the filled space around you. It starts conversations with strangers who want to know what you are reading. It has you sharing an interesting line or plot idea with the bartender as they fill your glass. All of this between sips of wine (or a gin martini), between the turning of a page, between pausing to let a sentence soak into your brain.

I know LinkedIn is about sharing business strategy and ideas, or some unique tips on how to manage your time, processes, people or relationships...but this post is a reminder to ensure people use their PTO.   I for one am as guilty as anyone for not taking enough time for myself, often driving myself to burnout and consequently impacting my own personal/mental health.Last week I took a few days off to recharge and spend some time with my brother chasing some fish around in Florida.  While not the extravagant resort vacation most would think of, I didn't realize how bad I needed some down time to recharge until I was floating around a lake and having good laughs and just being myself for a whileMorale of the story.... taking care of yourself is an important part of being a good employee, leader and co-worker.   PTO is a tool.... I for one will do better using it as well as celebrating those around me who do as well.....and for what it's worth, this is a pic of my paradise....

column7: As any great leader will tell you, they have made many mistakes along the way. They will admit that the collective insight from bad decisions taught them invaluable lessons “ and how to see opportunities in everything and anticipate the unexpected more quickly.Successful leaders are transparent enough with themselves and others to admit their wrongdoings so that those around them can also benefit from their learnings. They call this wisdom, and many leaders lack it “ because they are too proud to recognize mistakes as valuable learning moments for themselves and others.Credits: Glenn Llopis, 4 Reasons Great Leaders Admit Their MistakesCheck out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#leadership #management #leadershipdevelopment #leadershipfirst #giffordthomas

We spend all our time at work thinking about home and all our time at home thinking about work. It's no wonder we don't get anything done." “Zig Ziglar ° When I look at my days, weeks, months (or life if general), it feekls like we live a multi-dimensional world. As time moves forward, we have multiple responsibilities and aspirations we have to balance “ my family life, my work life & my Self.My wife's responsibilities & aspirations “ her work, tending to our various farm animals ´  ”, gardening, home repairs (she's the handy one between us...), and her own fitness routine. ‹™¸ Both our parents are aging and issues that pop up with their health and well-being, and making time to visit and spend time with them.My son has his daily school routine with now middle school on the horizon. Soccer, Fortnite tournaments, friends & summer camps.  He's less than a year from officially becoming a teenager. ˜± There are home duties “ dog walks, grocery shopping & laundry.  Breakfast. School drop-offs & pick-ups. Personal finances “ paying bills, budgeting & financial planning.I've got my training regimen for the next ultra “ diet, sleep, running, lifting, rowing, swimming while ramping up for the BJJ World competition in August. ½ Spring soccer league games, a tourmament & tryouts for next season.  Oh yeah, there's that work thing, too “ Clients, sales calls, speaking gigs, live events, workshops, conferences, travel, marketing, finances & the team. Plus the external forces of the news cycle, the stock market, economy, the election, the weather “ whatever we let impact our day-to-day our psyche.That's exactly why one of my mantra's is “ ”Focus on Now, now. Worry about Later, later. ” I came up with this 10+ years ago when teaching an MBA class. Before one of the lectures late in the quarter, the students were anxious about their final projects, exams, internship interviews, visa applications & everything else that goes with being a business school student. I could feel the tension and this phrase just came out of my mouth. Maybe it helped a few of them. I think it did “ everyone calmed down & we got to work.™ˆ ™‰ ™ Multitasking is a myth “ it's been scientifically proven.  As humans, when we think we're multi-tasking, we're just task-switching, and task-switching is expensive.When you're on a Zoom with a customer, focus on that customer. When you're preparing for the next big meeting, turn off email & Slack and get it done. When you're exercising, don't check messages. When you're sleeping, put your phone in airplane mode.Close the door. Don your headphones. Block your time.” Focus on Now, now. Worry about Later, later. ” Check out Go Farther Episode #3: Focus on Now, now. Worry about Later, later “ https://lnkd.in/gSKUDpxA#GoFarther #leadership #motivation

For Immediate Release:March 27, 2024Laolu Davies-Yemitan Appointed to Harris County Housing Authority BoardYesterday, the Harris County Commissioner's Court approved the appointment of Houston real estate developer and affordable housing advocate Laolu Davies-Yemitan to the board of the Harris County Housing Authority, Position 2. The nomination to this position by Commissioner Adrian Garcia, places Mr. Davies-Yemitan in a unique position to make significant contributions to the Harris County Housing Authority's ongoing efforts to address the housing affordability challenges within Harris County.Laolu Davies-Yemitan has been at the forefront of advocacy for policies promoting affordable housing opportunities, workforce development, and economic mobility for young people and working-class families. Laolu is a licensed Texas real estate broker, and serves as principal of Five Woods Realty, a development firm specializing in the construction of workforce and urban in-fill single and multifamily housing for working and middle-class families. He also holds the prestigious Certified Commercial Investment Member (CCIM) designation.Laolu is the District IV trustee for the Houston Community College System, where he serves as Vice Chairman of the Board, and is actively involved in various local and national organizations, including previously serving on the Urban Land Institute's Urban Revitalization Council. He serves on the board of directors for the Houston Housing Collaborative and on the executive committee of the Texas Lyceum, and currently serves as co-chair of the Political Affairs Advisory Group for the Houston Association of Realtors. #housingaffordability #affordablehousing #houston #harriscounty

There's no Nobel Prize in psychology. So if you're a psychologist and want one, you have to make a major contribution in another field. That's what Kahneman did. He never took a class in economics yet he won the Nobel Prize in economics. I was introduced to his work in grad school at Georgia Institute of Technology in the nineties and his work changed the way I think about human cognition. He also had a unique ability to tell science to non scientists (I strongly recommend his book Thinking, Fast and Slow if you haven't read it yet). Years later, Beth Cabrera and I had the privilege to have dinner with him and Tyler Cowen at George Mason University, a night we will never forget. Rest in peace, Prof. Kahneman, and thank you

column7: Many thanks to Hondo Powell for an invitation to yesterday's Icon Awards! It's not often you get to eat on the stage at the Long Center for the Performing Arts, while also enjoying some pretty incredibly talented artists (Ballet Austin, Austin Symphony Orchestra, and Austin Opera) who are all here (and thriving) today thanks to the determination, passion, and commitment of some wonderful women. A vibrant arts community is so important to the soul of a city, and I was glad to get to spend lunch learning about some of the Austin legends in that space. Let's be sure to carry those lessons forward as we continue to work to save and create spaces where artists and the arts can flourish.Shout out too to H-E-B for their corporate recognition. Seriously, I challenge anyone in the comments to name a better corporate citizen. I'll wait. Let's all try to live up to the examples set by these honorees. We, and Austin, would all be better off if we did.

Exciting News: A New Chapter Unfolds!I am thrilled to share some exciting news with all of you “ after much introspection and contemplation, I have decided to embark on a new chapter in my professional journey. I will be stepping away from my role in Contact Center Leadership at US Bank to pursue my passion for enhancing contact center and operations performance through the establishment of Simplicity Consulting Services.Starting my own consulting business has long been a dream of mine, and I am elated to see that dream materialize. Drawing upon my extensive experience in contact center leadership, operations enhancement, and customer service strategies, I am confident that I can assist organizations in reaching their objectives and optimizing their operations.I wish to extend my heartfelt gratitude to the exceptional leaders who have supported me on this journey, including Tim Welsh, David Little, Doug Whittemore at US Bank, as well as Dave Rennyson, Vic Pepe, Matt Slonaker, John Vella, Dave Pitera, Bryan Carey, Greg Nardiello and many others. Your unwavering support and guidance have been invaluable.As I venture into this new endeavor, I look forward to maintaining our professional relationships in a different capacity. I am excited about the prospect of collaborating on future projects together. Here's to embracing new opportunities and making a positive impact every step of the way!

Finally getting around to posting more about last weeks events!Last Friday and Saturday I had the pleasure of being one of 50 students selected to participate in the #TruistImmersiveLearningEvent. Together over the two days Green Team (Tharun Kumar Reddy Vattam, Deepthi Meher, Ayisha R., Fred Schuck, Riona Adela, Ruthvika Kosuri, Trinity Wells, and myself) participated in rapid prototyping and demoing a booking solution for IHG Hotels & Resorts utilizing Amazon Web Services (AWS), Verizon, Wicket, and Figma. The entire experience was unique, exciting, and a tad stressful (of course in a good way). I'm incredibly grateful for the chance and am hoping to participate again next year if Truist will have me!While we didn't come first in the pitch competition, all of the Green Team members came first in my heart; such an amazing experience to work with all of these skilled and hard-working individuals. It was also amazing to have real-time support from individuals from each of these companies as well as #TeamTruist staff. Special shoutout to Mike DeYoung, Brandon Castagna, Spencer Hawkins, Shannon Vanderhill, Michael Senuta, and David A. Lane for being our teams facilitators and guides through our rapid-prototyping journey.Another thank you to Eric Fender and Kourtney S. Peterson, MPA as well as the other UNC Charlotte Belk College of Business staff who helped organize the event and make it all possible. Thank you as well to, Edward Lopez, CCXP, Laura Smith, and again Shannon Vanderhill, MFA for introducing me to Design Thinking and inspiring me to seriously consider it as a career field I'd like to get into.Once again, thank you again to everyone I've tagged, getting to meet any of you is already a great joy for me, getting to meet all of you was beyond that, it was inspiring. I wish all of you good things to come!#InnovativeLeadership #RapidDevelopment #Charlotte #UNCCharlotte #BCOB

This year's theme for National Women's History Month's celebrates Women Who Advocate for Equity, Diversity and Inclusion. The theme recognizes women throughout the country who understand that, for a positive future, we need to eliminate bias and discrimination entirely from our lives and institutions.Today, we honor Vanessa Russell, a true force of change in our community. Ms. Russell has dedicated herself to empowering children through dance. Her journey took a profound turn when one of her students fell victim to human trafficking in 2010. This heartbreaking experience led Vanessa to found Love Never Fails, a nonprofit committed to restoring, educating, and protecting those affected by domestic human trafficking.Through Love Never Fails, Ms. Russell has educated thousands on the issue of human trafficking, providing safe housing and services for over 200 individuals, and launching initiatives like the IT Academy to create sustainable career opportunities. Vanessa believes in tackling this issue with love.Let's celebrate Vanessa Russell's unwavering dedication and transformative impact during Women's History Month and beyond.

column7: This #womenshistorymonth cannot end without recognition of a new connection thanks to an introduction from my colleague, Hari Kodakalla.Swathi Nelabhatla does good -- plain and simple. Her organization SheJobs-Diversity Focused Organization focuses on helping women succeed -- again plain and simple. It isn't easy and it doesn't stop her from curating events to encourage women and building a non-profit to support women in their job search with training and education. If you are in need of employees or are looking for a job, look at She Jobs. Her founder's pledge will inspire you to take action."We, team SheJobs, shall strive to eliminate bias and inequality in the job market. We consciously plan our activities to promote gender equality with measurable targets. We respect every job seeker who has the skills to do a job, fostering their ambitions. Spanning all industries, we honor the employers who care for inclusive productivity. We take pride in investing our resources in various community initiatives to advance recruitment practices. As we prosper together, dear citizens, we pledge to make this world a better place."

column7: We are Featuring Mary Tafuri, Vice President of PEGA, as a leader in "Women in Tech," Mary is the global leader for Pega GTM enablement and effectiveness. At SheJobs-Diversity Focused Organization, we are committed to continuously training and certifying women and underrepresented minorities. Pega is one of our primary training programs, and we are delighted to announce that we have provided free training in Pega to 100 women and URM individuals.We would like to dedicate this achievement to Mary Tafuri. Women leaders like Mary often work behind the scenes, yet their contributions directly benefit the advancement of women in the tech industry. We want to recognize and appreciate their efforts, which play a crucial role in improving opportunities for women in tech.Mary Tafuri's Bio :"As the driving force behind skills readiness across all roles, she leads a team in charge of crafting compelling content and orchestrates just-in-time learning experiences that resonate. Her accountability extends to shaping the strategic vision and ensuring seamless delivery of curriculum and certification for Pega's cutting-edge training and education enterprise" Eager to enhance the learner experience throughout their entire journey. Prior to this role, Mary was VP of Global Markets Sales Enablement at IBM (over 22,000 people in GTM). She has extensive experience in customer and product support, strategic planning, and business initiatives, including successfully leading multi-million dollar P&L lines of business. She has also led 43 IBM Innovation Centers around the world. Mary started at Pega in January 2022. Interests and Involvements: Loves art and science applied to food - The Kitchen is her creative lab. Mindfulness Ambassador.Pegasystems#MaryTafuri #SheJobs #Pegatraining #Pegasystems #womenempowerment #womenintech #diversity #inclusion #womenshistorymonth #pegainspire

column7: A LOVE LETTER TO MY NETWORK:You (Sham) Rock. ˜˜¸˜» (You see what I did there. ’»™¸˜‚)But, no, like, I mean it. For. Real. I have met with more than 80 of you over coffee, lunch, or Zoom in the last two months alone. And even more reached out via email, phone calls, and LinkedIn messages. Each time, we talked about me WAY more than I like talking about myself, but you listened to my plans to make a career change, you offered support and understanding, and your generosity in connecting me to good people and good job prospects overflowed.Because of the faith and confidence you had in me, you got me to consider everything from becoming a solopreneur, to making a transition into financial advising or selling insurance solutions, to shifting to business development in private equity, to helping launch a mortgage-backed securities business, and loads of fun ideas in between.Your selflessness and your precious time ultimately helped me secure several job offers. And not just any job offers. Really unexpectedly great job offers; so great that I was heartbroken I could only choose one. ² But, choose one, I did!Next time I meet with you all, yes, I'm sure we'll chat a bit about where I'm heading, but I hope we'll spend more of our time together talking about you and how I can help YOU! It's the least I can do to express my sincere gratitude for all the big and small ways you showed up for little ol' me during a time of healing transition. ˜¸’Professionally yours,JessPS - Don't worry. The career break is still on. My first day of the new adventure isn't until April 22. ™»#network #careerchange #gratitude

Amongst my personal values, fairness is probably the one I feel most strongly about. But is the game really fair? Not yet. But when we all do our part, I personally believe it can and will be. And there are inspiring examples. One comes from the company I joined two years ago: During my interview process, my son fell sick at home and had a crisis right in the middle of my third Zoom interview. I remember feeling like I had blown my chance at the job. However, my interview partner surprised me by showing understanding. She explained that one of the company's core values is being open and true to ourselves, acknowledging that being a parent doesn't stop when work begins. She kindly offered to reschedule, but I requested a couple of minutes to calm my son (and myself) before continuing the interview. That moment of support stuck with me throughout the process, and when I was offered the job, it was one of the reasons I said yes. The company I'm proud to be a part of is Logitech.Thinking about this experience recently, it reminded me about the pivotal role culture plays in creating an environment where everyone feels welcomed, included, and valued ” where all people get a fair chance to truly flourish. I feel this way about Logitech's culture. At the heart of it - like for any culture -are its people. It's up to all of us to inspire inclusion and ensure that no one feels left out. Individually and collectively as teams, allies, ERGs etc. If you want to drive change, you need to take action. Every small step counts. As the saying goes, "If you are not actively including, you might be accidentally excluding." Let's support, uplift, and empower one another, not just today, but every day. Happy International Women's Day!#inspireinclusion #iwd2024 #logiwomen

column7: It was an honor to recently meet the remarkable Jacinda Ardern. Incredibly eloquent, very humble, and driven by common sense. The former prime minister of New Zealand said something that stuck with me. She commented that she is an optimist and that she believes humanity is coming back. As someone in tech where we constantly look at the latest digitization and AI breakthroughs, I think this is a beautiful thought. We are surrounded by devices, AI-generated imagery and screens that show us what life should be. But despite all this tech, demand for real-world experiences are sky-rocketing, sales for quality wristwatches are always on the rise, and physical books and even records are in demand. Humanity, common ground, authenticity, and real values will always come back especially in times of extremes. Thanks for the wonderful thought.

Today we would like to recognize and honor the Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral Lisa Franchetti, for #WomensHistoryMonth! Admiral Franchetti has been in the Navy for 38 years and is currently serving as the 33rd and first female Chief of Naval Operations, making her the first woman on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. She has served in many roles across the military, including command of USS ROSS (DDG 71), Destroyer Squadron 21, U.S. Naval Forces Korea; Carrier Strike Group 9, Carrier Strike Group 15, and the United States Sixth Fleet. Admiral Franchetti continues to inspire colleagues and future generations alike. We are so grateful to have Admiral Franchetti leading our Navy. #AllAheadFlank #ChiefOfNavalOperations #AdmiralLisaFranchetti #USNavy #MilitaryLeadership #InspiringWomen #NavyLeadership #WomenInMilitary

column7: It is always with great enthusiasm returning to The University of Georgia to guest lecture with the MIS students. Even though stepping back into those classrooms, where I once sat as a student, evokes a bit of nostalgia, seeing the curiosity and passion in the students' eyes is just incredibly rewarding.Thank you for yet another opportunity to share my insights on cloud computing, DevSecOps, digital and data platforms, and GenAI with the students Terence SaldanhaMark HuberJohn-David Rusk, DBA, CISSP, GCFE. Each visit is not just a trip down memory lane but also a fun and enriching experience!Go Dawgs!

Two years ago, on Easter weekend, we achieved a miracle by flawlessly executing a cutover involving 80+ countries and 27 Manufacturing/R&D sites, cloning over 300 applications including SAP, and migrating them all from on-premises data centres to Azure cloud. Additionally, we reconfigured 4000+ interface endpoints to create Haleon from GSK. While the technical and business complexity of meticulously planning such a transition was immense, everyone, including colleagues from GSK, Haleon, and our partners, did a fabulous job to make it happen.However, as I reflect, the primary reason for our success was the extraordinary leadership demonstrated by GSK and Haleon leaders, who:1)Instilled a sense of purpose to seize this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to create a FTSE 20 company with a £30 Billion Market Cap.2)Set a clear strategy and ensured that every team member understood their role in executing it.3)Fostered a culture of collaboration by bringing a high-performing team together and defining clear accountabilities.4)Supported the team in the face of human errors, taking accountability as leaders and ensuring that the team learned from its mistakes.5)Defined contingency plan and ensured GSK & Haleon executive teams are aware of implications in case we need to activate it .I am incredibly proud to have been part of this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and I extend my gratitude to all the leaders and colleagues at GSK , Haleon and our partners who made the seemingly impossible, possible.Line De Decker Teri Lyng Joe Touey Amy Landucci David Venter Kelly Ellis Fraser MacFarlane Suzanne Ellis Agam Upadhyay Will W.#TransformationalLeadership #GSK #Haleon

Growing up in Cambridge, Massachusetts, I had the privilege of experiencing diversity in all its forms, including being exposed to a transgender woman named Lola West at an early age. She was a staple in the public housing development I grew up in and everyone knew her. As kids, we didn't quite understand, and I can only imagine what life was like for her back then. Today, I am grateful that our firm recently hosted our inaugural LBT+ Summit, where trans voices were elevated. It's an important recognition of International Trans Day of Visibility, and I wish Lola was here to celebrate with us. At our summit, we heard from inspiring trans individuals who shared their experiences and insights. It was a reminder that there is still much work to be done, but also a celebration of the progress we've made. I'm proud to work for a firm that values diversity and inclusion and is committed to creating a welcoming environment for all. Let's continue to elevate trans voices and celebrate the beauty of diversity in all its forms. #TransDayOfVisibility #diversity #equity #inclusion

column7: KC Woody Named Midrex President & CEO, Stephen Montague Continues on BoardKC Woody has been named President & CEO of Midrex Technologies, Inc. effective immediately and Stephen Montague, former Midrex CEO will continue to serve on the Board of Directors. Concurrently, Will Dempsey was appointed Chief Operating Officer (COO) and Sean Boyle was promoted to Vice President “ Commercial. Woody, a graduate of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point who served on active duty as an officer in the US Army, joined Midrex in 2010 and has held a variety of commercial roles including the first Managing Director of Midrex India Private Limited. He was named Director“Plant Sales in 2014, and was promoted to Vice President“Sales & Marketing in 2016. Woody became Chief Operating Officer (COO) in 2020, responsible for leading all the commercial and operations activities for the company, and in 2023, he was promoted to President of Midrex. column7: Time for the next chapter I am happy to share that I recently retired from the bank after 43 years in Product Strategy & Technology, most of that time in Commercial Banking across several great organizations. I would like to thank all the great people that I have worked with during this journey & offer my heartfelt appreciation for the opportunities, teamwork, support, confidence, and trust that I received along the way. It was my goal to provide the same to all of you & I hope I succeeded in doing that. The list would be very long if I mentioned everyone by name, but I know that each of you will appreciate how thankful I am for the time we had together, the challenges we overcame & the successes we celebrated. It was truly an honor to lead & be a part of great teams. I enjoyed meeting the members of my extended work family & all the personal discussions. Family is first, and I hope that we can continue this in the future.I would also like to thank my wife and family for their support & sacrifices they made during the long workdays & business trips. Without their love & support none of this would have been possible. They were & continue to be the driving force that motivates me.Those of you who know me well, can appreciate that I am not one to sit still “ at least not yet! Work Hard “ Play Hard has long been my motto along with giving back to the community & others! My goal in this next chapter is to spend more time with family, friends, and to travel while advising / consulting on a part-time basis. It's a great opportunity to spend more time doing all the things I love & enjoy! I am truly thankful for all who have come to appreciate my expertise, approach & have expressed their interest to engage my advising support in this next chapter. As I have often said & will continue to say, I am always here if I can help! Thanks again for a great 43 years and I wish each of you all the best in the future! Here's to the next chapter! Please stay in touch!

column7: Okay bankers - pretty fascinating chart from major study by the The Brookings Institution regarding 21st century of banking. Look at the growth of deposits to GDP and importantly the explosion of uninsured deposits. The great central-bank driven financial experiment  of mo' money mo' money has certainly impacted banking in that a lot of this QE fun runs through the system. This study is a policy wonks dream so I encourage a read, but tune in tomorrow for a piece of this report that gives me concern about the desire from DC to forcibly consolidate the industry into the TBTF. #banking #smarterbank #depositinsurance #liquidity

column7: I am deeply saddened to hear of the passing of my friend and former business partner, Joe Gracz. Joe was a leader in the IT department at Edgewell Personal Care, where I had the pleasure of working with him as his HRBP. He was a wonderful business partner who always valued my perspective and was a pleasure to work with. But Joe was so much more than just a colleague. He was a kind and wonderful person who always shared his deep religious convictions and love for his family. His family was his whole world, and he spoke of them often with great pride and affection. I am sending my deepest condolences to Joe's family and friends during this difficult time. He will be missed by all who knew him. Rest in peace, Joe.

column7: America is facing a serious problem that is only going to get worse if we don't take action now. Did you know that 97% of our GDP goes to pay off the USA debt service? That's a staggering number, and it's only going to increase to 116% in the coming years. The politicians keep printing US dollars faster than toilet paper, with zero consequences from their constituents. This cannot continue. We need to demand fiscal responsibility and take back our country before it's too late. Don't be silent, speak up for the sake of our children and grandchildren. #America #bankrupt #fiscalresponsibility

column7: At Homewood Suites by Hilton we like to think of ourselves as intentional conversationalists. We like to practice BIG TALK! The art of asking great questions, listening to the answers, which gives us the opportunity to surprise and delight our guests in special ways that shows we've been listening. Recently, I tried a BIG TALK question with my Mum! 'If you could have anything you want for your 85th birthday, what would it be?'. Her reply, 'It would be brilliant to see Mo Salah play for Liverpool'. Now 'Mo' is her favorite player and to see him live would be her dream come true. Well, what is a son to do! When Mum asks, she gets! This weekend I flew to England to help make that dream come true. Joined by Steve, Ali, Emily and Lucy, we had the pleasure of taking Mum to that game. Liverpool won 2-1 and who scored the winning goal for Liverpool ... Mo! What a beautiful experience. Such love and joy! I urge you all to ask a BIG TALK question, listen to the response, and deliver on the answer. You never know what you might hear. Enjoy.

column7: It was an honor to represent Colgate-Palmolive and ring the NYSE opening bell with EltaMD Skin Care to mark the inauguration of National Dermatologist Day. EltaMD is the #1 dermatologist recommended, trusted, and personally used professional sun-care brand “ dermatologists are at the core of what we do at EltaMD so that everybody under the sun can live freely. Dermatologists are vital to safeguarding skin health and deserve to be celebrated. That's why we established National Dermatologist Day, which will be observed annually on March 13. This important initiative is key to our Company's wider purpose to Reimagine a Healthier Future for All.A special thanks and congratulations to our dermatologist partners and CP Team who rang the bell with me today: Mona Gohara, M.D., Michelle Henry, MD., Dhaval Bhanusali, MD, FAAD; Constantin Sklavenitis, Echo Sandburg, Madhu McArdle, Drew Deering, Dean Pratt, Dr. Lia Arvanitidou, Tiia Piller. #EltaMD #ColgatePalmolive #dermatology #skincare

column7: March was an incredible month as we celebrated P&G's Equality and Inclusion Month! We began with a powerful event, the 4th edition of Nosotras en STEM, where we inspired and empowered 240 young girls aged 15-19 from 36 high schools across Costa Rica to pursue careers in STEM fields. Continuing our dedication to women's advancement, our International Women's Day commemoration featured five amazing sessions as part of our Women's program, starting with an inspiring and powerful message from our site leader in P&G Costa Rica, and followed by other internal and external speakers committed to supporting women's growth. Wrapping up the month, we hosted an E&I lunch with our Global Business Services Senior leaders where we shared the impactful results, initiatives, and testimonials of the E&I program at P&G Costa Rica, which continues being a best-in-class example, and hosted an E&I fair, spreading awareness and fostering inclusivity across all our affinity groups and site employees. The Neurodiversity stand focused on raising awareness and educating our employees about neurodivergences. As an advocate for Equality and Inclusion, I feel inspired and privileged to lead and contribute to such meaningful initiatives.#PGEmployee #EqualityAndInclusion #WomenInSTEM #GenderEquality #Neurodiversity #Diversidad #Inclusion #EquidadGenero #MujeresEnSTEM #Neurodiversidad

At Homewood Suites by Hilton we like to think of ourselves as intentional conversationalists. We like to practice BIG TALK! The art of asking great questions, listening to the answers, which gives us the opportunity to surprise and delight our guests in special ways that shows we've been listening. Recently, I tried a BIG TALK question with my Mum! 'If you could have anything you want for your 85th birthday, what would it be?'. Her reply, 'It would be brilliant to see Mo Salah play for Liverpool'. Now 'Mo' is her favorite player and to see him live would be her dream come true. Well, what is a son to do! When Mum asks, she gets! This weekend I flew to England to help make that dream come true. Joined by Steve, Ali, Emily and Lucy, we had the pleasure of taking Mum to that game. Liverpool won 2-1 and who scored the winning goal for Liverpool ... Mo! What a beautiful experience. Such love and joy! I urge you all to ask a BIG TALK question, listen to the response, and deliver on the answer. You never know what you might hear. Enjoy.

column7: Earlier this week, I announced my plans to retire on July 2, 2024, after 40 years with U.S. Bank. I have sincerely enjoyed my many roles within the company, especially the last 9 years as the Market President in Oregon & SW Washington. Growing up on the Oregon Coast, I have been a banker in the region for as long as I have been with U.S. Bank, and its predecessor company, Yaquina Bay Bank, where I started in February 1984.  I consider myself an accidental banker who turned my part-time high school gig into a truly phenomenal career.  Who knew that my family and I would eventually move five times for me to take on new leadership opportunities in Oregon, the place I love so much.  It's been a great run! Throughout my career, it has been my privilege to give back and support our community through my involvement in nonprofit, civic and professional organizations. Over the years, I've also had the opportunity to touch the lives of thousands of employees, clients, and community members with my passion for leadership, mentoring, and dedication to serving others. I like to say that bankers are dream makers and it has been an honor to help so many people achieve their most important dreams about home, business and life.  Some of my most treasured personal relationships have grown out of first meetings through my work.  It's always been about the people for me.Yes, I am retiring from my career in banking “ but not from business or a life of board service and mentorship. I plan to continue my corporate and non-profit board leadership into retirement. I'll take this summer off and then, see what opportunities emerge for me in my next chapter.  Oregon is my home and I'm sticking around to do more good work in the second chapter of my life.  Oregon remains a very important market for U.S. Bank, and the company will begin an immediate search for my replacement. Fortunately, I will be around to help facilitate the transition to a new market leader.Here's to "rewirement"!

column7: I'm happy to share that I'm starting a new position as Principal Data Analyst at Jacuzzi Group!  While the last month was often times a bit stressful, I have made it through.  This job market is insane, each opening getting what seems like 1000's of applicants.  Lots of rejection, recruiters sending msgs with job descriptions that I matched 100% to and when I replied I was completely ghosted.  What I will say is, it is important to have a strong network around you.  I was getting nowhere with applying on job boards.  I was stressed and simply reached out to my network of past co-workers and boom, I got a job.  I have often stressed that I do not go into a company and decide to just be a number, clock in/clock out and then do it again tomorrow.  I commit to the job 110%.  That is not just the work that needs to be done, it is to the people as well.  Because of that approach I have almost 25 years of relationships I have built with people I worked around and with.  I have continued those relationships even after leaving jobs and that is where the true gold is.  Never under estimate the power of a strong network.

column7: Celebrating Three Incredible Years at Buddy's! As I reflect on the past three years at Buddy's Home Furnishings and Buddy's Franchising, I am filled with gratitude for the enriching experiences, invaluable lessons, and amazing colleagues that have made this journey truly unforgettable. From day one, I knew I had found a place where passion meets purpose, where innovation thrives, and where every individual is valued for their unique contributions. The dynamic environment at Buddy's has not only allowed me to grow professionally but has also fostered a sense of belonging and camaraderie that makes every day a joy to come to work.Being part of the Buddy's Family has been the highlight of my career thus far, and I am incredibly proud of all that we have achieved together. We have nearly doubled our franchisee count and opened over 80 stores. This growth has happened because of the support of our talented teams across each department. Thank you for all that you do to make Buddy's Better!Each moment has been an opportunity for growth, learning, and collaboration. As I look ahead to the future, I am excited about the endless possibilities that lie ahead and grateful for the foundation of excellence and support that Buddy's has provided. Here's to many more years of success, innovation, and shared accomplishments! #BuddysAnniversary #Grateful #CareerMilestones

column7: I am thrilled to share that I have been recognized by Pinnacle Financial Partners and the Memphis Business Journal as one of the "People on the Move" for Women's History Month. I am truly grateful for this honor. As I reflect on this recognition, I am reminded of the quote, "Don't work for recognition, but do work worthy of recognition." This is a quote that I strive to live by every day. It is a reminder to focus on doing meaningful work that positively impacts those around me, rather than seeking external validation. I hope that this recognition inspires other women to pursue their passions and make a difference in their communities. Thank you again to Pinnacle Financial Partners and the Memphis Business Journal for this incredible recognition.

column7: On this day, 42 years and 3 months ago, on January 4th, 1982, I walked into what I remember calling the Southwestern Bell machine, otherwise known as the commercial business office in Houston, Texas. This was back in the day where one person cared for all business customer needs that included state of the art services from what was later called a monopoly. Collections was done via manual logs and a microfiche database we called the SBC bible. My first job right out of the military was as a FINAL BILL collection representative. The company figured if you could convince a business customer to pay once they were already turned off, you could sell and lead sales teams. The rest is history ˜. The company we work for matters. I will forever be grateful for the opportunity to represent the best communication company in the world, with the internal and external people relationships serving as the glue that motivated me to come back for 15 additional years after qualifying for retirement.  I never looked at notes like this from those that left before me as a goodbye, instead I would like to say, until next time. We never end relationships; we just keep adding on to the list.  If you are on this email, and were part of the journey (or a short stint when I stepped away from the firm), you had some role in touching my career in a positive way. For one last time as an AT&T employee, remember that doing the right thing always wins and follow the Golden Rule in both your personal and professional lives. Last, I owe a very special thank you to my wonderful wife, Debbie Garza, who I owe SBC/AT&T for because we met during my first gig at work. She has truly been my partner in life. I could have never made it this long doing my thing without her by my side. Also, huge thanks to my precious daughter Alex Garza who kept me motivated to keep going. To all those I met along the way during my work journey, thank you for the time we shared together. It has always been about the people as mentioned before. Signing off from the big T and looking forward to the remaining joys of life with friends and family. God bless.

column7: Meaningful relationships are invaluable for building and sustaining a culture of excellence, because they create the trust and support that people need to push each other to do great things. If the overwhelming majority of people care about having an excellent community, they will take care of it, which will yield both better work and better relationships. Relationships have to be genuine, not forced; at the same time, the culture of the community will have a big influence on how people value relationships and how they behave with each other. To me, a meaningful relationship is one in which people care enough about each other to be there whenever someone needs support and they enjoy each other's company so much that they can have great times together both inside and outside of work. I literally love many of the people I worked with, and I respect them deeply. #principleoftheday

We began with a powerful event, the 4th edition of Nosotras en STEM, where we inspired and empowered 240 young girls aged 15-19 from 36 high schools across Costa Rica to pursue careers in STEM fields. Continuing our dedication to women's advancement, our International Women's Day commemoration featured five amazing sessions as part of our Women's program, starting with an inspiring and powerful message from our site leader in P&G Costa Rica, and followed by other internal and external speakers committed to supporting women's growth. column7: Celebrating 35 incredible years a journey I almost missed!It feels like time has flown by in the blink of an eye. I still vividly remember being a bright-eyed 20-year-old graduate in the Philippines, with a dream to join the best company I knew Procter & Gamble.You may not know that I failed my 4th interview for the Marketing team in Manila and thought that my opportunity to join P&G was gone “ if I had given up then and there, this would have been a very short post! Instead, I picked myself up, tried again, and joined the Sales team. And so, P&G taught me my first lesson “ if one door closes, find another way in. To this day, I still keep my rejection letter, as a reminder of the start of my journey. Without realizing it, I became the first female Sales Manager in the Philippines! On my first day on the job, calling on small stores in the backroads of Manila, I was shown that a diverse team makes business and everyone else better. It was an exciting way to challenge social norms. I had the opportunity to demonstrate that women can be strong and resilient in jobs previously not thought to be suitable for them. I often had to tell store owners: I am not your demo girl, I am your P&G Sales Manager. Let's build your business together! If anyone told me that 35 years later, I would be leading our Global Baby, Feminine and Family Care business, have a career that took me all over the world while raising a family and 4 kids, I wouldn't have believed it. I've been blessed with incredible teams, friends, mentors, and a stack of lifelong lessons. 35 years in and looking back, here are some of the learnings I would tell my younger self, hoping that they resonate with some of you. https://lnkd.in/eibDbaeh I will always be grateful to be part of a company that has allowed me to go well beyond what I would have imagined as a young girl growing up in the Philippines.  #leadership

column7: In more than 34 years at Frost, I've seen firsthand that career development opportunities are part of the reason why people stay “ and I'm a real-life example. I started as a part-time teller, moved into management, then one of our #HumanResources leaders gave me a chance as a recruiter which put me on a path towards my c-suite role today. Frost supported me as I worked toward my HR certification at the The University of Texas at San Antonio and with some hard work and support, opportunities kept coming my way. Now, I get to lead our talent development and partner with incredible colleagues, like Candace Wolfshohl, on company culture to create programs that make a stronger Frost.These career development programs were a critical factor in my trajectory and have even expanded since I first started as a teller. Through tuition reimbursement, certification cost coverage, supportive study materials, career development training sessions and more, Frost supports its people in the journey to becoming the best version of themselves, in and outside of work.Human Resources is all about the people, and I believe #HR pros should foster an environment for employees to not only be their best selves but also to grow in a way that's fulfilling to them. From personal experience, reminding employees of the resources available to them is a great way of promoting growth at work “ and remember, you're their cheerleader and champion!

In Nooks listening to my rep book a meeting right now is such a great feeling.He just made about 162 calls with no luck for the last 59 minutes....call 163 was the winner.Always time for one more dial, it could be the one!

Next week is our Alloy Labs Annual In Person Member meeting. My palms are sweating with nervous anticipation. I'm not nervous that participants won't be happy or that things won't go well. I'm nervous because you don't know where the conversation will go. This is not your typical bank or fintech conference. We know that because every year our members tell us this is unlike any other event we attend. That is by design. This is not a spectator sport. Other feedback we receive include hard challenging unsettling and game-changing mind expanding what my whole team needs to be doing. Whether you're joining us in Nashville, here's the WHY and HOW of our meeting design that your teams should be adopting. Eric Schurr, Chief Strategy Officer at Alloy Labs member Sunrise Banks, and Todder Moning, Lead Futurist at U.S. Bank, gave a great breakdown on the Foresight Framework at SXSW. You can listen to it here on Breaking Banks Fintech Podcast if you missed it live. For those unfamiliar with Foresight, it is a 20 year old framework developed at Stanford to predict future events or trends. It follows seven steps: 1. Data Gathering 2. Analysis 3. Scenario Building 4. Risk Assessment 5. Strategy Development 6. Continuous Monitoring and Adjustment 7. Feedback Loop Eric and Todder bring the process to life in how they each adapted the framework to their bank. Here's how we infused Foresight into the Alloy Labs member meeting: Being Smart is Hard. Smart and intelligent are often used interchangeably but they are different things. Intelligence is about capacity vs. Smart is about the ability to perform a specific task. Smart is about being able to achieve a goal faster, easier, and more efficiently. Getting smart takes effort. The amount of effort is compounded when doing it on your own. Garbage In. Garbage Out. The infamous adage about scenario planning that poor inputs lead to poor results is nowhere truer than predicting the future. In this case, garbage is not enough diversity of perspective. We don't do panels that repeat the phrases and industry norms. The echo chamber is not useful for building scenarios. Critical without Critique. We've replaced panels with all group discussions. Members serve as facilitators to stimulate conversations. Thought provoking statements evoke debates and great debates require critical thinking with an openness to being disproven.  We believe in strong opinions, loosely held.  The future starts today, not tomorrow. One of the core tenants of Foresight is the ability to influence the future through strategic choices. This meeting isn't just a bunch of talk about what could happen, it is about defining strategies and deciphering which would win or lose in various scenarios. Getting smart about the future is harder. Doing something about it is even harder. We are at the end of one era of banking. And we are starting the next.

column7: A SaaS Account Executive was 9 minutes late to our demo appointment today.When he got on the call, it was clear he hadn't fully read the notes the SDR had given.Naturally, I decided to ridicule him, end the call, and go to LinkedIn to shame him.After all, I have 20 years of Sales and Sales Leadership experience, and I simply refuse to tolerate imperfection from an AE trying to sell to me.Bow at my feet, you loser.Or not.Instead, I stopped him and said the following:Hey. I've been in your shoes 5,000 times. I know we're not always at our best. I'm going to go on mute for 2 minutes so you can get your shit together.After 2 minutes, we restarted.He apologized.I told him it was no big deal, but I felt it was important to be straight with him.He then did a phenomenal job on the demo.- When I asked a question, he gave me straight answers.- When I asked for pricing, he told me pricing.- When I asked about contract terms, he told me the contract terms.- He also made it clear that his software is not good at two specific things and wanted to make sure we weren't going to need those things (we don't).We set next steps. He emailed the proposal.There is a 90% chance we do the deal.As one of the older generation, we have a few choices when a youngster isn't on their A-game:1. Be a prick.2. Remember what it was like when we started, show some grace, give honest feedback so they can improve, and then keep our minds open to what they are offering so we don't walk away from a great service out of pettiness.You choose.Hint: Don't be a prick.

column7: Friday reflection: I am thankful for the last 17 plus years at TruStage. I appreciate the great friendships, collaboration and development opportunities. Thank you to my leaders, staff and peers “ you all played a role in my professional and personal development.  It is the combination of great teamwork and a strong corporate mission that makes it a great place to work. I am also excited to announce that I have accepted a new role as the Sr. Director of IT Planning at Lands' End. It has been a bit nerve wracking leaving an organization where I was comfortable and familiar with the people, products and organization. However, the first two weeks have confirmed that this is the right time for me to make this move in my career. Thank you to the entire IT team for your energy and support as I get up to speed. I am excited to grow our IT planning capabilities as I learn about the retail space and build on the legacy that is Lands' End. Our future is bright and I look forward to contributing!

column7: On this day, 42 years and 3 months ago, on January 4th, 1982, I walked into what I remember calling the Southwestern Bell machine, otherwise known as the commercial business office in Houston, Texas. This was back in the day where one person cared for all business customer needs that included state of the art services from what was later called a monopoly. Collections was done via manual logs and a microfiche database we called the SBC bible. My first job right out of the military was as a FINAL BILL collection representative. The company figured if you could convince a business customer to pay once they were already turned off, you could sell and lead sales teams. The rest is history ˜. The company we work for matters. I will forever be grateful for the opportunity to represent the best communication company in the world, with the internal and external people relationships serving as the glue that motivated me to come back for 15 additional years after qualifying for retirement.  I never looked at notes like this from those that left before me as a goodbye, instead I would like to say, until next time. We never end relationships; we just keep adding on to the list.  If you are on this email, and were part of the journey (or a short stint when I stepped away from the firm), you had some role in touching my career in a positive way. For one last time as an AT&T employee, remember that doing the right thing always wins and follow the Golden Rule in both your personal and professional lives. Last, I owe a very special thank you to my wonderful wife, Debbie Garza, who I owe SBC/AT&T for because we met during my first gig at work. She has truly been my partner in life. I could have never made it this long doing my thing without her by my side. Also, huge thanks to my precious daughter Alex Garza who kept me motivated to keep going. To all those I met along the way during my work journey, thank you for the time we shared together. It has always been about the people as mentioned before. Signing off from the big T and looking forward to the remaining joys of life with friends and family. God bless.

I have learned so much during my time with the firm, working with and learning from some of the very best in Private Equity. And I enjoyed supporting many great portfolio companies on their own journey from good to great. The last two years have been a period of incredible transition for me, both personally and professionally. I am incredibly grateful for the support of my friend and manager, Rachel Spasser, as well as my friends on the Operating Team. This apple is not falling far from the tree. I am excited to be joining Basware, the Accel-KKR company I have supported most in my time with the firm. As Basware's new Chief of Staff I will be working across the firm to help drive value from strategic initiatives. Over the last two years I have watched as Basware has stepped out of the shadows to claim its rightful crown as the undisputed leader in Invoice Automation. Under Jason's leadership we have added many exciting hires to an already outstanding Basware team, including many good friends and former colleagues from over the years. Basware's journey is only just beginning and I simply could not let the chance to be part of something this special pass me by. I look forward to sharing more about this journey after I make my transition. For now, I'd like to say another big thank you to friends and colleagues at Accel-KKR and its many portfolio companies for an amazing couple of years. Thank you AKKR, it's been a joy!Team Basware.... Tremendous turnout today for the 2024 American Gas Association Underground Storage Operators Workshop in Normal, Illinois, with over 200 storage operator staff coming together for two days of technical presentations, networking opportunities, and a storage facility field trip. As I've mentioned before, I've always personally benefited from the willingness of the storage industry to collaborate and share knowledge and this is a great example of an event that pulls in talent and experience from across North America to connect and move the industry forward collectively.I appreciate the planning committee inviting me to speak on advancements in acoustic imaging for storage well integrity. DarkVision continues to expand our footprint among major storage operators, in reservoir, aquifers, and caverns, and it was my privilege to share some storage specific case studies highlighting how ultra-high-resolution, direct measurements can open up a whole new world of well integrity diagnostics to better inform operations and capital budget decisions.As always, if you'd like to learn more about DarkVision's well integrity platform and the work we continue to do in the midstream and upstream spaces, give me a shout.#aga #undergroundstorage #naturalgas #ccus #wellintegrity #utilities #pipeline #oilandgas #oilandgasindustry #petroleumengineering

column7: We are excited and honored to announce our 2024 Pathfinder Award Winner - Suzanne Tylko! Suzanne is known for looking at various automotive safety elements from a different perspective and we are so grateful to have her in our industry ˜ Here is a bit about Suzanne's Career in Automotive Safety ¼ Suzanne is Chief of Crashworthiness Research at Transport Canada.She holds a BSc in Nursing and a BSc in Mechanical Engineering. Her special areas of interest are injury mechanisms and the optimization of occupant protection in all types of road vehicles.Since 1999, Suzanne has led numerous studies on frontal and side impact crash protection by placing adult and child ATDs in passenger cars, school buses and transit buses. Since the research is conducted to inform regulations, her research programs aim to investigate crash configurations and ATD placements that challenge existing regulatory requirements. For example, her research has included rear seat occupant protection of small women and children. Crash test dummy development and the evaluation of test dummy instrumentation also form an integral part of her programs. The research is conducted at the Motor Vehicle Test Centre in Blainville, Quebec. The lab remains one of the few worldwide with the capability of conducting moving car to moving car crashes in frontal, perpendicular and oblique side impact.

Need your best employees to stick around? ”9 ways to keep them for good (without the worry)Your crew is your greatest asset.They keep the ship sailing.To earn their loyalty they need to be:1. Paid WellEmployees who feel they're being paid fairly are 4.5 times more likely to stay (Payscale) A well-compensated team is a motivated team. Make sure your pay rates are competitive.2. Mentored76% of employees believe mentors are important, but only 37% have one (CNBC). Mentoring helps them learn and evolve. Invest in their professional development.3. Challenged68% of workers say training and development is the most important workplace policy (ClearCompany). Stagnation causes boredom. Keep them challenged! Rotate their tasks to keep them engaged.4. Promoted75% of employees would keep their job if they saw a path for promotion. (Harvard Business Review) No one likes to be stuck. Promote deserving employees! Us this to show you value their contributions.5. InvolvedCompanies with high employee participation make 3 to 5 times more profit (Gallup). Transparency is key. Involve them in decision-making. Use this to create a sense of ownership.6. Appreciated69% of employees would work harder if they felt better recognized (Socialcast). Recognition fuels motivation. Show them they're appreciated Celebrate their achievements, big or small.7. Trusted82% of employees who trust their managers are likely to stay (Society for HR Management). Trust fosters loyalty. It them makes them feel valued. Delegate tasks and show faith in their abilities.8. EmpoweredEmpowered employees boost customer loyalty by 50% (Cornell University). Empowerment leads to innovation. Encourage them to take on new projects.9. Valued93% of employees who feel valued are motivated to do their best (American Psychological Association). Everyone wants to be valued. Show them they matter! Valuing them creates a productive environment.Remember,It's not just about keeping your team.It's about growing with them."Leadership is not about being in charge. It's about taking care of those in your charge." - Simon SinekP.S.™»¸ Repost to inspire your network.• Follow Dr. Miro Bada for professional growth insights

Showing appreciation and recognizing your team's efforts can go a long way in boosting their morale and motivation to become the best version of themselves. From my experience, a simple note of thanks for their exceptional work has been one of the most powerful motivators for my team. It is a way of showing that their work and dedication have not gone unnoticed and that they are valuable members of the team. This gesture of gratitude not only boosts their confidence but also inspires everyone to perform even better in the future. Make it a point to express your gratitude to your team members regularly, and you will witness significant growth and development that will help your team develop into great leaders and help your organization achieve its vision and goals. column7: A Sign on the Trail & A New Chapter Ahead....While on a recent hike with my family, I captured an image that resonated deeply with me - an arrow secured onto a tree, pointing forward. Simple, yet profound, it felt serendipitous, mirroring the inner journey I've been navigating personally and professionally. Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

column7: As I reflect on this recognition, I send my heartfelt appreciation to the many outstanding leaders, mentors, role models, and allies who have inspired me along my journey, including Guillermo Diaz Jr, Ron Lopes, Gary Matuszak, Sandy Torchia, Miriam Hernandez-Kakol, Pr Edin, Michael Galvin, Raj Echambadi, Alice Joseph Barda, Liad Wagman, Alberto Y©pez, Manny Fernandez, Jeremy Burton, Rene Bonvanie, Jose R (Pepe) Gomez, Ivonne Valdes, and Silvia Scandar Mahan. My parents inspired me to work hard and dream big. They sacrificed to make my dream a reality to come to the US for college. Illinois Tech gave me an academic scholarship and internships that changed my life and opened the door to work in Silicon Valley. I've been blessed to have the unwavering support of my parents and husband, the gift to mentor incredible individuals, learn from leaders at Oracle that showed me the art of the possible with tech, and the many opportunities KPMG has given me to have a rewarding career. Paying it forward is important to me. I'm fortunate to work with fantastic leaders at #KPMG, #IllinoisTech, the Cristo Rey San Jose High School #CRSJ, and #HITEC to empower the next generation of tech leaders from high school to the boardroom. I am passionate about supporting our Hispanic/Latin youth and students from underserved communities, so they have opportunities to achieve their dreams, as I have.I'm humbled and honored to receive this recognition. Thank you #SiliconValleyBusinessJournal!#KPMGproud #KPMGSiliconValley #SiliconValleyBusinessJournal #IllinoisTech #latinosintech #crsj

column7: A Sign on the Trail & A New Chapter Ahead....While on a recent hike with my family, I captured an image that resonated deeply with me - an arrow secured onto a tree, pointing forward. Simple, yet profound, it felt serendipitous, mirroring the inner journey I've been navigating personally and professionally. Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

column7: Me: Obsessed with pulling brilliant, capable tech talent further into healthcare Also me: Applying to be an honorary member of the brilliant Cisco alumni mafia.Meet incredible Silicon Valley superstars, Joe Pinto and Annie Shea WeckesserHow we met:Joe: in a driveway, I was leaving, he was entering and asked, 'What are you doin' here?" --in his trademark Brooklyn accent. Having run the #2 P&L at Cisco and now Chief Customer Officer at Pure Storage; there's no one in the Valley that understands the customer, services or certifications better than Joe. He combines deep empathy, passion for building people and processes with humility. He's the ultimate coach who is awesome at constructive feedback. It feels like he's making a joke and then you realize you just got coached.Annie: Santa Clara University and then the gym! And then mutuals. Annie's another unicorn with deep people organizational skills that are super scarce at earlier stages and across multiple rounds of funding. She's also a world class marketer and builder of marketing organizations currently driving the Uniphore business forward. With her humanity, grounded nature, and social skills while being an expert in enterprise conversational and generative AI; Annie strikes me as THE ideal board director of the future. Thanks for all the homework, can't wait for next time. P.S. Thanks to Brian Reynard and Kristi Bowers whose masterful orchestration of Thursday's SVEN (Silicon Valley Executive Network) event led to this "overflow" meeting.

column7: Graham is dedicated to safeguarding people and the planet. This principle guides our operations, including our efforts to mitigate climate change by reducing our GHG emissions. To ensure clarity and results, we're taking a science-based approach. Our goal is to reduce our GHG emissions in line with the 1.5°C Science Based Targets (SBT) by the end of 2030, and we're proud to announce that we have achieved a 20% reduction in GHG in 2023 from a 2020 baseline. #grahampackaging #sustainablepackasgingsolutions #GHGemissionsreduction

column7: A run with my husband. A walk with Chuck. Wake up snuggles with my son. Lunch and ice cream date with my bestie. With. One of the driving motivators for anything is who. Who we choose to go through life with. Who we choose to work with. Who we choose to become friends with. Who are you surrounding yourself with and how do you want to lean into the relationships that are meaningful and mutually reciprocal?The quality of those relationships is a major contributor to wellbeing. It is within these relationships we disperse stress and double joy. Whether personal or professional. #emotionalintelligence#iqeqtq#leadership

Had a pretty darn good (albeit very busy) week this past week at work. Started with a sales leadership conference in San Antonio. Incredible views from the top of the new Frost Bank Tower, but even better  fellowship with the friends and colleagues made over the years. Then, up early for a day at the new Frost Bank Center. Got to see the 5! World Champion Trophies the Spurs have won since ˜99 (shout out to those that attended the watch party out on the farm back in ˜99, and the many who sported the Go Spurs Go! window flags like mine on the old F-150), and have a shoot around on the arena floor (was definitely an unneeded reminder that playing basketball never been my strongest suit). As a bonus, we were welcomed by future Hall of Famer RC Buford (CEO, GM, and along with Coach Pop, architect of their unprecedented 20-year playoff run) - where he shared a bit of the shared Frost / Spurs story and highlighted our common core values of #integrity #caring and #excellence.Finally closed out the week with two days of strategy sessions with Blair McGrain Hillary Stull Jennifer Jaroszewski Monica Barrera and many more working on the Frost Austin expansion strategy.Now time to recharge with some #familytime. #lifeisgood.

column7: My partner Vivek shared some great advice recently. To start a company, you need an inspiring vision that by definition has to be aspirational, he said. If your 5 or 10 year vision is exclusively a problem you already know how to solve, then you're not dreaming big enough. By definition what you want to do five years from now should appear impossible at this stage.At our last company, Krux, we used to talk about a pervasive, always-on data fabric for consumers everywhere. And then people would say, what does that even mean? My answer back then? I don't quite know yet! But that kind of vision moves people. You have to have something provocative and huge to inspire yourself. Maybe you never get to the summit but your results across the board will be better if you set your eyes on the horizon.#startup #founderjourney #entrepreneurship

column7: I am thrilled to announce that I have been selected to be promoted to the rank of Colonel (06) in the U.S. Army Reserve. I am deeply grateful for the support of my family and fellow soldiers, who have played an integral role in my journey thus far. I couldn't have achieved this milestone without them. As I take on this new role, I am aware of the challenges that lie ahead. However, I am confident that with the unwavering commitment of our soldiers, we will continue to accomplish our objectives. It's amazing to reflect on my humble beginnings as a USMC Lance Corporal, and I am grateful for the opportunities and experiences that have led me to this point in my career. Thank you to everyone who has supported me along the way. I look forward to continuing to serve our country with honor and dedication.

This past week represented my last at Newell Brands. It has been an amazing 10 years and I am thankful for the opportunities, experiences and relationships that I was able to cultivate over that time. What started as a GM role in Canada, quickly transformed into what was to be a 2-year assignment in EMEA (London), and which ultimately became a series of diverse international brand management and market development roles and projects, across multiple EMEA-APAC geographies and cultures. I am thankful to those Newell Brand leaders and partners that I worked alongside, as their trust, support and ongoing encouragement has been invaluable. The strength of Newel Brands lies with their people, and I have been fortunate to be part of it, having forged along the way, several what I hope will be lasting friendships. I wish my Newell colleagues so much success in their future endeavours. I am confident and excited to take this next step in my journey, one that will build on a foundation that my time at Newell Brands has so wonderfully prepared me to pursue.

I am excited to share some news: I am Guild's new CEO. I joined Guild six years ago, driven by the opportunity to work for a company focused on transforming what greater access to economic advancement in this country can look like. Today, I'm proud to carry that mission forward in a new capacity, working with the incredible people, employers, and learning partners that make this mission possible. Read more about that here: https://lnkd.in/gFcp7aUr We are at a unique moment in history and have a special opportunity in front of us.Changing demographics are shrinking our labor pools while skills gaps, exacerbated by rapidly changing technology, risk leaving millions of people ” and businesses ” behind. We must embrace this challenge head-on, building a workforce that evolves to meet the talent needs of the future, and supports the economic advancement for millions of people and their families. I am coming to my new role with a deep, personal understanding of what realizing our mission can mean. Growing up as the daughter of two Indian immigrants, I saw firsthand the challenges my parents faced navigating rapid change: The turbulent waters of the 1980s oil industry crash and the 1990s data entry automation boom. Their experiences underscored a stark reality that immensely talented people often need more resources and guidance in adapting to evolving work landscapes.I've benefited from the guidance of mentors who recognized my potential and took chances to invest in my future. With these bets, I've experienced the transformative power of education and skill development. This journey instilled in me a profound belief in Guild's mission and its immense potential for unlocking your workforce.I want to thank a phenomenal team that has ” and will continue ” to drive our work forward. That includes Guild's executive team, Alana Brandes, Rebecca Biestman, Rohan Chandran, Terrence Cummings, Chris Garber, Dan Haley, Jonathan Marek, and Marty Martinez, as well as the 1,000+ Guilders who bring their fierce intelligence and commitment to our mission every day. I also want to thank Guild's Board of Directors, including the visionary and resilient Rachel Romer, for allowing me to carry Guild's mission forward. Along with the executive team, they have all rallied behind me in the last seven months in incredible ways.Finally, I want to acknowledge my friends and family for their steadfast support, particularly over the past several months, as I unexpectedly went from 3-months postpartum after my second child to the role of interim CEO overnight.In particular, I want to give a special shoutout to my partner-in-crime Amit Shah. Amit encouraged me to embrace the opportunity to lead and step up ” and there is no world in which I would be embarking on this next phase, carrying this critical mission forward, without his support, guidance, and reassurance. I am honored and excited to step up and help Guild further its impact and mission.

column7: A Sign on the Trail & A New Chapter Ahead....While on a recent hike with my family, I captured an image that resonated deeply with me - an arrow secured onto a tree, pointing forward. Simple, yet profound, it felt serendipitous, mirroring the inner journey I've been navigating personally and professionally. Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

I'm now a believer that every B2B company should standardize on a Contacts-only model in Salesforce, but with a few caveats...- Prospects still start as a Lead and are matched/converted- The Lead is still used as a "graveyard" for prospects with personal emails and prospects outside of your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)Why standardize on Contacts?1.) It is now cost-effective and relatively easy to implement2.) It simplifies a lot of the views/processes for sales3.) Speed to follow-up by sales no longer needs to be compromised4.) It dramatically simplifies reporting5.) It solves most ownership/routing challenges6.) It makes auto-associating Contact Roles on Opportunities simple (see our free app called Align.ly Contact Role)I'm thinking of writing up a playbook on how to do this in Salesforce including how to auto-create Accounts. Like or comment "I'm interested" and if there is enough interest I'll create a step-by-step playbook.

When you step out of your comfort zone, you'll likely have moments in which you feel overwhelmed and underqualified. That's normal. Going after an ambitious goal requires you to learn and grow. The truth is you already *are* doing it!
