What does burnout look and feel like at work?Look for signs in these four, main areas:”PERFORMANCE When we are burned out, our work suffers in both quality and quantity. We make more mistakes. We may also become more prone to procrastination.”MORALEBurnout is exhausting. It can torch enthusiasm for our work, leaving us discouraged and cynical. ”BEHAVIORBurnout causes us to take more unscheduled days off. Even when at work, we may still feel mentally "checked out." It's not uncommon for burned out employees to start avoiding responsibilities and skipping meetings. We may be distancing ourselves from the work because we are searching job boards and texting recruiters.”RELATIONSHIPSBurnout can heat up feelings of impatience, irritation, and rage. This manifests in higher rates of broken communication and conflict. Are you seeing any signs of burnout at work right now? If so, which signs are you seeing?***********************¡¸¡¸NEW INFOGRAPHICS EVERY WEEK¬…¸¬…¸RING THE”” TO BE NOTIFIED #burnout #signsofburnout #mentalhealthawareness #stressawareness #litvakexecutivesolutions #neurocoachinggroup

She may have retired from tennis, but Serena Williams is still serving up BIG wins. After establishing Serena Ventures, a venture capital firm specifically designed for women and minority founders, she estimates that 14 of the companies in her portfolio have reached unicorn status, meaning they're a privately held startup company valued at more than $1 billion.She shared, I learned that less than 2% of all VC money went to women, and when I first heard that, I actually thought it was a misquote. I also learned that even less went to people of color.She saw an opportunity to intentionally elevate underrepresented business owners and took it. Yes, she's investing in companies, but also equality. Real dollars are going toward a more equitable economy and future! I love to see it ‘

column7: This International Women's Day, I am overflowing with gratitude for the incredible women and girls who have touched my life and inspired me in countless ways. From the unwavering love and wisdom of my mother and grandmothers to the extraordinary women I've had the honor of meeting and learning from in the tech industry, each one has left a mark on my journey through high school, internships, and life!As a 17-year-old navigating the dynamic world of tech, the brilliance and resilience of the women and girls I've encountered along the way have been nothing short of awe-inspiring. Their determination, innovation, and unwavering spirit have fueled my passion and ignited my drive to make a difference.To my fellow students and peers, thank you for your unwavering support and for continually pushing the boundaries of what is possible. Together, we are breaking barriers, challenging stereotypes, and paving the way for a brighter, more inclusive future in tech. On this special day, let's celebrate the achievements, strength, and boundless potential of women and girls everywhere. Together, let's commit to amplifying their voices, empowering them to pursue their dreams, and creating a world where every woman and girl not only thrives but also soars! ’–#InternationalWomensDay #WomenInSTEM #Empowerment

The eclipse was much more beautiful than I actually expected it to be- the pictures just can't make justice. That said - these are straight iphone shots with no tripod with digital zoom and steady pulse, which is quite amazing. I had no plans, but also had no scheduled calls at the time- so I took these in our home backyard. It was cloudy in Austin - and incredibly lucky to clear to a thin layer for 1 of the 3 mins of total eclipse. The day turned to night, and then to day again. The sun crown shining around the moon is an amazing sight to see with the naked eye. No picture captures anything close to that experience. Looking forward to the next one in 20 years!!!

Consider the people who love and support you, the opportunities you've been given, and the things you've accomplished. column7: I had an incredible time at the 2024 Automotive Safety Council Meeting! Global leaders in #automotive #safety came together to tackle pressing issues such as road fatalities, injury research & prevention for all occupant types, lessons in AV safety and industry success, EVs vs ICE vehicle safety, and the benefits of orange road markings, all aimed at advancing #roadsafety towards #visionzero. Towards Zero Foundation discussed their global road safety initiatives, while Euro NCAP - For Safer Cars, Vans & Trucks NCAP unveiled their 2026 safety ratings, emphasizing the importance of #BringBackButtons for cars to earn 5-star ratings in Europe with fewer screens and more buttons. Standout moments:’¡The all-female panel discussion on #Occupant #RearSeat #Safety, consisted of esteemed experts Dr. Kristy Arbogast, Suzanne Tylko, Dr. Amanda M. (Mandy) Agnew, Dr. Cecilia Sunnevng, and Dr. Jessica Jermakian. They shared invaluable insights on women's safety in rear seat crashes and efforts to develop robust solutions.It was an honor to witness Suzanne Tylko, Chief of Crashworthiness Research at Transport Canada - Transports Canada receive the 2024 #PathfinderAward for her pioneering research since 1999 in injury mechanisms and #occupantprotection conducted at the Motor Vehicle Test Centre in Blainville, Quebec. #savinglivestogether #AutomotiveSafetyCouncil Insurance Institute for Highway Safety / Highway Loss Data Institute #IIHS #transportcanada #euroncap #ancap #globalncap #greenncap #InjuryBiomechanicsresearchcenter #Cchips #CHOP #TowardsZeroFoundation #VRU #CV2X #ADAS #NHTSA #AVTesting #childsafety #occupantsafety #AV #EV #activesafety #passivesafety #airbags #seats #vehiclesubmersion #vehiclesafety #roadsafety

More than 350,000 cardiac arrests occur outside a hospital each year and receiving Hands-Only CPR care can increase the chance of survival. For this reason, Illinois Red Cross Tiffany Circle members recently attended a Hands-Only CPR training event hosted at Northern Trust by fellow Tiffany Circle members Aileen Blake and Linda Nolan. Thank you all for attending this lifesaving event and your dedication to being prepared and ready to respond in case of a medical emergency. Sudden cardiac arrest can happen to anyone at any time, often without warning. Having life-saving skills and training can go a long way to keeping your loved ones safe in the event of cardiac arrest, as every minute that defibrillation is delayed, the person's chance of survival is reduced by 10%. Find out more by visiting redcross.org/handsonlycpr.

column7: Leadership is not just about giving orders and expecting people to follow them blindly. A great leader creates an environment that is safe and welcoming, where individuals feel comfortable expressing themselves without fear of judgment or retribution. When people feel secure enough to raise their hands, admit their mistakes, or ask for help, it shows that the leader has created an atmosphere of trust and respect. Employees who work in an environment of fear become preoccupied with protecting themselves from the forces within the company instead of helping the leadership protect the company from external influences. Leaders who prioritize creating a safe and supportive environment where people feel empowered to take risks and innovate build stronger and more resilient teams that are better equipped to face challenges and achieve success.Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#leadership #management #leadershipdevelopment #employeeengagement #leaders #people #leadershipfirst #leadershipfirstquotes #executivesandmanagement #inspiration #giffordthomas #entrepeneurship

I have spent most of my career working to better connect our world, and to help fulfill the positive role that both the private and public sectors can drive in building bridges across countries, economies and political systems. As I enter the next chapters of my life and professional career, I am working to bring my experiences to make a positive impact, in what is a very fraught geopolitical environment. I have chosen the boards on which I serve with those thoughts in mind, choosing to work with CEO's and missions that align with the values that I feel are more important than ever to uphold. These include creating a more inclusive economy, both domestically and across the globe. Advocating and standing up for our employees to assure they have physical, mental and financial health as a result of their employment. And that we aspire to listen to all points of view to create a more cohesive and just world, where people can talk to each other with open minds and hearts so we can come together to find common ground, and move forward in a positive manner. To continue to pursue these objectives, I am pleased to be joining Valor Capital Group as a managing partner. I will be spending a couple of days per week in this role, in order to give it the proper attention it demands, while providing me flexibility to pursue other passions of mine. I couldn't be more thrilled to work with Cliff Sobel (former Ambassador to the Netherlands and Brazil), Scott Sobel, and the rest of the Valor team. I have known Cliff and Scott for 25 plus years, and they are close friends. Valor is focused primarily on the LatAm region of the world, and is one of, if not the leading VC in that part of the world with ~$1.4B in AUM, and ~120 companies in their portfolio. Valor's ability to bring both diplomatic and economic assets to the region is spurring cross border trade between the US and the LatAm region, and that is a large positive force for our country and the Americas region. This is more important than ever as companies look to expand near-shoring in Mexico, Brazil and other LatAm countries. I'm eager to dive in with the Valor team and do all I can to make a difference, and work with their portfolio companies to maximize their growth potential and value, and contribute to economic development throughout the region.https://lnkd.in/gqa6uW6M

There are all kinds of different people in the world, many of whom value different kinds of things. If you find you can't get in sync with someone on shared values, you should consider whether that person is worth keeping in your life. A lack of common values will lead to a lot of pain and other harmful consequences and may ultimately drive you apart. It might be better to head all that off as soon as you see it coming. #principleoftheday

1 in 3 people will be diagnosed with cancer in their lifetime.Thankfully, through the American Cancer Society and premier fundraising events around the world like Tickled Pink Luncheon, there is hope for cancer patients. Being honored at the #TickledPinkLuncheon alongside Nelda Luce Blair, Chree Boydstun, Shelley Reeves Boyer, Cheryl Creuzot, CFP®, J.D., LL.M. MBA, Evelyn Leightman, and Sue Smith, was a powerful reminder of the gratitude I have for everyone who supported my healing journey and lifted me up when I needed it most. Seeing these beautiful warriors be celebrated was a fierce visual of the impact we each can make every day by sharing our stories, raising awareness, and supporting one another through whatever life may throw our way. I have endless gratitude for my support group, some of whom are pictured here, who were with me every step of my cancer journey. My medical team, family, friends, Airswift, and my community all showed up in great support. THANK YOU!!! My advice? If you're facing cancer, take things one day at a time. Surround yourself with positive people and find your way to accept the help from those willing to give it. When you can feel the love pouring out of those around you, it helps you heal.  If you know someone who is going through cancer treatment, reach out to them and offer your companionship. During the luncheon, Arif Kamal MD, MBA, Chief Patient Officer at ACS, shared that 60% of cancer patients report being lonely. A simple phone call, text, visit, or outing can make a world of difference “ it did for me. After four surgeries and the long road to recovery, I am now cancer free. Why? Because we caught it early enough thanks to my annual screening and because of the people who surrounded me. Today, I am stronger than ever. A year ago I asked you to get your screenings. Today, I am asking you again. #CEOsAgainstCancer #WeAreAirswift #ACS

I have spent most of my career working to better connect our world, and to help fulfill the positive role that both the private and public sectors can drive in building bridges across countries, economies and political systems. As I enter the next chapters of my life and professional career, I am working to bring my experiences to make a positive impact, in what is a very fraught geopolitical environment. I have chosen the boards on which I serve with those thoughts in mind, choosing to work with CEO's and missions that align with the values that I feel are more important than ever to uphold. These include creating a more inclusive economy, both domestically and across the globe. Advocating and standing up for our employees to assure they have physical, mental and financial health as a result of their employment. And that we aspire to listen to all points of view to create a more cohesive and just world, where people can talk to each other with open minds and hearts so we can come together to find common ground, and move forward in a positive manner. To continue to pursue these objectives, I am pleased to be joining Valor Capital Group as a managing partner. I will be spending a couple of days per week in this role, in order to give it the proper attention it demands, while providing me flexibility to pursue other passions of mine. I couldn't be more thrilled to work with Cliff Sobel (former Ambassador to the Netherlands and Brazil), Scott Sobel, and the rest of the Valor team. I have known Cliff and Scott for 25 plus years, and they are close friends. Valor is focused primarily on the LatAm region of the world, and is one of, if not the leading VC in that part of the world with ~$1.4B in AUM, and ~120 companies in their portfolio. Valor's ability to bring both diplomatic and economic assets to the region is spurring cross border trade between the US and the LatAm region, and that is a large positive force for our country and the Americas region. This is more important than ever as companies look to expand near-shoring in Mexico, Brazil and other LatAm countries. I'm eager to dive in with the Valor team and do all I can to make a difference, and work with their portfolio companies to maximize their growth potential and value, and contribute to economic development throughout the region.https://lnkd.in/gqa6uW6M

One year ago, a tragedy in downtown Louisville claimed the lives of five beloved ONB team members”Josh Barrick, Deana Eckert, Tommy Elliott, Juliana Farmer and Jim Tutt. These were extraordinary, loving and gifted individuals who were filled with passion and marked by a true spirit of generosity. Over the past 12 months, we have been humbled, blessed and sustained by an incredible outpouring of love, care and support from individuals and organizations throughout the country. We want to thank everyone who has supported us, and we particularly want to acknowledge and thank the members of the Louisville Metro Police Department (especially Officers Nick Wilt and Cory Galloway who were wounded); the University of Louisville Hospital Trauma Center; Governor Andy Beshear; Louisville Mayor Craig Greenberg; the FBI; the Louisville religious and mental health communities; the American Red Cross; and countless other heroes. Our Old National family will never forget!

column7: .Mike Maples, Jr looks for pattern-breaking founders who challenge the status quo and pursue their mission at all costs.These folks are willing to be disagreeable. Novelty can sound like heresy at first.A great leader is a  who absorbs new ideas like a sponge and is incredibly mentally flexible in their ability to acknowledge when they don't know how to do something or might be wrong.You have to navigate the idea maze ” look at every previous attempt at the boundary of you area and understand the assumptions behind them and why they failed--What other attributes has Mike seen in breakout founders? They're going to make this startup happen even if they can't raise money-  They get stronger under stress-  They have unresolved differences with the world. They have something to prove and won't accept failure as an outcome- Ethos of They practice something (work or non-work related) a lot- They see projects through- Radical Lots of people in business are persistent, but very few have the radical determination seen in startup founders who ultimately break the mold- Ruthless  They're tough-minded about the critical insights that power their business and the must-do things that have to happen, kind of like a Pareto principle- Great Great startups are a crazy journey that a bunch of people embark on (employees, customers, investors) where everyone is on a secret together. In order to make that happen, you have to be a good storyteller. The best realize they're not the hero of the story.”Mike's biggest piece of advice for someone thinking about starting a company: ”Tomorrow, I'll attempt to condense everything Mike has said and written about inflections and insights into one post. Thanks for reading!

column7: Kristin Olson, global head of the Alternative Capital Markets Group within Asset & Wealth Management, joined Bloomberg's Wall Street Week with David Westin and Katie Greifeld to discuss how we're advising our clients related to alternative investments. On the opportunities that investors should be thinking about, she shared: We've gone from a decade ago having $4 trillion in private investments to now having $15 trillion, which is incredible growth. What's fueled that has been institutional allocators, but if you look at what's going to fuel the growth going forward, forecasts would say of the $15 trillion in privates, about $4 trillion of that is in individual hands “ a decade from now, that number could triple.Watch the full interview: http://ms.spr.ly/6041cAxk1

column7: Bailey & Glasser, LLP has added two compassionate and dedicated lawyers to its national Asbestos and Lung Disease practice group. Jena Borden will practice in the firm's Maryville, Illinois office, and Timothy Leckenby is the newest member of the firm's Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania office. Jena and Tim focus their practice on representing individuals who have contracted mesothelioma, asbestosis, and other lung diseases caused by exposure to asbestos.Of Counsel lawyer Jena L. Borden is an experienced litigator with over twenty years of experience representing plaintiffs injured by products made by companies that put profits over people. Jena has collected millions in settlements for asbestos victims nationwide, but she also brings valuable regional expertise having litigated cases in the most active court in the nation for asbestos litigation, Madison County, Illinois.Lawyer Timothy Leckenby joins our busy Pittsburgh asbestos team focusing on investigating asbestos cases from industrial settings like steel mills, chemical plants, power plants, or factories to residential dwellings and school buildings. Tim brings prior litigation experience including contract, personal injury, professional negligence, e-discovery, class actions and multidistrict litigation, unfair trade practices, and federal declaratory judgment actions. To read full announcement, please visit: https://ow.ly/rxxk50RekPM To learn more about our Asbestos and Lung Disease practice, please visit: https://ow.ly/SaA250RekPL #Asbestos #Mesothelioma #newlawyers #BaileyGlasser

Most people tend to think of #STEM fields as a platform for individual success only. Compared to other fields like #law or #medicine or #business, STEM is consensually perceived as lacking in communal opportunities. These community oriented opportunities and pro-social goals are especially valued by women and minoritized.Thanks to Indiana University Bloomington for the spotlight on 3M sponsored #research led by Professor Amanda Diekman and her team where we found that students who reflected on their #inspiration, reported greater enjoyment in pursuing STEM, higher feelings of belonging within the field, and a greater capacity to handle stress. And this trend was consistent across students with different racial and gender identities. #Purpose reflection can benefit all. That is why we are very excited about the PRISM repository of reflection exercises for STEM faculty to use in their classes. (PRISM link below -> Purpose Reflection Integration in STEM Modalities)

A Sign on the Trail & A New Chapter Ahead....While on a recent hike with my family, I captured an image that resonated deeply with me - an arrow secured onto a tree, pointing forward. Simple, yet profound, it felt serendipitous, mirroring the inner journey I've been navigating personally and professionally. Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

column7: The average London adult buys more than 3 single-use plastic bottles every week ˜¬In total, some 7.7 billion plastic bottles are bought across the UK each year, resulting in substantial amounts of single-use plastic waste.Thanks to our work with Thames Water, we've made a dent in these statistics and Mayor of London continues to support the Refill London campaign. You can read more about our refill footprint in the capital here: https://bit.ly/3xtakKc #refill #london #mayoroflondon #hydration #plasticpollution

column7: Two years ago, on Easter weekend, we achieved a miracle by flawlessly executing a cutover involving 80+ countries and 27 Manufacturing/R&D sites, cloning over 300 applications including SAP, and migrating them all from on-premises data centres to Azure cloud. Additionally, we reconfigured 4000+ interface endpoints to create Haleon from GSK. While the technical and business complexity of meticulously planning such a transition was immense, everyone, including colleagues from GSK, Haleon, and our partners, did a fabulous job to make it happen.However, as I reflect, the primary reason for our success was the extraordinary leadership demonstrated by GSK and Haleon leaders, who:1)Instilled a sense of purpose to seize this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to create a FTSE 20 company with a £30 Billion Market Cap.2)Set a clear strategy and ensured that every team member understood their role in executing it.3)Fostered a culture of collaboration by bringing a high-performing team together and defining clear accountabilities.4)Supported the team in the face of human errors, taking accountability as leaders and ensuring that the team learned from its mistakes.5)Defined contingency plan and ensured GSK & Haleon executive teams are aware of implications in case we need to activate it .I am incredibly proud to have been part of this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and I extend my gratitude to all the leaders and colleagues at GSK , Haleon and our partners who made the seemingly impossible, possible.Line De Decker Teri Lyng Joe Touey Amy Landucci David Venter Kelly Ellis Fraser MacFarlane Suzanne Ellis Agam Upadhyay Will W.#TransformationalLeadership #GSK #Haleon

Last year this time I was riding a high as my son's team, the Northwestern University Wildcats, made just their 2nd March Madness tournament appearance in school history. My son Blake Smith was a 1st-year walk-on and didn't see much court time last season, but that didn't dampen our enthusiasm one bit. Fast forward to 2024..due to a few unfortunate injuries, my son's number was called. He was brought off the bench - agreeing to forgo his redshirt and an additional year of playing eligibility - to help secure an end-of-season 8 game stand to help the team make the NCAA tourney for a 2nd consecutive year. And he certainly rose to the challenge with his defensive prowess guarding some of the best players in the Big10. By the 1st round NCAA tourney regional in Brooklyn his story was written; a few of the headlines: Northwestern's Blake Smith an Unlikely March Madness piece and This Germantown AcademyGrad Had No D1 Offers and Now He's About to Play in the NCAA Tournament. After an overtime win in the 1st round against last year's Final Four Cinderella team, Florida Atlantic, up next was UConn. Northwestern's Cinderella dream came to an end at the hands of the eventual overall tournament champs. Fun fact “ Northwestern was the only team to win a half against UConn! After Brooklyn, my interest shifted to DJ Burns with his magnetic play and infectious smile. But, then came the women: Dawn Stanley (a University of Virginia alum) took the South Carolina women to a perfect season and a championship.  And Caitlin Clark beat every record that could be broken. I found myself scheduling my time around the women's matchups. I'm always sad to see March Madness end but always leave inspired. This year, it ˜hit different'. To see my son Blake shine and the women get their turn was magical.  As we encounter continued divisiveness, thank you to the college athletes who put their will and their dreams on full display to deliver something magical every March that brings us together. Shout out to all the amazing current and former student-athletes (Larry Smith Blake Smith, Alexis Smith, Tony Watkins). And Shout out to the women. We got next! #MarchMadness #StudentAthletes

column7: I read "People and Data" by Tom Redman over the Easter break. I had met Thomas last year at the Data master Class by Dr. Alexander Borek . He gave a keynote speech there that I found extremely insightful - I got a lot out of it. I wanted to get more tips like he had presented there. So, I bought his book. If you are working in data (and one of the main points of the book is - who isn't nowadays???) then this book is defos a recommended gem. My favourite chapter: Change Management. Especially loved the graph below, though it got me reflecting about all the projects I have done in the past. And I think I would add a (at least one) component which is: "Show some results fast; some lighthouse project" - else it's difficult to keep the momentum. Do you agree Tom Redman ?
I'm happy to share that I'm starting a new position as SVP, Client Integrations-Team Lead at BankUnited!

April 2nd is Autism Awareness Day. Many world monuments will be lit up in blue lights to show support for the cause. Colorful ribbons and pins will be worn and emotional sentiments will be plastered all over social media. Unfortunately, the concept of awareness is simply not enough. Without acceptance and inclusion, none of this actually makes a difference.As the father of a wonderful 19-year-old young man with autism, every day is Autism Awareness Day for us. All of us possess special talents. However, while many have proclaimed the benefits of diversity, society has created stereotypes and cultural obstacles that actually impede the inclusion of neurodiverse individuals - those who view the world differently than us. We need to value these individuals because of their differences, not in spite of them.Acceptance and inclusion of individuals with autism needs to happen more than one day a year.#diversity #inclusion #autism #disabilitysupport #love #understanding #neurodiversity

A great evening spent bowling with colleagues, in support of #BowlForKidsSake, the flagship fundraiser of Big Brothers Big Sisters of America, an organization that Kimberly-Clark has supported for over 10 years. This event was hosted by our North America Innovation and Operational Excellence Center in Neenah, and raised funds for their Eastern Wisconsin chapter. Beyond bowling, our campus in Neenah also serves as a workplace mentoring site, empowering our employees to volunteer as mentors for local youth. Big Brothers Big Sisters of America is the nation's largest donor and volunteer supported mentoring network, and we are grateful for the opportunity to support their work and support the development of positive relationships that have a lasting effect on the lives of young people. Thanks also to all the K-C employees who joined the event - we were more than 70! You made a difference!Christine Cowell Forest Himmelfarb Viviane Cury Alison Rhoten Gillian Lachance Curt Balara

column7: I'm thrilled to unveil my new role as the Green Digital Lead! As we embark on 2024, I'm brimming with excitement for the forthcoming opportunities in innovation & technology. In this capacity, my primary focus revolves around advocating green digital principles, especially within our cutting-edge software-defined solutions. Green digital it embodies leveraging technology to foster a more sustainable world. In energy management, it entails harnessing digital innovations to reduce energy consumption, minimize waste, and safeguard the environment. As the Green Digital Lead, I am dedicated to placing these principles at the forefront of all our initiatives. I extend my gratitude to Daniel GHENO and Julie Savino for their unwavering support as I embark on this journey!

column7: Ford Motor Company is the top-selling truck manufacturer globally and in the U.S a Ford truck is produced every 33 seconds! These are the amazing people behind this achievement. Here in North America, our teams at Dearborn Truck Plant, Michigan Assembly Plant and Kansas City Assembly Plant assemble America's best-selling trucks for our customers. I've witnessed their passion, dedication and teamwork firsthand.Today leadership and employees were at the plants to celebrate all their success as well as the new 2024 F-150s and Rangers we're shipping to customers right now. More than 35,000 employees support the production of the Ranger and F-150 in the U.S. Today and everyday we celebrate their hard work. Ford's 47 years of truck leadership couldn't be achieved without our teams! We are #BuiltFordTough because of them.#WeAreFord #FordMotorCompany

Good health not only means physical health but also mental health. We invest a lot of time and energy in healthy foods and exercise routines but not a lot in terms of our mental health. I'm a firm believer that therapy is the first step to taking care of our mental health. It provides individuals with a safe space to explore their thoughts, feelings, and experiences under the guidance of a trained professional. Through these sessions, individuals can learn coping strategies, gain insights into their behavior patterns, and develop healthier ways of relating to themselves and others: this is where true healing happens, and our EQ will grow. Remember, what may work for you may not work for others, and treatment options should be tailored to the individual's needs. #Health #Wellness #MentalHealth #PhysicalWellnessMonth

Great leaders don't create followers.They create more leaders.7 signs you work for a great leader:1. Gives Credit³ They spotlight your achievements.³ Your success is their success.2. Values Your Input³ Your ideas matter.³ Every suggestion is welcomed.3. Supports Growth³ They're there when you need them.³ Pushing you to reach new heights.4. Cares Beyond Work³ They ask how you're doing, really doing.³ They're there to support, not just supervise.5. Respects Your Time³ Your off-hours are yours.³ Work-life balance isn't just a buzzword.6. Sets the Example³ Actions speak louder than words.³ They lead from the front.7. Makes Decisions with Compassion³ Tough calls are made with a kind heart.³ They consider how decisions affect you.Work under a leader like this?Consider yourself blessed.Great leadership is rare but transformative.Spread the word. Repost to share ™»¸.Great leaders inspire more great leaders.P.S. Want hi-res PDFs of my 40 best cheat sheets?Follow Eric Partaker and try my free newsletter: https://lnkd.in/dF-VwKqi

column7: Technologist, linguist, diversity advocate, innovator, coach, change agent and shopping partner!We couldn't pick the best adjective to introduce you to Edwina Payne, so we are sharing them all!With a storied career spanning countries, industries and capabilities, Edwina is a veritable powerhouse of a leader. Edwina has taken every opportunity to learn, grow and teach : including moving to Brazil (and learning Portuguese along the way), leading ERP transformations and CX experiences with equal ease, all the while enabling and coaching teams, with a focus on enabling diversity members to achieve their best.As a board member to a number of organizations, Edwina continues her technology career path and is a guide to many at T200 thinking about their board career journeys.Edwina came to T200 serendipitously, enabled by a memorable, unplanned NYC shopping sojourn with Diane Schwarz! Diane do share some anecdotes!Another fun fact : Edwina is Purdue University alumni, alongside other T200 leaders including Diana McKenzie and Karenann Terrell. Diana do share some stories from those years! If you are a Purdue alumni, an Indiana native, an Atlanta resident like Edwina, or a curious #T200member, we have given you so many reasons to connect with Edwina (and some icebreaker ideas to boot!) Do connect! This member spotlight is presented by Tejaswi Urs, Sharanya CJ, and scribed by Lakshmi Pappu . #T200 is a fully volunteer run non profit focused on women leadership in technology. To learn more visit us at www.t200.org#T200, #Purduealum, #womenintech, #lessonsinleadership, #diversity, #boardready

In the wild world of positioning, it's not about what we say we are, but rather what our buyers think we are. ¯Working closely and observing a few SaaS companies recently, I've noticed a recurring theme in platform positioning endeavors: the rush from being a "solution for small problem x" to claiming the coveted title of "PLATFORM for solving bigger problem X."But then comes the #recordscratch moment”picture it: your unprepared customer, speaking at a webinar or user group, casually dropping, "We got <your product> because it's a darn good TOOL for tackling small problem x."Ouch.As much as we all dream of being "platforms," let's face it: the reality check hits hard. Most CIOs are juggling just a handful of application platforms across their line of business”those epicenters of major business processes like order-to-cash, purchase-to-pay, recruit-to-support, you name it.So, for many of the application companies in their early stages, maybe it's time for a more grounded positioning approach. Instead of aiming for the stars with the "platform" label, why not focus on staying true to our roots as a "solution to a problem buyers are actively trying to solve. As long as that problem is big and widespread, positioning around it hits home with buyers, avoiding the  perception gap issue. Now, if the problem isn't big enough, it's a whole other TAM/SAM challenge.And if you're considering hitching your wagon to one of those flashy "Platform" companies, do yourself a favor: chat up 1 or 2 late-stage prospects they've recently lost (if you can pull it off). It's like a buyer's perception polygraph test”a true glimpse into how your dream company is really perceived out there.Because, at the end of the day, we are What Our Buyers Think We Are. #positioning #PMM #GTM

Sikhs all over the world are celebrating 'Vaisakhi' this weekend! As a Sikh, I would like to share the story and how it reinforces the principles of #equality and #freedom of faith.On the Vaisakhi day of 1699 (the first day of the month of ˜Vaisakh' in the Sikh calendar), Guru Gobind Singh Sahib, the tenth Guru, formalized the concept of Saint-Soldier by introducing the Amrit ceremony (the formal initiation ceremony). He transformed the Sikhs into a family of soldier saints, known as the Khalsa Panth.The Guru requested the Sikhs to congregate at Anandpur on Vaisakhi. According to the Sikh tradition, he asked for a volunteer who was prepared to give his life for his faith to come into the tent. One came forward, whom he took inside a tent. The Guru returned to the crowd alone, with a bloody sword. He asked for another volunteer and repeated the same process of returning from the tent without anyone and with a bloodied sword four more times. After the fifth volunteer went with him into the tent, there was confusion and unease among the crowds. The Guru returned with all five volunteers, all safe. He called them the Panj Pyare (five beloved ones) and the first Khalsa in the Sikh tradition.Each of the initiates was instructed to keep the five K's: Kes (uncut hair), Kangha (a small comb), Karra (an iron bracelet), Kachera (a white undergarment), and Kirpan (a small curved sword of any size, shape or metal).The title of Khalsa refers to people whose life and spirit are solely the property of the One Universal Creator and not of any king, dictator, or even a messenger of the Creator. The Sikh faith was founded on the idea that there is only one Universal Creator and that all people are therefore equal, regardless of their religion, gender, ethnicity, color, caste, or other attributes.All five of the men were then seen emerging with the Guru, each wearing an orange suit and bib. These colors are symbols of Sikhism. In a novel and distinctive ceremony known as pahul, which Sikhs now refer to as the baptism ceremony known as Amrit, he baptized the five. Then the Guru asked those five baptized Sikhs to baptize him as well. This is how he became known as Guru Chela both teacher and student. Then he proclaimed that the Panj Pyare, also known as the Five Beloved Ones, would embody the Guru himself: "Where there are Panj Pyare, there am I. When the Five meet, they are the holiest of the holy." Thus with these principles, he established Panth Khalsa, the Order of the Pure Ones.

On behalf of the entire team at Ford, I want to congratulate Mike Felix, Director of Manufacturing, who is retiring after 35 years of dedicated service and invaluable contributions. From chief engineer of powertrain manufacturing to plant manager at five different plants, Mike has held leadership positions in U.S. and European operations and overseen multiple successful product launches across engine, transmission and axle. His strategic vision and unwavering commitment to excellence have been instrumental in driving our manufacturing operations to new heights. Thank you, Mike, for your exceptional leadership and service to Ford. You will be greatly missed, but the standard of excellence you set is something we will continue to follow. Here's to a long, healthy, happy retirement! ‘ #ManufacturingExcellence #WeAreFord #ServantLeadership

column7: Yesterday, we marked a significant milestone for ALPFA Washington, DC. In collaboration with CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield, we spearheaded the inaugural Health Summit. Our mission? To champion holistic care within the Latine community.The Latine community faces health disparities, including limited access to healthcare services and higher rates of chronic diseases. Therefore, at the core of this summit, we wanted to have a pivotal panel discussion on the State of Latine Health. Sheila Yahyazadeh, MPA, PMP, Kimberly Harris, and Suyanna Linhales Barker touched on navigated patient access hurdles, championed culturally competent care, and charted a visionary path forward for patient-centric healthcare.A heartfelt expression of gratitude is due to CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield, Eleazar Gutierrez, A. Tonya Odom, our fantastic speakers, and all attendees. Your unwavering support and dedication have fueled the success of this summit. Together, we march forward, steadfast in our resolve to bridge disparities and nurture holistic well-being.#HealthAndWellness #CorporateWellness #ALPFACommunity #ThriveTogether

column7: Some of you may know I'm a lifelong college basketball fan, and this season has been an especially memorable one for me”both as a woman and an Iowan. I was thrilled that Principal Financial Group became the presenting sponsor of the John R. Wooden Award, honoring the best collegiate coaches and players in the U.S. each year. Attending the awards ceremony and pairing up with finalists to coach a Special Olympics of Southern California basketball game was truly extraordinary and a highlight of my career. Thanks to the Los Angeles Athletic Club and the Wooden Award for hosting this weekend's events, and congratulations to our 2024 winners: Coach John Calipari, Iowa's Caitlin Clark, and Purdue's Zach Edey! All the honorees are as inspirational as you'd imagine, and it was an honor to celebrate with them.

Jon, you have been the best boss and leader I have worked with in my career! I only wish it could have been longer. What a loss, but it's only the next organization's gain. Thank you for taking a chance on me when I nervously did power poses in the bathroom before my interview with you and was horribly frightened I would fumble over my words. Thank you for being so supportive! It was one of the biggest moments of my career as well as the biggest moment of my life! I'm so grateful I shared these moments with you. I can't wait to see where you go next!

column7: Kristin Olson, global head of the Alternative Capital Markets Group within Asset & Wealth Management, joined Bloomberg's Wall Street Week with David Westin and Katie Greifeld to discuss how we're advising our clients related to alternative investments. On the opportunities that investors should be thinking about, she shared: We've gone from a decade ago having $4 trillion in private investments to now having $15 trillion, which is incredible growth. What's fueled that has been institutional allocators, but if you look at what's going to fuel the growth going forward, forecasts would say of the $15 trillion in privates, about $4 trillion of that is in individual hands “ a decade from now, that number could triple.Watch the full interview: http://ms.spr.ly/6041cAxk1

column7: I'm excited to announce that I've started a new position as SVP, Employer Sales and Strategic Alliances at Spring Health! Working alongside an incredible team of highly-qualified, talented, and hard-working individuals, we are dedicated to putting our members first and improving outcomes. Our mission is simple yet powerful - to eliminate every barrier to mental health.At Spring Health, we provide a unique and comprehensive mental health solution for employers and health plans. Our clinically validated technology, Precision Mental Healthcare, allows us to deliver personalized mental health solutions to each individual, including meditation, coaching, therapy, medication, and more. If you're interested in learning more about our mission and how we're revolutionizing mental healthcare, feel free to contact me. Let's work together to make a real difference in people's lives! #mentalhealthawareness #wellness #healthcare #springhealth #employersolutions #healthplans

column7: "Need a few weeks to get my arms around the business and then I can review the proposal." What should a seller do next?What most sellers do is send a generic, "Got it, here to help if I can be." reply (if they send one at all... ˜’) and set a reminder to reach out in three weeks.˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘˜‘So many deals fail to advance or close because we miss the chance to effectively nurture.This is your chance to educate.Here's how I'd run my play:1. Send a more customized thank you/understood note2. Send an email to educate them the following Saturday morning"Sean, thinking through two things that might be good food for thought as you consider buying our #SMYKM Masterclass - this post that says x and shows how easily I've been able to get meetings with senior leaders through personalization, and this recent screenshot on the data of personalization over spray/pray.Hope it's helpful!"3. Tag them in the comments of a relevant post. "Sean, what I was just mentioning in last week's email!"4. Send them another educational note, case study, or accolade."Sean, a client recently gave us a testimonial noting that our SMYKM training + sequence workshops netted them the same response rate as before - 9% - but that they switched from being 13% positive to 21% positive, almost doubling their meeting bookings, and it also took their unsubscribe rate from 17% to 1.5%, all in three months. Makes me think of the positive impact we could have to your sales team, but also to marketing, if helpful!"Key learnings here:1. You're creating a drip campaign to educate them while they navigate internal meetings - give them ammo in meetings by educating them2. Using multiple mediums to get their attention3. You're making NO ask whatsoever - this isn't about you getting another meeting or an update on your proposal, it's about you educating them while you await those few weeks to pass.4. You're putting in the effort that other reps aren't.5. Take the time to write a really great email and then keep that in a master Google doc of nurture emails that you can copy and paste through these next 12-18 months.6. After you send the email, pause and think, "Who else am I trying to win over on this product and who I can copy/paste this to?", rinse/repeat/nurture at scale.#samsales

column7: After 15 great years, I want to announce that May 15th will be my last day as Chief Investment Officer at Citi Wealth.As I look back on my years at Citi, I am filled with gratitude. After Jane Fraser offered me the opportunity to lead the rebuilding of Citi's investment platform in 2009, we assembled an extraordinary team that developed a global, integrated, open architecture investments business now at the heart of Citi Wealth. I have had the distinct privilege of working with extraordinary clients who expected and received Citi's best thinking due, in large measure, to the expertise of my wonderful colleagues. As CIO since 2019, we have enabled Citi to keep our clients abreast of extraordinary world events and navigate markets profitably through them. Together, we have demonstrated excellence and have recently earned Euromoney's recognition as Best Chief Investment Office in 2024.I extend my profound thanks to Shu Zhang, CFA, CAIA, Harlin Singh Urofsky, Deborah Q., Nicole D., Cristal Chung, CTP, Ben Roberts, Michelle Reese, Dan O'Donnell, Robert Jasminski, Michael Stein, Iain Armitage, MBE, Roger Bacon, Lisandro Chanlatte, CAIA, Jonathan Leach, Adam Harper and Shkurta Bera. Plus a special shout out to my partner, Steven Wieting.  You are the single most outstanding group of professionals I have ever had the pleasure of working with. To Andy Sieg and the CGW leadership team, especially Ida Liu, Naz Vahid, David Poole and Kristen Bitterly Michell, I am most certain that the businesses you lead will flourish for decades to come. Thank you for your partnership.And to all of the clients and professionals I have engaged with at Citi and around the world, thank you for the trust we share. As I begin a new chapter, I am eager to focus my energy and entrepreneurial spirit to address investment strategy issues facing family offices.  And I intend to partner with others who share that interest. I look forward to publishing independent market commentary and insights in the future. If you find my writings and opinions useful, please reach out via DM or email.Warmly,David Bailin, CIOCiti Wealth#FamilyOffice, #WealthManagement, #Investing, #AssetManagement, #HighNetWorth, #LegacyPlanning, #MarketInsights, #JaneFraser, #CitiPrivateBank, #Citibank

column7: After a lot of reflection and lots of conversations over the last few weeks, I have come to a decision in terms of my next chapter! Thanks to everyone who acted as my sounding board!I sincerely appreciate all the comments from all my partners, peers and team at Honeywell and my broader circle from my last post; it has been more than a little emotional these last weeks! I have found that when you have time to think and reflect, it is quite amazing to contemplate all the astounding transformations that our team have been able to deliver over the years at Honeywell (and especially in the last few years). Whether it is driving cost efficiency, improving compliance, enabling the business or improving the digital experience, we have been relentless in our pursuit of improvement across the IT environment.I have learned so much over the years as a senior member of the IT Leadership at Honeywell and being part of a Fortune 500 Global Corporation, it has allowed me the opportunity to set the strategies, be a thought leader and deliver against those roadmaps and plans. Thanks again to everyone who I have had the pleasure of working with over the years! I believe I can add a lot of value to many other companies with my experience so now it's time for me to fly solo! More to come on that as I get everything finalised and setup in the coming days!

column7: I had a great time earlier this month in Minneapolis St Paul at the Midwest Energy Association (MEA) Environmental conference! I'm happy to be part of the planning committee to put this together each year. We had great presentations including PFAS, hydrovac spoil management, and an Army Corps permitting roundtable. One of my favorite presentations was on the latest addition to Southern Nuclear - the new Vogtle 3 and 4 units which are the first nuclear units built in the US since the 1980s.  Our trip to the Minnesota Wild hockey game was a highlight too! Mark your calendars to join us in spring 2025. Date and location TBD.

column7: During times of uncertainty, it can be easy to get lost in our thoughts and worries. We may find ourselves constantly wondering and imagining what the future holds, and obsessing over things we cannot control. However, sometimes the best thing we can do is to take a step back, breathe deeply, and trust that everything will work out for the best. By focusing on the present moment and having faith in ourselves and the universe, we can find peace and clarity amidst the chaos. Remember that life is full of ups and downs, and that every challenge we face is an opportunity for growth and learning. So take a deep breath, let go of your worries, and trust in the journey ahead.Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#leadership #management #leadershipdevelopment #employeeengagement #leadershipfirst #giffordthomas

In 2006 I got a call about a job at a wine store in the town over from mine in New Jersey. I remember the recruiter saying It's probably not what you had in mind as the next move - but telling you this guy is thinking different, you've at least got to talk.Looking back I've kicked myself for not going with my curiosity enough to spend an hour with someone who has become an inspiration to me and so many others. Frankly it was a real lesson in humility and always stuck as a reminder to keep an open mind - because really, you just never know. Thanks #POSSIBLE2024 for bringing so many awesome members of our Ad Tech community together, and the opportunity 18 years later to finally meet Gary Vaynerchuk in person and let him know how he's helped change my way of seeing the world.Photocred Mitch Paletz POSSIBLE

We're thrilled for Truist to be first-time sponsors of the 2024 Payments Fraud and Control Survey (link below) from the Association for Financial Professionals. As fraud attempts increase, Truist is committed to helping businesses protect their assets with speed, simplicity and security. Key findings from the survey: - 80% of organizations experienced targeted fraud attempts in 2023, a jump from the previous year. - Checks remain the most fraud-vulnerable payment method. - ACH credits now surpass wires for BEC fraud exposure. These findings underscore the relentless evolution of payments fraud. Truist provides solutions that empower businesses to stay ahead of these ever-changing tactics. Reach out today to let us help develop the right fraud strategy for your business! https://lnkd.in/exUvEp2y #paymentsfraud #payments #treasury #TeamTruist

column7: When you speak in such a way, others love to listen to you and listen in such a way that others love talking to you. It shows you value your team by actively listening to their concerns, feedback or suggestions. I sometimes wonder why companies ask their employees for their feedback when, time and time again, they never listen to what their employees are saying. I can remember during many meetings I attended, the routine was always the same coming to the end of the meetings, anyone have any suggestions, feedback or questions for the management team? the CEO always asked. So many people always voice their concerns or offer some form of suggestion. Still, nothing came from any of it; I can distinctly remember watching the managers at the front table when people were talking, and no one seemed remotely interested in anything anyone was saying. It was so glaring and so disrespectful. But you know what was ironic? I've heard some of these same managers complain that my employees won't speak up and label them as bad or uncaring employees, but these same leaders should look in the mirror and ask themselves how their people ended up that way. When someone is sharing their ideas and feedback, and they are not taken seriously, at some point, that person will become very quiet, and the worst thing for any organization is when their most passionate employees become quiet.Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#giffordthomas #leadershipfirst #leadership #executivesandmanagement

column7: Today marks the start of a new beginning as it is my last day at Dell. I started at Dell in 2000, left for a few years and came back in 2011. I have worked for this company over a total of 18 years in Austin Texas, Sydney Australia, Auckland New Zealand, London UK, and Atlanta GA. The decision was not an easy one, as I feel I am leaving a lot of friends and family behind, but one I need for my own personal and career growth. I have worked for, with, and alongside some amazing people over the years. To the first leaders as an ISR, Rob Argabright and Bart Arnold to those that helped me adjust in Australia: Lida Lazzari, Mark Voorhies and Tom O'reilly, to the ones that hired me back into the business in 2011 and moved me to the UK in 2017, Kyle Dufresne and John Green. Those that made the move to the UK easier, David Mckeown and Varry McMenemy, to those that were constant support and mentors Jim Molasky and John Baxter. Thank you! Dell has some of the best people. Looking forward, I am excited to be joining a company where all my knowledge and expertise will help the growth and trajectory of the future. I am excited to be working for Brian Wright and RC Damle where I believe I will be able to make a huge impact here in the Southeast for. Zscaler. So here is to new beginnings.. and transformation ˜

column7: "If you can't measure it, you can't improve it."  Peter DruckerIn the work I do for my clients, it's critical not just to execute the work but to provide a means of measuring the success (and occasional) failures along the way.  These measurements provide insight, support funding alignment, and focus the team in the right direction.  But as Tom Alder notes, multitudes of metrics can lead to confusion and lack of focus.  A North Star Metric cuts through the chaos to guide the overall picture - a tactic my team and I regularly employ in our metric dashboard work at the US Navy.Are you looking for an amazing company to drive results and enhance efficiencies for your business?  At Ignite Digital Services, Performance Management Consulting is just one of many services we perform to increase enterprise value and support mission impact.  We do amazing things for others.  We can do it for you too. #weareids#metrics #optimization #northstarmetric #performancemanagement #consulting

column7: Greetings!!!  This 20-21 April I will be participating my 12th Face of America, an inspiring, two-day, 100+ mile bicycle and hand cycle ride to the historic Civil War battlefields of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. This annual ride from national non-profit World T.E.A.M. Sports honors our adaptive military veterans and includes nearly 200 veterans, active-duty military and civilian participants with injuries and disabilities ranging from amputation to paralysis to blindness to post-traumatic stress and traumatic brain injury.Held annually since 2006, the Face of America is one of the largest non-competitive bicycling events in the mid-Atlantic region. In 2018, more than 600 riders participated in the ride - many of who traveled from across the United States and Canada to Washington and Valley Forge. I would like to ask you to support me in this year's ride through your generous financial donation. Each able-bodied participant is riding in support of the adaptive veterans, raising money to cover the costs for the ride, and to support upcoming events from non-profit World T.E.A.M. Sports. Donations and sponsorship funding provide opportunities for military and civilian athletes with disabilities to join remarkable outdoor adventures. These remarkable events range from the annual Adventure Team Challenge in the high Rocky Mountains of Colorado to the Coastal Team Challenge along Long Island, New York, where developmentally-disabled teens and young adults paddle sea kayaks on a two-day journey. At all World T.E.A.M. Sports events, persons with disabilities participate at no cost.As a registered 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, contributions to World T.E.A.M. Sports are tax deductible, provided you meet the IRS criteria and maintain certain records. (A relatively simple explanation of IRS requirements can be found at IRS Tax Tip 2010-60). World T.E.A.M. Sports sends donation receipts to all contributors to aid in this process. For questions regarding the tax or legal aspects of your donation, I encourage you to contact your legal or tax adviser.https://lnkd.in/eA6Pcfmr

column7: Equipping graduates with a richly defined base of technical expertise, a well-grounded sense of social responsibility, and an awareness of the need to improve the human condition should be top priority.That is why the Ivan Allen College of Liberal Arts created their Distinguished Alumni Awards to highlight exceptional individuals who have contributed to the College, Institute, and public welfare. Thank you John Lyon and the Georgia Tech School of Modern Languages for recognizing my actions with this distinction! https://lnkd.in/grMM6hW9’¡ My language journey started with my German grandmother, who not only was the main reason for learning the language but also instilled in our family the importance of education. That education started at the German International School Washington D.C., thanks to my parents who enrolled me there in kindergarten and equipped me with the tools and resources to be successful. In college, I pursued a minor in German and participated in the Language Business and Technology program under Bettina Cothran who broadened my perspective and enriched my experience.™ In graduate school, I studied abroad at the University of Stuttgart, which was only possible thanks to Paul Neitzel's support and guidance from multiple exchange students working under Laurence Jacobs, Ph.D.Special shout out to Ryan Hon, PhD, PE, who continues to master his own German language skills and is on this journey with me to inspire and educate others to be passionate, empathetic, and generous global leaders! column7: Leverage in an organization is not unlike leverage in the markets; you're looking for ways to achieve more with less. I am always eager to find people who can do things nearly as well as (and ideally better than) I can so that I can maximize my output per hour.Technology is another great tool for providing leverage. To make training as easy to leverage as possible, document the most common questions and answers through audio, video, or written guidelines, and then assign someone to organize them and incorporate them into a manual, which is updated on a regular basis.Principles themselves are a form of leverage--they're a way to compound your understanding of situations so that you don't need to exert the same effort each time you encounter a problem. #principleoftheday

Austin III announced that the president has made the nomination for appointment of Rear Admiral Dion D. English to the rank of Vice Admiral, with assignment as director for logistics, J-4, Joint Staff.  English is currently serving as director, logistics division (N4L), Office of the Chief of Naval Operations.His afloat assignments include disbursing and sales officer, USS Scott (DDG 995); cargo and stock control officer, USNS San Diego (T-AFS 6); supply officer, USS Barry (DDG 52); and commanding officer, Explosive Ordnance Disposal Expeditionary Support Unit ONE.His shore assignments include ship force support officer, Supervisor of Shipbuilding, Newport News, Virginia; executive assistant to the Commander, Defense Supply Center Columbus, Ohio; deputy logistics operations officer, Joint Task Force Civil Support (JTF-CS), Fort Monroe, Virginia; logistics readiness officer, Logistics Current Operations Division, N4 Directorate for Commander, U.S. Pacific Fleet (USPACFLT); director, Supply Corps Detailing, Navy Personnel Command (PERS-4412), Millington, Tennessee; commanding officer, Naval Supply Systems Command (NAVSUP) Fleet Logistics Center (FLC) Sigonella, Italy; deputy director, supply and distribution, J44, Joint Staff, Washington, District of Columbia.His flag assignments include director, logistics, fleet supply and ordnance, N4, USPACFLT, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, and vice director for logistics, J-4, Joint Staff.English is designated as a Surface Warfare Supply Corps Officer and as a Navy Expeditionary Supply Corps Officer.  He is a member of the Defense Acquisition Corps and is a Joint Qualified Officer.  While under his command, NAVSUP FLC Sigonella earned recognition in partnership with the team that received the prestigious Admiral Stan Arthur Award for 2018 Logistics Team of the Year.Please join me in congratulating Rear Admiral English on this historic achievement.K.W. EPPSRADM, SC, USN#NavySupplyCorps #USNavy
column21: Congratulations Vice Admiral English! All my best to you and your family.

column7: A bittersweet moment to share with you all that today, April 18th, is my last day at SABIC.  These last 5 years have been a tremendous journey - I have been priviliged to experience new cultures, build lasting friendships, be challenged professionally, and lay the foundation for an ambitious pathway for innovation and sustainability that I feel our industry must advance at this critical time. The moment is bittersweet, as although I am excited to move to a different career phase, focused on consulting with SABIC and across our value chain, growing my portfolio of board roles, and yes finding the balance needed both for myself and my family, I leave behind (only to an extent ˜) my SABIC family.  I cannot thank all of them enough for how I was welcomed and embraced, and I am proud of all that we have accomplished together, for SABIC, for KSA Vision 2030, for our industry, and society.These two photos, one taken when I joined in 2019, and one recently taken this year, hopefully sum up my hope... that I have left an imprint that, with all of the SABIC teams help, will continue to grow long after I am gone.THANK YOU ALL! #sabic #chemistrythatmatters #sustainability #innovation

column7: A Sign on the Trail & A New Chapter Ahead....While on a recent hike with my family, I captured an image that resonated deeply with me - an arrow secured onto a tree, pointing forward. Simple, yet profound, it felt serendipitous, mirroring the inner journey I've been navigating personally and professionally. Today, I am excited to share that, much like the arrow, I am embarking on a new chapter in my career. This transition is more than a change; it's a declaration of growth, new challenges, and uncharted territories waiting to be explored.This decision comes after much reflection, inspired by the conversations, experiences, and the invaluable support from many of you in my professional and personal circles. The path forward is not just a new role or title, but a commitment to personal and professional development, to seeking out new horizons and embracing the opportunities they present.The arrow on that tree was a poignant reminder that growth and change are both necessary and beautiful. It's an encouragement to step out of our comfort zones, to take the path less traveled, and to trust the journey.As I prepare for this exciting transition, I carry with me lessons of the past and the promise of the future. This move is a step towards what I believe is a fulfilling direction, one that aligns with my values, skills, and passions.I look forward to sharing more about my new role and the adventures it brings in due time. For now, I am reminded of the boundless potential that comes with embracing change, much like setting out on a new trail with an arrow pointing forward.Here's to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows that guide us. ¹

column7: The Wall Street Journal recently shared a video raising concerns about Boeing's quality assurance processes and their impact on aircraft safety following the 737 MAX crashes.This is an unfortunate example that illustrates, why, at Graham, we strongly emphasize a Safety First, Quality Focused mindset to ensure that our products meet the highest standards of safety and quality. Our Quality Cardinal Rule program outlines behaviors that could critically impact product safety and quality, jeopardize consumer safety, cause major failures for customers and risk defects reaching the customer. By continuously developing skills, sharing knowledge and mentoring others, we are better able to address quality concerns and maintain high standards. While we may not be making airplanes, the importance of having a Safety First, Quality Focused mindset cannot be overstated. It is essential to ensure that our products meet the highest standards of safety and quality, and that our customers can trust us to deliver products that are safe and reliable.Click here to view the video: https://buff.ly/3U5wKcb#grahampackaging #safetyfirstqualityfocused #quality

WEoB member Montse Montaner Picart is thrilled to announce her recent appointment to the Board of Directors of Bavarian Nordic A/S. Montse is sincerely grateful for the trust placed in her and eagerly anticipates leveraging her experience and expertise to further the success of the esteemed company. Bavarian Nordic is a fully integrated vaccine company committed to safeguarding and preserving lives through groundbreaking vaccines. Renowned as a global leader in smallpox and monkeypox vaccines, the company supplies governments to bolster public health readiness. Additionally, they boast a robust vaccine portfolio catering to travelers and endemic regions. column7: Katapult X: Amazing News - F5 Welcomes Birmingham City University Students!Check out the highlights video!F5 hosted and Insights Day for students from Birmingham City University and I have to say it was an absolutely awesome day.This event was powerful because it showcased the multitude of categories within #cybersecurity where students could choose to specialise and build a career.  The team really lifted students aspirations by instilling a level of self-belief that careers within corporate organisations are in their reach.The day was packed with different sessions, one of the highlights was meeting the engineers who shared what a typical day involves and really engaged with #students answering all their questions.What stood out for me was the number of people, at every level,  who took time out of their working day to lead sessions, contribute and show support.A big thanks to Cathy Walkington, Paula Hewitt and Christian Bennett who took an idea and made it a reality, really showcasing their commitment to the development and growth of young people's careers.Katapult X is looking forward to creating more events with F5! #workexperience #cyber #inclusion #socialmobility Alex Wilson Jon McKellar Arthur Reynolds Daisy Blecker David Bond Amardeep Panaser Melissa Arouni Uzmaan Rizwan Kristina D.

Take a moment to appreciate the smallest things in your life as you start your day and before you end it. It could be the warmth of the sunlight on your skin, the sound of birds chirping outside your window, or the taste of your favorite morning beverage. These little things that we often overlook can bring a great deal of joy into our lives. By recognizing and being thankful for them, we can shift our focus from what we lack to what we have. column7: What a day yesterday was at the #orbieawards. One of the key messages from the fabulous Archie Deskus was about the importance of relationships.That was clear from the moment I arrived. The HoustonCIO community has accepted me as one of their own. Rob Franch and I were reflecting on how challenging it can be to relocate a family to a new and somewhat foreign place. We both grew up as leaders in Chicago and were part of the ChicagoCIO community. Armed with that knowledge and experience, we are building relationships here in #Houston with so many talented and experienced leaders who have welcomed us.If I only heard the keynote and had the opportunity to speak with Rob alone, it would have been a great day. What made it an exceptional day was I got to meet with a client who was also being recognized. Ralph Owens, congratulations and thank you for the partnership. In another illustration of how these relationships we invest in span beyond a professional level, I had the opportunity to catch up with Dave Upton. We both share a passion for home theater. Congratulations Dave on winning in our category. I can't think of anyone better to represent us.The icing on the cake was the opportunity to be seated at the same table with Lise Monahan. Lise and I were part of the office of the CIO at another company. Under the leadership of Jake Dominguez, we learned and we grew since. It was great to catch up with Lise and celebrate her recent successes and promotion. I'm still in awe to be able to be considered in a group that reflects the best of the best. It's always a huge honor to represent Jack Henry, my team and our community. Thank you all for the opportunity and the investments you continue to make in me. In particular my wife Julie Zelinka, PMP, SP, PSM I who has been along for my journey almost from the very beginning. You had your work cut out with me, to some extent you still do, but I have become the leader I am largely because of you. Sharing these moments with you is very special.

column7: Dear baby me,I am writing this at the beginning of #lesbianvisibilityweek because yes, you will grow up to be a lesbian.I'm not going to lie, it won't always be easy. You will pretend to be something you are not for many years just to fit in, you will be spat at and discriminated against just because of who you love. You will also be in a relationship with someone who will harm you. But don't stop reading, because I promise you it gets better!You will find your tribe, friends who will love you for who you are (for many many years), you will also finally find people to look up to (and not just dead poets or fictional TV characters) And you will meet your she-roes (special mention to Linda Riley Head Lesbian of the World, and creator of #lesbianvisibilityweek and Nancy Kelley trailblazer like none other)This week will be an important week for you - you will celebrate what it means to be a lesbian and it will put the L word front and centre without shame or fear. This year you will even go to New York to host a fireside chat with another she-roe Phyll Opoku-Gyimah. And that's another thing - your identity will help you find a job that you are passionate about. You will use your lived experience to make sure workplaces are as inclusive and safe as possible, for everyone to be free to be themselves. And you will love it!But the best thing is you will love and be loved - you will know great love that will give you wings and fill you with joy. So enjoy it, I promise you, you will not want to change anything.

Today is World #creativity and #innovation day. An ode to the human brain that can spark uncommon connections between neurons, between synapses and between head and heart. A day to remember that the brain is like a muscle and we can strengthen our imagination, deepen appreciation of detail, broaden knowledge base and widen our network to harness the transformative power of our creativity, and drive innovation. #inspirationSo change it up today! If you can:-Switch up a recipe with fusion of ingredients from different cultures or cuisines-Take a walk outside, examine an individual leaf and observe the color, texture, smell, and patterns-Listen to a song from a genre or artist that is new to you-Call a friend you haven't interacted with in a while#StayCurious

column7: The line between work and home life has blurred over the last several years, especially amid the pandemic. Today, many companies have returned to the office or adopted a hybrid schedule, but Microsoft continues to challenge the notion that you have to leave your personal life at the door. Each April, we recognize Families Month, celebrating all our unique family dynamics and supporting employees in whatever role they play.  My family is my biggest blessing”I wouldn't be the person I am today without my wife, children, and grandkids. I'm grateful that I can step away or take time off to be present in their lives, especially as the little ones grow up. My work family of team members, mentors, and peers help make that possible. I'm beyond thankful for their support and the abundant goodness they have poured into my life, inspiring me with graciousness and resilience every day.  #FamiliesMonth #Gratitude #Family #InclusionIsInnovation

column7: Real Progress now in sight at Pelican Harbor Seabird Station After four long years of meetings, inspections, and piles of paperwork, I are thrilled to announce that site work has begun to prepare for the groundbreaking of Pelican Harbor Seabird Station's 7,000-square-foot wildlife hospital and education center. PHSS received its Notice of Commencement on April 4th and has since begun archeological excavation in tandem with soil remediation efforts. Vertical construction is expected to begin in June.  Visit https://lnkd.in/ethzh9Gv to learn more and cement your support of PHSS and its future by donating to the Capital Campaign fund, purchasing a personalized brick, or exploring our various naming opportunities.Chloe Chelz Jeff Corwin Robert Glidewell Jacqueline Contney Adrian Chapman Gwen Myers Hannah McDougall

column7: Biggest mistake I hear ” especially from execs ” is that brand and demand are separate things. They aren't. When done right, brand fuels demand.BUT brand isn't your logo, colors, or style guide.’It's your reputation’It's how you make people FEEL’It's what people say about you when you're not aroundAnd when done right, it drives action. And those actions lead to revenue.Doug Landis dropped this gem on Episode 4 of Reed Between The Lines. He's a triple OG who gets brand and collects tattoos. Might be why we vibed on our first meeting.… You can watch the full episode on YouTube now (click "view my website")Or listen on Apple and Spotify.

We are celebrating Earth Day this year as Solventum for the first time, just weeks after we became an independent healthcare company. Our team members around the world are united in our mission to enable better, smarter, safer healthcare to improve lives. On Earth Day, we recognize how human health, and the health of our planet are deeply interconnected. The healthcare industry has a large environmental footprint, which impacts human health, especially women and children in underserved communities globally. As a mission-driven organization, we believe in our corporate responsibility to reduce our environmental footprint, give back to our communities and those in need globally by addressing social drivers of health and increasing access to care.If you are curious about your impact on the planet, here is a global calculator to learn more and take action https://lnkd.in/gAk-yFTzWe at Solventum look forward to working together to build a healthier and more sustainable future for all.
