column7: Humility is a fundamental aspect of great leadership. According to Unbridling Your Brilliance, humility is rooted in a desire to serve and a dedication to helping others become great. Never confuse humility with weakness; in fact, it takes great strength of will and character to put the needs of others before your own, admit your mistakes, and be vulnerable, transparent, and fallible in front of your team.True humility is rooted in the desire to make a positive impact on the lives of others. It involves viewing ourselves as part of a larger community and recognizing that our actions, no matter how small, can have a significant impact on the world around us. To develop into one of the greats of leadership and to become a better person, it's imperative to practice humility. Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be, by simply clicking the link below.https://geni.us/4JmlQU#leadership #management #leadershipdevelopment #employeeengagement #leaders #people #leadershipfirst #leadershipfirstquotes #executivesandmanagement #inspiration #giffordthomas #entrepeneurship

I was delighted to welcome Vanessa Kerry, MD MSc, the first World Health Organization Special Envoy for Climate Change and Health, to The Minor Consult podcast. We explored how climate change is impacting human health — from the rise of vector-borne diseases to the effects of extreme weather on health care access — and we discussed what individuals and the global community can do to mitigate this crisis. Along the way, Vanessa shared insights from co-founding and leading Seed Global Health, which helps train the health workforce in resource-limited countries. Thank you for joining me, Vanessa!

Listen to our entire discussion here:

https://lnkd.in/gTvxJbTP

column7:
Camilo Serna, a long-time industry professional, joins NERC as senior vice president of Strategy and External Engagement. He will work with the Board of Trustees, our Executive team, our stakeholders, and the Regional Entities to set NERC’s strategic direction and lead stakeholder engagement efforts to support NERC outreach and engagement. Serna comes to NERC with decades of experience in corporate strategy, strategic planning, regulatory affairs, and stakeholder engagement. 

“This position provides NERC with the strategic expertise needed to lead us into the future, and we are fortunate that Camilo is joining our leadership team. His strategic acumen and stakeholder engagement expertise will be instrumental in helping NERC elevate our outreach capabilities while navigating our transforming industry,” said Jim Robb, NERC president and chief executive officer. “Our industry has grown to encompass a wide array of new stakeholders and technologies, which require us to manage new uncertainties and challenges strategically as we learn more about them. Camilo’s experience will elevate our current capabilities to engage our expanding audiences in a meaningful way.”

For more information, please see the full announcement: https://ow.ly/S9So50Rluv5

column7:
Hello all,
 After 28 years working for SAP, it is now my turn to take the exit ramp to early retirement. 
 SAP has been very good to me and one of the best experiences in my life. I’ve met a lot of colleagues, partners and customers that I also call friends and will miss working with all of you.  What I loved the most during my time at SAP was the chance to meet and work with so many great people from around the world. 
 
 I wish you all the best and continued success.  I’m going to enjoy the summer and see where it takes me next.

Regards,
Patti

I’m thrilled to join Navan as CEO of Travel in May. It’s exhilarating to return to Navan and the travel space, which is close to my heart. In a world more global and digitally connected than ever, it's become clear that nothing compares to the richness and depth of in-person connection. We launched revolutionary AI technologies to reshape the future of litigation & investigation, accelerated growth and net retention, and transformed how we work with customers and partners. I’m incredibly proud of what we’ve built and look forward to Everlaw’s continued success in the legal industry.

Today we announced that I will be leaving Haleon at the end of the year and that Dawn Allen has been appointed Haleon’s Chief Financial Officer, joining in October 2024.

I am so incredibly proud of this business and of the role I’ve played in building it, right back from my early days at Novartis through to listing and beyond. With Haleon now set up for long-term success, I concluded that the time was right for me to step down from executive life to find more balance in my own life. I have been very open in today’s communications that as a Type 1 diabetic, I’ve always needed to very carefully manage my health, and having the time to do this properly becomes even more important as you get older. In the next phase of my career, I plan to focus on non-executive and advisory roles - a big and exciting change for me, alongside mentoring and coaching; something which I have always been committed to. 

I will be staying in the business until the end of the year, so for now it’s very much business as usual!

column7:
I have long opposed the use of employment non-compete agreements as they are bad for employees and the economy. 

Yesterday's announcement of the FTC rule against non-competes is a step in the right direction, but it is not the same as a federal law. The FTC rule can be contested in court or changed as the administration changes. We continue to work toward a more durable solution, which would be a federal law banning employment non-compete agreements across the country.

Read more about non-competes in my January 2023 Medium post. bit.ly/3iG7Otn

When you are working on something that you genuinely care about, you will find that you don’t need to be forced or pushed to get things done. Instead, the vision of what you are trying to achieve will pull you towards it, motivating you to keep going and pushing yourself further. This is because when you are passionate about your work, you are more likely to feel a sense of purpose and drive, which helps you to overcome any obstacles that come your way. So, if you aspire to achieve something great, it’s important to find something that you are truly passionate about and let the vision of your goal pull you towards it. 

Check out our new Amazon Best Seller, “Unlock The Hidden Leader, Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be,” by simply clicking the link below.

It's encouraging to see so many women in influential sustainability positions in large global companies across the world.

Anna Robertson, Debra Everitt McCormack, Francesca Mahoney, Leah Borgeson Stigile, Margaret Egan, Gayle Schueller, PhD, Jayme Smoot, Faith Taylor, Kate Williams, Kim Dabbs, Monica Batchelder, Maya Colombani, Virginie Helias, Bea Perez, Nancy Mahon, and so many more!

They care about taking ESG to the next level with collaboration and cooperation on a new scale.

They're embedding ESG within their organizations and across a broader business ecosystem.

They face a myriad of challenges: 
- Consumers are reluctant to change their behaviors and stakeholders at all levels are disengaged
-  Suppliers are siloed and innovations are not being adopted across the value chain
-  Local policies are fragmented, disrupting efforts to improve sustainability at scale
-  Leaders and employees lack the skills to build a more collaborative business ecosystem

But they are leading with pragmatic optimism. They are accustomed to complex challenges and the need to meet people where they are at. They are able to see the forest and the trees to create meaningful long term goals and important daily targets.

Like me, they love hiking with their kids and pets. They love science and well tested theories of change. And together we can accelerate the pace of change and intensify our efforts to maximize their scale and impact long term.

Let's build more capacity to lead change through developing changemaker skills in our employees, customer and communities.

Let's design multi-level ESG solutions that address root causes and are engineered for widespread impact and scale from their inception. 

Let's foster growth and ignite engagement through shared decision making  so that the promise of circular economy can be realized today, not tomorrow.

Let's empower collective collaboration across a broader business ecosystem through mutual respect and reciprocal resources so that innovations and efficiencies can be translated into social and financial value without delay.

I am confident about the future with sustainability progress in these women's hearts and hands.

 #earthday #humanresources, #change, #culture, #leadership #behavioralscience #employeeengagement #organizationaldevelopment #inclusion #future #innovation #management #sustainability #socialimpact

I want to commend the 153 incredible students who participated in the fourth Goldman Sachs Market Madness: #HBCU Possibilities Program. Representing 12 HBCUs, they competed in a case study competition where they had to devise and pitch an innovative solution for Nike. The program is part of our $25 million commitment to HBCUs and provides the next generation of talent with hands-on training in the fundamentals of finance, mentorship, and opportunities to network with the people of Goldman Sachs. 
 
This week, after months of preparation, we held the final competition at our New York headquarters, where schools and students were awarded $5 million in grants and scholarships. Congratulations to Victoria, Makhi, Olivia and Symone from Spelman College for winning first place, and thank you to all of this year's participants – we hope to see many of you back at Goldman Sachs.

I often read posts about how remote working is soulless and unproductive and employees need to return to the office to form more authentic relationships. 

And I understand the sentiment, that Teams/Zoom meetings are not a full substitute for face to face connection. 

But also, I disagree. You CAN build genuine relationships with people you’ve never met in person. 

This is me and my good friend Amy Rummel, MBA. Up until this week we’d only ever met via Teams meetings, hundreds of them over nearly 4 years. All with camera on, making time for small talk and getting to know each other, our interests, our families, our life outside of 3M. 

The distance between our homes (London, Ontario vs Derbyshire, UK) made a face to face coffee kind of challenging. 

But we still built a great working relationship, challenging and coaching each other and creating award winning training programmes together with our global team.

And we also developed a beautiful friendship, which was joyously cemented this week over actual coffee, real life trips to English pubs and a short Derbyshire road trip when Amy came to the UK on business, and made sure she passed by my house. 

When we fully utilise tech platforms like Teams without forgetting the basic principles of human interaction - keep your camera on, your body language positive, show interest in your colleagues as people, not just fellow employees… you can build working relationships but also friendships that transcend geographical boundaries and time zones. 

Cheers, Amy! Was great to finally ‘meet’ you 😃

This is Leah! She organized a group of 103 students and chaperones from her elementary school to pack at FMSC Coon Rapids for her passion project. 🙌 With the help of her teachers, Leah talked to the principle, helped to arrange buses, did a slideshow, rounded up permission slips and counted the people coming to the packing session.

Together this group packed 19,656 meals, enough to feed 54 children a meal every day for an entire year! 🍚 When asked why she chose FMSC, Leah responded, "Because I want to help people."

We are humbled and amazed by young volunteers who are passionate about feeding kids. Amazing work, Leah! You are a world changer. 🩵

#feedingkids

column7:
The line between work and home life has blurred over the last several years, especially amid the pandemic. Today, many companies have returned to the office or adopted a hybrid schedule, but Microsoft continues to challenge the notion that you have to leave your personal life at the door. Each April, we recognize Families Month, celebrating all our unique family dynamics and supporting employees in whatever role they play. 
 
My family is my biggest blessing—I wouldn't be the person I am today without my wife, children, and grandkids. I'm grateful that I can step away or take time off to be present in their lives, especially as the little ones grow up. My work family of team members, mentors, and peers help make that possible. I'm beyond thankful for their support and the abundant goodness they have poured into my life, inspiring me with graciousness and resilience every day. 
 
#FamiliesMonth #Gratitude #Family #InclusionIsInnovation

As a longtime Austin resident and community advocate, Jacqueline spearheaded relief efforts in the aftermath of record-breaking floods that devastated the neighborhood in July 2023. Thank you phyl terry for your inspiring messages on "Never Search Alone"! Your insights shed light on the fact that job search can bring anxiety no matter how credentialed you are. Your experience and skills are the product, so it's important to do a product/market fit. You emphasized the importance of knowing what you want and don't want in the next position and how joining a Job Search Council at https://www.phyl.org/ can help you achieve your goals. 

Before going to the interview, it's wise to write your own version of the job description with OKRs, maybe even share it with the hiring manager. Negotiating on salary/comp, budget, resources, and support are the four pillars of negotiation, which you highlighted.

I would like to extend my gratitude to Natasha Irani and Lakshmi Pappu for coordinating this session with Phyl, Darlene Taylor for beautifully talking about the purpose of T200, and Sunitha Vinnakota for facilitating the Q&A. 

Stay tuned for next month's session on "How to build your personal brand" 

Suja Chandrasekaran, Angela Yochem, Wafaa Mamilli, Diana McKenzie, Diane Schwarz, and Marina F Bellini.

column7:
This week, we had the honor of hosting a visit from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) delegation, led by Najat Mokhtar, IAEA deputy director general and head of the Department of Nuclear Sciences and Applications; and Laura Holgate, U.S. Ambassador to the Vienna Office of the United Nations and to the IAEA. The delegation met with our MD Anderson leaders and visited our Proton Therapy Center and our Interventional Radiology facilities. As the most comprehensive radiation oncology facility in the world, MD Anderson is the first IAEA Collaborating Centre in the United States focused on health care. Working together, MD Anderson and the IAEA aim to enhance radiation oncology, radiation physics, radiology, nuclear medicine and nutrition globally. 

Thank you to May Abdel-Wahab, director of the IAEA’s Division of Human Health, Department of Nuclear Sciences and Applications; Welela Tereffe, M.D.; Albert Koong, M.D., Ph.D.; Marshall Hicks, M.D.; Sarah Berger; Kathleen Schmeler, M.D.; Christine Martin, foreign affairs officer, U.S. Department of State; Lisa Wilkinson, political officer, U.S. Mission to IAEA; Edward Miller; Noura El-Haj, IAEA; A; Stephen Kry, Ph.D.; Anuja Jhingran, M.D.; Karen Basen-Engquist, Ph.D.; Celina Horak, IAEA; Alda Tam, M.D.; Toma Omofoye, M.D.; TJ Whitaker, PhD.; Laurence Court, PhD.; Kamaria Lee, M.D.; Michael Overman, M.D.; Reina Guerrero; Lydia Davis; and Shubhra Ghosh, M.D., for their contributions in making this visit a success.

This week, we welcomed Bonnie St. John to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital to share her inspiring story and her wisdom on the power of resilience — a quality our St. Jude patients, families and staff must often use in their everyday lives. 

If you don’t know Bonnie, hers is a story of courage, commitment and discipline. After having her leg amputated at 5 years old, she fell in love with skiing and went on to become the first Black medalist in the Winter Paralympics.

Thank you, Bonnie, for inspiring our team to continue working to make the impossible possible — to cure the incurable, treat the untreatable, and reduce treatment toxicity.

Amid evolving circumstances, Richard Webby, PhD, a St. Jude virologist and influenza expert, believes it is still possible to eradicate the bird flu (H5N1) virus from dairy farms, but effective control measures are dependent on the scope of the outbreak. 
 
“You’d want to go not just to the places you knew there was activity and cows — you want to go to places where at least there’s no reported bird flu”, Webby said in The New York Times. 
 
The FDA continues to monitor the spread of bird flu in cattle, with the latest turn in the story showing fragments of H5N1 in roughly 20 percent of retail milk samples in a national study. However, live virus has not been found in any samples and regulators have found no evidence that milk poses a danger to consumers because the pasteurization process inactivates the virus. 
 
Although there is no cause for immediate concern, eradication is important because sustained spread among cows would give the virus time to acquire mutations that could make it transmissible among humans. The outbreak among cows remains a low threat, as cows are not exhibiting symptoms of H5N1 and are recovering. https://bit.ly/4bfpD8e
 
#H5N1 #Virology #BirdFlu

Help at Home’s “Category of One” meeting kicked off this week in its hometown of Chicago! As a company with remote workers across the country, we have the rare opportunity to come together as a team every so often. This year the theme of the event is “Unlocking the Power of Community”. Our teams have the opportunity to spend valuable in-person moments connecting and ideating on ways to “do more for more” in the communities we serve.
 
“During our time together, we’re focused on the ‘ripples’ that this company started 50 years ago in one zip code in 1975. Those ripples led to hundreds more zip codes in hundreds of communities across the country,” said Help at Home’s CEO Chris Hocevar. “Our journey is just getting started. Thanks to all those who have paved the way to today to spending thousands of hours daily caring for the most vulnerable populations. And, thanks to all of our employees in this room, our admin staff and our 50K+ caregivers, clinical teams and Community Health Workers across the country in advance for all of the ripples we’ll create together in the future.”
 
“Personally, I’m amazed by the passion and energy our caregivers and staff bring to their jobs every day. It’s that part of our culture “to do more” that’s just so impactful to our clients and to the communities we serve,” said Help at Home’s President Tim O'Rourke.

column7:
How can you get better? Take note, this is important. 📝 

The other day we hosted a dinner with 100+ of Smartly clients. 
Laura Desmond, our CEO, went to each and every one of them, one by one, and asked a simple question: "How can we improve?" 

Instead of gloating after an incredible 2-day summit and ask "What did you like?" and receiving praises and compliments, she went the opposite way: "How can we improve?"

It took over two hours but we got really incredible, candid, sometimes brutal, but always honest opinions from 100+ of our clients.

Thank you, we heard you. 
Now it's our job to take that feedback and get even better. 🚀

I applaud the Federal Trade Commission for adopting a comprehensive ban on new non-competes. While the U.S. Chamber of Commerce challenged the regulation, Pure Storage offers a different perspective. 

Since 1941, California has made non-competes unenforceable, except in certain situations such as key executives in the sale of their company. A highly competitive labor environment is one important reason why this State remains the world's fifth-largest economy, which is significantly enabled by the absence of non-compete agreements. 

In our early days, Pure Storage faced a barrage of non-compete lawsuits from a large entrenched vendor, which did not want its people leaving for a competitor. Certainly, seeing trained personnel go to a competitor is uncomfortable, and employees certainly need to protect confidential information. But, competitive hiring works both ways and companies need to create attractive and competitive workplaces to retain their top talent. 

To create a competitive economy and world beating companies, our country needs to enable a mobile, competitive workforce. Eliminating non-compete agreements will enhance our country’s competitiveness, and encourage companies to focus on their work environments rather than their legal contracts. 

How do you feel about non-compete agreements?

Congratulations to Ryan Harrison, Tripp McGarrie and Luke McGrath on successfully passing the Certified Financial Planning (CFP) exam.  For 50 years, the CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER™ certification has been the standard of excellence for financial planners.  The path to CFP certification requires completion of the education requirement (up to 18 months), passing the CFP exam, fulfilling the experience requirement (6,000 hours) and a commitment to adhere to the high ethical and professional standards for the practice of financial planning.  According to the CFP Board, just 68%* of candidates passed the CFP exam during the most recent testing period, March 2024. 

The discipline and commitment required to obtain this designation is representative of Ryan, Tripp and Luke's commitment to professional development and a valuable investment in their future.  Please help me congratulate each of them on this outstanding accomplishment!

In Prompt Engineering for Vision Models, taught by Abby Morgan, Jacques Verré and Caleb Kaiser of Comet, you’ll learn how to prompt and fine-tune vision models for personalized image generation, image editing, object detection and segmentation. The prompts you'll use for vision models could be text, point coordinates, or bounding boxes, depending on the model. You'll also learn to tune hyperparameters to shape the output. 

Models you'll use include Segment-Anything Model (SAM), OWL-ViT, and Stable Diffusion. You'll also learn to fine-tune Stable Diffusion to generate personalized images (say, an image of a specific person), using a handful of images for training. As an example of a multi-step workflow, you'll use OWL-ViT to detect an object based on a text prompt, then pass the bounding box to SAM to create a segmentation mask, and input that mask into Stable Diffusion to replace the original object with a new one based on a text prompt. 

Controlling vision models can be tricky; this course teaches prompting and fine-tuning techniques to get precise control over their output. Get started here: https://lnkd.in/d2bNwRuC

This news is overdue, but I’m thrilled to share that several months ago I joined NIKE, Inc., as EVP and Chief Technology Officer. Those who know me, know how big a role sport plays in my life – whether it’s long-distance running or recovery or growing in my yoga practice. This passion for sport is one of the things that led me to Nike and it’s been energizing to see a similar passion fueling so many who are part of this brand. The athlete is always at the center of all we do, and I’m thrilled to work with the strong, talented team here to leverage technology to innovate for our athletes and fuel Nike’s growth.
 
I feel incredibly lucky to have spent the last 16 years at Amazon, where I had the privilege of working on some of the most fascinating problems and be able to contribute to the foundation of so many successful businesses from same day, sub same day and ultra-fast delivery program; to building our covid employee testing, to transforming online shopping for our customers for fashion and fitness. I learned so much from everyone and I am proud of what we accomplished together and will treasure the experiences, lessons learned and friendships I gained. I will always be rooting you on!

column7: Vogtle-4 enters commercial operation — Read more at #Nuclear News: https://lnkd.in/eAVaCKtm

🎉 Exciting News from Plant Vogtle! 🎉 

Now that Georgia Power's Plant Vogtle Unit 4 is online, the site is the largest generator of clean energy in the United States and is powering 1 million homes and businesses for generations to come.

IN SERVICE: Georgia Power Company announces Unit 4 at Plant Vogtle is now in commercial service. 

Unit 4 becomes the 94th commercial reactor in operation in the U.S. and makes Plant Vogtle the largest clean power generator in the nation. 

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/eS2Y8WAX

Today marks a monumental achievement as we celebrate the safe and successful commercial operation of Plant Vogtle Unit 4, marking the completion of the Vogtle expansion project near Waynesboro, Georgia.

Oglethorpe Power is proud to be a 30% co-owner of this important emission-free resource on behalf of the Georgia electric cooperatives we serve.

“The completion of the Vogtle expansion project signifies the culmination of a remarkable journey filled with dedication, perseverance and a commitment to a cleaner energy future for Georgians. We celebrate not only the completion of this reliable emission-free resource but also the historic achievement it represents as the first advanced commercial nuclear project in the United States in more than three decades.”

- Mike Smith, Oglethorpe Power President & CEO

We are thrilled to announce Dr. Tyra Hall-Pogar as the new Department Chair for the Professional Studies Department at the School of Multidisciplinary and Professional Studies. Tyra officially began her new role today, April 29th. Join us in welcoming her to this exciting new chapter!

With nearly 15 years of dedication to our university, starting in 2009 as an adjunct faculty member in the Science Department, Tyra has made significant contributions across various capacities. She has enriched our academic community as a full-time faculty member, contributed to curriculum revisions, mentored fellow faculty, and led numerous courses with distinction.

Beyond her teaching, Dr. Hall-Pogar has played a pivotal role on several committees, including the Institutional Review Board and the General Education Science Literacy Committee, showcasing her commitment to enhancing educational standards and student experiences at Purdue Global.

Previously, as the Assistant Department Chair in the Humanities and Social Sciences Department, Tyra managed the Individual Learning Plan (ILP) and scheduling procedures, advocating strongly for our programs and leading several graduate MPS courses as an SME/course leader.

Before her tenure in academia, Tyra was a medical writer focusing on critical issues like antibiotic resistance and Alzheimer's disease. Her academic journey began at Neumann University, where she was an MCAT review editor in biochemistry. Dr. Hall-Pogar holds a PhD in biochemistry and molecular biology from Rutgers Graduate School of Biomedical Science, with research focused on RNA molecules.

Residing in Houston, TX, with her family, Tyra Hall-Pogar enjoys the outdoors, walking her dogs, and gardening.

We look forward to the innovation and leadership Dr. Hall-Pogar will bring to her new role. Here's to continued success!

Congratulations to Southern Nuclear, Georgia Power Company and all our project partners as the second U.S.-based Westinghouse AP1000® reactor today entered commercial operation at Plant Vogtle in the state of Georgia!
 
Plant Vogtle Units 3 and 4, both AP1000 reactors, can each generate enough #CarbonFree electricity to power approximately 500,000 households and businesses. Combined with Vogtle's other two pressurized water reactors, the #NuclearEnergy power plant is now the largest generator of clean energy in the United States.
 
“As Unit 4 joins our global fleet of proven, state-of-the-art AP1000 reactors, I applaud the dedicated Vogtle team whose relentless work and continuous effort made this project a success," Westinghouse CEO Patrick Fragman said.

(Photos courtesy of Georgia Power)

After nearly 40 years in the IT industry, the last 18 of which have been at Korn Ferry leading the CIO/CTO Executive Search Practice in EMEA, I have taken the plunge and have retired.  So far so good - in fact (as someone observed to me) I've found plenty to do and it's a wonder I found any time to work!  For now, it is great not having to worry about deadlines and Teams calls, but I daresay I may be tempted to do some freelance part-time advisory, coaching or NED work at some point. So please do keep me in mind if you think I can be of help.

I have been privileged to have worked with many talented people over my time as a practitioner, a consultant and most recently in executive search.  The last 18 years has been a sheer joy, working with so many talented CIOs across multiple industries and geographies.  We have a rich seam of talent in our industry and the opportunity to work with incredibly able and dedicated IT professionals and to be a small part of helping companies put technology at the heart of their operations has been a real career highlight.  Little did I know 46 years ago, when I first programmed a DEC PDP 11/34 at school, that it was the start of my career in IT - it has been a fun ride!

Finally a huge thank you to the colleagues, teams and mentors with whom I have had the privilege to work - you know who you are and I thank you for all your support, help and friendship.  Here's wishing everyone a happy and successful future.

Hello friends, colleagues and clients. I want to share some news. After five  years with NTT Data, I left the organization earlier this month. 

I joined NTT Data in 2019 as part of a multi-year growth and transformation agenda in North America. Throughout this time I thoroughly enjoyed working for one of the world’s leading Technology Services organizations, initially focused on Financial Services & Insurance clients and then over the last three years in Consulting & Digital Transformation across all industries in North America.

Every day, I sought to take the world class ingredients available there to 1) elevate the impact our work and our brand had on clients; 2) improve the value proposition for our employees and 3) drive business performance. My favorite work was bringing all of these together when we were all collaborating on what a previous CEO of mine referred to as “our best day.” 

I don’t have immediate plans. In the near term, I’ll be enjoying Spring & Summer in Chicago, traveling, playing LOTS of golf and eventually figuring out my next career step.

Arigatou gozaimasu to all my global NTT Data colleagues. I’ve enjoyed our journey immensely. I wish you all Godspeed. To all the clients that I’ve served, much continued success and I look forward to our paths crossing again at some point in the future.

Wayne

In the first quarter, we delivered strong results that were better than our expectations as we returned to adjusted organic growth and achieved double digit adjusted earnings growth. We improved performance across our businesses and our operational execution. We also completed the spin-off of Solventum and finalized two major legal settlements.
 
Our results demonstrate the positive impact of the changes we have made over the last several years. C++ Core Guidelines with Clang-Tidy


Last Friday, we conducted a survey, and the winner was "Clang-Tidy cppcoreguidelines." I confess this is one of my favorite resources, and I use it in all my projects. But before we delve into the subject, let's first understand what the "C++ Core Guidelines" are.

The C++ Core Guidelines are led by Bjarne Stroustrup, the original creator of the C++ language, and include other prominent figures such as Herb Sutter, chair of the ISO C++ committee. They provide a set of guidelines and recommendations for the effective and safe use of the C++ programming language, aiming to promote best programming practices, especially concerning interfaces, resource management, memory management, and concurrency. Such rules affect application architecture and library design. The goal is to help developers write modern and robust C++ code (specifically from C++11 onwards) that is safe, efficient, and easy to maintain.

I strongly recommend that you also use them; after all, who knows C++ better than its own creator?

Now that we understand what they are, let's examine some types of checks that Clang-Tidy provides us, based on the C++ Core Guidelines:

- cppcoreguidelines-avoid-non-const-global-variables
- cppcoreguidelines-avoid-magic-numbers
- cppcoreguidelines-virtual-class-destructor
- cppcoreguidelines-explicit-virtual-functions

Below, see how the code looks before and after integrating Clang-Tidy directly into Qt Creator:



#ClangTidy #CppCoreGuidelines #Cplusplus #BjarneStroustrup #HerbSutter #ISOcpp #ProgrammingGuidelines #CodeSafety #MemoryManagement #Concurrency #SoftwareArchitecture #ModernCplusplus #Cplusplus11 #BestPractices #SoftwareDevelopment #SoftwareEngineering #CodeRobustness #CodingStandards #QtCreator #StaticAnalysis #CodeQuality #SoftwareDevelopmentTools #DevelopmentWorkflow #ProgrammingTips #CppCommunity #VirtualFunctions #GlobalVariables #EfficientCode #SafeCode

We partner with Route 1 MN, a resource hub for emerging BIPOC farmers based out of Hamel. It’s an impactful, symbiotic relationship that gives local farmers the opportunity to offer their produce through our online market for community food shelf partners. 

In their first year of operation alone, Route 1 supported 31 area farm families, 70 percent of whom are immigrants from Western Africa. These farmers grew approximately 50,000 pounds of fresh food, 90 percent of which was bought by The Food Group to help support our programs.

Georgia Power ogłosiła wczoraj, że 4. blok Elektrowni Jądrowej Vogtle rozpoczął działalność komercyjną i przez co najmniej 60-80 lat będzie produkować energię elektryczną wystarczającą do zasilenia około 500 000 domów i firm.

Budowany jednocześnie blok Vogtle 3 rozpoczęł działalność komercyjną 31 lipca 2023 roku. Obecnie w Elektrowni Jądrowej Vogtle pracują 4 bloki jądrowe, co czyni ją największym źródłem czystej energii, zdolnym do wytwarzania ponad 30 milionów megawatogodzin energii elektrycznej rocznie.

Elektrownia jest obsługiwana przez Southern Nuclear w imieniu jej współwłaścicieli, w tym Georgia Power, Oglethorpe Power, MEAG Power i Dalton Utilities.

- Zakończenie rozbudowy elektrowni jądrowej Vogtle o blok 3, a obecnie blok 4, to wyjątkowe osiągnięcie dla Southern Company, stanu Georgia i całych Stanów Zjednoczonych - powiedział Chris Womack, prezes i dyrektor generalny Southern Firma.

Oprócz 800 stałych stanowisk pracy utworzonych w nowych blokach, w szczytowym okresie budowy na miejscu zatrudnionych było ponad 9 000 pracowników, w tym inżynierów, spawaczy, elektryków, monterów rur, hydraulików i wielu innych.

Blok 4. Elektrowni Jądrowej Vogtle jest jednostką referencyjną dla bloków do budowy w lokalizacji Lubiatowo-Kopalino w Polsce.

column7:
Today’s announcement is disappointing for those of us who understand the need to transform healthcare and fought hard to do our part. My immediate thoughts are with our impacted associates. To a person, these amazing talents were drawn to Walmart Health's mission to solve access, convenience, and affordability challenges for the communities we have been honored to serve. I could not be prouder of them and the care they have consistently provided since our opening. I think about the hundreds of thousands of patients we served and who have come to rely on Walmart as a partner in health and wellbeing. We will continue to support you and care for you as your care is transitioned to new providers. And finally, to my leadership team and the many professionals that supported us, there are not enough words nor the right ones to express my deepest gratitude for your consistent excellence and drive. We have been on quite a journey, and though it didn’t end where I had hoped it would, there is much to celebrate in the accomplishments achieved and the friendships that have been forged. There will be a time in the future to think about and discuss the challenges specific to retail healthcare. Suffice to say, it is a sad day, but I will not allow it to diminish my determination or reduce my optimism in the good that retailers like Walmart can accomplish with its scale and resources.
#walmarthealth #retailhealthcare #healthcare #primarycare #dentalcare #behavioralhealth #healthequity #communitycare

I’ve joined the Logi team!

One week in and I’m already loving the vibe with the team. I’m also loving my new WFH setup with the Casa Pop-Up Desk. It turns my favorite spot in the house into my office so I can stay productive while satisfying my foodie cravings 😋. It neatly stores everything away into a compact case, disguised as a cookbook. No mess in the kitchen!🧑🏻‍🍳

Logitech has been an integral part of my computing experiences from my first desk setup back in the day to my mobile setup today. I’m pumped to lead product and innovation for mobile solutions and partnerships that will shape computing experiences of tomorrow!

#LogiLife

Well, after 26 years, today, I took early retirement from SAP.  I took a picture of my badge from about 21 years ago, the original badge did not have a picture.  What a terrific career, great company and great friends.  When, I first started, I thought I would be there for no more than three years, well I was wrong.  Time to relax, enjoy the summer, then in September go back to it, albeit part-time (that’s the plan anyway.)

I can never fully explain why God’s favor rests on me this way. I want to thank you as I do everyday for blessing me with the opportunities, perseverance, and resilience to achieve my life-long goals. Thank you for guiding me in letting my dreams be bigger than my fears. Thank you for sending such a beautiful village to get me through. Thank you for being my guiding light, and I pray for your continued guidance as I step into the future with confidence and gratitude. May 4th be with us..from Little Rock, Arkansas to Chicago, Illinois ya girl will be graduating from the College of Engineering with a B.S. in Electrical Engineering w/ a minor in Urban Studies in 4 days..let the count down begin. 

#graduation #engineering #electricalengineering #womeninstem #uic #blackwomeninstem

Logitech has been an integral part of my computing experiences from my first desk setup back in the day to my mobile setup today. I’m pumped to lead product and innovation for mobile solutions and partnerships that will shape computing experiences of tomorrow!

#LogiLife

“If anyone saves a life, it shall be as though he had saved the lives of all mankind.” [Quran 5:32]

There won't be awards, no accolades, no money in this... no one may know the work you did. But knowing you have done your best for your patients gives you an inner satisfaction and reward greater than any on earth. 
My husband Dr. Muhammad Ahsan Iqbal, one of the finest primary care #physicians I know, always tells me this. Especially on days when I come home 1.5-2 hours later than my #workschedule, when I'm exhausted from all the patient tasks, Saturday shifts, or when I'm upset with #insurancecompanies #advocating for my patients for their #healthcare rights. We had the absolute best teachers in our residency program The Institute for Family Health one whom we speak about all the time Mark Josefski. His patient care was so outstanding rarely did his patients get admitted to the hospital. Thankfully his critical but #compassionate #precepting pruned our #medicalcare.
I often have some motivational theme song playing in my head after work. Coming home to my small children, one now 7 months old, I acknowledge that my heartstrings are pulled being away from them. On my ride home I think about one or two people I saw in the day whose lives were #transformed by meeting me. I #thankGod for the part I played.
Last week I saw a patient that astounded me. She had initially seen me asking for permanent disability/Govt financial assistance due to mismanagement of all her medical conditions by past provider systems and #hospitalsystems here. I told her I can help her with her medical problems in the meantime. I thought I was in the wrong room when I walked in seeing her wearing a suit, her hair/makeup done well, a business bag. She's working for an investment company now, and just needs more support to help her medically as she's thriving. No more thoughts of #disability. Nothing short of a miracle. She really rose up in just 5 months with her incredible #selfdetermination. She gave me a long hug to thank me for my help. I hear these stories weekly if not daily. Most patients that have never seen a #primarycare doctor in 10, 20, 30 years. All #selfpay #noinsurance .
I'm heartbroken to be separated from the #patients I love genuinely now that #WalmartHealth is closing. David Carmouche, MD I have always been that physician l that went above and beyond for my patients. Being #human, knowing them wholly with the small details of their life, caring for them as close family, and with #sincerity has always been the key. I thank my husband for being my #partner. He has more life changing #patientstories than I do. I will miss the exceptionally caring, highly trained staff I call my work family.
 Photo credits Judy O'Hara Onwards to our the next journey...The #future is open.

column7:
When you join a company and the product backlog was created without a strategy...

(True story)
I've seen some crazy backlogs.
I've seen backlogs 100s even over 1,000 items long! 😱

Here are 3 strategies to help keep your backlog short:

1️⃣ Automatically archiving old backlog items

Let's be real. 
If something has sat in your backlog for 2 years or more now, you're never going to do it! 

Set an expiry date on your backlog items. For example is something has been in your backlog for longer than 18 months it automatically gets archived.

Trust me, if it's important, it'll come back!

2️⃣ Leverage your Product Roadmap

If an item is on your roadmap and it's long into the future,
does it need to be on your backlog? 

Allow items to graduate from your Product Roadmap onto your backlog.

Keep your backlog focused largely on the near term, on the work that you've already done discovery on and have decided to build.

(More on building effective Product Roadmaps: https://lnkd.in/grfcg_33)

3️⃣ Breaking down Outcomes first

Many teams have long backlogs because they're they're still working too big. 
They break a very large initiative down into lots of backlog items.

Instead they should be trying to break down their outcome first to work small.

e.g. rather than trying to come up with every improvement idea for your product, focus on an outcome. Say improving acquisition. 

You can then break that down even smaller. 

Rather than looking at the whole conversion funnel, hone in on the worse spot (Improve experience/click-through-rate of page X)

More on this approach: https://lnkd.in/gP_HrrQ5

====

Want more backlog techniques? 
Watch '8 Different Ways to Organize your Product Backlog': https://lnkd.in/grZ3xQmH

Lakuna Consulting announced today that Gabrielle Mangum joined the Company as Director, Consulting Services with a focus in finance and risk management, effective April 29, 2024. 

Gabrielle has extensive experience in complex financial analysis in a regulated utility environment. Most recently Ms. Mangum was Sr. Manager and Finance Business Partner for Power Delivery & Utility Support at Entergy Corporation.  In this role, she oversaw the development of the five-year transmission and distribution plan to ensure alignment with the enterprise strategy, including the achievement of continuous improvement efficiency goals. She led the design of an enterprise-wide capital prioritization process and implemented this process across the organizational functions and business units in the holding company structure. Gabrielle’s financial acumen within utility operations combined with experience in managing budgets in operations position her to advise companies on strategies for successful value realization from projects. 

“Gabrielle’s knowledge of the intricacies of financial planning in a multi-operating company environment combined with the nuances of utility regulation brings tremendous knowledge to our clients seeking to identify value opportunities from technology and process improvements,” explained Lakuna CEO Lauren Kenney. “Not only does Gabrielle have extensive knowledge in financial planning and strategy, she has also worked in operations to support the change management and process improvement needed to achieve value realization from technology implementations.”

As we wrap up #NationalVolunteersMonth, I’d like to share two photos. The first is of some of our Cisco CX Americas GES Premier team earlier this year at the State Fairgrounds in RTP. Together with nearly 1,000 volunteers from 13 other companies, they made it possible to provide more than 220,000 meals for those facing hunger.
 
Volunteers sorted and prepared culturally versatile foods such as rice, lentils, and pasta, that are being distributed through the 34-county food bank network as a part of a “Sort-A-Rama” event led and organized by the Food Bank of Central and Eastern North Carolina and made possible by presenting sponsors including Cisco and Food Lion. Since 2011, Sort-A-Rama volunteers have packed and prepared 1.5 million meals for distribution to families throughout Central and Eastern North Carolina.
 
High Touch Operations Manager – Team Lead, Caroline Davis shared that, “I do this because it hurts to know that someone can’t eat.”
 
Together with Paul Bard, she has been leading and coordinating volunteer activities for CX Americas GES Premier. CX Americas GES Premier Team Leads pictured among the more than three dozen volunteers include Caroline Davis, Daphne Britt, and Mike Walsh.
 
The second photo is from an on-site volunteer day with Note in the Pocket, an organization that tackles clothing insecurity by providing quality clothing to children and families in need, improving their comfort and confidence.
 
One of my favorite things about working at Cisco is the people, and these are just a few examples of why.
 
Thank you Cisco volunteers for all that you do.

column7:
More unsolicited fundraising advice... Please, I am begging you, think before you send that email. Does it have a subject line that would make you click open? Even better, would your distant cousin who knows nothing about your organization want to open it?

Think about the previews that drive you to check out a new movie on Netflix. Think about what makes you curious and in need of more information. Your writing should read like a human wrote it for a friend. Not like corporate robots aligned it with brand standards and whitewashed it in flavorless cream.

Not great (generic, who cares...):
- Spring Campaign (just got this one from a place I love 😫)
- ABC Giving Day is Here!

Better (only opening if you're my top 5 favorites or if I'm hate reading):
- You can change the world!
- $10 will help 10 pets

Best (Got me curious and nosey, specific call to action):
- Great news inside! Bingo's life changed when he was rescued. See the before and after you made possible.
- This is our chance to make sure grandparents like yours experience a warm smile and a hot meal every day. See how you can make a difference.

Keep an eye on your open rates and what is working. Don't be afraid to try something new! You've got this!

#NonprofitFundraising #NonprofitDevelopment #NonprofitLeadership #NonprofitManagement #Nonprofit

Annie Duke is a decision-making expert, former professional poker player, special partner at First Round Capital, and the author of Thinking in Bets (a national bestseller) and Quit: The Power of Knowing When to Walk Away. She also co-founded Alliance for Decision Education, a nonprofit whose mission is to improve lives by empowering students through decision skills education. 

In our conversation, Annie shares:
🔸 Her biggest lessons from the late Daniel Kahneman
🔸 How to use pre-mortems and “kill criteria”
🔸 The power of “mental time travel”
🔸 The relationship between money and happiness
🔸 The nominal group technique for better decisions
🔸 How First Round improved their decision-making process using her techniques
🔸 A ton of tactical decision-making frameworks
🔸 Much more

Listen now 👇
- YouTube: https://lnkd.in/g3anuten
- Spotify: https://lnkd.in/g4u3X2FU
- Apple: https://lnkd.in/gNDkaj8f

Some key takeaways:
1. Use the “3Ds” framework to make better decisions for your org:
a. Discover: Collect individual opinions independently before group discussion and then share these with everybody prior to the meeting.
b. Discuss: Compare perspectives within the group, focusing on understanding points of disagreement rather than building consensus.
c. Decide: Make decisions independently post-discussion to minimize group influence.

2. Incorporate the word “nevertheless” into discussions, especially when making decisions or addressing disagreements. It acknowledges the other person’s perspective while affirming your decision or stance.

3. Replace confrontational language like “I disagree” or “you’re wrong” with phrases like “I don’t understand” so everyone feels heard and valued. If people feel heard, they are more likely to feel like they contributed to the decision, even when they disagree.

4. Use pre-mortems to set kill criteria. Before starting a project, imagine failure and what early warning signs might have predicted it. Commit in advance to reassess or pivot if you notice those red flags later on. This makes it easier to walk away when sunk costs and overconfidence bias loom large.

5. Know that if you’re considering quitting, it’s likely overdue. Uncertainty, sunk costs, identity, and ownership effects conspire to make us persist with failing efforts longer than we should. We wait for incontrovertible proof to quit. If quitting crosses your mind, examine if you’d start the project today given what you now know.

The naturally aspirated engine of the #Porsche 911 has come a long way over the past 60 years, now with four times the power from twice the displacement. Culminating in the anniversary model, the 911 S/T. It still has six cylinders (911 S/T (WLTP): Fuel consumption combined: 13.8 l/100 km; CO₂ emissions combined: 313 g/km; CO₂ class: G; Status 04/2024) and its boxer design and is still free-breathing. 

It epitomizes the 911 principle, the uniquesness of the 911, reinventing itself time and time again, and yet always remaining true to itself. Its drive technology has continued to develop, but the fundamental concept has remained unchanged.

Read the full story: https://lnkd.in/dSPFpn2x

When I joined Walmart's Health & Wellness team nearly 5 years ago, part of my responsibilities included leading the staffing for our new Walmart Health clinics. I felt fortunate and blessed to play a role in bringing these clinics to life. I knew what we were trying to accomplish was difficult, but I was so hopeful we could disrupt our nation's problematic healthcare system. Sadly, this week we learned that goal will not become a reality but over these past 5 years, we were able to help so many patients and touch so many lives. I will always be proud of what we achieved!

I am also especially proud of my incredible talent acquisition team led by Analissa Sanchez. You all brought in top-notch talent that made our patients feel cared for. This is no easy task given the demand for this talent and the limited supply but you persevered and never took short cuts. You all put your heart and souls into this work and what you achieved was pure magic! Thank you for your hard work. Thank you for your relentless persistence. And thank you for the many laughs and fun we had along the way! May the road ahead bring you continued success and happiness always!

#dreamteam #walmarthealth #walmarthealthvirtualcare #talentacquisition

As promised in my previous post, I want to highlight some of my Walmart Health team members.

In this post, I'll highlight Eleta Hillyer.

Eleta is my only "official" direct report.  Eleta started her career at Walmart Health and the Center Administrator in our Walmart Health in our Springdale, AR center.  Let me tell you, being a CA in NW Arkansas, 10 miles from the Home Office, is no picnic.  Eleta and her team was the first recipient of every new big idea we had.  Some were great...others not so much.  Eleta led her team through all of these tests with a positive attitude and a smile (most of the time) on her face. 

In 2022 I had the privilege to bring her to my new site opening team.  She adapted so quickly to the task at hand it was amazing.  In this past year, she, with support from Alicia Johnson, BSHA created our first ever comprehensive Center Administrator onboarding program.  She worked closely with our Annie Hughes Patterson, Erin Edminister Hollingshead, Melissa Walsh, MBA and our associate communications team to develop a comprehensive new center marketing approach to reach both internal and external audiences.

In August of last year, as I assumed a leadership position within the central operations team, Eleta readily took on the vast majority of the new site opening program.  Together, with our support team from Sevan Multi-Site Solutions, she drove the program to open the sites we had the privilege of opening this year. 

Eleta is highly adaptable, smart, passionate, and meets my number one criteria...she is a good human.

Whatever comes next for me, if I have an opportunity to bring Eleta along, I absolutely will.....so you better make your best offer before I have the chance.

With the news of Walmart Health closing earlier this week, I have been reflecting on my journey through healthcare as a whole, as well as my time with the organization. 
I am extremely proud to say we worked tirelessly to bring affordable, high quality medical, dental, and behavioral health services to those who needed it most. 
We paved the way for others to look at healthcare differently, and I strongly believe there will eventually be a path to deliver consistent, accessible, quality healthcare to all.
We forged incredible relationships with our many teams that became not only friends, but truly like family.
While I am now #opentowork I will forever be #grateful to Walmart for this opportunity and all it has given me. 
#openforwork

“Last time co2 concentration was this high on this planet was 3 million years ago. Shame on us if we blow it - this is our last chance.” – stated Peter Sena, President of Southern Nuclear yesterday at #SMR2024.

The panel session focusing on navigating innovation: streamlining regulatory paths for advanced reactor licenses highlighted the importance of avoiding delays and staying ahead of the curve when it comes to regulation and licensing methods. 

Here’s what are experts had to say:

🎤Michelle Catts, MBA, SVP Nuclear Oversight, GE Hitachi Nuclear Energy, “We need over 3,000 reactors, and if we started deploying those operationally by 2030, this means 167 reactors per year coming into operation. So how do we actually get there? We’re not going to get to 2050 without some real streamlining of licencing guidelines. A lot can be done on the industry side and the government side. So there’s the “why”. 

🎤Doug True, Chief Nuclear Officer and Senior Vice President of Technical and Regulatory Services, Nuclear Energy Institute “If you look back at the history of what has delayed nuclear power in the past, it’s not nuclear safety but environmental reasons - we have to keep the door open for public to engage and have lots of opportunities to do that.” 

🎤@Scott Morris, Deputy Director for Operations, U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission, “Absolute focus on safety and security is imperative, but we are now in the position to use data and AI, and other methods to innovate.”

🎤Corey Hinderstein, Deputy Administrator for Defense Nuclear Non-proliferation, National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) “The more we can work on collaborative approaches for export, the more we can help level the playing field”.

🎤Pete Sena – “Just because we have done it year over year in the past doesn’t mean we have to do it like that in the future, now it is about how do we make it happen, together”.

Thank you to our speakers for sharing their insights! 

#nuclearregulation #reactorlicensing #newnuclear #smallmodularreactor #advancedreactor

𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐞 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐜𝐤𝐥𝐲 𝐢𝐧𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐨𝐟 𝐬𝐥𝐨𝐰𝐥𝐲.

I'm sharing some CEO experiences in a few short stories, hoping you'll find a worthwhile nugget or two. Here's story #7.

My most frequent mistake as a CEO was slow personnel changes.

It’s hard to let someone go—I believe that with enough coaching, anyone can improve, and there’s risk with every departure. They may not be perfect, but they know where the data is, they have the customer relationships, they know the daily flow their job requires. Worst of all, I’ve often really liked the people I had to fire.

But here's the hard truth: 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐢𝐬 𝐚 𝐇𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐮𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐧 𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐤—it's more complex and energy-consuming than we anticipate. Sometimes you just have to recognize when it simply isn’t the right fit. They aren’t bad or incompetent, they are just in the wrong place. Getting fired might even be the best thing that could happen to them.

𝐓𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐠𝐮𝐭. I’ve learned that if someone's natural strengths don't align with their job, no amount of coaching can bridge that gap. A creative soul may never thrive in the rigid world of data, just as someone whose likes the big picture may struggle with the minutiae demanded by their role.

It’s tough letting someone go, but it’s rarely a mistake – for you, or for them. I’m still personal friends with many people I’ve fired, and they’ve gone on to be successful in roles that were a better fit for them.

So I offer this advice when it comes to firing: do it with kindness, do it with professionalism, but most importantly, 𝐝𝐨 𝐢𝐭 𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐜𝐤𝐥𝐲. The courage to act, to make those tough calls, is what leadership often boils down to. And it’s a skill I wish I had honed much earlier in my career.

Reflecting on the recent announcement of Walmart Health’s closure, I am filled with immense pride and a deep sense of accomplishment for what we’ve achieved. As I continue to process this news, I reflect on the following points:

1. Commitment to Care: Our approach at Walmart Health emphasized accessibility, price transparency, and integrated services. We became a healthcare haven for many who felt overlooked by traditional systems. It was an honor to support our patients’ health and wellness journeys.

2. Exceptional Team: The dedication of our health center providers and associates, along with the relentless support from our home office team, were nothing short of extraordinary. This commitment reminds me of my time in the military, where every individual plays a crucial role in a collective mission.

3. Advocating for Change: The challenges we faced underscore the broader issues within our national healthcare system, which requires a fundamental overhaul. We need a model that prioritizes quality and outcomes, ensuring economic alignment with these goals.

The lessons learned at Walmart Health are invaluable. I have no regrets about our innovative approach and remain passionate about transforming healthcare. I am incredibly proud of our contributions and the persistent spirit of innovation we championed at Walmart Health.

Deeply saddened by the news of Walmart Health's closure of all healthcare clinics. As we navigate this challenging time and determine our next steps, I find myself reflecting on the journey and the proud moments of teamwork and determination to provide healthcare to communities in need. It's disheartening that this opportunity has come to an end. Nevertheless, I am grateful for the relationships I have forged and remain open for new opportunities, eager to continue making a difference in lives of others. #OpenForWork

If you hear of any exciting opportunities or are open to chatting, send me a message or comment below! #OpenToWork

Today’s announcement is disappointing for those of us who understand the need to transform healthcare and fought hard to do our part. My immediate thoughts are with our impacted associates. To a person, these amazing talents were drawn to Walmart Health's mission to solve access, convenience, and affordability challenges for the communities we have been honored to serve. I could not be prouder of them and the care they have consistently provided since our opening. I think about the hundreds of thousands of patients we served and who have come to rely on Walmart as a partner in health and wellbeing. We will continue to support you and care for you as your care is transitioned to new providers. And finally, to my leadership team and the many professionals that supported us, there are not enough words nor the right ones to express my deepest gratitude for your consistent excellence and drive. We have been on quite a journey, and though it didn’t end where I had hoped it would, there is much to celebrate in the accomplishments achieved and the friendships that have been forged. There will be a time in the future to think about and discuss the challenges specific to retail healthcare. Suffice to say, it is a sad day, but I will not allow it to diminish my determination or reduce my optimism in the good that retailers like Walmart can accomplish with its scale and resources.
#walmarthealth #retailhealthcare #healthcare #primarycare #dentalcare #behavioralhealth #healthequity #communitycare

This 54 year old Indian immigrant went from sewing her own clothes at the age of 12 to becoming CEO of the largest fashion retailer in the US.



Meet Sonia Syngal, Former CEO of Gap Inc..

Born in India, Sonia and her family immigrated to Canada at a young age.

Surrounded by creativity, Sonia showed an early interest in fashion at a young age. 

By the time she was 12, Sonia was sewing and making her own clothes.

By her teenage years, Sonia was making prom dresses for her friends. 

Despite her love for creativity, Sonia pursued a more stable path in engineering.

In 1988, Sonia moved to the US and enrolled at Kettering University, where she studied mechanical engineering.

Immediately, she started working at Ford Motor Company.

By 1995, Sonia graduated from Stanford University with a Master's in Engineering.

That's when Sonia took a leap into the dot com boom and joined Sun Microsystems as a Senior Director of Manufacturing.

After a decade, the facade of Silicon Valley wore off and Sonia decided to make the transition into her childhood dream: fashion.

By 2004, Sonia joined Gap Inc. in Global Supply Chain.

By 2011, Sonia was promoted to Managing Director of Europe.

By 2013, Sonia was promoted to SVP of Supply Chain.

By 2016, Sonia was promoted to CEO of Old Navy.

During her three year tenure, Sonia grew Old Navy's sales from $7B to $9B annually.

Then in 2020, it happened. 

Sonia was promoted to CEO of Gap Inc., the country's largest specialty apparel retailer. 

She became one of only 3 women of color CEOs on the Fortune 500.

Then, catastrophe hit.

Within 48 hours of becoming CEO, Sonia had to take over 10,000 employees to shelter in place during the pandemic lockdown.

Then, Sonia had to figure out how to furlough 100,000 employees across the continent. 

Overnight, The Gap lost 70% of our revenue, leaving the $16 billion giant with only eight weeks of cash at their burn rate.

Sonia calls it, now affectionately, her "Apollo 13 moment".

Fortune named Sonia one of the most powerful women in business in both 2021 and 2022.

Sonia went on to lead the retail giant through the pandemic and shutdown,  retiring soon after.

When asked about her time as CEO, Sonia's advice is clear: get a mentor.

Sonia shares that Scott McNealy, former CEO of Sun Microsystems, provided great support to her over the years. She believes that your direct and former bosses are often the best mentors.

Today, Sonia spends her time mentoring younger professionals. 

Sonia's number one rule when looking for a mentee?

"I don't like whiners."

Sonia's incredible ride to the top is a testament to hard work.

Yet, you hardly ever hear about her story.

In fact, I bet this post might be the first time you've ever heard of Sonia.

That's why I'm going to be sharing the stories of more women execs & founders like Sonia every Wednesday for #WomenFounderWednesday.

Subscribe to my profile by hitting the 🔔 in the top right corner.





#womeninbusiness #womenfounders

HYPE ALERT: for my Master's #capstone project at The University of Memphis, I chose to  pursue the Accreditation in Public Relations (APR). For those of you not familiar, it's a pretty big deal :) #SpoilerAlert, I earned my APR on April 20th! 

With the help of Matt Knight, APRᐩM Elizabeth Whittington, MBA, APR and Kim Marks Malone, APR, Fellow PRSA, I kicked off the process in January. It culminated in a small, windowless conference room with me passing the 171-question, three-hour, thirty minute computer based examination which was every bit as challenging as it sounds. Along the way, I presented to a panel highlighting the research, planning, implementation, and execution that went into the launch of the #RoamingGnome marketing campaign from my days on the PR team at #Travelocity. Thanks to Kim Cherry, APR and Beth Wilson, MBA, APR for your participation on my panel!

As professionals, we're lucky to have a few moments like this over the course of our careers. I've been extremely fortunate to have crossed paths with many, many elite communications professionals and even luckier to have learned from and been mentored by the likes of Dan Toporek, Al Comeaux, Helen Vollmer Caudle, Teri Daley, APR, and Judy Cohen. Cheers to all of you!

Congrats to my fellow APRs listed below who recently gained entry into this prestigious cohort of communicators! Here's to continuous learning and the ongoing advancement of our profession!!!

column7: Today, Deanna Yancey earned her master’s in electrical and computer engineering. Almost 60 years earlier, her grandfather, Ronald Yancey, EE 1965, became the first Black student to graduate from Georgia Tech. Not only did Deanna’s grandfather attend today’s ceremony, but he also presented the diploma to his granddaughter onstage at McCamish Pavilion. The First Graduate sculpture in honor of Ronald Yancey is located in the Clough Undergraduate Learning Commons. 🐝🎓 #WeCanDoThat

It’s been 3 years since joining Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, and the journey has been nothing short of legendary. Reflecting on this time, I am grateful for the #DreamTeam I work with every day, proud of our accomplishments, and energized for what’s ahead. 

From launching the inaugural #FSYachts venture to creating a Commercial organization, we’ve learned some valuable lessons that have allowed us to #BeLegendary. Here are the top 3: 

1. Be Bold – By taking creative risks, attracting new guests, and entering new markets and lines of business, we’ve achieved our ambitious goals in stride.

2. Be Brave – Creating a Commercial organization took trust and confidence, but the success that followed proves that taking that leap of faith was worth it.

3. Foster Belonging – At Four Seasons, a meaningful sense of belonging is deeply connected to our approach to luxury. Our legendary culture and dedication to The Golden Rule are fueled by the 50,000+ kind and caring individuals that make up Four Seasons. Our people are the key to our success. 

Cheers to 3 years and here’s to many more with the #LOVEFourSeasons family! 🥂 

Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts 
Alejandro Reynal

8 months ago I knew nothing about Mangroves. I didn’t know how crucial they are to our environment and in the fight against climate change. Last week I got to visit and learn more about how unique mangrove swamps are as I visited the South East coast of Thailand.
 
Their role in purifying water, providing breeding conditions for most species of tropical fish, absorb massive amounts of carbon, and pump oxygen into our skies is mind blowing. They even provide a natural barrier to the erosive powers of the ocean and provide economic opportunities for the local communities.
 
All in all, Mangroves simply ROCK!

#SaveOurPlanet #WorkWithaPurpose #EverydayIsEarthday #ERM

On April 28th I will be competing in the SurfAid Cup Santa Cruz and raising funds for SurfAid. When you support my fundraising you give people in remote communities connected to us through surfing a hand up, rather than a handout.

SurfAid's geographical focus is on the heartlands of surfing where few visitors but surfers go, make their work unique. They specialise in working in very isolated villages where the maternal and child mortality rates are some of the highest in the world.

With your support, we can give families the best chance of getting ahead by providing access to healthcare, clean water and sanitation, food security and improved nutrition.

Dutch Canadian CFO of FRAM + Slokker, Paul Michel, spoke movingly about his personal odyssey as a Dutch immigrant during the Dutch Flag Raising Ceremony at Queen's Park yesterday, which signalled the beginning of Dutch Heritage Month in Ontario.  May is #DutchHeritageMonth in Ontario. 

Paul Michel's speech also highlighted the work he is spearheading with a group of dedicated Dutch Canadian volunteers and Dutch Consular Staff to create a lasting Tribute commemorating the 80th Anniversary of the Liberation of the Netherlands by the courageous Canadian Armed Forces! #Forever_Grateful. Exciting news! I am thrilled to share that I have started a new chapter in my career as Logitech's Head of People & Culture. It's an incredible honor to be trusted with this role after spending 23 years with this wonderful company. People often ask me why I've stayed so long, and the answer is simple - it's because of the exciting career opportunities and the amazing people and culture here at Logitech. So to now be charged with a role that guides the impact and experience of all our employees at Logitech is a real privilege!

I am incredibly lucky to have wonderful support so I must give some necessary recognition to those who have had an impact on my Logitech career. 

-The incredible Kirsty Russell, a force for people and a mentor to many. The words ‘thank you’ do not seem enough for the impact you have had on the company and me. Our results will give you homage!
-Our new CEO Hanneke Faber, in the few months she has been at Logitech she has already led by example showing her commitment to internal development. Thank you for your belief and trust in me.
-Our Chair Wendy Becker, thank you for always being an encouraging voice, sharing wise words and provocations to help me grow. 
-Of course thank you to my wonderful supportive husband Eoghan!

And so many others thank you Anne Carrigy, Delphine Donné, Prakash Arunkundrum, Ujesh Desai, Quin Liu, Joe Sullivan, Alastair Curtis, Bracken Darrell, Philippe Depallens, Michele Hermann 

I can't wait to embark on this journey with my new team and I look forward to all the FUN we'll have together. Roll on the next chapter... #Logitech #PeopleAndCulture #NewChapter #ExcitingOpportunities

As promised in my previous post, I want to highlight some of my Walmart Health team members.

In this post, I'll highlight Eleta Hillyer.

Eleta is my only "official" direct report.  Eleta started her career at Walmart Health and the Center Administrator in our Walmart Health in our Springdale, AR center.  Let me tell you, being a CA in NW Arkansas, 10 miles from the Home Office, is no picnic.  Eleta and her team was the first recipient of every new big idea we had.  Some were great...others not so much.  Eleta led her team through all of these tests with a positive attitude and a smile (most of the time) on her face. 

In 2022 I had the privilege to bring her to my new site opening team.  She adapted so quickly to the task at hand it was amazing.  In this past year, she, with support from Alicia Johnson, BSHA created our first ever comprehensive Center Administrator onboarding program.  She worked closely with our Annie Hughes Patterson, Erin Edminister Hollingshead, Melissa Walsh, MBA and our associate communications team to develop a comprehensive new center marketing approach to reach both internal and external audiences.

In August of last year, as I assumed a leadership position within the central operations team, Eleta readily took on the vast majority of the new site opening program.  Together, with our support team from Sevan Multi-Site Solutions, she drove the program to open the sites we had the privilege of opening this year. 

Eleta is highly adaptable, smart, passionate, and meets my number one criteria...she is a good human.

Whatever comes next for me, if I have an opportunity to bring Eleta along, I absolutely will.....so you better make your best offer before I have the chance.

TA Managing Directors donned their aprons this week to whip up pancakes and omelettes for our Boston office! It’s moments like these – filled with camaraderie, good company and friendly competition – that remind us how special it is to be part of the TA network. A big thank you to our MDs for a fun start to the day!

Yesterday we reported our first-quarter 2024 results and raised our revenue and earnings expectations for the full year. 

- We achieved record Q1 revenue and record Q1 cash flow. 
- Our non-GAAP earnings per share grew 27% to $2.81.
- Our revenue grew 10% to $2.4 billion and our ending backlog grew to a record $14.4 billion. 
- S&P and Fitch upgraded our credit rating to BBB, reflecting the strength of our business and balance sheet. 

These strong results reflect the need-to-have nature of our technologies and we’re very well-positioned for continued growth. I'm proud to be a part of this team, tirelessly committed to solving for safer communities, safer schools and safer businesses in all that we do every day.

It is with deep sadness that I share the news of Walmart Health closing. The dedication and care provided by the amazing associates across the country will be missed by so many communities. I am grateful for the opportunity to have worked for such an incredible company and the growth it brought me, both professionally and personally. 

I had the privilege of working with exceptional mentors and leaders such as Eleta Hillyer, Lexie Thomas, Daniel Czwornog, James Jones, Pharm.D., Shannon Borkowski, and Haresh Desai. Thank you for making a significant impact on my journey. 

I cannot express enough gratitude to the team members I worked with over the last 3+ years at our clinics in Arkansas, Illinois, and Missouri. We provided care for tens of thousands of people, and I am proud of the incredible growth we achieved together. 

To everyone who was part of Walmart Health, thank you for the memories and the opportunity to serve our communities. 

#WalmartHealth #Walmart #Healthcare #Grateful

Congratulations to NAE member Ellen Ochoa for being named a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom! Dr. Ochoa is the first Hispanic woman in space and the second female Director of NASA’s Johnson Space Center. She has flown in space four times, logged nearly 1,000 hours in orbit, and continues to inspire the next generation of scientists. 

She was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2020 “for service as an astronaut, a technical leader in government, and an optical scientist/engineer.” 

Read more: https://ow.ly/fULX50RvVaM
Proud of Team Ardurra and all of their accomplishments! Thank you for building an incredible company that we are all excited to be a part of.

"We'll figure it out!"

If you've ever had worked with Carla Hackett, you've definitely heard her say those words.  This is her attitude...day in and day out...no matter the adversity that comes her way.

Carla is one of the best humans I have had the privilege to know.  She is smart and compassionate.  She cares so much for others and it shines through.  And, because those around her know how much she cares, they will go the extra mile to help her be successful.

Since Carla's LinkedIn doesn't tell her full story (Carla, you need to update your LinkedIn), let me tell you a little about her success as part of the Walmart Health team.  Carla and her team are responsible for leading on site implementation.  Her team takes an empty health center and brings it to life with equipment, supplies, technology, etc.  Over the past few years, Carla has taken this program from "barely getting by" to "best in class".  This year alone, I witnessed her team take a building from bare to fully functional IN 3 DAYS.  This didn't happen by accident.  Carla and her team have worked tirelessly on sequencing and checklists.  She has built strong relationships with vendors who bend over backwards to support her.  She gets it done.

In addition to all this, Carla has extensive experience in construction management.  She has an eye for detail and won't accept shoddy work.

Lastly, and most importantly, Carla is one of my dearest friends.  She is my "sister from another mother".  If you don't take the opportunity to hire Carla Hackett, you are missing the chance to hire one of the most talented people I know.
