After years of hard work and dedication, I am thrilled to share that I am finally graduating with my MBA from the University of Arkansas! This accomplishment represents a significant milestone in my career, and I am excited to apply the knowledge and skills I have gained to make a positive impact in the business world. I am grateful for the support of my professors, classmates, and family throughout this journey, and I look forward to the opportunities that lie ahead. #classof2024🎓 #universityofarkansas #mba

In the last year since I was laid off, I have heard from so many friends, colleagues, and collaboration industry leaders, offering so much encouragement and advice. I cannot tell you all how much that meant to me. At the request of my amazing wife, Jenny, I took the past year off and didn’t think much about work. I focused on myself, my health, and my mental well-being. In that year, I lost 75 pounds, traveled the globe to some amazing places with family and friends, built a new home, completed many projects in that new home, and ridden my motorcycle thousands of miles to see some amazing sights. 
During that time, there has always been one nagging thing, not around WHERE I will work next, but HOW I will work next. What can I do that will make me happy? 
I’ve done so much in the collaboration and workplace transformation business that it’s like second nature to me. I talk to people about collaboration solutions like most people talk about making a PB&J sandwich. It’s just something I get and truly enjoy. That’s why I’ve decided to start a business focusing solely on that. 
Officially launching today, Meeting Standards will set a new bar in collaboration experience and workplace transformation design. Bringing the absolute best solutions from major industry partners like HP, Logitech, Poly, DTEN, Microsoft, Zoom, Cisco, Google and so many others, Meeting Standards will offer custom tailored room solutions for any size business and any budget. 
I can’t express how unbelievably thrilled I am to be starting this new chapter, and more importantly doing something that I can be proud of. I was watching the Compaq documentary, Silicon Cowboys, a few weeks ago. In it, Rod Canion, former CEO and co-founder of Compaq, says he, Jim Harris and Bill Murto didn’t start Compaq to make a bunch of money, they started it so they would have a fun place to work. I’ll be adopting this motto for Meeting Standards. A “great place to work” culture is so important for the overall health of a company, and I will be putting this into practice to promote a fun and accepting place to work. 
Please follow Meeting Standards for more content from me and the team as we launch and grow this exciting new company. In the meantime, if you have any questions or want to chat, I’d love to talk more about this amazing new adventure I’m on! You can also see what we’re up to at www.meetingstandards.com 
Steve

I am waving the "Open to Work" banner and Celebrating Walmart Health's Legacy

Hello everyone, I am sharing that I am now Open to Work. However, I'd like to take a moment to reflect on my journey and express my pride in the transformative project that was Walmart Health.

Our founder, Mr. Sam Walton, dreamt of changing the landscape of healthcare, driven by his personal experiences with healthcare costs. He aspired to improve the situation for both his employees and customers. After all, 90% of the population live within 10 miles of a Walmart. His vision inspired us to strive towards establishing healthcare centers across the United States within our Walmart Centers.

Over the span of 5 years, we served 51 communities through Walmart Health. We reached out to thousands of patients, improved lives, educated communities, and genuinely made a difference. Each individual that walked into a Walmart Health location was impacted by the collective effort of every team member.

From the welcoming face at the front desk to the clinical staff, dental staff, Nurse Practitioners, Dentists, and Medical Doctors providing care, everyone played a part in the success of Walmart Health. Not forgetting the unsung heroes behind the scenes - those who sourced the staff, advocated for change in healthcare, negotiated terms, and all who worked under the banner of Walmart Health.

The closures of these centers are a loss, impacting patients, communities, employees, and Walmart itself. Yet, they underscore the urgent need for more accessible and affordable healthcare centers in the United States.

I am profoundly proud of the work we accomplished, of being a part of this remarkable initiative, and of our collective effort to revolutionize healthcare.

A special thank you goes out to the amazing recruiting team and leaders. We changed lives, we made a significant impact, and you should be incredibly proud.

For anyone in healthcare looking to hire dedicated, patient-focused professionals, I encourage you to connect with the administrators of the Walmart Health centers and meet the staff. Please also consider the many talented individuals from Walmart who are now entering the job market that worked behind the scenes. They are exceptional in what they do, and I firmly believe they will be an asset to any organization.

Thank you for my time with Walmart, and I look forward to the next steps in my professional journey.

column7: We had a great day in Maricopa, #Arizona as Freedom Alliance and U.S. Bank gave a mortgage-free home to Sgt Chris Hayden. Chris has a history of #military service in his family and was interested in continuing his family’s tradition. At the age of 15, he was further inspired toward #service when he read the book, “Blackhawk Down." If he had any doubt as to whether or not he would serve, it was erased on September 11, 2001, when he saw the damage that was done to our country and the lives that were brutally taken. Chris enlisted through the Delayed Entry Program at age 17 and celebrated his 18th birthday in basic training. He was wounded in #Iraq and his injuries grew worse over time. But Chris is grateful for the new beginning this home provides. He loves to hike and be active in the outdoors and now has many new mountains to climb in Arizona’s beautiful landscape. We are grateful to Chris for his service and ask God’s blessings on him as he begins a new and exciting chapter in his life. #veterans #wounded #Soldier #Army #nonprofit
Thank you for always lifting up our Latino community, Latino Corporate Directors Association (LCDA)!!! 🙏🏽

column7:
Are you working from the best location today to maximize your effectiveness to do your job?

Most of Comerica Bank's Technology Team is based in Auburn Hills, Michigan, USA.  Given the location of my home in Peterborough, Ontario, Canada, I do not go to the office every day, but I do go to the office on the occasions where there is value to be gained from in person collaboration.  It is a 5 hour drive.  Most people would just assume that I would always work from my home 100% of the time, but I don't.

This week I spent three days in Michigan that were extremely valuable to me and Comerica.  It was an important moment to come together to solve difficult business problems that required strong team collaboration.  As one of our collaborators highlighted, "we accomplished in 3 days what we would have accomplished in 4+ weeks virtually!"  This was a great example of coming to the office for a moment that matters.

While I was there, I had the secondary benefits of informal discussions with members of our team, a mentoring session, a 1:1 with my leader, and the wonderful art that the Take Your Children to Work participants created on my office wall.  All human-to-human engagements that were enriched by the value of in-person collaboration.

I am not saying that we must come to the office every day, but we cannot expect that working 100% remote is the best tool for the job for every task.  We have to look at the office environment as an enabler in our tool bag that can be used to effectively solve problems.  Ask yourself this question every morning, "Are you working from the best location today to maximize your effectiveness to do your job?"  If the answer is no, then it is time to get in the car, on your bike, or on the transit, and move yourself into the work location that maximizes your productivity and efficiency.  Your willingness to choose the work location that maximizes your productivity and efficiency will ultimately increase the quality of your output and the value contribution to your organization. 

I acknowledge that I have an extreme commute of 500km or 300 miles, but most of you reading this do not have a 5-hour drive to the office.  The vast majority are likely well under an hour on a bad day.  Therefore, making the right decision for maximizing value when you ask yourself, "Are you working from the best location today to maximize your effectiveness to do your job?" is even easier than mine.

Value is a key contributing factor when assessing your readiness for future roles on your career journey.  We should all be looking to maximize our ability to deliver value.  Don't ignore the value that being in the office can create in your productivity and efficiency, particularly during collaborative work activities.

For me, the commute this week was worth it as it maximized the value that we delivered this week.

#leadership #hybridwork #commuting #creatingvalue

Tomorrow I have a goal to hit a qualifying half marathon in order to get into NYC 2025 marathon. 
And so 18 months before NYC 2025 I’m putting down a solid effort. For a long term goal. 
Running the 6 major marathons - of which I’ve done 2 (Chicago and Boston). 

And I’m excited that even though I’ll have to wait on the long term goal, it’s meaningful to me to make strides on it now (pun intended!). 

What long term goals do you have that you are committed to and consistent for right now?
How do you maintain your motivation? How many strategies are you using?? When motivation wanes (and it does a lot for long term goals), what systems, habits, and frameworks do you have in place to stay consistent?

Let’s go!!
#emotionalintelligence
#selfactualization is the skill that speaks to one’s wellbeing and it is the consistent pursuit of growth and challenges that are meaningful. 
#iqeqtq

column7: JPMorgan Chase has been fined a total of $448 million by US regulators for failing to adequately monitor potential market misconduct on billions of transactions within its global trading operation. The bank reached a deal with an unnamed US regulator, adding an additional $100 million in penalties to the $348 million enforcement action by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) and the Federal Reserve Board (FRB). In March, the OCC and FRB accused JPMorgan of “unsafe or unsound” banking practices, highlighting significant gaps in the bank’s trade surveillance program. Specifically, the bank failed to properly monitor its traders and clients, potentially missing market misconduct across at least 30 global trading venues. JPMorgan has now committed to enhancing the reliability of its trade infrastructure and maintaining rigorous controls. Despite these fines, JPMorgan reported a net income of $49.6 billion last year.

Ten years ago….

…I landed with a visa and two suitcases at New York’s JFK airport. My family followed shortly after and we started our life here in New York. 

While I still learn on a daily basis, I have seen and learned so many things in the last ten years. And I would like to share a few of those. Not to be pretentious, just to add some things that might be new or different insights for some of you. 

1. Unbias yourself. 

Believe systems can narrow the solution set too quickly. Keep an open mind for different and new ideas.

2. Transparency builds trust. Trust builds alignment. Alignment builds success. 

It’s a simple success formula that really works. If intentions and actions are transparent, then we will trust each other. And when we trust each other, we will align on the intended outcomes and all our energy flows to a common goal. Instead of wasting energy on politics or second guessing….

3. Your culture is defined by the worst behavior that you are willing to accept. 

Every time someone on your team or organization does or say something that could harm your culture or ethical standards, you have a choice to make as a leader. If you let it go, you have lowered the bar of your culture. If you say/do something about, you maintain the standard that you have set as a team…

4. When you want people to build a boat, make them long for the sea. 

Freely translated from a french writer. It’s a about crafting a vision, an aspiration that gives people a sense of purpose and direction. And therefore we will build the boat, instead of giving them the command. Don’t get me wrong, in certain cases a command is the only way yet it’s so much easier when people execute by self-motivation:-)

5. The hospital process worked, but the patient still died.

Meaning, following the process is not enough. Don’t hide behind the process. Instead dive into the content, understand the real risks and ask the right questions to make informed decisions. 

6. Careers are not only built on successes. They are also built on failures and crises and how you deal with these. Own it up, blameless post-mortems, root cause analysis, discover the learnings and apply the learnings going forward. 

Thank you all for the great ten years! To be continued….

Last summer, I was burnt crispy.

Like many climbing the career ladder, somewhere along I bought into the notion that securing and holding onto coveted leadership roles meant sacrificing parts of myself. As a Latina in the C-suite, the loneliness alone was challenging enough. When you add the relentless demands of COVID, social unrest, economic uncertainty, interpersonal tensions, and continuous organizational turmoil, the pressure wore me out.

Yet, a persistent voice inside me insisted, "Burnout isn't a mandatory badge of honor in leadership. There's a different way forward, and it's not just for you!"

Deep inside I knew that to lead others with compassion, clarity and intention, I had to first apply those principles to myself. Writing increasingly became my method for making sense of my experiences. And the process of writing what would evolve into my forthcoming book, Burnt Out to Lit Up: How to Reignite the Joy of Leading People, became the balm I needed.

Through my writing, I came to grips with the fact that, though I was far from my best self, thankfully, my best self hadn’t given up on me. I hung onto the hope that we could patch up the tattered edges of modern leadership and steer a fresh course—one fueled by intentional, compassionate, and courageously pragmatic leadership, all while crafting creative ways to support today’s workforce.

Writing Burnt Out to Lit Up was, and continues to be, my path to healing. It has served as both my medicine and my muse. As I wrote down my experiences to help others reignite their leadership spark, I found mine flickering back. Unpacking the layers of past leadership mistakes, unavoidable setbacks, and the heartaches endured through years of relentless change strengthened my resilience and led me to actionable, research-backed tools and strategies crucial for transforming individuals and organizations.

I’ll share more about Burnt Out to Lit Up in the months leading up to its release in September. For now, I leave you with what inspired me to write, what sustained me through the process, and what I’ve gained from it. If, as Bethany Saltman advises, you have a story you can’t stop talking about, and as I've discovered, a calling that tugs at your heart, exploring it through writing might not only be your own path to healing but also a balm for others.

Get a copy delivered straight to you when it comes out on September 18: https://bit.ly/3QxCYRn

#burntouttolitupbook #leadership #management #burnout #mentalhealth #wellness

column7:
I’m taking a personal day today. I felt moved to post about it because, although we encourage folks to take these, I still sense pretty significant resistance. 

I’m not nearing a breakdown. I’m not falling apart at my keyboard. I’m not completely overwhelmed and exasperated. I have been feeling the pressure of work, my honey-do list, kid’s activities and early spring farm work all building up. The to-do lists keep building. 

Younger Steve would have put his head down and just worked his way through it, potentially leading to frustration or overwhelm. Older Steve is learning that to stop getting deeper in the hole you occasionally need to put down the shovel. I can be more proactive about releasing building pressure rather than needing to be reactive to fixing a breakdown. It is easier and faster to maintain your tools than to repair broken ones. 

Things I will NOT do today:
-         Check my phone (and I have turned off my notifications)
-         Watch the news, YouTube or other distracting videos
-         Consume a bunch of comforting junk food or drinks (sugar is my nemesis)

Things I will do today:
-         Be present in the moment
-         Spend time talking with my wife
-         Exercise in the sunshine
-         Eat a bunch of healthy nutrient rich food that I prepare at home
-         Read for a couple hours
-         Keep myself hydrated (a personal challenge as I tend to be pretty camel-like)
-         Finish re-facing my deck and get that task to ‘done’

There is no judgement in this list – these are the things that I know personally recharge me and allow me to reset my systems. 

I hope that you are able to find time today to carve out space for yourself in whatever way is most meaningful for you.

As I prepare for my next venture in the greater New York area, I am reflecting on the incredible journey I've had in the greater Dallas area. When I first arrived in this vibrant city, I had no connections in the area. 

I vividly remember contacting these wonderful professionals in the area and seeking their connections. The response I received was overwhelming. They graciously extended their friendship, shared invaluable insights, and welcomed me into their networks. Because of their kindness, I was able to build a meaningful and supportive professional community in the Dallas area. Thank you Asha Devasia, JJ Rorie, and Jana Gerber.

The connections I've made here will forever be cherished. #Networking and supporting one another is crucial for women's professional growth and advancement. We inspire and uplift each other by sharing our experiences, challenges, and triumphs. These connections have provided a safe space to learn, seek advice, and gain invaluable perspectives from women who have walked similar paths. The bonds formed through this powerful network have been a constant source of #motivation and #empowerment.

As I embark on this new chapter in the greater New York area, I carry the lessons, experiences, and friendships forged in Dallas. I look forward to continuing to nurture these relationships and building new ones along the way.

If you're in the greater New York area or have connections there, I'd love to hear from you. Your guidance and introductions would be invaluable as I navigate this exciting transition.

Thank you, Dallas, for the incredible memories and opportunities. I'm grateful for the journey and excited for what's to come!

column7:
Completely misaligned.

Hospitals get to essentially write off their bad debt, but physicians don't - supposedly because they're "nonprofit" and engaged w serving the "public good."  We are literally the only US small business sector not allowed to do so.

The solution for uncompensated medical care provided by physicians always defaults back to either employment/RVU based PSAs or undervalued call contracts (if they're offered at all) - both of which center around the brobdingnag of corporatized health systems, both of which also ironically drive up the costs of care locally. 

A simpler, more holistic solution would be allowing physician practices to write off our losses for uncompensated care at Medicare rates. It would achieve a better alignment and empower independent physician practices.  I'll bet the return on this would be far better than what we have in place for the NFPs presently. I'd be curious if this would be worth studying for a health care economist Ge Bai (not that your plate isn't already full.)

Benjamin Schwartz, MD, MBA Marty Makary M.D., M.P.H. Adam J. Bruggeman, MD, MHA, FAAOS, FAOA Katie Orrico Nashville Health Care Council

column7:
At the end of 2022, I could hardly run a mile without huffing and puffing. In late April 2023, I ran my first “Broad Street Run,” a 10-mile run that has been a Philadelphia tradition for 40 years. My average speed was 11:36/mile and my total run duration was around 1 hour and 56 minutes. In November 2023, I ran my second 10-miler, another Philadelphia tradition called “The Rocky Run.” My average speed was 11:20/mile and my total run duration was about 1 hour and 53 minutes. Today, on 5/5/2024, I ran my second Broad Street Run, my third overall 10-miler. Today, my average speed was 10:15/mile and my total run duration was 1 hour and 42 minutes. A whole 14 minutes faster than a year before, and 11 minutes faster than just 5.5 months ago. 

If someone would have told me just two years ago that I would be able to do THAT, I would have never believed them. Why am I posting this here? Well, firstly, because I am proud of myself! But even more important, it’s because I want to remind everyone that you CAN do that thing that you never thought possible, if you just put the effort in. A little perseverance coupled with belief in yourself can go a very long way.  I know it may sound like a hallmark card to some but believe me, it is true, because I am living proof. 

My first half-marathon is this November. And I can’t wait!

Long lasting impression….

What a memorable meet with Ann Marie Janke! 

As always, she is as accomplished as ever while being the CIO of Nieman Marcus. It was great catching up with her after almost 15 years. By the way, she has the exact same bright aura and a big smile😄

Why is she special to my leadership growth? She was my boss (and a great one indeed) in 2005/2006 . She left a lasting impression in my leadership journey. When I was driving to meet her, I remembered one of the meaningful leadership feedbacks she gave me during an annual review. She told me she liked my passion and intensity, but warned me not to be a “whirlwind.” I have to say…I am still working on it😊. However, that advice always worked as an invisible and silent whisper. It kept me grounded when I got anxious from things moving fast but not fast enough🤔. Reflecting on my reunion with Ann Marie, it reaffirmed the need for an enduring impact of great mentorship and actionable feedback in one’s leadership transformation journey.

I want to thank her for being that mentor for me.

Community looks different in all aspects of our lives, and today, I am leaning into my LinkedIn community…

It is with the heaviest of hearts that I write this post to share the tragic loss of three amazing men in my life – Carter Rhoad, Callum Robinson, and Jake Robinson. These men embodied the essence of community. When good people know good people, love, kindness, and joy spread like crazy and that is what happened here in San Diego. I am so heartbroken and can’t comprehend this type of evil in the world, and I'm not sure I ever will, but we won’t lose hope or faith. Carter, Callum, and Jake would never want that to happen.

Today, I am asking for action from this community. We need to support three families during this time and rally around them; we’ve created three GoFundMe pages.

Stand with Natalie, Remember Carter's Impact – https://gofund.me/5e1b14d6
We've created this GoFundMe page for two purposes…The first is to rally support for Carter’s wife during this unimaginably difficult time and provide essentials such as housing, food, transportation, and more. The second is to honor Carter by raising money for scholarships and donations he felt passionate about. No donation is too small, and every contribution is deeply appreciated.

Rhoad Family Expenses - https://gofund.me/858cdfeb

Robinson Family Expenses - https://gofund.me/a703b630

If you can't donate, please consider sharing these pages with your community. Together, we can continue to surround the families with the love and support they need to navigate this challenging journey. Thank you for your kindness, compassion, and solidarity during this time of profound loss.

It may be a bit overkill as this has already been posted through various organizations, but I wanted to share my own version of my appointment as the CEO and President of PetMeds®  and PetCareRx Inc. 

So many people ask me how they can get on boards…sometimes it’s this simple: 
 
A year ago, Michael Rempell mentioned to Stacy Berns (or my dear friend, Stacy Bernsita) that a pet company was looking for a board candidate. She recommended me because she knew I was already serving on boards AND she knows that I am passionate about my farm and animals. That information was shared with Peter Cobb who graciously jumped on a phone call with me and then passed that along to the rest of the  BOD of PetMeds®  including Gian Fulgoni Leslie C. G. Campbell Diana Garvis Purcel, MBA, CPA (inactive), NACD.DC and Jodi Watson 

Since then, I’ve had a year of learning the company, under the leadership of Matt Hulett and extend my gratitude to Matt and the entire board for granting me the opportunity to serve as an independent board director. This esteemed group is driven by a mission that resonates deeply with me.

Beyond what has been written elsewhere, my professional career is rooted in the entrepreneurial spirit instilled by my parents, who had me and my siblings working in their tortilla factory from a young age. From warehouses to retail, from Texas to New York City, my path has been shaped by diverse corporate and entrepreneurial experiences. 

I've had the privilege of working for leaders who have been my strongest supporters and gave me the opportunities to grow professionally and personally: Mindy Grossman Jason Rabin Diane von Furstenberg and my former business partner Tony Melillo to name a few. And…I have so many other sponsors in my life that promote my name when I’m not in the room (the list is too long but thank them all). 

I’ve had people who have “mentored” me without knowing it and have had the past three years of board experiences learning from too many impressive leaders to name. What I can tell you is that I continue to learn from every experience and have been able to round out my skills to be a better leader and operator because of each and every experience. 

I’ve lived the roller coaster ride of retail over the past decades of transformations. Building relevant and profitable businesses, finding white space opportunities, and centering everything around the ever-evolving consumer is what drives me to succeed.

I didn’t think my personal passions and my professional life would intersect in this way but my 8 rescue horses, 2 rescue dogs, and 1 talkative senior cat at Sugar Bear Farm in upstate NY will be happy that I am helping other pets live healthier and longer lives too. 

I am truly excited to partner with the PetCareRx Inc and PetMeds®  team to foster a company that exemplifies excellence for our employees, customers, and investors alike. Now it’s time to buckle up (thanks Meahgan (O'Grady) Martin) for this fun ride ahead!

column7:
After nearly 40 years in the IT industry, the last 18 of which have been at Korn Ferry leading the CIO/CTO Executive Search Practice in EMEA, I have taken the plunge and have retired.  So far so good - in fact (as someone observed to me) I've found plenty to do and it's a wonder I found any time to work!  For now, it is great not having to worry about deadlines and Teams calls, but I daresay I may be tempted to do some freelance part-time advisory, coaching or NED work at some point. So please do keep me in mind if you think I can be of help.

I have been privileged to have worked with many talented people over my time as a practitioner, a consultant and most recently in executive search.  The last 18 years has been a sheer joy, working with so many talented CIOs across multiple industries and geographies.  We have a rich seam of talent in our industry and the opportunity to work with incredibly able and dedicated IT professionals and to be a small part of helping companies put technology at the heart of their operations has been a real career highlight.  Little did I know 46 years ago, when I first programmed a DEC PDP 11/34 at school, that it was the start of my career in IT - it has been a fun ride!

Finally a huge thank you to the colleagues, teams and mentors with whom I have had the privilege to work - you know who you are and I thank you for all your support, help and friendship.  Here's wishing everyone a happy and successful future.

column7:
Whoever thought of this deserves a raise.

Sprite gave beach goers the ultimate shower experience by bringing a massive Sprite machine to the beach that dispensed water for beach goers to shower.

Picture this: you're at the beach, the sun is scorching, and you're longing for a refreshing shower.

But what's this?

A giant Sprite fountain drink machine towering over the shoreline, ready to drench you in cool, revitalizing water.

That's exactly what beachgoers experienced thanks to Sprite's ingenious guerrilla marketing campaign.

It's not every day you see a beverage company take their branding to such creative heights.

But that's exactly what Sprite did with their larger-than-life installation.

Instead of just handing out free samples or sponsoring beach events, they went above and beyond to create an unforgettable experience for their target audience.

And it worked like a charm. People couldn't stop talking about the Sprite Soda Shower (both IRL and on social media), and it left a lasting impression on everyone who got caught under its refreshing cascade.

This act of showering after a long day at the beach is undeniably refreshing, just like the experience of sipping on an ice-cold Sprite. It's a perfect synergy that revitalized Sprite's brand image.

It's a perfect example of how thinking outside the box can elevate a brand from ordinary to extraordinary.

Small things matter 📈

If I told you that the three words presented during the first 1.5 seconds of your videos determine heavily the effectiveness of your advertising, would you believe? This was the question that rose to me after I joined Smartly Growth Summit a couple weeks ago and got some new ideas for testing. Specifically the idea was to test:

Would it be better to talk about (A) the retail stores nearby OR (B) a dream car for the upcoming summer? Afterwards, it’s easy to say that the latter was a lot better approach since Cost per Lead was almost -39% compared to the former.

The lesson learned once again: never take anything for granted and always test at least two different options to make better and more effective advertising.😎

#digital #costeffective #advertising #luxury #cars #Porsche #PorscheApproved #WorkSmartly

When it comes to supporting employee health, addressing burnout is important—but not enough. Our research offers insights into how organizations can help create a workplace that prioritizes physical, mental, social, and spiritual health. 

For employees, good holistic health is most strongly predicted by workplace enablers. These are aspects of work that provide positive energy, such as meaningful work and psychological safety. Those who find meaning in their work and feel they can raise new ideas or objections with their coworkers are more likely to feel they are in better health across all four dimensions. mck.co/49rG8Oo

#EmployeeExperience

People Leaders are taking on more than ever before. 

Not only are they tasked with managing the intricate intricacies of human resources, but they also often find themselves shouldering the emotional weight of their organizations. 

As the frontline responders to employee concerns, conflicts, layoffs, compliance issues, and crisis management, HR leaders play a pivotal role in maintaining the well-being of both their workforce and their organization. However, this responsibility often comes at a cost to their own mental health. Many find themselves in the role of unofficial therapists, navigating complex interpersonal dynamics and shouldering the emotional labor of their colleagues.

In this webinar, we will explore the impact of these challenges on the mental health of People Leaders and provide insights into how to recognize and address the signs of burnout, stress, and compassion fatigue. We will also equip attendees with practical tools and techniques for establishing healthy boundaries, managing stress, and seeking support when needed.

Join us as we ask the crucial question: Who is HR for HR?

Register here: https://lnkd.in/gN553fda

Not a surprise to anyone in the Boston area, but Steward Health Care filed for bankruptcy protection last night. Steward is a PE-backed (Cerberus Capital Management) hospital system, operating 32 hospitals in 8 states and a physician group that it plans to sell. They are blaming poor reimbursement from Medicaid and Medicare. There are many who are pointing to this as the failure of PE and VC in healthcare - investors made their returns, loaded it with debt until it was no longer sustainable. Is this the result of bad actors or a failed system? 
I've seen both the good and the bad of PE/VC. I've also seen how reimbursement can hamstring whole-person, high quality care. What do you think? 
One thing is for certain - the people and patients in the most vulnerable, underserved, and lowest socioeconomic communities will be hurt the most.

column7:
After an incredible journey spanning over 14 years, I am bidding farewell to Google to embark on a new chapter in my career with a dynamic startup. While this transition is bittersweet, as I reflect on the remarkable accomplishments, the exceptional team and colleagues, and the genuine camaraderie fostered at Google, I now look forward to learning and growing in a new company and making an impact there. 

Google Networking has always held a special place in my heart. I joined in 2010 as an optical networking technologist, and from the outset, I was captivated by the heady mix of massive scale requirements, talented teams, empowerment, and the tenacity to drive bold transformations in network architecture. We fostered deep partnerships with equipment vendors and pioneered numerous industry firsts in optical transport, subsea cables, and routing platforms. Additionally, we developed groundbreaking technologies in-house, including software-defined networking, traffic management, planning and design, and network observability. Together, we built and operated one of the largest, most resilient, and most scalable global networks, serving as the physical backbone for Google's internal applications and Cloud offerings, essentially becoming critical societal infrastructure. 

It has been a true privilege to have been part of this incredible journey as both a technical and people leader. While we built an awesome network, it is more than about the nodes and links, it was the people and the relationships forged that truly made it exceptional. We shared moments of joy, overcame challenges and setbacks, and created countless cherished memories filled with laughter and, at times, tears. I am incredibly thankful to my leaders, mentors, and teammates for the ride and pride of my career.

As I transition from my tenure at Google to a new adventure, a sense of nostalgia is intertwined with excitement. I can playfully say that while the "search" has ended, a new quest begins.

column7:
“No, you’ll sleep in my bed.”

A simple act of kindness no doubt altered the trajectory of my life.

It was the interaction that ultimately led me to choose West Point over Annapolis – and it’s a lesson in how org culture ultimately attracts or repels interested individuals.

I was a senior in high school and recruited by both Army and Navy.

I hate to admit it now, but Navy had the initial edge. My older brother was my hero growing up, and he played football at USNA’s prep school in Newport, RI.

Thus, I was pumped for my Navy recruiting trip. 

But my host, an upperclassman, kept introducing me to everyone during my visit as his “drag,” Naval Academy slang for a recruit who they had to “drag” around. He was nice enough, but pawned me off on some plebes to entertain me. I felt out-of-place, like a burden.

A few weeks later, I went on my West Point recruiting trip. The coaching staff put me up with John DiMuzio, a plebe from NJ, where I’m from.

John had a larger-than-life personality and introduced me to ALL his friends – not as his drag - but as “his” recruit. We had a blast at the hockey game despite walking in 14 in. of snow! He couldn’t have been nicer or more accommodating. 

When it was time for bed, I went to lay down in the military cot that was in the room, just like I did during my Navy recruiting trip.

“No, you’ll sleep in my bed,” John said. “I got the cot.”

At the time (not true now), Navy had a more successful program. Better facilities. Better dorm rooms. Better town, restaurants, and bars (sorry Highland Falls). Better weather.

But at West Point, I ran into better people – and that’s what made all the difference.

This isn’t a slam of USNA nor a glorification of West Point – no doubt I could’ve had a much different experience during both recruiting trips.

But John’s kindness made my decision easy.

He’s no longer with us – John passed away in 2018 from brain cancer. But I think of him often, including every time I tell the story of why I chose West Point.

Never underestimate the power that a cultural ambassador (or assassin) can have on your organization’s recruitment.

If you are wanting to improve your mindset, please take a look at my friend Colleen’s posts and give her a follow. Masterful insights on a regular basis. Plus she is one of *the* coolest people I know … airplanes and saunas for starters! That she and her husband built!

I booked a trip to Disney this week. 

The whole family is going. 

My husband and I took the kids many times when they were young. 

We have great memories from our Disney trips. 

But our kids are grown now, 32 and 25….and family vacations have become fewer and fewer as they build their own lives. 

This week I was at a funeral for a friend who I grew up with. 

He tragically passed away after a simple medical procedure went horribly wrong. 

His family loved Disney too. 

In fact, through the years, we’d run into them there from time to time. 

After being witness to the shock, grief, and pain on the faces of his family….

I realized that time is shorter than it used to be. 

So, on a whim, I booked it. 

Flights too. 

Then I texted the kids the screenshots of the reservations and waited….

I thought for sure that someone would say “I already have plans that week, or I can’t get off work…”

Instead I got “OMG, I’m so excited!”  And, “I’m putting in my vacation request right now!”

I rarely take vacations. 

I’m always at work. 

But this week, I saw first hand that our time is not unlimited….

And that sometimes you have to risk being silly, spontaneous or impulsive….

While you still can. 

Take the vacation. 

Reach out to the old friend you haven’t seen in years. 

Invite the family over for dinner even if your house is a mess. 

Surprise your kids with an unexpected get together. 

Go to the beach. 

Or show up with your fishing gear or golf clubs. 

Go to the baseball game. 

Do whatever you love with the people you love 💕 for as long as you can. 

#resumewriting
#disney
#family

Alive Day….

Seventeen years ago, I woke as I did my previous days in Iraq. Focus on the mission at hand with my teammates; I also knew that day that I would be attending a memorial service for two young man that I did not know, but we’re part of my brigade, and her sister battalion who had been killed a few days earlier by an improvised explosive device. Part of me, wondered in the chaos if we were making a difference, if all this sacrifice was worth it. That evening, after attending the memorial service and catching up with my peers and my boss that I had not seen for several months; I headed back to my headquarters again with a heavy heart when my vehicle struck by a command, detonated improvise explosive device. I immediately knew what it was, and very quickly understood that I was severely wounded and my prayer to God was not to die in this country. He answered my prayer through my teammates, and all of the medical professionals that touched me that evening and gave me a chance to live. But I submit to you that the real miracle was not just surviving, but it was being healed. The burden of uncertainty and the fear of the unknown was lifted by my Lord and Savior Jesus Christ.

I am blessed and I strive to be a blessing every day. As Memorial Day approaches, I understand how close I was the being memorialized and so fortunate to be able to live a thriving life and to watch my six grandchildren grow up.

I didn’t do this by myself, I want you to understand that my faith, my family, and my friends, all too many to recognize and acknowledge, provide me hope to fight on my merry men. And I lay me down to bleed a while and will rise with you and fight again .

Good Bless!!!

Greg

I’ve been fairly quiet on LinkedIn since I left Goldman Sachs in New York 9 years ago to embark on a year of travel, amazing experiences and to see where the wind took me. Leaving the only place I had ever worked after 10 incredible years was one of the harder decisions I ever made… and certainly one that has played on repeat in the back of my mind through all of the amazing times I’ve had since then - visiting 26 countries in a year, living and working in China, serving on boards, returning to the US, starting a family and becoming a US citizen. 

With great excitement I want to share that today was my first day back at Goldman Sachs. I am coming back as a Private Wealth Advisor and will be working out of the LA office. 

There have been so many people who have gone above and beyond to make this the right move for me and I am incredibly grateful to all for the wisdom, guidance and time over the last several months. Big shoutouts to Simon Osborn Thomas Schwartz Mike Siegel Heather Brownlie Brooke Mayne (Moldenhauer) Justin Tobe, CFA Anushka Gupta Megan Young, CFA Sylvia Yeh Alexa Gordon and Laust Helmig, CFA Tristan Blood 

It’s good to be home!

I am 45 years old…but still go to electronic music festivals

➞I have two kids…but drive a sports car 

➞I care a lot about education...but won't sign up for a 529 Plan

➞I teach and love sales…but refuse to go "networking"

➞You’ll rarely see me at conferences talking about marketing… but I'm a LinkedIn Top Voice

➞I focus on branding and messaging...but English isn't my first language

➞I grew up dirt poor, but train around ultra high net worth psychology

💡There is no “rule book” to this thing we call life 
💡There is no "ONE" way to go about business & career growth
💡There is no value in conforming to stereotypes (positive or negative)

Live your life and career on your own terms and ENJOY the journey! 


#branding #stereotypes #careeradvice

U.S. Bank CEO Andy Cecere is passing his role as president to Gunjan Kedia. Some analysts say the move positions Kedia, who has been a senior executive at the Minneapolis-based company since 2016, as its next chief executive.

Kedia is a six-time American Banker Most Powerful Women in Finance honoree. She is one of 16 people — and one of three women — on the company's managing committee.

Today I hosted an amazing group of women for my very first “Power Lunch”- an idea planted in my heart by Jennifer Merritt of Bluestock Advisors back in February. It was in the style of a Feast of Reason, or Jeffersonian Dinner- a small group focused on one topic, discussed as a single group.

It was more than I could have dreamed of! It came to be because Jayshree Seth, Courtney Jordan Baechler and Kim Olson donated a lunch at the American Heart Association gala. We added the brilliant leadership of LeeAnn Rasachak, Kelly Aronson , Dara Beevas and Jennifer Alstad to the mix.

Our focus topic was women and power. We laughed, helped each other find words for things we didn’t know, and left as new friends.

I will admit I was nervous going in. Was this a silly idea? Was I overthinking this? Nope and nope.

I can’t wait to do this again! ❤️

Change is an inevitable part of life, and it can be a source of fear and anxiety for many people. However, it's important to remember that change can also bring new opportunities and growth. Embracing change means being open to new experiences, learning new skills, and adapting to new situations. It may require stepping outside your comfort zone and taking risks, but the rewards can be worth it. So, never be afraid of change and, instead, try to approach it with an open mind and a willingness to grow.

column7:
If we never take risks and step outside our comfort zones, we will never truly discover our full potential. Making mistakes is an inevitable part of learning and growth. It is through our mistakes that we learn what doesn't work and what we need to improve upon. Therefore, instead of fearing failure, we should embrace it as an opportunity to learn and grow. 

Trying new things can be daunting, but it's important to remember that every successful person has failed at some point in their life. They didn't let their failures define them; instead, they learned from them and used the experience to improve themselves. By doing so, they were able to achieve great success and make a positive impact in their lives and the lives of others.

I’ve been fairly quiet on LinkedIn since I left Goldman Sachs in New York 9 years ago to embark on a year of travel, amazing experiences and to see where the wind took me. Leaving the only place I had ever worked after 10 incredible years was one of the harder decisions I ever made… and certainly one that has played on repeat in the back of my mind through all of the amazing times I’ve had since then - visiting 26 countries in a year, living and working in China, serving on boards, returning to the US, starting a family and becoming a US citizen. 

With great excitement I want to share that today was my first day back at Goldman Sachs. I am coming back as a Private Wealth Advisor and will be working out of the LA office. 

There have been so many people who have gone above and beyond to make this the right move for me and I am incredibly grateful to all for the wisdom, guidance and time over the last several months. Big shoutouts to Simon Osborn Thomas Schwartz Mike Siegel Heather Brownlie Brooke Mayne (Moldenhauer) Justin Tobe, CFA Anushka Gupta Megan Young, CFA Sylvia Yeh Alexa Gordon and Laust Helmig, CFA Tristan Blood 

It’s good to be home!

column7:
Very interesting article. It compares hospital and health plan consolidation in specific markets. Indiana is a market that is deemed a high cost market (7th highest in nation for hospital costs) because of hospital consolidation per studies, yet when you look at the market, plans have more leverage as the top 3 represent 91% of the large group market. 

A few thoughts: 1) you can look at number of hospitals, but it would be better to compare commercial spend for these systems as I would imagine a lot higher than the counts indicate. Some hospitals may have a higher proportion of governmental business and that needs to be considered. 2) Based on plan leverage, one would think plans would say no to continued commercial price increases. It's important though that employers support plans in these discussions. I have seen many times over the years that employers want access above everything else, which means the plan has little leverage with the hospital to take hard line stands or risk losing large national employers who will just switch to another plan creating a vicious cycle of continued cost increases. 3) Under this environment, there is little incentive to move to VBC like arrangements vs. fee for service.

7. For example, in Indiana, the systems with the largest share of total hospitals are St. Louis-based Ascension (13.9%), Indianapolis-based IU Health (11.3%), Mishawaka-based Franciscan Health (8.7%) and Franklin, Tenn.-based Community Health Systems (8.7%). These four systems own 42.6% of all the hospitals in Indiana combined
8. On the other hand, the three largest payers in Indiana — Elevance Health (68.9%), UnitedHealth Group (17.1%) and Physicians Health Plan of Northern Indiana (5.3%) — represent 91.2% of all privately insured patients with insurance from the large-group market.

*American Telemedicine Association (ATA) Nexus - AMA PIN Recap*

Big shout to Physician Innovation Network (PIN) at the American Medical Association (AMA) for gathering an incredible group of clinician innovators at the American Telemedicine Association (ATA)'s annual summit. 

*PIN IRL Breakouts*
I had a blast getting to know Salman Hirani, MD; Gregory Goodman, M.D.; Hansa Bhargava MD; Oren Mechanic, MD, MPH, MBA; Thomas Kim; and Eli Lourie, MD, MBI, FAAP, FAMIA. These folks are pushing innovation in specialty telemedicine (pain management, pediatrics, psychedelics, obesity) and driving progress in clinical informatics, hospital-at-home, and medical news/education. 

Thanks to Aditi U Joshi MD, MSc, FACEP; Ryan A. Grant, MD, MS, MBA, FAANS; Michal Tzuchman Katz, MD; Christina Gerdes, MD and others for attending our "PIN IRL" breakout sessions and sharing best practices for optimizing telehealth, the various roads (and struggles) of physician entrepreneurship, creating a healthier environment for alternative payment models (bundles, capitation, P4P) to succeed, the importance of policy and legislative advocacy, and successful implementations of technology by health systems from an informatics lens. 

*Telehealth Innovators Challenge Judging*
I was honored to be 1 of the judges of the final round as 11 startups across specialty telemedicine, remote monitoring, women's health, patient experience, and care solutions pitched in 3-mins slots. My go-to questions were "what's the pricing, how are you acquiring customers, and how are you different from competitors?" 

Congrats to winners:
• Kwamane D. Liddell, JD, MHA, BSN at ThriveLink (telephonic social program enrollment)
• Ryan A. Grant, MD, MS, MBA, FAANS at Vori Health (interdisciplinary virtual MSK care)
• Eric Dy at Bloomlife Inc (maternal health home monitoring)
• Noel Khirsukhani at Andor Health (hospital genAI and virtual nursing)
• Tero-Pekka Alastalo at CardioSignal by Precordior (heart disease remote monitoring) 

Thanking AMA innovation leadership Margaret Lozovatsky, MD, FAMIA, Stacy Lloyd, Amanda Azadian, Jasmine J. Thekkekara and others for organizing these meetups and sessions.

If you're interested in understanding the energy transition on the ground in one of the world's densest and most energy constrained regions, New York City could use your skills. Con Edison's new Distribution System Innovative Planning and Analytics group will be digging into the complex interactions between energy efficiency, distributed solar and batteries, building electrification, electric vehicles and demand management, and their effect on the electric, gas and steam systems. We need to keep the grid reliable and affordable while simultaneously rebuilding it to support New York's ambitious climate targets.

We are hiring several Senior Specialists who will help develop new forecasting and modeling tools to better understand the massive changes already underway. If you have a background in energy, engineering or urban planning and strong data and organizational management skills, please reach out. Experience in electric and gas distribution systems, distributed energy resources, and energy efficiency and demand management programs preferred.

 Applications close May 31!

Here is the full 60 MINUTES segment from tonight 

The work they showed represents the ongoing efforts of many, many people and organizations.  There’s only so much they can cover in 15 minutes.  We had a long conversation about how #ESOPs represent our best shot at creating a more balanced economic system.  We also discussed the specific legislative support we need to make ESOPs much more common, particularly among larger businesses - but that understandably hit the cutting room floor as policy is probably pretty bad TV.  But you can check out the website for Expanding ESOPs for a preview.  And please stay tuned for developments on our legislative push.  Imagine how different our economy, and our country, would be if more workers owned a slice of their companies.  The potential impact on wealth for workers, financial literacy, employee engagement, employee quit rates, and productivity is massive 

Also pls check out Ownership Works for information about and updates on the broader employee ownership movement underway.  The team at OW is doing a lot of amazing work 

Lastly, a huge thank you for all the support and kind notes.  We’ve got a long way to go but at least we’re on the journey…

column7:
Today, I'll be highlighting another talented member of our Walmart Health central operations team.

Janice MacKenzie was minding her own business as our Walmart Care Clinic provider relations lead when Shannon Borkowski asked she and I to take on the task of standing up a call center for Walmart Health.  I had managed a call (dispatch) center in the past, but admittedly neither of us knew what we were doing.

Janice learned quickly, and I worked feverishly to stand up infrastructure, she took on the task of developing processes and procedures.  Janice would go on to become the call center leader.  We affectionately named the call center "Care Center", because we believed that for many patients, that first interaction was where there care would begin. 

Janice, along with her partner in crime, Michelle Wise, has been a fantastic leader for the Care Center.  Under her leadership, the Care Center has gone from a standard call center operation taking a few dozen calls a day, to a center that not only was managing 15,000 inbound calls per week (with a 25% appointment conversion rate), but also managed:

- 12,000 outbound calls per week
- Virtual dental treatment coordination
- Centralized patient referrals
- Medicare Advantage outreach
- New employee systems onboarding
- Centralized PO/Invoice Processing
- Soft collections

These leaders motivated their team to do incredible things!

Janice is a curious and dedicated leader.  Her care for her team is unwavering.  I would go into battle with Janice (and Michelle) any day of the week.

If you have opportunity to add either of these ladies to your talent pool, you will not be disappointed.

Nurses have a very special place in my heart!

My mother was a nurse.
My daughter is going to college to be a nurse.
So many friends are nurses.
Some very special mentors were nurses.
And, I get to work with over 4,500 of the very best nurses at Cone Health!

Happy National Nurses Week - the world, truly, is a better place because of all that you do! 🫶

#NationalNursesWeek2024 #ABetterWorld #Impact #Commitment #Nursing #ThankANurse

Thank you to Edison Electric Institute (EEI) for having AES at EEI's 8th Annual Global Electrification Forum (GEF). Our CEO and President, Andrés Gluski, participated in a discussion with EEI’s Lawrence Jones, during the 'Global Circuit Exchange' segment, highlighting the significant role of innovation in meeting the world's future energy needs. Recently, I attended one of the best nights of the year -- the Make-A-Wish® Connecticut annual Evening of Wishes Gala. There were several moments during the night that stood out. I got to meet a special young lady with cystic fibrosis who wished to make memories with her family, receive a pop-up camper on stage!!! She was awestruck and vowed to hunt Big Foot. Or, when a fellow former Board member and pediatric physician spoke of the power of a wish buoying spirits as patients fight illnesses. I had a lump in my throat hearing from several of her former patients and wish kids, who are now adults, speak about her impact. One person can truly make a HUGE difference! 

It was extra special to celebrate Make-A-Wish® Connecticut with several of my wonderful teammates -- thank you, Julian Andreas Hannush Suzanne Klotz Kelly Cole Molly Minerly Dawn Romberg!

There are still hundreds of kids in Connecticut waiting for their wishes but the generosity of so many that night will help close the gap.

column7:
Question - Which fintech companies are actually interested in hiring people over the age of 50?

Through Fintech Takes, I get to know a lot of people who are looking for a new role. 

These folks span the gamut. 

Some are trying to get their first job in financial services or make their first jump to a new company. 

Some have 5-15 years of experience and are looking to climb up to the next rung on the ladder.

And some of them have 15-30 years of experience or more. Obviously, these folks are older (generally 45-70), and their resumes are more likely to include stops at banks or traditional bank technology vendors. 

This last group has, by far, the most difficult time getting jobs at fintech companies. 

And it's not just early-stage startups, where there might be a legitimate mismatch on expectations regarding compensation or work/life balance. It's later-stage and public fintech companies too!

This is baffling to me. Obviously, it's not a stated policy at these companies to not hire anyone over a certain age (that would be illegal). However, the anecdotal evidence (and I have a lot of it at this point) has convinced me that this is a real thing.

I mention this for two reasons:

1.) As the overlap between fintech and banking increases, the value of employees with more financial services experience increases as well. Fintech companies of all sizes should be critically examining their candidate sourcing and evaluation processes in order to ensure they aren't missing out on opportunities to hire these folks.

2.) If you work at a fintech company and are legitimately interested in hiring some of these folks, let me know. I am happy to add your company to the list of places I'll recommend moving forward!

column7:
Pay people what they deserve 💵, it'll cost you more if you don't!

Employee: "I'd like to be considered for a 15% raise. My performance over the years has been consistently at the top, I'm managing people and putting in place processes & standards even though I'm not a manager."

Company: "We can manage a 2.5% increase."

Employee: "I appreciate it but I do have another offer with a 20% raise, I don't want to leave, is there anything you can do to come close to matching."

Company: "Unfortunately not. Our hands are tied."

Employee: "Thank you, I appreciate the effort, but I'll have to move on."

This scene plays out all too often, unfortunately.

As a matter of fact, I'm in Spain 💃 at a conference and a brilliant Performance Engineer just walked me through a very similar scenario at his startup (shocker, it happens both at enterprise and startups). I hear about this issue constantly. It's baffling how companies will balk at fair pay for their standout employees but will pay over the odds for external hires when their stars leave.

Does this strategy ever truly pay off? NO! The cost of losing an irreplaceable team member goes far beyond the financial—they take with them invaluable knowledge, experience, and spirit! ⚡

The math is simple: paying well is cheaper than replacing excellence.

Why wait until it's too late to recognize the value of your best people? Pay what they deserve, not just what you think you can get away with. Even if it means you have to fight for an off cycle exception, just do it!

#Leadership #HumanResources #EmployeeRetention #PayFair #dataanalytics #ai #engineering #engineer

We are SO excited to unveil our partnership with New Relic and our membership of the Secure Developer Alliance. 

Our industry is still very early in understanding how to secure our developers.  Our first step in the alliance will be focused on education — where we’ll be working with Gigamon, Lacework, Aviatrix, and Opus Security to publish:

 - Best practices for implementing and managing observable DevSecOps processes and compliance
 - Guidance on using technologies and tools conducive to the adoption of observable DevSecOps
 - Requirements, benefits, and approaches to DevSecOps for application security

Beyond training, we expect to share more news about technology integrations between New Relic / FOSSA to tie build-time and runtime vulnerability insights together for developers. 

As Krystle Portocarrero summarizes in our announcement: "Together we’ll offer a seamless, integrated experience that empowers developers to innovate in the cloud and confidently leverage the full spectrum of open-source software to accelerate their projects while maintaining a strong security posture."

New Relic is leading the pack on innovating in how observability can distill the signal out of noise coming from cloud security tooling.  I encourage everyone to try New Relic Vulnerability Management and follow the SDA to see what is possible.

Huge thanks to our many friends at New Relic that made this possible — Krystle Portocarrero, Oren Ben-Shaul, Manav Khurana, Ashan Willy, Peter Pezaris.  Excited for what’s next!!

Today, I'm highlighting one of the newest members of our Walmart Health central operations team.

If you were to ask people how long Margaret Downs has been part of the Walmart Health team, they would likely say that she's been with us for years.  That's because in the short 11 months that Margaret has been with us, she has made many years worth of impact.

I am proud to say I was part of the hiring team that brought Margaret to Walmart.  It is unequivocally one of the best hiring decisions I have ever been a  part of .  Margaret is wicked smart.  She is a quick learner.  She is tenacious.  She will does not accept failure as an option.  She is everything that you want in a strategic or tactical leader. 

We hired Margaret to help drive success in our new sites.  That said, as we were in a lull between last year's site launches and this year's, we gave Margaret other work to do.  It did not matter if we asked her to lead a project team, or tackle a complex business case analysis, Margaret rose the challenge.

Margaret once told me that she applied for 41 positions at Walmart before we hired her.  To that, I saw 41 Walmart hiring managers' losses were our gain.  As Margaret looks for what's next, I say to my Walmart colleagues, DO NOT BE THE NEXT LEADER who passes of the opportunity to keep Margaret Downs in the family.  If you're not a Walmart leader, this is talent you should strongly consider adding to your organization.

I don't know what the future hold for me, but the one thing I know for certain is that if I have opportunity to bring Margaret Downs along, I absolutely will.  Good luck being the person that beats me to the punch!!

Thank you GitLab for helping me maximize the fleeting time I have with all three of my precious kiddos, and thanks to Edmond Chan and Reshmi Krishna for making it possible for me to disengage from work and focus on family.

Today, I'm highlighting one of the newest members of our Walmart Health central operations team.

If you were to ask people how long Margaret Downs has been part of the Walmart Health team, they would likely say that she's been with us for years.  That's because in the short 11 months that Margaret has been with us, she has made many years worth of impact.

I am proud to say I was part of the hiring team that brought Margaret to Walmart.  It is unequivocally one of the best hiring decisions I have ever been a  part of .  Margaret is wicked smart.  She is a quick learner.  She is tenacious.  She will does not accept failure as an option.  She is everything that you want in a strategic or tactical leader. 

We hired Margaret to help drive success in our new sites.  That said, as we were in a lull between last year's site launches and this year's, we gave Margaret other work to do.  It did not matter if we asked her to lead a project team, or tackle a complex business case analysis, Margaret rose the challenge.

Margaret once told me that she applied for 41 positions at Walmart before we hired her.  To that, I saw 41 Walmart hiring managers' losses were our gain.  As Margaret looks for what's next, I say to my Walmart colleagues, DO NOT BE THE NEXT LEADER who passes of the opportunity to keep Margaret Downs in the family.  If you're not a Walmart leader, this is talent you should strongly consider adding to your organization.

I don't know what the future hold for me, but the one thing I know for certain is that if I have opportunity to bring Margaret Downs along, I absolutely will.  Good luck being the person that beats me to the punch!!

After forty years with Mars, Eric Minvielle, our Global Vice President for People & Organization (Mars Chief Human Resources Officer) is set to retire at the end of the year. 

Eric has had a remarkable journey at Mars since joining in France, in 1984. During his impressive career with the business, Eric led various business functions across all continents (except Antarctica), moving 12 times and living in five countries. Eric leaves a legacy of making Mars a place people want to join, stay and grow. He helped the business expand into what it is today, leading through complex changes, uncertainty and acquisitions. One of his most notable contributions was the role he played in the acquisition of Royal Canin, a business unit he subsequently ran in the Americas. We are incredibly grateful for all that Eric has done to advocate for our Associates and help our business grow, always using the collective strength of the Mars Five Principles. 

I am also very pleased to share that we are appointing Rebecca Snow as Eric’s successor. Rebecca is particularly passionate about fostering a culture of belonging and creating sustainable growth through people development. She brings great perspective and sets high standards for intellectual curiosity and personal accountability. I am excited about welcoming Rebecca to the Mars Leadership Team.

Eric will be with the company through end of year to ensure a best-in-class transition. I will miss working with Eric but I’m lucky to have him as a lifelong friend, and I will certainly cheer to that!

#ProudlyMars

Thrilled to have participated in a fantastic panel discussion at #CLEANPOWER24 today. We tackled the critical issue of messaging clean energy projects effectively and engaging stakeholders in the communities we serve.

A key takeaway: local #opposition is increasingly organized, and #misinformation can be a significant hurdle. This underscores the need for strong, targeted communication strategies that build trust and highlight the (shared) value proposition of clean energy.

But beyond communications strategies, there's no replacement for #humanconnection. Active listening, empathy, and understanding (+adaptation) are essential for building genuine support.

I'm thankful to my The AES Corporation colleagues who cheered me on today and inspire me every day. Opportunities like this are a celebration of their hard work on the front lines, empowering communities as we deploy the energy of tomorrow. While I may be on stage, the spotlight truly belongs to my amazing team.

This conversation carries on. I'll be continuing to beat the drum for the value of in-person engagement and socially + environmentally conscious development.

Thanks to my fellow panelists for a lively discussion. Rosanna Maietta Josh Lahey Lori Lodes Emily Domenech

column7:
Walmart Health's recent announcement has led to much Monday-morning quarterbacking. While there have been many failed retail health attempts, I think this one is different. In this case, David Carmouche, MD, is a very talented leader who truly understands healthcare and how to build successful programs. At least, as successful as a program can be given the real problem. Instead of discussing how the balloon could have or should have been squeezed differently, let's talk about the actual underlying problem: unit economics of a quality patient-provider encounter.

1. The foundational problem with providing accessible and affordable healthcare is that the unit economics are unfavorable, even with Walmart's buying power and low price savvy. 

2. This dynamic will only change once there are genuine ways to improve clinical efficiency (productivity + quality), which requires clinically driven technological disruption of our healthcare delivery system. 

3. When that happens, we will have unit economics that enables accessible and affordable healthcare. 

Until then, we are just squeezing different parts of the balloon and wondering why something always breaks.

Fun news: I’m excited to share that I started last week as a Group Vice President in the Travel & Hospitality industry vertical of Publicis Sapient! As an Executive Client Partner, I will be accountable for some of the firm’s largest clients, and collaborating with amazing folks in leading growth and transformation programs. 

Many of you know I’m passionate about meaningful and profitable innovation. This role will certainly embrace that passion by integrating Publicis Sapient’s strategy, product, experience, engineering, and data/AI capabilities (known collectively by the cheeky but handy acronym, SPEED). I couldn’t work any other way. 

After exploring many potential options — going industry-side again,  bringing a human-centered growth capability to private equity, launching a startup, or even being stridently independent — Publicis Sapient felt like the right blend of smart folks, a challenger mindset, and an innovative culture where I would thrive. 

Many thanks to the friends and colleagues who’ve lent their perspective as I explored, very notably Sapient colleagues like Abby Godee and J F Grossen (also ex-frogs), Eldridge Doubleday (also ex-Fjord), longtime friend Todd Cherkasky, Ph.D., and Jagdish Ghanshani. And for great reasons that are too numerous to mention, a shout-out to Justin Marshall, Rob Dalton, Eric R West, Graeme Asher, Martha Cotton, Steve Weinswig, Charles Stephens, Élida Cruz, Matt Kamhi, Lindsey Mosby, Ndidiamaka Oteh, Erik Long, Kevin Willer, Betsy Ziegler, Sara Whiteleather, Courtney Brown, Jennifer Kilian, Ebun Onagoruwa, Marin Gjaja, Christopher McNally, Josh Mallamud, Dan McCarthy, Jennifer Zierden Maurer, Jef Fowler, Mike Giansanti, Krista Reeder, Ajay Easo, Carrie Vincent, John Barratt, Andrew Falcon, Richard Tyson, Amanda Kranz, Dave Sonders, and Adam Caplan. I’m sure I’m missing someone, but I appreciate you all.

Gracias a todos for taking part in this great session! 

Led by Carlos Beltre, Head of DEI for Global Technology at JPMorgan Chase & Co., Dan Domenech, the Chief Talent Officer at Hewlett Packard Enterprise, shared invaluable insights on fostering diversity and nurturing the next generation of Hispanic leaders. His passion for talent development and commitment to inclusivity shone through as he discussed strategies for creating a robust executive pipeline. 

Key takeaways from the chat included the power of networking, and the need for organizations to embrace develop skills in their employees, having mentors and sponsors that are different than themselves, and using your culture as a strength. 

Domenech also challenged leaders to ask themselves the following questions: 

How are you giving back? 
Who are you mentoring? 
Who are you coaching? 
What is the legacy you wish to create? 

Lastly, Carlos shared with the audience a quote from John C. Maxwell, that “everyone communicates, few connect.”  He encouraged the participants to go beyond connecting via LinkedIn and build relationships that will last. 

Overall, with tips like these, and support from companies, the future for Latino professionals is looking bright! 

#HITEC2024 
#DiversityInLeadership 
#ExecutivePipeline 
#HPE 
#HITECglobal 
#HewlettPackardEnterprise 
#JPMorganChase

I’m Amy, I’m a parent and I don’t belong on LinkedIn.

After taking 5 years out to care for my children, and with my eldest starting school, I was ready to return to the workforce. However, when updating my profile, I felt too afraid to add ‘Full Time Parenting’ to explain my career gap, knowing that it would likely be ignored, rejected or even criticised when seeking employment. So I didn’t. I just removed myself from my LinkedIn, feeling insignificant, worthless and lacking in confidence, as a person who is not welcome in the professional world anymore.

I then started hopelessly searching for school-hour or flexible jobs that would work for my family. Having previously been a teacher, with the aim of becoming a psychologist, I looked for assistant psychologist jobs, as a way to find my identity again. It didn’t help. In fact the job I landed made me feel more confused, as the career I was aiming for before children, wouldn’t work with my new priorities. A three-year, full-time doctorate didn’t seem feasible in the hours I had to play with between the school runs. I’d created a small business whilst my eldest was young, so maybe that was my only option now. I just felt stuck. And I still do.

So after a long-time in limbo, trying to figure out my next steps in my career, I decided to return to LinkedIn. This time, as a mother, who feels proud of the new skills I have gained during this time raising my children.

I have also joined as a woman who wants to raise awareness for the other women who are affected by taking time out of their career by having children. For those who may have been forced out of their previous job and now lack confidence in getting a new one. And for those struggling to return to work, or even apply for jobs, because they cannot find the flexibility they need for their family. 

So this time, I am not only proudly adding 'Full Time Parent' to my profile, alongside a new picture with some of my greatest work, but I am also adding my new business venture, the Five Hour Club: a community to help women return to work after children. 

Not only do I want to raise women up, and recognise the hard work that goes into building a family, but I also want to work closely with employers who also value their previous experience and new skills, so that when they are ready to return to work, there are flexible jobs available that suit their family needs.

Together I believe that we can shape the future of flexible working, because let’s face it, working 9-5 doesn’t work for parents. 

If your career has also been affected since having children, I would love to hear your story. Share below, send me a message, or join our community on Instagram  @fivehourclub.

Yesterday at the HITEC Spring Leadership Summit brought by Hewlett Packard Enterprise Marcelo De Santis led an inspiring discussion featuring a young trailblazer who's paving the way for women in motorsports. Maite Cáceres the first Latina driver in F1, a 19-year-old Uruguayan, defied all odds to achieve her dreams, a common trait among #trailblazers. Marcelo's insights into Maite's incredible journey provided valuable lessons applicable to both our personal and professional lives. Here are a few key takeaways:

1. Breaking Barriers - Demonstrates the power of breaking gender stereotypes in traditionally male-dominated fields, highlighting the importance of diversity and inclusion.
 
2. Creating Movements by being the First- Emphasizes the impact of individual actions in sparking broader change and inspiring others to follow suit.

3. Balancing Innovation and Intuition - Underscores the balance between using data to continue to innovate while highlighting the importance of authenticity and intuition in decision-making, showcasing the irreplaceable role of genuine human judgment.

4. Being a trailblazer can feel isolating at times - While success is shared with the team, moments of defeat can be solitary. Having a strong support system is crucial for those times when you feel alone.

5. Resilience and Pursuing Dreams - Illustrates the resilience required to pursue dreams despite challenges, emphasizing the message that it's never too late to follow one's passions and achieve success.

6. Legacy and Gratitude - Reflects on the importance of feeling fulfilled and grateful for support received, emphasizing the significance of acknowledging and appreciating the contributions of others.

7. Confidence and Self-Belief - Underscores the importance of self-belief and perseverance in overcoming obstacles and achieving personal growth.

#WomenTrailbrazers
#BeTheFirst

I am increasingly worried that instead of addressing systemic challenges we're choosing to direct our ire on personas (e.g., zero-interest PMs).

I understand Casey Winters's statement (and have spoken with him about it), and I understand Ed Biden's sentiment. But...

Someone hired those PMs. Someone funded those companies. Someone set expectations for those PMs. A leader benefitted (or didn't from their work). Someone had the job to mentor those PMs, and share business context and the strategy (assuming one even existed). Zero-interest rates impacted their companies, and may have in turn set expectations for their roles. This makes it about the PMs vs. the perverse incentives in companies during zero interest rates.

Also creeping into these descriptions are character judgements on individuals ("Don't feel accountable"). Do we really believe there is some epidemic of people who don't feel accountable vs. environments where accountability is increasingly unsafe, unhealthy, or otherwise?

These statements are giving a get-out-of-jail card to people presiding over  (and shaping) these environments.
