column7:
SUPPOs on Littoral Combat Ships 

Flash from the Commander, NAVSUP, and Chief of Supply Corps
9 MAY 2024

I am excited to announce that first tour Supply Corps officers will now have an opportunity to serve as department heads onboard littoral combat ships (LCSs).

As Navy missions have evolved, so too has the LCS. The platform is equipped with long range, precision naval strike missiles that can seek and destroy enemy ships at great distance.  LCSs were originally designed to meet the Navy’s urgent requirement for shallow-draft vessels to operate in the littorals, countering growing asymmetric threats like coastal mines or diesel submarines.  Mission modules give LCSs tremendous flexibility and increasing lethality.

We’re looking to send six ensigns to LCSs over the next year.  The training pipeline will be similar to other existing Independent Duty BQC billets, where candidates will attend Supply Officer Department Head Course (SODHC) immediately following graduation.  We’ll follow up this formal training with immersive stops at the TYCOM and LCS Squadron before reporting for duty.

It’s rare we get an opportunity to expand our footprint at sea, but one that we relish with enthusiasm.

I am pleased to announce our first SC LCS Suppo is ENS Kwame Kusi.  ENS Kusi will report to USS Charleston (LCS 18) out of San Diego and was hand selected out of the most recent BQC class to fill this critically important new DH assignment.

K.W. EPPS
RADM, SC, USN

#NavySupplyCorps

What a fast-paced and engaging talk on Accelerating Diversity! 

We heard from Maite Cáceres, the 19-year-old Uruguayan trailblazer who is poised to become the first Latina driver in Formula 1. Despite being one of the few sports in the world where men and women can compete together, no woman has raced in F1 – the highest level of motorsport – since the 1970s. 

She has shown that she isn’t just racing cars; she is racing towards inclusivity, shattering long-standing records and preconceptions as the first Uruguayan to compete on the international Formula racing stage and the only female driver from Latin America in the circuit. 

As an engaged audience member made note of Maite’s accomplishments, “if they can see it, they can be.”  Maite’s wins are a win for all women, as she has made history and opened doors for others to follow. 

Maite also signed the gloves and the helmet she used in her race! Both will be auctioned in the fall HITEC gala, with proceeds benefitting the The HITEC Foundation . Don’t you want a chance to own gloves and a helmet from the future 1st Latina Formula 1 champion? 

#MaiteCaceres 
#F1 
#DiversityInMotorsport 
#WomenInRacing 
#Formula1 
#TechInRacing 
#BreakingBarriers 
#HITECglobal 
#HewlettPackardEnterprise

Another unique experience at the HITEC Leadership Summit.

column7:
Wow! What a privilege to be in Houston at Hewlett Packard Enterprise this week for the HITEC Emerging Executive Program and Spring Summit! Thank you to my leadership team and Bank of America for the opportunity to engage in a truly special program. My heart is full of gratitude, reflection and inspiration! There were so many impactful moments, some of which included:
- Hearing from and connecting with Nellie Borrero, a fearless Boricua from the Bronx, who built a successful 35-year career in Corporate America based on authenticity and claiming her space. I am so excited to read her new book “Unwavering: Rejecting Bias, Igniting Change, Celebrating Inclusion.”
- Meeting and connecting with Yamila Harris, who made me feel warm and at home, leaning in to my childhood growing up in Miami, sharing her personal stories and how she inspires her team to adopt a growth mindset. I am impressed by her tenacity and accomplishments, and aspire to lead in the way she does. 
- Listening to some amazing speakers and published authors like Marcelo De Santis and David Olivencia who shared their journey and the art of storytelling. There is value to being vulnerable, not only to see how far we’ve come, but share our stories with others to inspire and educate.
- Hearing from and meeting Maite Cáceres, who is poised to become the first Latina driver in Formula 1 motorsports. At the age of 17 she became the only Latina to be accepted into the F1 Academy. She is challenging the status quo, breaking barriers, and carving out her own path. Proud and inspired to learn from her and look forward to following her journey! 
Last and most importantly, it was incredible to be in a room full of 500+ Hispanic/Latino Senior Leaders, everyone with a different background and story, from different countries and islands, all with the same mission to #pushupandpullup and create connections that embrace us all as #familia. HITEC is “one-of-a-kind” and I’m so grateful for all of the new friends I’ve made. A special shout out to Catalina Caro, Rebeca Trujillo, MBA, Michael Irizarry, and so many others for your charisma and camaraderie. To the HITEC Staff and Board, and to the Bank of America HITEC delegation, thank you for your continuous push up, connections and support!

column7: I connected with a former leader the other day. He was a frustrating person to work for because he’s incredibly smart and has high expectations for himself and others. I never thought I was living up to what he expected. I definitely acted like a brat - a lot. It’s a wonder he kept me around. Since I left that role, I’ve realized how much of an outlier he was - I have never encountered another person who was so on top of his craft. He has literally shaped how I have approached the rest of my career. He graciously took a call from me and shared some of his new passions. I got to tell him how much I learned from him. He told me a couple things about me that I had forgotten. And while he shared a bunch of interesting ideas he has about A I,  what I learned last week was people can be gracious and kind and humble and helpful. I am trying to put that into the world, too.

column7:
“Lindley’s legacy lives on.” A humbling headline if ever there was one.
 
For those who have been following Lindley Center at Washington and Lee University since it was announced a year ago, I’m happy to share a progress report.
 
Just last weekend, we received an incredible boost from Lindley’s classmates in the class of 1999. They generously made the center’s construction their 25th reunion class project, exceeding every benchmark they set for donations. In total, they raised over $1.4 million dollars… an inspiring sum, dedicated to the memory of a truly inspiring person. All of us involved in this project from the Spaht Family Foundation — my parents, brother, and brother-in-law — are humbled by her class’s generosity.
 
W&L holds a special place in the hearts of us Spahts — not just as the alma mater of my late sister, but as the now-home of my eldest daughter. When the Lindley Center is completed in fall of 2025, Eliza will be entering her senior year. She and her classmates will be able to use Lindley as a resource for their own physical and mental wellness — just as so many of her loved ones and patients did in life. 
 
Lindley’s legacy lives on indeed.

We are thrilled to announce Tauana McDonald FACHE as the new President and Chief Executive Officer of Mount Carmel Health System, effective July 1, 2024. Tauana brings a wealth of experience to the role, having joined Trinity Health in 2003 and has served in numerous leadership positions, most recently as the President and Chief Operating Officer of Mount Carmel Grove City.

Tauana is the first African American woman to lead as president and CEO in the 138-year history of Mount Carmel, marking a historic milestone for health leadership in Central Ohio. Her dedication to excellence and a values-driven approach have been instrumental in transforming our health system, especially during critical times of stabilization and growth.

As we welcome Tauana into her new role, we look forward to her continued leadership and commitment to advancing our mission and serving the Central Ohio community. Join us in congratulating Tauana on this well-deserved appointment!

column7:
35k seniors lost their insurance because of Walmart Health and UnitedHealthcare.

Just wait 'til 2025 (well actually AEP this fall) same story, different names and this time I'm guessing it could be hundreds of thousands that have to find a new plan. HCC v28 is proving as lethal to Medicare Advantage as the Balanced Budget Act was in the late ‘90s. 

I dug into the Medicare enrollment data and was honestly surprised. I couldn’t find any Walmart Flex enrollees in the 2024 data. I started to wonder if my hypothesis of last week that the bigger reason Walmart Health made such an abrupt departure was because of their Medicare Advantage risk. 

Imagine my surprise when I found that there were actually close to 35k enrollees in Walmart Flex MA plan in July of last year. Admittedly I thought it would be a few thousand. 35k is impressive for the first year MA plan in 2 states, even a co-branded Medicare Advantage offering. But it’s a risky proposition - not just because you may not have the acumen to design a profitable product, manage the population well early on but there is also that pesky little thing called risk score that can wreak havoc on that first year of being an MA plan. 

I’m making a whole slew of assumptions here (so forgive me if you know the details and I'm wrong) BUT after modeling some things this morning I've affirmed my stance that the financial risk of these 35k lives dwarfs the FFS revenue mix of business issues that certainly existed and many have highlighted. It also sheds more light on the complexities and nuances of generating meaningful profit as a primary care clinic, especially one you are trying to scale quickly. 

The devil is in the details. Managing lives is HARD. I have so much more to say, this might warrant a detailed write-up. Oh and we will talk about this and more next Friday with our actuarial friend Colby Schaeffer on our first Live edition of The Reverse Mullet Healthcare Podcast - more info to come...

Preston Alexander Blake Madden Matthew Holt Feby Abraham (just to name a few) - I think you will find this interesting.

column7:
There is something awe-inspiring about looking out from the stage of a giant ballroom and seeing thousands of energy thought leaders and innovators, all assembled in one place. My fellow engineers and I gathered this week, for the IEEE Power & Energy Society bi-annual conference, led by Shay Bahramirad, in our collective quest to build solutions to the biggest problems we face today.

It gives me great hope when I think about the strength of this community of talented, dedicated engineers and energy professionals all over the world. My good friend and recently retired Southern California Edison (SCE) executive, Erik Takayesu, kicked off the event, welcoming the crowd who traveled great distances from more than 70 countries. I had the honor of taking the stage after Erik. I shared how we find ourselves in a time of convergence of both growing challenges and maturing advantages that, taken together, can help us unlock the solutions to the issues we wrestle with every day. 

In addition to our guests from around the world, I was so impressed with our robust team of SCE volunteers who have worked behind the scenes for two years, allowing our company to host this special event. Too many to list here, I do want to recognize Manuel Avendaño Mora, Abder Elandaloussi ,PE, MSEE, MBA, Ana Hafiz, Analene Arellano, Editha Toms, CMP, Gianela Gozalo, MBA, Jad Farah, MBA, P.E., Laura Leung Koizumi, Reba Liggett, Tinamarie Loza and the dozens of others for making possible this week of connection, information sharing, and inspiring collective problem solving.

column7:
On Friday, my dear wife Ashley Bryant was promoted to Partner (well, actually, Principal) at #pwc, capping a decade of her excellent work on some of the company’s most high-profile and consequential matters and marking the beginning of her journey among the firm’s leaders. 

There is not enough space here to convey how amazing of an accomplishment this is—particularly while raising two young children—and even the deeply kind sentiments from Zachary Stern, Patrick Delaney and Patty Ferrick Brandt at last week’s ceremonies don’t fully do it justice. All I can add is that since I have known her, she has been a daily role model for me on how to be a better law firm lawyer and in-house counselor. She works tirelessly so that her advice feels effortless; she stresses fine details so that she can speak confidently; she is calmest when things are the most chaotic. 

155 folks were elevated alongside Ashley last week, but none are more deserving of the honor. And given the recent trend of diss tracks, I’m happy to go on wax and take on anyone that argues otherwise!

As a healthcare leader deeply devoted to enhancing access and equity within our industry and for the communities we are so privileged to serve, I draw profound inspiration from the enduring legacy of the National Association of Health Services Executives (N.A.H.S.E.). For over half a century, this organization has stood as a symbol of unwavering commitment to reshaping healthcare and championing the well-being of communities nationwide.

My connection to NAHSE runs deep. From receiving a book scholarship as a high school senior, which set me on an unforeseen path towards a career in healthcare, to founding a chapter in Connecticut early in my career, to having spent these last few formative years in St. Louis serving as part of one of its founding chapters, NAHSE has been a guiding force every step of the way. 

It fills me with pride to celebrate the legacy of Morris Henderson, who led what is now CareSTL Health, for playing a pivotal role in establishing this esteemed organization. The founders’ vision and dedication laid the groundwork for an association that continues to thrive and make a tangible impact to this day. And now, returning to the N.A.H.S.E. Connecticut chapter I helped establish, I am brimming with excitement and determination to propel NAHSE's mission and vision forward.

One of the most striking attributes of NAHSE is its ability to cultivate a dynamic community that spans all stages of professional development. Whether individuals are just starting out on their educational journey, navigating the complexities of early-career growth, or driving organizational change as seasoned executives, NAHSE offers a supportive network where aspirations are nurtured and connections flourish. The annual spring event serves as a vibrant gathering, uniting professionals from diverse backgrounds with a shared goal of catalyzing positive chang and I’m grateful to have been part of it. 

At the core of NAHSE's mission lies a steadfast commitment to promoting health equity. Through advocacy and action, NAHSE empowers its members to not only excel in their individual roles but also contribute to the broader objective of fostering a more equitable healthcare landscape. These efforts extend far beyond institutional boundaries, touching the lives of countless individuals within communities.

The ongoing dedication of the NAHSE STL chapter to advancing health equity initiatives, such as amplifying the Bias Time Out, exemplifies the enduring spirit of NAHSE. I’m excited to be speaking about the Bias Time Out Tool at our June 4 symposium. Details coming soon!

#NAHSE #HealthEquity #CommunityImpact #CycleBreakers #NextGenLeaders #Dedication #Inspiration
April Mickens Jolly Michelle M. Heavens MHA, BSN, RN, FACHE Dr. Ekene Ejimofor DNP. RN. MSHCM Ibukun Afon, MSHA, RN Dr. Marissa H. Lindsey Erb, MBA, MHA

When we first introduced the food as medicine group medical visits, I imagined the possibility of providing our patients with a bag of produce during each session. Year and a half later, our partners at Desert Mission food bank transformed that vision into reality!

Today marks the kickoff of our produce prescription pilot program at HonorHealth led by Anne Costa and her team. The produce comes from local small farms, including many BIPOC farms across Arizona.

Our office was the first location to receive the produce. Patients collected it, and afterward, we gathered in the group space to empower and educate one another with shared wisdom during our food as medicine group medical visit . We even prepared a salad using the fresh ingredients. Some patients took inspiration from this and created beautiful recipes of their own! 

I extend my heartfelt appreciation to Denise Coventry MS, RD, IFNCP our exceptional dietitian, for consistently sharing her wealth of knowledge on nutrition with our food as medicine groups. Her insights enrich our understanding of the crucial relationship between food and health.

This experience encourages us to pause and reflect on the notion of food as medicine, urging us to reimagine and reclaim our health.

#integrativehealth #foodasmedicine #groupmedicalvisit #healthequity #sdoh #honorhealth

As we approach #MothersDay this weekend, I found myself reflecting – with gratitude – on the relationship I have with my mom. She’s served as a role model for me in more ways than one. 

While growing up, my mom experienced tremendous hardship and tragedy, losing both her biological father and then her stepfather. When she was a toddler, her biological father passed away, resulting in her mother (my grandmother) placing her in an orphanage for five years as she was unable to care for three young children. Later when my mom was in middle school, her stepfather passed away of cancer. 

As my grandmother became ill, my mom – a teenager at the time – found herself becoming a caregiver for her younger brothers.

Despite all of these obstacles, my mom managed to become the first in her small high school to attend the top university in Taiwan.

And she managed to then attend an Ivy League graduate school in the United States! 

I want to thank my mom for teaching me life lessons:

➡️ Always be there to support those in your care in both the good and tough times

➡️ #Resilience is built through challenges

➡️ Change is constant

➡️ Be positive and believe in possibilities

These lessons can also be applied to leadership.

I hope that my kids will one day thank me for similar life lessons that they have learned from me as a mom.

Happy Mother’s Day, mom. And to my kids, I am so proud of you and grateful each and every day to be your mom!
 
Being a mom is my most rewarding – and at times, the toughest – role that I’ve ever had. ❤️

Happy Mother’s Day to all of the mothers, stepmothers, grandmothers and mother figures out there. To those of you who have lost a mother, my thoughts are with you during this difficult time.

Images:
1. My mother and me
2. My son and daughter

The AES Colombia team's commitment to excellence extends far beyond mere technological advancements, leaving a profound social impact in its wake. 

In 2023, we made significant investments in social initiatives aimed at bolstering agricultural production, fostering entrepreneurship, and promoting self-management. 

Among our proudest achievements is the Ruta del Agua (Water Route) Program, which has delivered over 960,000 liters of water to the Wayúu communities in La Guajira.

Our social initiatives have touched the lives of more than 2,000 individuals across 16 municipalities spanning four departments. Over the course of 2020 to 2023, we implemented a comprehensive river transport plan in La Esmeralda, facilitating connectivity between Macanal's villages and neighboring areas, enriching the lives of over 6,500 people.

Our holistic approach underscores our unwavering commitment to not only advancing energy solutions but also uplifting the communities we serve. I am extremely proud to highlight the groundbreaking efforts of the AES Colombia team, under the leadership of Federico Echavarria. Their work has brought about enduring changes to the country’s people and revolutionized the energy landscape.

Through innovative projects like Jemeiwaa Ka'I in La Guajira, boasting an impressive installed capacity of over 1,000 megawatts, our team continues to lead the charge in renewable energy development.
Together, we are accelerating the future of energy.

Discover more about our community-focused initiatives in the insightful article by Revista Semana: https://t.ly/xYDNV

#AESValues #EnhancingLives #GreatTeam

column7:
Six years ago I joined Domino’s, which at the time was a risk I wasn’t sure I wanted to take.  Uprooting my family, leaving a company I loved for a new job, new schools, church and neighbors, seemed much too difficult.  Looking back, I will forever be grateful for the peaceful feeling my family and I experienced when we decided to take the leap. 

Last fall I was asked to lead HR for all of Domino’s.  It was my dream job, working with an amazing boss, peers, and team for a company I had come to love.  All was wonderful!  Not long afterwards, I made one of the toughest decisions of my life.  My wife and I decided we needed to move back to Utah, which resulted in departing Domino’s and Saline, Michigan - leaving our friends, and new family. 

To many, this move doesn’t make sense.  How could I walk away from all of this?  In the moment, I had similar thoughts.  However, the same peaceful feeling that confirmed to us that moving to Ann Arbor was right, however scary, told us that moving closer to family, now, was where we were supposed to be.  Our three children have never known what it’s like to live around cousins or their grand parents.  Especially at a time when our parents are aging, family has never been more important.

While the last few months have almost been overwhelming, I express my sincere appreciation to my Domino’s and Michigan family.  Informing my boss and great friend, Russell Weiner, tells you a lot about him.  Putting aside his initial shock, the first thing he did was give me a hug and asked how he could help.  I can’t describe how much that still means to me.

And so we move forward as a family, trusting that we can both be guided and comforted through doing hard things that we know to be right.  I am confident in the future, whatever it holds!

column7:
Our Health Tech journey at SeamlessMD has been full of failures:

→ Our first hospital pilot had just 17% patient adoption

→ Changed our company name because too many people - including my co-founder - couldn’t say it properly

→ Couldn’t convince a VC investor to lead our seed round

→ Churned our 1st US customer because we sold the product without getting clinician buy-in (and by then it was too late)

→ Bounced around in research study and grant project purgatory for many years

→ Signed wrong-fit customers because we were desperate to work with anyone (of course it was more work than we expected and of course they eventually churned)

→ Wasted countless hours on stuff that didn’t matter (e.g. a town hall debate over whether a healthcare company should provide “unhealthy snacks” in the office… yes this actually happened)

And yet… we’re still here.

We are living proof that you can make tons of mistakes in Health Tech and still survive.

Just get a little better each day.

And never give up.

#digitalhealth #healthcareinnovation
column16: Vice President of Digital Health Innovations

Today, San Diego Gas & Electric and the Farmers Insurance Open (Century Club of San Diego) hosted nonprofit and philanthropic partners at the Nonprofit Thought Leaders’ Summit - Building Your Organizations People & Culture. 

The goal of the Summit is to curate a space where funders and nonprofit partners can truly engage in meaningful discussion on how to build a better community together, for the benefit of our great region. 
 
In this fourth installment of the series, participants focused on capacity-building topics that support and lift the nonprofit sector, such as staffing, retention strategies, and building and sustaining organizational culture. 

The Summit started with a panel discussion followed by breakout sessions that dug deep into their own organization’s strategic plans for the coming year. 
 
Today’s event provided a unique opportunity to learn and gain insight from each other in a more personal way. I hope these discussions foster the growth of philanthropy in San Diego, aligning with the evolving needs of nonprofits. 

We were honored to have been joined by Danny Kim, PhD, Sr. Director of People, Culture, and Diversity at the San Diego Foundation who moderated today’s discussion with Taylor Mauriello (Harrell), Ph.D., Chief People Officer at MAAC, Christiana Tasto, MA, Executive Director for Nonprofit Solutions and Tony Teravainen PMP CSSBB, CEO and Co-Founder of Support The Enlisted Project (STEP). The panelists discussed how philanthropy can play a significant role in the aspirations of the communities that we serve, and the intersectionality of Value/Mission, Capacities, and Public Support. 
 
I would like to send a big kudos to Shaina Gross, Jennifer Cota and Marvin Ordonez for organizing and curating such a magnificent event for our nonprofit partners. 
 
Lastly, thank you to the Century Club, funders, and all the local nonprofit leaders who participated in this seminar series! We truly hope it was informative, beneficial, and transformative.
 
#SDGEgiving

We loved having the opportunity to celebrate entrepreneurs in Idaho and Utah this month. 
 
Our President and CEO Paul Burdiss offered the keynote address at the U.S. Small Business Administration Utah District’s National Small Business Week Awards ceremony.
 
Edith Gallegos and Alma Lopez of Cakes by Edith received the Minority-Owned Business of the Year. Gallegos immigrated to the U.S. in 1995, making and selling cakes out of her home until it became too small to meet the growing demand for her delicious cakes. They were introduced by Zions Bank's Board Chair Scott Anderson.
 
Zions Bank was proud to receive three awards in recognition of our efforts to provide capital to small businesses: Export Lender, 7(a) Women-Owned and Rural Lender for 2024. 
 
In Idaho, Molly Leadbetter of Meriwether Cider was recognized as the Woman-Owned Business of the Year by the SBA Boise District Office. Leadbetter is the Gem State’s only pommelier and has been instrumental in the growth of this award-winning family-owned business.

Congratulations to all the honorees — we wish you much continued success on your entrepreneurial journey!

Being the #1 Pizza Company in the world means embracing the responsibility to do even more. Our Hungry for MORE strategy lets us do just that. By driving MORE sales and building MORE stores, we can do MORE for others – including raising MORE donations for the children of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. I’m so proud to announce that this week at our World Wide Rally…in front of over 9,000 Dominoids from around the world…we shared our intention to increase Domino’s fundraising goal for St. Jude to $300 million by 2034, the year we mark 30 years of partnership with this lifesaving organization.

One of the many things this will help support is the expansion of the St. Jude Global Alliance. The St. Jude Global Alliance is an effort to improve access to care for children with cancer in every corner of the world and raise global survival rates for six of the most common forms of childhood cancer from 20% to 60% by 2030. This is a big… life changing… inspiring… global effort. Thank you to our team, franchisees and customers. And thank you to our incredible partners at ALSAC/St. Jude.
Amazing opportunity for someone looking to make their mark in the healthcare space. DM me if you are interested in learning more or know someone who might be a good fit.

That’s right — the largest-ever corporate or private financial commitment to a children’s hospital. That’s the generosity and compassion of Domino's.
 
What an honor to be with Richard Shadyac, Russell Weiner and the entire Domino’s family — 9,000 strong — yesterday in Las Vegas for this historic announcement in support of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Domino’s is such an amazing partner to our mission.

Brilliant ideas are rarely born in isolation. That's the power of SE Ventures - by connecting ground-breaking start-ups with Schneider Electric’s in-house expertise and resources, SE Ventures expands the horizons of what's possible and helps to build a #sustainable future through disruptive innovation.

This was the purpose of my visit to Menlo Park last week, where I met with the SE Ventures team and several exciting start-ups to learn about their #innovative technologies and discuss potential areas of #collaboration with Schneider Electric.

It's always striking to me the vast variety and far-reaching benefits of the innovations coming out of Silicon Valley - from using #AI to detect wildfires and streamline sustainable procurement processes, to creating #digital platforms to connect home #electrification contractors or enable organizations to monitor and respond to water risk. The potential for modern technologies to have a positive #impact is endless.

Thank you to everyone I got the chance to meet with during my visit, for your time and insightful conversation, and your ongoing pursuit of the solutions our planet needs. Shannon Miller, Hannes Boehning, Sonia Kastner, @Arvind Satyam, Forest Flager, Zachary Kimball, Rick Klau, Julia Y., Ashwin Dias, José Ignacio S. G., Seyed H. Madaeni, Ph.D.

For the past few years, it’s been my privilege to serve as a volunteer board member for the Frankfort Falcons Football and Cheer Athletic Association. In my role as Director of Scholarships, I’ve had the joy of assisting over 50 alumni in their transition from high school to college by providing them with scholarships.

As my twin daughters, who are cheerleaders for the Falcons, prepare to transition to high school to join their older sister, my time on the board will soon come to an end. It’s been a bittersweet week as I reflect on the last time I’ll have the honor of awarding scholarships to these deserving student athletes. I’m immensely proud of the tradition we’ve upheld, and I’m confident that the scholarship program will continue to thrive under the guidance of the next board member.

Thank you to everyone who has been part of this journey. I look forward to witnessing the future successes of the Frankfort Falcons and the incredible students who pass through its ranks.

column7:
An incomplete list of changes I have experienced since starting Testosterone HRT in November 2020:

👀 Physical:

- A lower voice
- Increasing muscle mass 
- Fat redistribution in my face & body 
- (Some) facial hair 
- My feet have grown so much I've gone up two shoe sizes (weird I know) 
- Increased body hair 

🧠 Non-physical: 

- The ability to look in the mirror and love what I see 
- The motivation to take care of my health and wellness 
- The self-confidence and self-belief to start my own business
- Better relationships with my friends and family because I am happier and calmer
- Significantly improved mental health including a reduction in my anxiety
- The ability to address my issues with alcohol and maintain my sobriety for over three years and counting 
- A new interest in investing in my future
- The capacity to care better for others and be involved in activism and non-profit work to support marginalised communities 

The point? It's not always about the things you can see. 

#Transgender #LGBTQ #PrideMonth #DEI 

Image description: Left image Max on his first day of testosterone therapy in November 2020, he is smiling and wearing black 70s style glasses. Right image Max on 3 year testosterone anniversary in November 2023, he is smiling and wearing round silver glasses. He has a moustache and longer hair.

column7:
I continue to be inspired by our work at HITEC. I strongly believe our work has never been more relevant. Demand for our work continues to soar because major companies recognize that if they want to grow, they need to be able to retain and attract diverse leaders. Companies that have a diverse workforce and diverse leaders outperform those that do not. The Hispanic community continues to be one of the fastest-growing and most economically influential population segment in the US. HITEC brings it all together — Diverse leaders, skilled in technology – helping companies innovate and grow. 

Last week, more than 500 Hispanic technology professionals and executives gathered in Houston for the largest-ever HITEC event. The HITEC Spring Leadership Summit hosted by Hewlett Packard Enterprise brought together the very best in our community - intent on connecting and inspiring, and committed to accelerating the power and impact of Hispanic technology leaders achieving lasting equity from the classroom to the boardroom. 

Coming off last week’s summit, I am both filled with gratitude and energized to advance our work. HITEC is well positioned to help our partners grow and to contribute to the growth of the US and global economy through technology - we are positioned to be the arcHITECs of growth!

Today I had the honor of leading the Fifth Third Day celebrations at our Madisonville Office Building in Cincinnati. This special day at Fifth Third Bank not only highlights our commitment to the community and our customers, but it also showcases the collaborative spirit and dedication of our fantastic teams.

Fifth Third Day is more than just a celebration; it's an opportunity for us to give back and address pressing community issues like food insecurity. By partnering with local organizations like the United Way of Greater Cincinnati, Ronald McDonald House Charities of Greater Cincinnati, and The Society of St. Vincent de Paul - Cincinnati, we're able to make a significant impact and help those in need. 

A huge shoutout to our MOB core team of Lasabra Hyden, Melessa Walker, Beth Fillmore, Kimberly Murray, Jamie Chapman, and Delisha Murray. Your dedication and hard work were instrumental in making today a success. I am truly grateful for your collaboration and support.

Thank you to everyone who participated and helped us move forward in our mission to fight food insecurity. Let’s continue to make a difference, together!

#53Day #53better #FightFoodInsecurity #CommunityImpact

🌟 Celebrating Mother's Day with Deanna Moreno Hernandez. 🌟 

As we honor the incredible women who shape our lives, we shine a spotlight on Deanna Moreno Hernandez, a beacon of strength and inspiration. From humble beginnings in a Mexican 🇲🇽 immigrant family to her current role as a field marketing officer for McDonald's, Deanna's journey embodies the essence of maternal resilience and determination.

In our heartfelt tribute, penned by Ximena N. Beltran Quan Kiu, we delve into Deanna's story of triumph over adversity. Despite facing challenges as a teen mother, she defied expectations and carved out a path to success, fueled by love for her family and an unwavering drive to excel.

Join us in celebrating Deanna's achievements, her unwavering dedication to her children, and her remarkable ascent in the corporate world. Today, and every day, we honor the strength, courage, and boundless love of mothers like Deanna who inspire us to reach for the stars.💐 

Read her inspiring narrative and witness the transformative power of resilience here: https://hubs.la/Q02wBHx00

#HispanicExecutive #SuccessStory #MothersDay #Inspiration

column7: Wishing a very Happy Mother's Day to all of the moms in our lives!

I have been blessed with three extraordinary women who raised me: my Great Grandmarie, who literally fought for my right to vote;  Gammy Biff, an RN who compassionately cared for desperate women in their homes pre-Roe; and my own mom, who planned out my career by sticking me in 4-H speaking competitions by age 9 (due to her own fear of public speaking), which has served me well throughout my career. 

All three raised me to be determined, principled, and courageous. I’m grateful to be their granddaughter and daughter. 

Happy Mother’s Day to all. 

#gratitude #MothersDay
Wishing all a  Happy Mothers day !!

As we put the final touches together for this incredibly important discussion at The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., my bestie was in her last week of preparation for my Goddaughter’s arrival. I thought of her and each of my sister-friends that delivered the greatest little joys in my life. I’m deeply grateful they had safe and healthy deliveries and deeply saddened to also know that an alarmingly high rate of other Black women have had, are having, and will likely have a very different experience. My hope is that as more awareness is raised around Black maternal health, more ACTION will be taken and more SOLUTIONS will be implemented. Our lives and the lives of our future generations quite literally depend on it.

Integrity is getting harder to find.
24 ways to know if you have it:

First, what integrity's not:

Doing what's popular instead of what's right
Acting differently in private than in public
Saying one thing and doing another
Letting fear dictate your decisions
Taking credit for others' work
Valuing success over ethics
Hiding your mistakes
Following the crowd
Turning a blind eye
Making excuses
Blaming others
Staying silent

Integrity is:

Transparency
Ethical behavior
Keeping your word
Acting with courage
Treating others fairly
Owning your mistakes
Respecting confidentiality
Showing respect for others
Admitting when you're wrong
Standing up for what you believe
Refusing to compromise your values
Doing what's right, even when it's hard

In a world that values success at any cost,
integrity is the ultimate success.

➟ It's always doing the right thing.
➟ Not because someone is watching.
➟ But because it's the right thing to do.

Agree? Repost to share this with others ♻️.
And follow Justin Wright for more.

I spent the last couple of days with Leadership Pittsburgh Inc. XL Cohort visiting the state capital in Harrisburg.  We were fortunate enough to spend time here when the house and the senate were in session.  Even more so, Governor Shapiro, Lt Governor Davis, Speaker of the House McClinton, Republican Whip O’Neal, and President Pro Tempore Ward all took time out of the day to talk with us and answer our questions.  Special thanks to Representative Dan Frankel, Chair of the Health Committee, for meeting with a small group of us to discuss legislative matters related to health/healthcare, social determinants of health, equity, and gun control. 

We were able to experience first-hand and spend time in the House Majority Caucus Room (photo with blue/gold ceiling), Senate Majority Caucus Room (photo with green walls), the House floor and the Governor’s Reception Room. 

It was a special, informative and rewarding time and it was well spent!  Thank you to Leadership Pittsburgh and Buchanan Ingersoll & Rooney for the arrangements, and to Highmark Health and Allegheny Health Network for this tremendous opportunity.

Charlotte Keenan Jessica Taylor Debbie Gim Anne Wellde Brad Weinstein John Olson Adele Langton Dorie Smith Caitlin Belt Emily Silver Kristina Shaw Kristen Little Dara DiLeo Adam Ganik Jon Foster Lydia Finnegan Ashley Keenan Will Neaverson Mayo Kaneko Giada Portaluppi, MSc. Roma S. Sanjana Govindan Ritu Farsaiya Ankita Bose Sara E. Rogers Carlos Bernabe Bridget Barry Isha Singh Stephanie Fernandez Maria Najem Alexis Kenworthy Olivia Petas Caroline R. Madison Baptiste

We recently hosted ~170 of our family office clients and friends of the firm from 15 different countries at our annual Apex Global Family Office Symposium in New York City. The day opened up with Sara Naison-Tarajano, global head of Goldman Sachs Apex, who kicked off an impressive line-up of speakers who discussed a range of timely topics, including the evolving macroeconomic and geopolitical landscape, opportunities in venture and growth, what it takes to build a multigenerational family office, and more. Here are a few insights from the sessions:
 
• Michael Rubin, chief executive officer of Fanatics, discussed how constant innovation in business is critical to success. His thought process on ensuring that Fanatics had longevity was simple: “If we're just selling what other people are selling, we have no chance of existing long term. We needed to provide a differentiated experience.”

• John Paul DeJoria, co-founder and chairman of John Paul Mitchell Systems, and co-founder and chairman emeritus of The Patron Spirits Company, shared his secret to making the most of his time: “Pay attention to the vital few. Ignore the trivial many.” 

• Patrick McCurry, partner at McDermott Will & Emery LLP, Eric Naison-Phillips, managing principal of Winged Keel Group, and Cliff Schlesinger, senior wealth strategist for Goldman Sachs Family Office, shared insights on the key considerations in building and sustaining a multi-generational family office. Naison-Phillips discussed how in later generations, there is a critical realization that the responsibility of strong stewardship is on your shoulders. “You have to ingrain that generation to generation, and it has to be a consistent message,” he said.
 
Thank you to everyone who joined us!

Two days ago, on Mother’s Day, my dear friend Crystal Welch, her mother, and her sister were all violently taken from us. I am stunned and consumed with grief, yet grateful for over two decades of friendship and mutual growth. We’ve abruptly been robbed of a true powerhouse—a selfless advocate and changemaker. Today, on my birthday, I am dedicating this space to memorialize her—a brilliant, beautiful soul I have known, trusted, collaborated with, and loved for the last 24 years.

Crystal was a force of nature. As Supervising Attorney and Associate Clinical Law Professor at Mississippi College School of Law, she practiced and taught adoption and youth court law. Here, she created an adoption clinic that transformed many lives and families. She was a revered leader, serving as President of the ACLU of Mississippi and Vice President of the Mississippi Free Press, Immediate Past President of the Board of Directors for the Children’s Advocacy Centers of Mississippi, and a member of the MS Commission on Children’s Justice’s new Website Development Oversight Committee.

Attorney, Professor, Champion, Daughter, Aunt, and my best friend. The thought of going from dozens of daily texts to none is unfathomable. Our friendship began at Bowdoin College, where we discovered a shared spirit of fun, intelligence, and style. Crystal was a discerning connoisseur of words, debate, all things CHANEL, and Hello Kitty. She was a confidante and partner in crime, an irreplaceable friend whose laughter I hope never fades from my memory.

We were supposed to travel to Maine in a few weeks for her Bowdoin Reunion—a trip that will now carry her spirit rather than her presence. The tragic and untimely loss of Crystal, her mother, and her sister in an act of violence has left us numb and heartbroken, reminding us of the fragility of life.

As I grieve for Crystal and her family, I find solace in the immense impact she had on her clients, students, and friends—everyone fortunate enough to know her. Her legacy is not just in the laws she shaped or the students she inspired, but in the love she shared with her family, friends, and little nephew, Dallas.

Though our daily conversations have ceased, her voice will guide me always. Crystal's remarkable life and the devastating circumstances of her passing remind us that we can be forces of change and pillars of support in our communities.

Crystal was a popular influencer on social media and a prominent figure in Jackson's community. Over the past few years, I had urged her to broaden her reach by posting to LinkedIn, believing her unique perspective and insights would be invaluable amidst a sea of noise. Unfortunately, it's now too late for her to do so herself, so I am writing this post for both of us.
column21: I’m in utter shock. Crystal was a wonderful person. What a devastating loss. Tim, I’m truly sorry for your loss.

column7:
As a working Mom, I appreciate the flowers, brunch and "me" time that comes every year with Mother's Day. But let's be honest. It's quickly back to reality on Monday morning, and we're already juggling the week's agenda....dinner menus, sports schedules, band concerts and squeezing in your kiddo's long overdue dentist appointment.
 
Moms are amazing, but they are also exhausted. We need to take all of the Mother's Day gratitude and appreciation and channel it into reimagining the way we support moms at work.
 
We're doing it at Brillect by leading with our value of taking care of people. And that starts with connecting people with careers that fit their lives. For one of our consultants that means taking the summers off. For another, it's taking a short break from consulting to focus on a home renovation project. To others, it's having Fridays off or a workday that ends at 3.
 
But it also means giving people the space to do what they need to do. Not eyeing the clock when someone leaves early or raising an eyebrow when someone arrives 10 minutes late to your morning meeting. It's about trusting people to do their work. And leaders, it also means walking the talk to show our employees we practice what we preach when it comes to flexibility and putting people first. 
 
We're all in the thick of this dance called life, and it's not easy to juggle it all. But when we give each other grace, flexibility and the freedom of having a career that meets you where you're at...I think we start to reclaim that joy we have on Mother's Day all year round.

#worklifebalance #careers #finance #accounting #HR #consulting #mothersday

Looking ahead, I remain fully committed to the Foundation’s work across all our strategies, and to realizing the opportunities we have to continue improving the lives of millions around the world.

Our foundation team is incredibly strong and deeply passionate about our work, and under the leadership of Mark Suzman, and a committed board of trustees, I am confident we will keep making substantial progress on our mission to create a world where every person can live a healthy, productive life.

Never underestimate the power of an encouraging word / act of kindness. 

The hand-crafted certificates, letters, and "record" pictured below were created by my 5th & 6th grade basketball coach, John Fleury.  I'm not here to talk about my love for hoops - I'm here to share the power of going above and beyond for your team members. 

John was a dude that was probably in his 20s when he was coaching a bunch of pre-teens.  He likely wasn't getting paid for his job as our coach.  There were no requirements for him to create custom recognition for his players. 

But he did just that. 
And he made an impact on me that lives on to this day. 

He demonstrated what it looks like to lift others up, to speak into someone that needs it.  The two years I played for him overlapped directly with a time period that I was struggling to deal with my parents' divorce - that team, and his direct support, are two things that enabled me to get thru that season of life. 

John helped channel my emotions into healthy activities and provided stability and feedback when I needed both most.  And, because of that, I seek to do the same for those that I work with within my team. 

I'm thankful that I re-stumbled across these when I did - it's a great reminder to think about ways to wow those that I appreciate. 

How are you bringing recognition and kindness to life in your personal and professional lives? 

Cheers to using our creativity to lift each other up generously and having folks remember our actions 40 years on. 

p.s.  Experiences like this are the reason I coached my kids when they were young.  And why I created similar certificates for every kid on my teams.  :)  I hope at least one of them felt seen in ways that they hadn't before. What a gift! 

#gratefuldude #peopleleadership #speakingintoeachother #encouragement #kindness #lifelongimpact #anyoneelserememberponyhightops? 

Eric Goetsch - look familiar?  :) #blazersforlife

column7:
On nearly every Mother’s or Father’s Day, my girls inevitably ask, “When is Kid’s Day?” To which my husband and I predictably respond, “Every day is Kid’s Day.” But the truth is, I feel like every day is Mother’s Day. Maybe that's because it was hard for me to get pregnant and I can still feel the intense yearning to be a mother, worrying it may stay forever out of reach. I kept my difficulties with fertility out of work conversations for over a decade. But I recently recounted this struggle in a meeting, and I was blown away by the number of people who reached out to share their own experiences. It was such an important reminder of how powerful our relationships at the office can be, both professionally and personally. 

There are days when I feel exhausted, pulled in too many directions, and like I’m not doing any one of my many jobs at work and home well enough. But through it all, I feel deeply grateful that I have the honor to be the mother to these two amazing young women. Thank you to everyone celebrating caregivers of all kinds in our workplaces today, and every day.

A brief update: Earlier this month, I had my last day at Standard AI. Here’s a lightly edited copy of my message to the team:

As you all know by now, I am not big on goodbye’s. So on my last day, let me instead say THANK YOU. Thank you to my teams who I’ve worked side-by-side with, laughed with, almost wanted to cry with (oh, bank crises) and who have made me proud and who I know will continue to make me proud. Thank you to all my fellow Standard peeps who have built great tech, come together as a team and are bringing the next iteration of Standard forward. And thank you to Angie, Dave and Jordan who have been thoughtful sounding boards, true friends and real warriors.

What’s next? I’m looking forward to time off to reconnect with folks, travel and explore, read (including trying to keep up with what’s going on in AI & robotics) and continue investing in and advising start-ups.

#thankyou #startups #nextadventure

It is an honor to announce that I graduated from Clemson University with an M.S. in Packaging Science.

Tailored to my interests and research goals, my master’s program has had a strong emphasis on sustainability and marketing. My research, sponsored by Printpack, compared consumer perceptions to environmental impact realities. With the rise of sustainable initiatives in the packaging industry, my work illuminates the gap between sustainable packaging innovations and consumer sentiments to propose an aligned path forward for future packaging designs. I gained valuable insights into creating life-cycle assessments (LCAs), analyzing material trade-offs, and conducting consumer surveys. It was a privilege to have my research showcased at the Sustainable Packaging Coalition (SPC) Impact conference in April 2024.

I want to extend my sincere appreciation to Andrew Hurley, PhD and my committee, Dr. Billy Bridges, Dr. Duncan Darby, and Dr. Sarah Griffin for supporting me throughout my time as a graduate student. Additionally, thank you to Clemson’s Packaging Science community for its continuous encouragement.

Though it is bittersweet to have completed my time at Clemson, I am eager to apply my knowledge and talents as I join the Newell Brands Packaging Engineering team in Charlotte, NC this summer.

As always, Go Tigers!

Continually thankful for the opportunity to expand my horticulture experience at Pleasant Valley Farm. I’ve grown a number of finish crops this year (freshly transplanted plugs that I grew). 

Growing finish crops is different in some aspects than plug growing, but I tend to think of them like a huge plug tray. Just like plugs, the edges and corners will dry out first. Big difference is how long they take to dry down before they need to be watered again.

I’m happy to share that I’ve completed my Bachelor of Applied Arts and Sciences at University of North Texas with my concentration in Data Analytics.

As I look back on my journey at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, earning my MBA in 2021 was a significant achievement, especially during the unprecedented times of the COVID-19 pandemic. Like many graduates worldwide, I didn't have the opportunity to cross the stage due to restrictions.

However, this year, something special happened. I connected with one of my best friends, Asif Merchant, who was graduating from the same program this year. Despite the challenges life threw at him—torn ACL, Asif and his wife welcoming their beautiful daughter Sophie into the world, and transitioning companies—Asif persevered, excelled, and earned his MBA.

In a random conversation, we joked about walking the stage together, and I decided to reach out to the University about the possibility of walking the stage this year. To my delight, they said yes!

Walking the stage with Asif this past Friday was more than a symbolic gesture; it was a celebration of resilience, friendship, and shared accomplishments.

Congratulations, Asif, on this incredible milestone. Your journey inspires us all to push through obstacles and embrace change. Here's to new beginnings and the exciting adventures that lie ahead. Looking forward to the great things you do. 

#GiesProud #GiesCollegeOfBusiness #UofI #GraduationDay #Resilience #Friendship

Last Thursday, I had the privilege of immersing myself in the wisdom and experiences of incredible leaders from the Top 50 Companies for Latinas to Work for in the United States at the LATINA Style 50 Awards and Diversity Leaders Conference.
 
Since 1998, LATINA Style 50 has been a beacon of excellence, celebrating the achievements of Latinas in the workplace, and this year's event was a testament to the power of diversity and inclusion, bringing together voices from across the country to celebrate progress and inspire change.
 
From thought-provoking panel discussions to dynamic exchanges with corporate leaders, I gained invaluable insights into the journey of Latinas ascending to the pinnacle of success, reinforcing my pride in being a part of Marriott International, a company that doesn't just talk about diversity but actively creates pathways for Latina talent to thrive in leadership roles.
 
Particularly honored to have been able to accept the award for one of the top Hispanic ARGs from the LATINA Style team for our work in 2023, but also share that moment with many leaders from our company and members of our ARG. 
 
Thank you, LATINA Style 50 for creating a platform to celebrate and elevate Hispanic women in the workforce. Together, we're building a brighter, more inclusive future for all.
 
#LATINAStyle50 #MarriottInternational #DiversityandInclusion #Leadership #Empowerment

column7:
Two days ago, on Mother’s Day, my dear friend Crystal Welch, her mother, and her sister were all violently taken from us. I am stunned and consumed with grief, yet grateful for over two decades of friendship and mutual growth. We’ve abruptly been robbed of a true powerhouse—a selfless advocate and changemaker. Today, on my birthday, I am dedicating this space to memorialize her—a brilliant, beautiful soul I have known, trusted, collaborated with, and loved for the last 24 years.

Crystal was a force of nature. As Supervising Attorney and Associate Clinical Law Professor at Mississippi College School of Law, she practiced and taught adoption and youth court law. Here, she created an adoption clinic that transformed many lives and families. She was a revered leader, serving as President of the ACLU of Mississippi and Vice President of the Mississippi Free Press, Immediate Past President of the Board of Directors for the Children’s Advocacy Centers of Mississippi, and a member of the MS Commission on Children’s Justice’s new Website Development Oversight Committee.

Attorney, Professor, Champion, Daughter, Aunt, and my best friend. The thought of going from dozens of daily texts to none is unfathomable. Our friendship began at Bowdoin College, where we discovered a shared spirit of fun, intelligence, and style. Crystal was a discerning connoisseur of words, debate, all things CHANEL, and Hello Kitty. She was a confidante and partner in crime, an irreplaceable friend whose laughter I hope never fades from my memory.

We were supposed to travel to Maine in a few weeks for her Bowdoin Reunion—a trip that will now carry her spirit rather than her presence. The tragic and untimely loss of Crystal, her mother, and her sister in an act of violence has left us numb and heartbroken, reminding us of the fragility of life.

As I grieve for Crystal and her family, I find solace in the immense impact she had on her clients, students, and friends—everyone fortunate enough to know her. Her legacy is not just in the laws she shaped or the students she inspired, but in the love she shared with her family, friends, and little nephew, Dallas.

Though our daily conversations have ceased, her voice will guide me always. Crystal's remarkable life and the devastating circumstances of her passing remind us that we can be forces of change and pillars of support in our communities.

Crystal was a popular influencer on social media and a prominent figure in Jackson's community. Over the past few years, I had urged her to broaden her reach by posting to LinkedIn, believing her unique perspective and insights would be invaluable amidst a sea of noise. Unfortunately, it's now too late for her to do so herself, so I am writing this post for both of us.
It has been an honor hosting HITEC in Houston; thank you Fabiola Corvera-Stimeling for the summary on our fireside chat today #hpe #dei #HITEC #hispanicsintech

Today marks the 10th anniversary of Acxiom acquiring LiveRamp. The part of the journey I’m most proud of in retrospect is the incredible alumni network: today, there’s still a tight network of ex-LiveRampers building thriving businesses; more than half of the first 40 employees are CEOs of startups or executives at larger companies (and several execs in key roles at LiveRamp who joined in the early days). This post walks through the factors that I think led to a thriving "LiveRamp Mafia."

column7: Patty Samar of Chicago, as this year’s Healthcare Hero. Patty worked at Rush Medical Center as an apheresis nurse when she met Kirk, a dialysis patient. Samar befriended Kirk and when she learned that his donated kidney was failing, she helped launch a search campaign to find a live donor. Samar also decided to get tested and when she learned she was a match for Kirk’s kidney donation, Samar did not hesitate to give Kirk the lifesaving gift of one of her kidneys. Sponsored by Aon #RedCrossHeroes

Jacqueline Reed of Chicago is the 2024 Disaster Relief Hero. As a longtime Austin resident and community advocate, Jacqueline spearheaded relief efforts in the aftermath of record-breaking floods that devastated the neighborhood in July 2023. As the chair of the Westside Long Term Recovery Group, Jacqueline mobilized resources and volunteers, which have since helped around 75 homes become habitable. Reed's dedication highlights her lifelong commitment in Austin to building community resilience and supporting those in need. Sponsored by Nicor Gas #RedCrossHeroes

Angela Thompson of Chicago is this year’s Community Impact Hero. 
 
Angela is a devoted Chicago Public School Safety Crossing Guard, stationed on a busy southside corner, who not only impacts the lives of children daily with her kindness and care on the job, but also through her cherished annual holiday toy drive. Over the past 14 years, Angela has organized this heartwarming initiative, initially single-handedly and now with support from her community. Since 2009, her efforts have reached 3,000 families in the Chicagoland area, highlighting her remarkable commitment to spreading love and joy to children. Sponsored by United Airlines #RedCrossHeroes

On my 59th birthday in December 2010 I reached the peak weight of my life and was completely out of shape. I made a life changing decision to work out with a personal trainer, Dez White, and 13 1/2 years later I'm 25 pounds lighter and in the best shape of my life at 72 years old! In addition to boot camps, Dez and I competed in many 5K races and loved the competition. This morning was our last boot camp (burned 1,350 calories) at the present location for The Body Firm Atlanta.

At first, I said I didn't have time for exercise. I was too busy with work. Actually, regular exercise and healthy eating helps me with my work! I'm energized, my mind is clear, stress is gone, and confidence is high from something I did at boot camp that I didn't think I could do. You have one body for your entire life - take good care of it and invest early to have a good quality of life as you get older!

I attended the Milken Institute's #MIGlobal for the first time, where I was lucky enough to partake in a lively conversation about Global Real Estate with Barry Sternlicht, Al Rabil and David Steinbach, moderated by the great Erik Schatzker. I shared our perspective that a real estate recovery is coming into view thanks to the cost of capital coming down and new supply moving sharply lower. 2024 has been busy for our deal teams as we lean into dislocation to capture value in our high conviction sectors, especially logistics, rental housing, and data centers. We’re fortunate to have the capital, scale and insights to help us capitalize on this moment for our clients.

Steve and Sheila Conner of Oak Park are this year’s Education Heroes. Steve and Sheila, motivated by their son Stone's disinterest in traditional math and science education, launched the HEPH Foundation in 2014 to revolutionize STEM learning. Utilizing innovative approaches to learning, such as gaming, sports, and music, the foundation’s materials engage students and foster a lifelong passion for science and technology. Through tailored programs and partnerships with schools in the Chicagoland area and beyond, the Conners have engaged about 20,000 learners in STEM through the program they designed. 
 Sponsored by William Blair #RedCrossHeroes

column7: Chez Smith of Chicago Heights and Venisha Bonds of Dolton are this year’s Blood Services Heroes. Gyrls in the H.O.O.D, a Chicago-based non-profit, is dedicated to empowering young women with a "Healthy, Optimistic, Outstanding, and Determined" foundation. Led by Chez and Venisha, the organization launched a free phlebotomy training program to help address workforce challenges faced by women. Recognizing the financial struggles of many of the participants, the organization covered the cost of tuition, books, medical scrubs, and the state exam. With several certified students, Gyrls in the H.O.O.D is helping supply skilled phlebotomists to aid in a crucial field. Sponsored by Fresenius Kabi USA. #RedCrossHeroes

A bit of wisdom I imparted to him at his graduation party this weekend...
"Be authentic and grateful, do your best, and most importantly, always do the right thing.  Make a positive difference in this world.  Show everyone that kindness still matters, and that love does triumph over hatred.  Listen more that you talk and give everyone respect and your full attention.  Don't take yourself too seriously, and remember to laugh at yourself when deserved." 

I threw in, "Even though you're leaving the nest, know that we will always be there to support you.  And please, don't forget about us as you go out and conquer the world!"

Daniel Viayra Chavez of Aurora and Joseph Elrod of Sandwich are this year’s Lifesaving Rescue Heroes. 
 
On September 19, 2023, Daniel and Joseph, water department employees with the City of Aurora, were doing routine maintenance work on an Aurora neighborhood sewer when they heard cries for ’ayuda’ (help). Both Viayra Chavez and Elrod ran and found an Aurora resident holding an unresponsive one-year-old who was not breathing. Viayra Chavez immediately began performing CPR while Elrod phoned 9-1-1 for help, their efforts helped the child to begin to breathe. 
 Sponsored by KPMG US. #RedCrossHeroes

Declan and Tiernan Devlin, Tommy Nitti, and Charles Valerio of Glen Ellyn are this year’s Youth Heroes. On a Saturday evening, shortly after school had let out for the summer, classmates and friends Declan, Tiernan, Tommy, and Charles, initially jumped into action to retrieve a wayward remote-control boat in the middle of Lake Ellyn. On their way to the middle of the lake, with their paddle board and life jackets, they soon realized they needed to also pull a drowning man to safety instead. Sponsored by ITW #RedCrossHeroes

Congratulations to Nina Patel Shah, DO, for earning a coveted spot on Becker's Healthcare list of "Chief Medical Officers to Know" for 2024! https://bit.ly/4aIfxwo 

Dr. Shah is the CMO at HonorHealth Thompson Peak Medical Center and Chief Quality and Clinical Value officer for the HonorHealth network. She is tasked with strategic leadership over our quality, patient safety, clinical effectiveness and care coordination initiatives. She oversees inpatient and outpatient programs in highly reliable value-based care delivery and guides the integration of evidence-based practice across all aspects of clinical care. Additionally, she handles the operational management of quality, infection control, patient safety, case management, behavioral health and utilization review.

HonorHealth's exceptional quality and safety scores are a reflection of the dedication and effectiveness Dr. Shah brings to her role. Thank you and congratulations, Dr. Shah!

Nancy Economou is this year’s Global Citizenship Hero. As the founder of Watts of Love, Nancy works to provide sustainable solar lighting solutions to communities in need across the globe. After witnessing the dangerous effects of families using kerosene for illumination in the Philippines, she designed a solar light to aid these communities and to help promote financial literacy by enabling families to save funds previously spent on kerosene or batteries for entrepreneurship and education. Watts of Love empowers recipients via solar power and also helps them achieve additional financial freedom. Sponsored by UL Solutions #RedCrossHeroes

I am excited to share this wonderful opportunity that I was fortunate to partake in earlier this year! My teammates Maitri Pandya, Noah Philips, Muktadir Ansary, and I competed against 500+ teams in the final round of the National Investment Banking Competition (NIBC Global) held in Vancouver, Canada.

This experience allowed us to deepen our knowledge of investment banking by analyzing a sample M&A case and presenting our findings to industry professionals. While it was a challenging task, I take pride that my team was able to persevere through the case and deliver impactful insights. This competition not only enhanced our technical skills but also allowed us to forge valuable connections in the industry, paving the way for future opportunities in finance.

Know a high school interested in learning about a career in the trades? 👷‍♀️ Applications are now open for our #CONSTRUCT Youth Academy! 
This paid summer program exposes high school students who are interested in careers in energy and construction to a variety of positions ranging from entry-level craft positions to roles in #STEM, engineering and more.

"ComEd is committed to expanding career pathways for youth across northern Illinois as we work to create a talent pipeline that is needed for the transition to a #CleanEnergy future,” said Dave Perez, our executive vice president and COO. “In partnership with the YMCA of Metropolitan Chicago and Goodwill Industries of Southeastern Wisconsin, Inc., the CONSTRUCT Youth Academy is growing to reach more youth in more communities with a chance to prepare for fast-growing careers in our field, giving them a chance to play a role in building a stronger future for their community, while earning a good paying wage.”

Learn more: spr.ly/6004jJnSe

One day you’re young and wild; the next, it’s Tuesday, and you’re dialing into a teams call.

You got this. Go out and paw-sitively crush it this week. May your meetings be short, your coffee plentiful, and your problem-solving skills on par with a bear. For example, bears are resourceful creatures and can adapt to changing circumstances in their environment. They are skilled at finding creative solutions to challenges they face, whether it’s figuring out how to catch fish in a fast-moving stream, finding a way to access hard-to-reach food sources, or responding to an email without coming off as unbearable. It was passive-aggressive, but it is what it is, Carl.

Image: A brown bear staring intently while resting on a log at Katmai National Park & Preserve, Alaska. NPS/ J. Ehrlenbach

column7:
An interesting thing happening with fiat-backed stablecoins. They benefit from the deeply underserved demand for USD as a reserve currency and are creeping into the top 10 holders of US Treasurys

Some potential implications:

1. Non-US consumers worldwide are a large holder of US Treasurys (or stated differently, the US Govt is increasingly borrowing directly from non-US consumer s)
2. Defi makes it easier for a non-US citizen to buy stables than for a US citizen to buy USTs

3. Our model for financial contagion in a crisis is already outdated; instability in money markets and stables probably will interact with each other in unpredictable ways 

4. The decoupling of US-China probably won't play out as linearly as we think it will

5. Tools for capital controls probably need to adapt in order for governments around the world to manage the fact that money that used to sit in locally denominated savings accounts now essentially sit in USD

Yesterday, I announced my plans to retire after a 32 year career in financial services…

From a youth service posting in Lagos, Nigeria to the C - suite of one of the most important financial institutions in the world, I am thankful for the journey and that I get to decide that it is time to say goodbye and pursue other passions. My career has not been a linear path, but it has exceeded my biggest dreams. 
I’ve had amazing experiences, grown as a leader and forged so many close friendships over the years, and I owe a big thank you to the many sponsors, and mentors who supported and advocated for me along the way. They told me what I now tell so many others – step out of your comfort zone. 

Purpose has fueled my career  and it has been a privilege to help advance economic mobility in communities around the world and also make our industry more representative of the clients we serve. 

I am very fortunate to close out my banking career at Citi working for Jane Fraser, a truly inspirational leader, and will always be a proud Citi alum! In the last few years, I’ve had the incredible opportunity to work with colleagues around the world who delivered with excellence for the firm and our clients as we sought to divest our international consumer businesses and simplify the firm in a very significant and meaningful way. 

As to what’s next? Some downtime first. I plan to travel with my husband and biggest supporter, Wale Cole to spend quality time with friends and family before beginning my next adventure in the nonprofit sector focusing on women and healthcare and giving back to the communities that have given so much to me.

I look forward to sharing more about my next chapter in 2025…

This is insane! Brazil's FinTech giant Nubank just posted another massive quarter. The growth & numbers NU is showing are out of this world and make it one of the best-run tech companies in the world 😳

Key facts and figures from Nubank's 1Q 2024 earnings:

👥 100 million customers globally (+26% Year-over-Year)
🌍 It's now the largest digital banking platform outside of Asia
🇧🇷 54% of the adult population of Brazil now uses Nubank
🇧🇷 It's now the 4th largest financial institution in Latin America
💰 $24.3 billion worth of deposits (+53% YoY)
💸 $2.7 billion in revenues (+64% YoY)
🤑 $378 million in profit (+160% YoY)

What's also wild is that their average customer is now using more than 4 products 😳

But here comes the crazy part.

NU's customer acquisition costs is something we have not seen before.

Due to customer-friendly, low-cost products, Nubank has a high NPS of around 90. Even a popular brand like Apple only has an NPS of 72, and banks are often in negative territory.

That's why Nubank, to date, still acquires ~80% of its new customers cost-effectively through recommendations and word-of-mouth 😮‍💨

On top of that, despite serving more than 100 million customers, its monthly average cost per active customer remains below $1 🤯

This coupled with a stunning efficiency ratio of ~32% makes Nubank not only one of the best digital banks globally.

It's probably the best-run tech company on the planet right now.

Remarkable.

This guy runs an $8.5 billion company. But he DOESN’T have a mobile phone, drives a beat-up Hyundai, and was forced to build a house by his wife.

His company’s stock price also beat the market by 58,500%.

These are a few cool things I just learnt about R Thyagarajan - founder of Shriram Finance (a microfinance bank). 👇

🛡️ 1/ 𝗟𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗼𝗼𝗿 > 𝗹𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗵.

Shriram ONLY lends to the poor.

98% of their loans are repaid on time.

Another 1% are paid late.

And only 1% of loans end up defaulted.

Big traditional banks are jealous of repayment rates that high.

Media brainwashes us all to believe that the poor are not credit-worthy.

The facts?

Shriram actually made $200mn in pure profit this year.

Those at the bottom of the pyramid will always find a way to pay you back.

But a rich man?

He’ll just file bankruptcy and move on. (ahem ahem)

📈 2/ 𝗨𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗳𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗽𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘁𝘆 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗢𝗡𝗟𝗬 𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗴𝗿𝗼𝘄.

India’s economic engine is the most impressive thing our world has seen.

But it is uneven as hell.

The top 1% own 40% of the wealth.

Most new wealth creation flows directly to the top.

The ONLY (and I mean ONLY) way to build a sustainable society which doesn’t turn into a scary utopia of upper and lower classes is to push the lowest rungs of the ladder up further.

Bottom-up.

🔗 3/ 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝘄𝗲𝗮𝗸 𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗼𝘁𝘁𝗼𝗺.

Poor people are given exorbitant rates on their loans.

- Truck drivers have to cough up 80% interest
- Grocers and kirana owners have pay 50% interest
- Education loans go for 35-40% interest

Most poor people just accept this, because there was no other alternative.

Shriram saw the opportunity here and gave them below-market rates.

The result?

Tons of trust built and billions in profit.

💥 𝗕𝗼𝗻𝘂𝘀/ 𝗚𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝟭𝗫 = 𝗴𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝟭𝟬𝗫.

Thyagarajan gave away $750 million of shares to his employees.

Just like that.

But he also pays mid-level employees 30% BELOW market, and senior executives almost 50% BELOW.

Despite him underpaying employees, most of them reject higher-paying job offers from other banks.

The work is simply that good.

He could have a mansion, but he lives in a 1500 sqft house that his wife forced him to build.

He could drive a different color Rolls Royce for each week of the day, but he goes to work in a Hyundai i10.

He could deck an iPhone 14 in diamonds, but he has no phone and enjoys reading newspapers + birdwatching.

Insane...

column7:
40!!!!

A few weeks ago I turned 40 and was fortunate enough to celebrate with friends and family. Turning 40 made me reflect on a bunch of things (hello, mid-life crisis?) including my career.

If I think back 15 years ago, I remember sitting in class at the London School of Economics after a long day of work writing down my future career path. It looked a little something like: 2 years investment banking at XXX firm, MBA at XXX elite institution, 2 years consulting at XXX firm, corporate development / strategy role at XXX fortune 100 company and so on. 

Fast forward, I literally accomplished none of my plans and in fact, I failed at mostly all of them. I bombed an interview with Citibank, I was too scared to apply to MBAs because I am awful at standardized testing, I made it to the final round with McKinsey - did not get the job, I applied for countless strategy roles - did not even get any interviews.

But ironically, I would not change anything. What both college and my career taught me is there is no substitute for grit, work ethic and perseverance. Yes, I've probably had 4-5 different career paths since I graduated college but as I tell each founder I meet, it is unlikely you will meet someone else that has started their own business, worked for a growth stage company, worked for a company of 2,500 people and worked for a company of 30,000 people (btw, none of it planned). This experience enables me on one hand, to sit aside founders, rolling-up my sleeves and working just as hard as them while on the other hand, strategizing with founders on how to scale a large global business.

As I think about the next 15 years of my career, for me, it is not about roles, companies or responsibilities anymore. It is about continuing to fulfill my personal and professional mission I set with my former executive coach a few years back which is: how do I help people and give back. If I can consistently do those two things, I know everything else in my career will be fulfilling. 

PS. Thank you to everyone for all the kind birthday wishes via LinkedIn!

Vanguard’s board announced the appointment of Salim Ramji as Vanguard’s next CEO. Salim is a longtime financial services executive with more than 25 years of experience in investments, capital markets, and wealth management. Salim has served in senior roles at both BlackRock Inc. and McKinsey & Company. He will assume the CEO role and join the Vanguard board, effective July 8th, at which time Tim Buckley will retire and step down as Chairman and CEO.

Greg Davis, Vanguard President & Chief Investment Officer, and John Murphy, President & Chief Financial Officer of The Coca-Cola Company, have also been appointed to the Vanguard board.

Mark Loughridge, Lead Independent Director, said “In Salim, we have found an exceptional next leader for Vanguard who is aligned with our mission-driven culture. Vanguard has an important future, and with his experience and perspectives we believe Salim is the best person for the job. On behalf of the board, I want to again thank Tim for his unwavering commitment and outstanding, dedicated service to Vanguard and its investor-owners and crew for more than 33 years.”

Salim commented, “It’s an honor to join Vanguard, an institution I have long admired and respected. I am drawn to Vanguard because of the firm’s clarity and consistency of purpose and am excited to get to work and partner with the outstanding leadership team and crew to lead the company into the future.”

Press Release: https://lnkd.in/emMxHuCm
