For the past few years, it’s been my privilege to serve as a volunteer board member for the Frankfort Falcons Football and Cheer Athletic Association. In my role as Director of Scholarships, I’ve had the joy of assisting over 50 alumni in their transition from high school to college by providing them with scholarships.

As my twin daughters, who are cheerleaders for the Falcons, prepare to transition to high school to join their older sister, my time on the board will soon come to an end. It’s been a bittersweet week as I reflect on the last time I’ll have the honor of awarding scholarships to these deserving student athletes. I’m immensely proud of the tradition we’ve upheld, and I’m confident that the scholarship program will continue to thrive under the guidance of the next board member.

Thank you to everyone who has been part of this journey. I look forward to witnessing the future successes of the Frankfort Falcons and the incredible students who pass through its ranks.

Though we are well into another year at Qlik, we took time to pause and celebrate our team's remarkable achievements. Qlik CEO, Mike Capone and I hosted Qlik's exceptional talents at the President’s Club event—an exclusive gathering designed celebrate our top sales performers. 

This year, we set off to the breathtaking shores of Aruba. It wasn’t just a retreat but a testament to our team members' hard work, relentless dedication, and unparalleled teamwork in achieving and surpassing our goals. 

At Qlik, we believe in reaching targets and setting new benchmarks for excellence and innovation. The President’s Club is our way of recognizing outstanding achievements and saying a huge “Thank You” to our top performers and their invaluable contributions to our success. 

To all the qualifying sales leaders, I hope you found time to relax, reflect on the past year's triumphs, and gear up for even more incredible feats. It was a great few days made even better knowing that we were celebrating hard-earned success. 

And to all our people across sales, thank you for your continued hard work and supporting our clients in achieving their potential and goals. It’s a team effort and everyone’s hard work is appreciated. 

#Qlik #Teamwork #Success #SalesExcellence

Welcome to our team!

In April I celebrated my 8-year anniversary at OnDeck and Enova International, and at the end of the month I concluded a great run. 

These past 8 years have been a real journey for my product career and for me personally. 
- I’ve had the privilege of managing a number of really excellent Product Managers (shouts to Anukrati Pachauri, Rahul Mangalore, Michele Lemze, Tanay Ved, Casey Ritt, Amruta Somalwar, Jessie Moog and Kyle Campbell).
- I’ve gotten into the field to speak directly with many of our incredible Small Business owners in order to build a best-in-class lending experience for them (never forget “Gaia” Nicole Gengaro and Adam Brodowski). 
- And I steered through the ups and downs of the economy (including those strangely heady times in the beginning of the pandemic navigating the PPP waters Bernice Lim and Aaron Eddy) to play a role in providing more than $11B in financing to small businesses across the country.

I've learned so much from great leaders in the space, but most especially Noah Breslow, Jim Granat, and Cory Kampfer. My approach to product has evolved immeasurably learning from, and working alongside Parilee Edison Wang, Gagan Kanjlia, Scott Totman, Tracey Varnell, Sarah Litt, and Mohan Chitrapu. 

Personally, these past 8 years have also seen the birth of our two sons, the loss of a parent and beloved pet, and a move to the City of Brotherly Love. It's been a transformative time to say the least.

As I start to look for my next opportunity - I'm excited to reconnect and see what amazing things everyone has been up to. I would be thrilled to leverage my experience in the Fintech space, but I'm open to any opportunities trying to solve especially knotty product problems or design for underserved customers. I'm particularly interested in getting back to working with people in person again (after 4 years remote!), so if you know of anything happening in the Greater Philly area, I'd love to learn more. 

(Pics from my first and last days for the algo and the memories)

“Lindley’s legacy lives on.” A humbling headline if ever there was one.
 
For those who have been following Lindley Center at Washington and Lee University since it was announced a year ago, I’m happy to share a progress report.
 
Just last weekend, we received an incredible boost from Lindley’s classmates in the class of 1999. They generously made the center’s construction their 25th reunion class project, exceeding every benchmark they set for donations. In total, they raised over $1.4 million dollars… an inspiring sum, dedicated to the memory of a truly inspiring person. All of us involved in this project from the Spaht Family Foundation — my parents, brother, and brother-in-law — are humbled by her class’s generosity.
 
W&L holds a special place in the hearts of us Spahts — not just as the alma mater of my late sister, but as the now-home of my eldest daughter. When the Lindley Center is completed in fall of 2025, Eliza will be entering her senior year. She and her classmates will be able to use Lindley as a resource for their own physical and mental wellness — just as so many of her loved ones and patients did in life. 
 
Lindley’s legacy lives on indeed.

Yesterday I got to watch two women who I admire greatly take the stage to tell stories that reflect their passion for missions that transform lives. 

In the AM, Celena Sarillo talked about how the American Red Cross of Illinois is there for people on what is likely the worst day of their lives, helping them get back on their feet after a disaster.

In the PM, I watched Christen Ng take the stage for Bottom Line to advocate for degree aspiring students from low income households. She said, “We’re all an amalgamation of those who invested in us.” Dang, I couldn’t agree with that more!

My head hit the pillow last night full of inspiration for the ways humans are building foundations for eachother when we need a lift, and admiration for these two leaders who demonstrate what it looks like to live with purpose every day. ♥️

Apple can spend $500k on a rather bad TV ad and everyone goes nuts 
But …

The entire digital ad complex spends    $500,000,000,000 a year showing you utterly terrible ads that don’t work, are rife with fraud, targeting that fails, broken links, tracking software, that are ugly , tiny and destroy brand equity

and all while clogging up the internet with dubious content , fake news and fake traffic.

and nobody cares ! 

I wish we could focus on making the internet a place for better ads that people care about more , that work better for brands and people and media owners . 

It doesn’t need to be this bad for everyone.

It is with great sadness that I share the news of the sudden passing of my friend and former colleague from PNC Bank, Sandra Ashby, on Sunday, May 12th.

Sandra (or Sandi as everyone knew her) worked at PNC her entire career - 44 years - where she retired as a Vice President of Treasury Management. She had an infectious personality and lived life to the fullest. An avid storyteller, she loved people and was always open for a chat or adventure. In college, she found an artistic outlet in designing and making jewelry. She continued this passion for the rest of her life creating beautiful works of art and developing deep friendships. The relationships she made along the way were very special to her.

Sandi is survived by her husband of 45 years, Ronald and their three children - Nia (Adam) Green, Courtney (John) Schwartz, and Ryan (Brittany Lala) Ashby. She adored her three grandchildren - Parker, Kinsley, and Grayson.

Friends and family are welcome to attend her visitation from 10am to 12pm Friday, May 17, 2024, at St. Luke Greek Orthodox Church, 35 N. Malin Road, Broomall, PA 19008. Her funeral service will take place at 12 noon in the church. Her interment will be private.

In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation to the Four Diamonds Fund. She was an enthusiastic supporter of the organization, which helps families battling childhood cancer.

Please keep her husband, their children, grandchildren, and family in your thoughts and prayers.

At CanxLab we are known for collaborating with many beer breweries. That is also what we have focused on from the start.

Our ambition once was: Offer independent, smaller brewers the same opportunities that large breweries have created for themselves.

And we succeeded, we provide (filled) cans with the most beautiful sleeves or printing for many beautiful breweries.

But... we have now come a long way beyond this ambition. We now also serve a different market by producing cans for drinks other than beer. Like this Ice Tea from Oxfam Novib

Want to know more about canned drinks? We get that. Contact Arjen or Jan: arjen@canxlab.com / jan@canxlab.com

[NL]

Met CanxLab staan we er bekend om dat we samenwerken met veel bierbrouwerijen. Dat is ook waar we vanaf het begin de focus op hebben gehad. 

Onze ambitie was namelijk ooit: Onafhankelijke, kleinere brouwers dezelfde mogelijkheden bieden als die grote brouwerijen voor zichzelf hebben gecreëerd.

En dat is gelukt, we verzorgen voor veel mooie brouwerijen voor (afgevulde) blikjes met de mooiste sleeves of bedrukking. 

Maar... inmiddels zijn we alweer een stuk verder dan deze ambitie. We bedienen nu namelijk ook een andere markt door blikjes te produceren voor andere drankjes dan bier. Zoals deze Ice Tea van Oxfam Novib

Meer weten over drankjes in blik? Dat snappen we. Neem contact op met Arjen of Jan: arjen@canxlab.com / jan@canxlab.com

#canxlab #cans #printedcans #deventer #whatcanwedoforyou

O anfitrião Pedro Carter Salazar, supervisor do Centro Gráfico da Ball Corporation, acredita que essas visitas são uma ótima oportunidade para os visitantes entenderem de perto as técnicas para envase das bebidas. column7:
This is National Police Week, when we acknowledge and honor our nation’s law enforcement officers -- especially those who have given their lives in service of our communities. 

At U. S. Steel, we understand in our bones the vital importance of law enforcement. Throughout our facilities, many of our security and safety personnel are former law enforcement and their work is crucial to always keeping safety first. We also know how challenging and at times even dangerous this work is, and the selflessness that it requires. 

Please take a moment today to recognize and thank these everyday heroes for the work they do. And then let’s get back to work…safely.

column7: My mom always wished for grace and thoughtfulness, among other things, for me. While I don't always get these aspirations exactly right, their importance is never lost on me (and it’s a big part of what drew me to Bluemercury). My mom also thinks A LOT, and because of that she is one of my closest thought partners and best friends. And her litmus test on self-care has been, “where’s your lipstick?!" I guess it shouldn't surprise me that my days now are focused on thinking A LOT about beauty! I 💙 my mom today and every day. To all the moms out there, Happy Mother's Day!

column7:
“Poor planning on your part, does not constitute an emergency on mine”

Those words made me flash back immediately to internal medicine residency, when that was one of my attending’s favourite catchphrase. As a senior resident, it taught me accountability and responsibility, and the importance of thinking two steps ahead. In the hospital, it is easier for the team to rally around “right” thing to do - which is to get the patient feeling better and discharged.

In the informatics world (and upper levels of administration in general), we sometimes lose sight of the patient as the point of singular focus. It’s the budget, or team resources, or personal reputation, or political capital, or many other competing priorities.

Thank you CT Lin MD, FACP, FAMIA for a piece that truly resonated and for practical and effective tips you outlined in your article. Definitely a worth read!

Over the last 40 years, Cisco has built one of the most sophisticated and extensive Go-to-Market engines in the industry, with a mission of helping customers adjust to changing market conditions and achieve their most urgent outcomes. During our Earnings call, I announced some important updates to Cisco’s Executive Leadership Team that will help us take the next step in that mission.
 
First I am pleased to share that Gary Steele, the former CEO of Splunk who joined Cisco as part of the acquisition, will be stepping into the newly created role of President, Go-to-Market.
 
Gary and his team will evolve our Go-to-Market motions to execute against our strategy, align with customer needs, and drive a culture of intense competition, agility, and continuous improvement. I look forward to partnering more deeply with Gary in this new role.
 
As part of these changes, Jeff Sharritts, our current EVP and Chief Customer and Partner Officer, will be leaving Cisco after 24 years.
 
Jeff has a long list of accomplishments at Cisco and is known for his authenticity and integrity. He’s well respected across the company, and I am grateful for his leadership, friendship, and unwavering dedication to Cisco and our customers.

column7:
🥇It brings me great pleasure to commend the AES Indiana team for their unwavering dedication to the highest standards and operational excellence.

In 2023, AES Indiana marked the completion of its fourth year of the Power of Change program, designed to assist those facing challenges in paying their winter heating bills. Through partnerships with organizations like the Dollar Energy Fund, a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit, contributors can make tax-deductible donations to support neighbors in keeping their homes warm and well-lit.

Continuously striving to bolster system resilience, AES Indiana undertook significant initiatives in 2023. This included the rebuilding of 208 miles of 15kV circuits and the installation of over 40 miles of static wire. Furthermore, upgrading four 16kV circuits to 15kV capacity has significantly reinforced the grid's robustness, thereby supporting the evolving needs of the community.

A standing ovation is well-deserved by the exceptional team at AES Indiana, who have earned a Great Place To Work US (GPTW) certification in the US for the second consecutive year.

🧾 The 2023 Community Impact Report by AES Indiana highlights these remarkable efforts. As we continue to accelerate the future of energy forward, our commitment to serving alongside our customers remains steadfast.

Explore the report here: https://aes-in.co/3QuQhlm 

#YesAES #Partnership #AllTogether #HighestStandards

Please join us in congratulating Lisa Saragusa on her new position, serving as the senior manager in Function Finance Business Partners (FBP), reporting to Elizabeth Dominguez, operations FBP director.

Saragusa most recently served in a rotational development position as a line superintendent supporting our Power Delivery Louisiana team in the New Orleans area. 

“Lisa’s outstanding tenure and cross functional experience within finance and operations surely makes her a great asset to any team,” said Shelton Hudson, director of reliability in metro New Orleans. “These rotational opportunities challenge employees to learn a different side of the business. On the other hand, they bring a unique level of expertise and perspectives from their previous roles that will further push our departments along the path to premier.” 

Saragusa has more than 26 years of experience with Entergy, serving in various management roles as well as in a regulatory role where she led filings for multiple jurisdictions. She also spent three years in corporate planning before transitioning to power delivery in 2021, taking roles in work management and later as a line superintendent. 

“It’s amazing to see our employees focusing on enhancing their development to achieve career aspirations,” said Steven Benyard, vice president of reliability in Louisiana. “We continue to promote a collaborative work culture to motivate and build ambitious enterprise leaders like Lisa through development programs, leadership coaching and cohort experiences. Personal career development is not only beneficial to your own growth, but also contributes to the success of the company.”

#Oneteamonefight, #Diversity, #IntentionalDevelopment

Lisa DaBello Saragusa, Shelton Hudson, Shauna Lovorn-Marriage, Aaron Cooley-Themm, SHRM-CP

One of the most effective things you can do to prepare for emergencies is to practice through exercises.

Last week the Avangrid Emergency Management team brought together Incident Managment Teams from across NYSEG and RGE with our external partners to walk through our response to a Hurricane coming up the Atlantic into New York.

With Climate Change and the prediction of a more active Hurricane season, these connections and events keep us ready. 

So proud of the dedication our teams have to supporting our communities and making sure we can safely and swiftly restore power.  Special thank you to our lead Exercise Planner, Brienne Lenart, and Shannon Ethier, Sr. Manager of New York Emergency Operations for leading the design and execution of the exercise and making it a fantastic event.

column7:
COMMUNITY IMPACT!!

Recognizing how individuals suffering from addiction have long battled shame, stigma and isolation, Corewell Health has opened eight nurse-led addiction clinics with same-day walk-in services for adolescent and adult populations. In partnership with the State of Michigan and other established agencies, clinic staff provide education, training, and easy access to care.
The Corewell Health supply chain has been instrumental in supporting the clinics, leveraging GHX Lumere and collaborating with the health system’s value analysis team to procure the necessary specialty medications needed to address high risk substance use. They have worked with the State of Michigan to maintain a steady supply of Narcan into communities served by the clinics and now stock and supply over 50 Narcan distribution boxes across the state.
The number of individuals treated by the clinics has steadily grown year-over-year; already nearing 1,000 patients in the first two months of 2024. Through this program and its partners, one community reported over 150 overdose reversals in 2023. In 2024, Corewell Health is opening two additional clinics and launching a telehealth program to meet individuals suffering from addiction in their homes, communities, and comfort spaces.
Corewell Health Dependent Drug Stewardship Program Operations Manager Cecily Heaton is recognized as a key contributor for this award.

It's May, which means it's Military Appreciation Month! This is the perfect time to honor our U.S. Armed Forces and their families who have made so many sacrifices in service to our country. This month holds a special place in my heart as I have many family members, friends, and colleagues who have served, and I am constantly humbled by their dedication and bravery.

On behalf of my grandchildren and myself, I would like to express our gratitude to the U.S. Armed Forces. Your service and sacrifice have made a significant impact on our country, and we are forever grateful. Thank you for your dedication and commitment to protecting our freedoms.

column7:
As Nurses Week comes to an end, I took a moment to look back on the wonderful week filled with celebrations. 
 
The Atlanta Journal-Constitution held its 19th Nursing Excellence Awards where three Wellstar nurses were honored. 500 nurses from all of Metro Atlanta gathered to celebrate each other. 
 
On Wednesday, May 8, almost 200 Wellstar DAISY Award honorees celebrated their accomplishments at a luncheon. It was an honor to have Dr. Deb Zimmerman, CEO of The DAISY Foundation and President of the American Organization of Nursing Leadership in attendance along with Wellstar’s CEO, Candice Saunders. The room was filled with excitement as nurses came together to celebrate one another. We heard nomination stories, which allowed all of us to reflect, laugh, and cry. It truly was a amazing event. 
 
Nurses Week is a special time when we can all celebrate nurses, and in turn, nurses can reflect on how they make a difference in the lives of the patients, families, and communities they serve. By fostering a culture of care, our nurses are the heart and soul of our health system.

As I take a moment to reflect on my own nursing career of over 40 years, I am grateful for every experience, patient, and colleague I have met as this has led me to Wellstar. Every day, I am amazed and inspired by the work that the 8,000+ nurses at Wellstar and Wellstar MCG.  You are remarkable. It was such an honor to round this week and meet so many of you. My heart is filled with pride!

You, truly are difference makers!
 
Happy Nurses Week!

Bravissimo! A heartfelt thank you to Reggie Van Lee for inviting me to witness the incredible talent of J’Nai Bridges, a mezzo-soprano star who is currently gracing the stage of the Met in "El Nino.” What a night...
 
The intimate gathering reminded me of my upbringing in Milan, where my mother taught music and where opera was not just entertainment — but part of our cultural fabric. 
 
It was a beautiful reminder that, regardless of professional pursuits, there are universal experiences that can connect us all. 
 
In any industry, it's easy to get caught up in the intricacies of our work. Which makes moments like these — shared experiences beyond the boardroom — all the more vital. 
 
Thank you again, Reggie, and to Loida Lewis, for creating space for such meaningful moments. And thank you, J’Nai, for sharing your extraordinary talent with us. Here's to the power of music and more shared experiences.

I'm excited to announce that, after 16 incredible years of fostering connections among the world's most innovative c-suite leaders, I am eager to bring my passion for community-building and strategic expansion to a new role at World 50: overseeing EMEA Growth.

Here's to new beginnings and meaningful growth ahead!

In festivities across campus, the St. Jude Cell Therapy Program celebrated the production of its 100th batch of cell therapy product. St. Jude faculty and staff watched as it was transported from the Children’s GMP to the Human Applications Lab, where it will be stored before patient use. 

Located on the St. Jude campus, the GMP facility produces biopharmaceutical products such as recombinant proteins, viral vaccines, viral-based gene therapy vectors and monoclonal antibodies. 

“The GMP facility here at St Jude is a very unique asset that allows projects to be accelerated, timelines shortened and the outcomes to patients improved,” said Frank Fazio, president of the Children’s GMP. 

Indeed, the GMP manufactured a landmark therapy for X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency (Bubble Boy Disease), a rare and life-threatening disorder. 

As investigators continue to explore the possibilities of cell therapies, work with the GMP facility will be the cornerstone to developing potentially life-saving treatments and cures. To learn more about the St. Jude Children's GMP, LLC, visit https://ow.ly/PIFG50RKopb

column7:
I’ve been at Synchrony for a little over two years and this week, had the pleasure of attending the annual Global Diversity Experience for a second time. This is one of my favorite events that we have as a company.  It is an event where employees come together to reflect on the diversity that strengthens our culture and drives our success. The meeting is attended by hundreds of employees including our entire executive leadership team and members of our Board and is broadcast virtually to thousands of global employees. 

Not only did I have the pleasure of attending the event this year, I also had the  honor of joining a panel titled "One Synchrony, Many Voices" where I and three of my colleagues talked about how our identities shape our experiences walking through the world.  This is just one example of how Synchrony is "walking the talk" and listening to employees across the company in order to build an inclusive culture, a culture that enabled us to jump 15 spots this year to become a top 5 Great Place To Work US in 2024. 

I couldn’t be more thankful to work for a company that makes me feel seen, heard and cared for.  A culture and community that enables me and many others to show up at work based on how we define ourselves and not how society defines us and I am proud to have had the opportunity to represent voices like mine in that community.

Thank you to my colleagues Miguel Goldfeld, Dana Pirolo and Faisel Uddin Mir for standing with me. and thank you to DJ Casto for guiding us through.

I thought when I got 'Senior' in my title, my imposters syndrome would be gone, but it actually put a magnifying glass on it!

Every day I'm waiting for that comment in a meeting or code review to ask 'Man, you're really a Senior Data Engineer?'

While this seems like a negative, I realized this is part of my fuel for continuous improvement in my craft. 

I love the process of learning and improvement that helps me ship value more often but having that additional push from 'fear of stupidity' makes studying, working, and adding value just a little bit easier. 

Just know if you're dealing with Imposters Syndrome, there's a strong likelihood the people you work with have the same feeling. 

just remember: You don't have to be great to start, but you do have to start if you want to be great - Zig Ziglar

column7:
For Mother’s Day I received a book this year where my children filled in 50 blanks about me. My daughter (7) wrote in blue and my son (10) wrote in red, which helped me compare and contrast themes. 

Woven throughout my son’s comments was admiration for my professional successes and talents, from explicitly mentioning how gifted I am with crafting emails to an inside joke about a “saga” I was struggling with for a bit that produced lots of dinner conversation. 

I knew from my first maternity leave that — for me — I would be the best mother I could be if I was working and remaining engaged outside of the house.  With my newborns, I treated each challenge as a mini consulting project with research and tinkering.  For everyone’s sake, I needed a variety of outlets for problem solving and creativity. 

Yet more often than not I feel guilty.  I have my laptop out at swim practice or gymnastics, less attentive than (some) other parents and bartering around the minimal number of videos I will take to appease my children and conscience. 

If someone had told me a decade ago my son would admire my dedication to my employer, I wouldn’t have believed it.  I may not have believed it a week ago. 

This book was such a beautiful narrative through two lenses, my daughter valuing me for my heart and my son for my mind.  It felt like a tipping point with my eldest where he appreciated how much he benefits from my professional experience.  I can masterfully craft a text to a peer’s parent or teacher on a tricky subject as a seasoned communicator, and I can mentor on small issues having mastered basic persuasive techniques…at least to tackle the biggest challenges of a 4th grader. 

Bravo to all the working mamas out there this Mother’s Day season.  Your children see and admire you more than you know. 

And I implore you to help your friends and coworkers be reminded of their talents in a tough season for working mothers. 

I also appreciate Optum for continuing to afford me the flexibility to juggle the demands of being a dynamo manager and mother. 

#hypewomen

Excited to Announce My New Role as Chief Revenue Officer at Sibros! 🚀

I am thrilled to join this company revolutionizing the connected vehicle industry. Our mission is to help customers unlock the full potential of their connected devices, generating value, insights, and new possibilities.

We deliver a world-class software platform built by true industry visionaries. This platform empowers customers to manage, update, and derive meaningful data from their devices. Our vision to enable connected devices to serve humanity's needs positions us as the core of the connected device ecosystem.

I spent this week at our vibrant office in San Jose, and the excitement of the team was palpable. The energy and passion here are truly inspiring, and I am enthusiastic about being part of this dynamic environment.

“One day in retrospect the years of struggle will strike you as the most beautiful.”

This has been my greatest achievement. Not because of how prestigious the degree is, but how much I had to overcome to get here. I struggled mentally so much the past three years and law school contributed to it hectically. But through all the trials and tribulations I learned to love myself again. I learned to battle my mental struggles and fight for happiness. This J.D. is symbolism for the level of perseverance I developed through my mental journey. I know the job is not done but we must celebrate milestones.

What does Graduation and the Cannes Lions Festival have in common? 

🎓✨ As graduation season unfolds, it’s a poignant time to reflect on the journeys we embark on, both personally and professionally. This photo of me with my father at my high school graduation is a cherished reminder of those who have been pillars of support and wisdom in my life. 

Inspired by the work of Lucia Knell and Gabriel Reilich of Upworthy by a project to find the best of humanity (which will be released as a book later this year), I am looking so forward to a conversation with Mindy Nguyen , Robin Lickliter along with with other brand leaders 
at the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity.  Hosted by Sparks 
we will explore the theme of generosity from both a personal and brand perspective. It's a theme that resonates deeply, as we contemplate the impact we aspire to make in the world and the role of media and partnerships in that equation.

As we collectively think about the opportunity to work together within the industry, it’s crucial to remember and appreciate the good people who make our journeys meaningful.

Happy to share I’m retiring today!

I have had the privilege to work with some amazing teams over my career and had a multitude of great “work families”. As I became a manager, I had the opportunity to see a number of young people enter the profession and was able to mentor them and watch them excel in their careers. Many of them became good friends and I lovingly called them my “work kids” as they were part of my family. As I retire I know that I’ve left the profession with so many smart and capable people that I’ve had the  privilege to work with.  Those relationships I will take with me wherever I go and those “work families” give me a good reason to travel to visit them. 

Now we get to start the fun part of retirement! Can’t wait to see what the future holds!

At GetYourGuide we believe the future of travel will be guided. 

A week back we took our kids to the USA for the very first time. While eating our own dog food, I could see first hand how the above statement is the right vision: 
1) Personal Passions: history, food, aviation, biking, sports. We found activities and guides to match the wide variety of interests between us. 
2) Tech Innovation: from last minute bookings to a self-guided tour with the RayBan Meta Smart Glasses. 
3) Human Connection: at the dr. Martin Luther King memorial our guide told personal stories how his mother lived through the Civil Rights Movement. 

We have just wrapped up our 2024 Global Summit in Berlin with 800 colleagues from around the world. I'm so grateful to be part of such a divers and talented team that is building the future of Travel Experiences. And there are so many roles open for more talent, please DM me if you're interested!

#loveyourdogfood #travel #experiences

Traveling all the way from the United Arab Emirates to Washington, D.C., to deliver the commencement ceremony speech for graduate students in Georgetown’s McDonough School of Business Class of 2024, His Excellency Mohammad Al Gergawi left a lasting impression on the students, families, faculty, and staff on the Healy Lawn.

He recalled a lesson he learned working as a manager at the Department of Economic Development in Dubai. While at work, he chose to help an elderly man who appeared to be in need of assistance with some paperwork.

As it turns out, this gentleman was a secret shopper for the Crown Prince of Dubai at the time, His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, who later appointed him as the deputy director general of that organization.

Fast forward to today — this moment of kindness — helped spearhead Al Gergawi’s career and overall successes to date. 

Read more here: https://bit.ly/4apHBUG

column7:
Hi everyone - In just under 4 weeks, I am taking part in the Quintessentially Foundation Bike Ride from Lake Zurich to St Moritz including climbing the iconic Furka Pass. I am taking on this challenge to raise money for The Firefly Project, a child poverty initiative from Quintessentially Foundation. I will be cycling 350km, climbing over 7,500m (that is the height of 25 Eiffel Towers, 16 Empire State Buildings, or 9 Burj Khalifa's!!) across one of the highest mountain passes in Switzerland.  And I'm doing this with two other team members from Sabre - Richard Addey and Brett Thorstad.

The Firefly Project focuses on supporting children and young people living in poverty. Over 700,000 children in London live in poverty - the highest child poverty rate in England, and in 2024 this is only getting worse. They face daily challenges that prevent them from reaching their potential.  The Firefly Project finds and funds impactful frontline charities and helps ‘turbo charge’ them through funding and tailored support, allowing disadvantaged children to access their life-changing services. 

I'd be so appreciative of any support you'd like to provide.  See the link below for more details and to donate.  Thank you!

As you may or may not be aware I am a big fan of horse racing and yesterday was the running of the second leg of the Triple Crown – The Preakness Stakes. I’m drafting this today not because I want to pique your interest in the game, but I found the result and the team involved in preparing the horse for the race to be a relatable story, especially to those in the twilight years of their careers…
 
The horse that won is named SEIZE THE GREY, a high priced purchase as a yearling for $300,000 (although many horses go upwards of 7 figure price tags) and he was the 15TH Triple Crown race winner for his 88 1/2 year old trainer D. Wayne Lukas, and it came 44 years after his first Triple Crown race winner - Codex in 1980. D. Wayne still runs an incredible operation, and from his base in Kentucky he is up everyday at 3:30am to be the first to the barn and gets up on horseback daily to watch his string of horses train. 

When they interviewed him after the race about the long line of colleague trainers waiting to congratulate him, he said; “I think they’re trying to get rid of me, they probably want me to retire. I don’t think that will happen there’s still a purpose for me”. Side note; Lukas has been a boss and mentor to countless other horse trainers over the years, some of them have also achieved stardom as triple crown winning trainers.

Simply stated the message here is if you enjoy what you’re doing and still have a passion for hard work which breeds success, then lead by example. Mentor and support others, share your experiences, your unbridled enthusiasm, your secrets, and your legacy can, and will, live on through others. Age is only a number, father time will someday catch up with D. Wayne, but hearing about the many who waiting in line to congratulate him speaks volumes about how much he’ll live on in his industry…

The Class of 2024 has been challenged with navigating volatility in a way few classes have, and I am so proud of the way our students have found a way to thrive amidst the uncertainty.

In addressing the four groups of The Wharton School graduates during this weekend, I shared why I believe their unconventional experience has uniquely prepared them for what’s certain to come in the future stages of their life: change. (In the case of our undergrads, this point is particularly resonant with me given that I began my deanship in 2020 under similar circumstances to theirs – remote, online, and unsure of what the future held amid pandemic restrictions.)

After many years of studying leadership, I can say with confidence that this won’t be the last time they face unfamiliar obstacles or difficult situations in which there is no playbook or precedent for how to respond.

In my remarks, I encouraged them to view the education they’ve gained, and the resiliency they’ve developed, as invaluable, necessary foundations capable of leading them through both professional and personal unknowns. I also pushed them to lean on the leadership skills they honed as students as they forge their path forward.

Congratulations to our graduates and their many loved ones who joined in celebrating with us! #WhartonGrad

column7:
Exterior siding is the first line of defense from fires that start on the outside of the home. 

Ontario homeowner Blair Payne described an instance where a tree collapsed on a power line due to a lightning strike, causing a hazardous flash back that traveled up to the side of the house. 

Upon speaking to the fire chief, Payne says that by the time the volunteer firefighters showed up, he would have lost the entire building if he didn’t have noncombustible Hardie® siding to protect the home.

Unlike other building materials – engineered wood, cedar, or vinyl – Hardie® fiber cement products will not ignite when exposed to direct flame*. Watch our latest fire demonstration to see this in action! 🔥🚫

https://lnkd.in/gEYek3aD

*Noncombustible per ASTM E136, with zero flame spread per ASTM E84

#JamesHardie #Siding #Durability #BuildingProducts #FiberCement #FireResistance #StormDamage

What an exhilarating day at the NYSE with First Lady Jill Biden, Chelsea Clinton, Carolyn M. Mazure and a powerful group of women's health investors (and for me personally, many friends). I'm honored to serve as a co-chair alongside super-women Jessica J. Federer and Christina Jenkins, MD and moderate a panel with powerhouses Cathy Friedman (GV (Google Ventures)), Ashlie Tyler (Bank of America) and Konstantina Katcheves. 

Huge thanks to the incredible NYSE team (Johanna (Rodriguez) Grossman, PhD, Samantha Nelson) for convening so much capital-deploying power into a room. And to the sponsors making this all possible - McKinsey & Company (Lucy Perez), Manatt, Phelps & Phillips, LLP (Randi Seigel), Leerink Partners (Sasha Kelemen), The Bowdoin Group (Katelyn Marini), McDermott Will & Emery (Caroline Reignley).
 
My favorite quotes and highlights:
💡Hearing from Lynn Martin, the 2nd female President at the NYSE out of 68 (!!)
💡 Dr. Jill Biden: "We will build a healthcare system where women aren't an afterthought, but a first thought"
💡Chelsea Clinton: "It’s important to measure progress. But I don’t think we’ve reached success until we’ve reached parity” and "We can’t sit here in 2024 and not talk about abortion"
💡Anna Mason: "What is the best possible question we should be asking" 
💡Cathy Friedman: "We need killer companies in women's health"
💡Marsha Henderson: "Now is the time. The answers could be in this room. What actions will you take, in what time frame?"
 
Cheers to the women's health zeitgeist!
 
cc: RH Capital family - Elizabeth Bailey, Amy Pollack, Justine DeCoste, CFA (Crestone Capital, LLC), Michaela Edwards (Capricorn Investment Group), Maya Hardigan (Mae), Alexander Fisher (AOA Dx), Priyanka Jain (Evvy), Madeleine L. (Thirty Madison)

column7: Friday marks my last day at Oscar Health after five years of working with the smartest, empathy-driven colleagues and friends to solve our broken healthcare system. Companies talk about culture, at Oscar it’s just the way things are. I got to be myself at work, talk about matcha (too much) and teach meditation on the side for the past four years to Oscar employees. I believe in what Oscar is doing and it comes down to the incredible people who work there and actually care (a lot). I will miss being an Oscarian💙. As for my next step, I’m excited to share that I’m headed to Northwestern University - Kellogg School of Management this fall to pursue my MBA with a focus in AI & machine learning. I would not be where I am without the support of so many on this journey and in this process, I am incredibly grateful for all who gave their time and insights as I navigated this next step. I truly can’t wait, see you soon Chicago!

column7:
At the age of 45, I had my first piano recital.

Growing up, I always wanted to take piano lessons. We didn’t have very much money, and we also didn’t have a piano. Some family friends sold us a piano very inexpensively, and I started taking lessons for $7 a week.

I was 11 when my dad lost his job, I wasn’t able to continue lessons. So with 2 years under my belt, I just sort of kept self-studying. I am *no* expert, but I enjoy music immensely.

Fast forward decades, I always made piano lessons for my kids a priority. Even when they complain, I insist.

There is an annual recital, and I get to celebrate the success of watching them learn and memorize music that I couldn’t have imagined they could play.

This year, I was at a lesson with my youngest, and the teacher suggested I do the duet with my daughter. I was thrilled! She’s 9! How hard could that be?

Well… the accompanist part is much more challenging than the child’s part. 😂

I had to practice and learn my song for the recital. We performed this weekend without error, and I was so happy to share that experience with my family! 

Here is what I learned:
1). No matter how old you are, it is nice to show off for your parents. My parents were 77 and in the audience. 💖
2). Committing to a deadline, even if you’re unsure is outstanding motivation. 
3). Leading by example is a better teacher than anything else. My daughter heard everytime I practiced. I never ask her to practice more than I expect from myself…
4). Working with others enhances your craft. I learned my part. My daughter learned her part. And then we had to learn it together. 

What a wonderful journey.

#mnfit #cio #cto #cdo #parenting Inspire Leadership Network Better Business Bureau Genesys Works Twin Cities Second Harvest Heartland Donaldson

At Conectado, we are about inspiring the next generation of innovators and leaders, empowering them to pursue their dreams and make a meaningful impact in the world of technology and make generational change in the families and community.

Today, we are proud to celebrate our ongoing sponsorship and mentorship of Hollister High School’s Robotics and Engineering Program which just completed its 7th year and competitive season that included four major regionals. Conectado’s very own Michael Martinez is the founding mentor of the program embodying our dedication to nurturing young talent and fostering a passion for STEAM education.

The team is an incredible story of growth and diversity. Participation has increased 50% year-over-year since the program was started, with students from diverse cultural backgrounds and genders coming together to push the boundaries of innovation. The team by the numbers:

- 60% Latinx students (80% overall diversity)
- 25% Female
- 3.5 average GPA
- 90 combined Advanced Placement (AP) and Honors Courses (avg. 3 per student)
- 100% graduation rate

Most impressive is seeing these students go straight to colleges and universities including University of California, Berkeley, Northwestern University, California Polytechnic State University-San Luis Obispo, University of California, Davis, University of California, Merced, University of California, Riverside and California State University-Sacramento with most majoring in Engineering.

It's inspiring to witness the creativity, passion, and collaboration that fuel this program's success. Having embraced Conectado’s mission “from classroom to career to the boardroom,” they are living proof of what is possible. They are Conectado!

Together with Hollister High School, we will continue to shape the next generation of leaders and innovators. 

🌟 #STEAMeducation #Robotics #Engineering #DiversityinSTEM #ConectadoCommunity #WeAreConectado

IHA has named Blake Dye as Interim President of the association. Dye served as IHA Board Chair in 2010 and brings decades of experience in hospital administration across a broad range of health care facilities. He began his career at Henry Community Health, where he served 31 years in various roles, including more than a decade as president and CEO. He later served as president of St. Vincent Heart Center of Indiana and as senior vice president at Indiana University Health where he retired in 2022. Dye earned his Bachelor of Science in Public Health Administration and his Master of Health Administration from Indiana University.

This weekend - Shea and Pierre graduated with a DOUBLE masters from Georgetown University from one of the most prestigious programs in the world: a Masters in Science and Foreign Services (with a Certificate in Refugee and Humanitarian Crisis) and a Masters of Arts in History.

Shea also received the DEI award from the Foreign Services Program, awarded for both bringing ASL/sign language as an accepted language requirement for the program and pushing Georgetown hard to be more accessible. There were a LOT of challenges, such as showing up to events that had no ramps / ways to attend to navigating a very inaccessible campus, but Shea continued to fight to be included at every single event and classroom. This has now opened Georgetown up for the next person as they have made major improvements after working with Shea on being more accessible. 

What’s next? While searching for Shea’s next opportunity, Shea is working with a few local congressmen in Virginia on passing a BILL in Congress (being voted on shortly) for disabled people and wounded veterans to have more job opportunities in the military. Shea is also continuing to educate others on disabilities, releasing another children’s book, “Perfect Pierre” in August, about growing up with a disability with the help of Pierre and how it’s not so different as everyone has thier own challenges whether they are visible or not. 

Shea is already making huge changes in the world, and I’m so proud. I know this won’t be my last update on Shea’s accomplishments, but in the meantime….. Congratulations to Shea C. Megale!!

column7: I'm excited to announce that I have joined Sophos as Chief Financial Officer.   I am excited to work with Joe Levy again and the rest of the amazing team!  I am excited about what we will all accomplish together at this amazing Company!

Meet me in Tribeca at The WSJ Future of Everything festival this week, so that we can discuss … well, everything. What I am curious to see there:

- Mushroom lamps! That is, biofabricated lampshades grown with mushroom mycelium and hemp (MushLume Lighting)
- An AR mirror that tries on clothing for you (ZERO10) and 3D-printed clothing (Project B) – wouldn’t that make life easier!
3D-printed shoes (HILOS) and shoes made from apple skins (PROTA FIORI)
 - An AI-powered interactive version of a future me (Future You project by MIT Media Lab)
 - And finally, and perhaps most importantly: guilt-free chocolate made from plant proteins – no sugar required (Oobli)

The future of business is focused on AI, as are many of the event discussions and products to be displayed. As someone who works at a company that delivers services in the AI/ML space, I am excited to have conversations that can lead to some extraordinary ideas coming to life.
See you there!
#Intellias #GenAI #futureisnow

column7:
✨Career Highlight ✨Throughout my career in education, I’ve been blessed to receive numerous accolades, but one moment stands out as truly special. In late 2020, I became the inaugural VP/GM at 2U to launch Morehouse College Online – the online bachelor’s degree program of Morehouse College. We had examined the data and recognized that there were 3.4 million Black men over the age of 25 in the U.S. that had some college credit but no bachelor’s degree and we wanted to change this.

We partnered with President David Thomas and Morehouse College – the nation’s only Historically Black College and University (HBCU) dedicated to developing and educating men – to begin to address this problem by designing a high-caliber online learning experience and supportive brotherhood needed to become a Morehouse Man. We wanted to expand the genius of Morehouse College beyond the campus in Atlanta, GA and create a meaningful educational opportunity for Black talent to progress in their careers and pursue leadership positions that drive #EconomicMobility and #SocialChange.

In our first cohort in Fall 2021, we enrolled over 200 students, far beyond initial expectations!! ✨ YESTERDAY, I was filled with pride that 40 #amazing brothers from Morehouse College Online walked across the stage and received their diplomas 👨🏽‍🎓🤎 including brothers like Joe Williams! 👏🏾🙌🏾💪🏾

Although I am now a 2U alum and focused on another big problem in education – #ChronicAbsenteeism in K-12 schools – my goal is to create opportunities for our students to one day get accepted into top-ranked institutions like Morehouse College. 🙌🏾

Morehouse College Online would not have been possible without so many of my #exceptional 2U colleagues including our Co-Founder Chip Paucek, David Sutphen, Ebony Lee, Ebony N. Middleton, LMSW, CSM®, PMP®, Andre Singleton, Jeremy S., Krystal Johnson, Nicki Cornelius, Delilah Clayborne, MSW, Charsett Wright, Shaté L. Hayes and my #outstanding Morehouse colleagues including Provost Kendrick Brown, José Mallabo, Thelbert Snowden, Jr., Ed.D., Descatur "Des" Potier, Michael Gumm’MA, Illya E. Davis, Paula Resley, PCM, CDMP, CCMP, Jasmine Gurley, Justin Jones and many more!

Congratulations to all the brothers and graduates of Morehouse College Online!! 👏🏾👨🏽‍🎓🚀 I’m looking forward to seeing even more graduates in the future. Never underestimate what you can accomplish with intentionality, focus, and partnerships of purpose. 🙌🏾💪🏾

PS. I want to give a special shoutout to my mentee and the 92nd SGA President, Mekhi P., who graduated from the traditional Morehouse College program yesterday as well. Mekhi gave my son — an elementary school student at the time – a tour on campus a few years ago and I will never forget how much time and attention he provided him amongst a sea of high school students on that same tour. That’s just one example, but Mekhi is on the path to great things and becoming a man of consequence in this world! 👨🏽‍🎓💪🏾🚀

We are thrilled to announce Dr. Tyra Hall-Pogar as the new Department Chair for the Professional Studies Department at the School of Multidisciplinary and Professional Studies. Tyra officially began her new role today, April 29th. Join us in welcoming her to this exciting new chapter!

With nearly 15 years of dedication to our university, starting in 2009 as an adjunct faculty member in the Science Department, Tyra has made significant contributions across various capacities. She has enriched our academic community as a full-time faculty member, contributed to curriculum revisions, mentored fellow faculty, and led numerous courses with distinction.

Beyond her teaching, Dr. Hall-Pogar has played a pivotal role on several committees, including the Institutional Review Board and the General Education Science Literacy Committee, showcasing her commitment to enhancing educational standards and student experiences at Purdue Global.

Previously, as the Assistant Department Chair in the Humanities and Social Sciences Department, Tyra managed the Individual Learning Plan (ILP) and scheduling procedures, advocating strongly for our programs and leading several graduate MPS courses as an SME/course leader.

Before her tenure in academia, Tyra was a medical writer focusing on critical issues like antibiotic resistance and Alzheimer's disease. Her academic journey began at Neumann University, where she was an MCAT review editor in biochemistry. Dr. Hall-Pogar holds a PhD in biochemistry and molecular biology from Rutgers Graduate School of Biomedical Science, with research focused on RNA molecules.

Residing in Houston, TX, with her family, Tyra Hall-Pogar enjoys the outdoors, walking her dogs, and gardening.

We look forward to the innovation and leadership Dr. Hall-Pogar will bring to her new role. Here's to continued success!

Yesterday was a very emotional day for me. I went back to visit my undergrad alma mater Mount Holyoke College (MHC) — a place I absolutely love. They recognized my work with an honorary doctorate in Science. Additionally, I had the honor of delivering the commencement address for the graduating class. 

The class cheered as President Danielle Holley introduced me. Being welcomed that way by the graduating class was SO heart warming. I sat in their shoes exactly 20 years ago. I remember how big that moment felt. And all those feelings came right back as I delivered my address. 

My dad traveled from India to watch me get hooded. And my 9mo watched the full ceremony very curiously. I am so lucky to have had Mount Holyoke as my launch pad. I started my journey in AI there as an undergrad under the mentorship of an amazing roboticist who’d built one of the well known early robots in the field. That early research got me a Microsoft full scholarship to fund my undergrad and the opportunity (rare back then) to take on ambitious AI research as a college sophomore/junior alongside primarily PhD students and postdocs. 

As I’ve mentored students at The Johns Hopkins University and previously at Stanford University, I realize the importance of having an environment that supports women undergrads in STEM. There are so many unsaid barriers that exist today. Because I was at MHC, I experienced very little of it. Turns out, MHC has also produced the most number of women who go onto receive PhD in STEM fields. #thankyouMHC

Today, I am reflecting on the extraordinary journey of my friend, partner, and brother, Joe Frampus.  Together, we traveled the world and shaped an industry. From the dot com boom and bust, through the Information Age and into the Digital Age, we saw it all. Joe, as you embark on your next adventure, we are left with a treasure trove of lifelong memories, lasting legacies, and an enduring friendships.

As we grieve this immense loss, I find solace in the legacy Joe leaves behind. He taught us the true meaning of friendship and loyalty, and his memory will continue to guide us in our journey ahead.

Joe, as you embark on this new chapter, know that you carry with you the gratitude and admiration of those whose lives you have profoundly influenced. 

Here's to the adventures ahead and the memories that will always be with us. Thank you, Joe, for everything.
Avasant

A great privilege to study history for the past year at Yale, where the subject is still being taught rigorously and objectively.   To any potential career changers, it is never too late. And now to the next phase, persuading high school students that history matters.  Some reading suggestions from Yale faculty that you might enjoy. Professor David Blight, Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom, Tim Snyder, Bloodlands, Paul Bushkovitz, A Concise History of Russia, and Paul Kennedy, Victory at Sea.  The other remarkable book – and an easy read - published in 1919 that forewarned of the perils of the 1930s and 1940s  is Keynes, The Economic Consequences of the Peace. 
#Yale

column7:
I want to share a quote I've always tried to base my life around:

"Don't be the exception, set the expectation."

This week, 450 graduates will receive their diplomas from University of Southern California as part of a special ceremony focused on celebrating the unique achievements as members of the Latina/o and Hispanic community. 

For many in their family, they will be the exception, the first to graduate college — as I was in my own family. They will go on to land wonderful jobs working for great organizations — some, surely, will start-up their own companies.

I wish to share with these graduates the same encouragement I offer to the young entrepreneurs I mentor and work with at L’ATTITUDE Ventures, my venture fund that backs Latino-owned high growth startups; 27 outstanding companies, so far. 

Being the exception is something to be proud of. But your responsibility is to make this success the expectation, not the exception, for young people (of whatever background) who too seldom receive an equal share of opportunities. In other words, "Pave it Forward." 

Congratulations to the class of 2024!

#LatinoBusiness #Business #VC #LatinoCommunity #FutureLeaders

Joe was a pivotal part of our team at Avasant, and his absence will be deeply felt by all who knew him. He was not only a respected professional but also a remarkable leader, cherished mentor, and friend to all of us.

Joe's impact on Avasant and all who knew him was immeasurable. He brought laughter, wisdom, and a spirit of camaraderie that will be greatly missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with Joe's family during this difficult time.

Please join us in remembering Joe and keeping his family in your thoughts and prayers.

Sincerely, 
The Avasant Team

My learnings from mountains:

Today, I return back to the USA after an extraordinary few weeks in the breathtaking Himalayas region. Our group of seven embarked on conquering the heights of Gokyo, Kala Patthar, and Mt. Everest Base Camp. Words cannot adequately describe the sheer magnificence of these peaks, pristine glaciers and rugged landscapes that unfolded before my eyes! With each day presenting a new formidable challenge, this arduous expedition pushed the boundaries of our endurance to the very limits. However, the rewards of this journey far outweighs the struggles and etches three invaluable lessons on my soul:

#1 - It is all about the journey
No matter how high we climbed, there was an another mountain taller and more majestic awaiting our embrace. This is the essence of our existence – a relentless pursuit of growth, a constant unraveling of new puzzles to solve, and new horizons to explore. Life's odyssey is all about the journey and not the destination. Colorful memories of people, places and moments make life extraordinary!

#2 - You are a team
Our quest of conquering peaks very much depended on the collective strength as a team. It did not matter how strong an each individual was, all that mattered was what we, as an individual, added to the team's strength. We embarked on this journey as a team, struggled as a team, and emerged victorious as a team. This experience has reaffirmed the wisdom: "If you wish to travel swiftly, walk alone, but walk together if you seek to travel far"

#3 Mountain is you
"Mountain Is You" – a profound quote that I read on one chalkboard instantly ignited the fire within me, reminding of the limitless power we possess as a human. No matter how towering mountains were, their altitudes remained finite. We, as a human, possessed limitless power to conquer any summit that dared to stand in our way. This realization helped propel ourselves forward, and climbing on the mountains that once seemed formidable to us. Let this be the mantra of our life too.

After three wonderful years at Walmart, the company is transitioning to centralize its teams in Arkansas. Unfortunately, this move isn't in the plans for my family. While I'm sad to leave behind an amazing team and the incredible projects we've worked on, I'm also excited about the new opportunities that lie ahead. I do have a few months left to find something.

I have nearly 30 years of experience in the industry, with a rich history of leading UX teams at some of the top companies in the world, including Amazon, Home Depot, PayPal, GM, and Adobe. 

My journey at Walmart as the UX Director, leading our efforts in Adtech, Supplier B2B tools, and social commerce, has been incredibly rewarding. We've built innovative platforms and consolidated tools to enhance user experiences for advertisers and suppliers alike.

I'm now actively seeking UX leadership roles, either remote or hybrid, in the Denver area. If you know of any opportunities or can connect me with someone who does, I would greatly appreciate it. I'm looking forward to bringing my expertise in e-commerce and B2B to new challenges and contributing to another amazing team.

Thank you for your support and connections! Let’s stay in touch. column7:
🎉Announcement 🎉 
 
Dechra today announces the appointment of Jesper D. Nordengaard as its CEO and the retirement of Ian Page effective June 10, 2024. 

Jesper Nordengaard will join Dechra from Colgate-Palmolive where he is currently President, North America. Jesper previously was President and CEO of Hill’s Pet Nutrition, an iconic global pet food brand anchored in science and recommendation. He brings successful experiences in animal health and consumer brands globally, with a focus on innovation and commercial execution.
 
Jesper shared, "I am honoured to be given the opportunity and responsibility to lead Dechra into its next chapter. Dechra has an enviable position in a large, resilient and growing animal health market and a clear vision and purpose, making this an exciting time for the business."
 
We bid a fond farewell to Ian Page, whose 42-year journey in the Animal Health industry, including 23 years as our CEO, has been nothing short of remarkable. We thank Ian for his leadership and wish him a well-deserved retirement!
 
Expressing confidence in Dechra's continued success, Ian added, “I would like to thank the veterinary community for all their support. Dechra remains well positioned for further growth and will continue to prosper. I look forward to watching the business flourish in the years ahead, and I wish Jesper every success in his new role.”

Read the full article here https://lnkd.in/eyF6ZUHU

#Dechra #LeadershipTransition #NewBeginnings #TheVeterinaryPerspective

column7: So proud of the work we are doing at Blackstone partnering with our portfolio companies to help manage healthcare costs and provide an exceptional concierge service experience for their employees. We've held medical inflation to an average of 2% and achieved an NPS of 79 over the past 15 years, while partnering with innovative companies like Twin Health to help reverse Type II diabetes. Our future is so bright!

A personal note...
We all come from somewhere and reflect indelible elements of people that have been part of making us who we are. I would like to honor one of those people for me--my father. He passed away the other week, and I have alternated between mourning his loss and heralding his accomplishments. 

He was the definition of a self-made man and entrepreneur. He built his company from the ground up, and instilled hard work and determination in his children. He was exacting and methodical, creative and smart, and always looking at new ventures and deals. When I told him about starting Second Curve Strategies, he was enthusiastic and proud.

As I begin my own entrepreneurial journey, I think about his business acumen and indomitable spirit. I am grateful to have had him as an example. And I won't let him down. I love you, Dad.

I’m excited to share the great news that Matthew Metsker PA-C, MPAS, MHA has transitioned into the role of president at St. Clare Hospital in Lakewood and Danna Shaner is assuming  the role of president at St. Elizabeth Hospital in Enumclaw.  We conducted extensive national searches to fill these roles, but ultimately found the very best candidates right here at home. Both Matt and Danna have been highly impactful, collaborative leaders at Virginia Mason Franciscan Health for a number of years, and we are proud that they are taking the next steps in their careers within our system. Matt spent the past five years leading VMFH's Mission Control and Virtual Hospital operations, turning them into hubs of efficiency and progress - but when he first joined VMFH he was a hospitalist at St. Clare, so this is a full circle moment for him. Danna was most recently market director of hospital operations for VMFH, while also serving as interim senior director of ambulatory services, medical and surgical specialties at VMMC. We are incredibly fortunate to have both of these exceptional leaders in our health system and I’m confident that they will help us better serve the growing communities in Enumclaw and Lakewood in their new roles. 
#healthcareleadership
#healthadministration
#hospitaladministration
column21: Congratulations Danna and Matt!

column7:
Last week, our amazing Emerging Leadership Program (ELP) had their graduation after a year of online sessions, leader presentations, and facility visits. The group of extraordinary individuals shared their learnings with leadership, showcasing the program's impact. Though unable to attend the closing ceremonies in person, I am grateful for the opportunity to lead a session and travel with the group. It has been a truly rewarding experience to get to know each one of you!

Reflecting on the evolution of the program over the years amazes me. Partnering with Ruth Villegas, we piloted the program for the Global Operations team six years ago. Its success led to launching it for US emerging leaders. With Ruth and Kaitlyn Arnold now at the helm, our first class encompassed all Topgolf Callaway Brands, expanding globally to include employees in Europe and China.

Congratulations to all our ELP graduates! Your achievements are a testament to your dedication and hard work. I look forward to witnessing the incredible contributions you will make in the future!

Isn't it amazing what believing in someone can do? 

In most cases, it can completely can change their life. 

We never forget those first managers, mentors, and leaders who saw something in us and said "Yep, I want to work with you."

Hiring the "perfect person" or the "perfect candidate" doesn't really exist. 

And while qualifications and meeting certain criteria will always have an important place, there's A LOT MORE we often learn just by doing. 

Trust and support really does go a long way.

This week, I had the honor of kicking off the Annual Morgan Stanley Sustainable Finance Summit at our NYC headquarters. 
 
The two-day event, focused on driving growth and profitability through sustainability, featured discussions on the importance of DEI in driving business performance, responsibilities of boards in governing risks and opportunities, climate change, the carbon offsets markets and the role of governments in accelerating the transition. With more than 90% of sustainability business leaders expecting climate change to impact their business model by 2050, and almost a quarter of respondents having already seen the effects of climate change on their business (according to our 2024 Sustainable Signals Report), these critical dialogues are essential to a deeper understanding of the business opportunities that exist and helping chart a path to a more sustainable future. 
 
Kudos to Jessica Alsford, Melissa James and our cross-firm Sustainability team, and thanks to all the impressive panelists who joined us!

column7:
The diary of a leader on Wednesday.
Wednesday Wake Up: complete.

7 hours of sleep|No phone in bed.
1 hour Movement|Outside.
Black coffee|No creamer|Focus on nutrient dense whole foods|No processed stuff.
2-20 minutes of quiet|breathwork|prayer|mindfulness.

It's wild how simple these four commitments seem, yet how hard they are to keep!

However, when my day includes these four commitments: 
Sleep | Movement | Nutrition | Mindfulness

I show up differently.

I show up awake.

It’s crazy how much ROI the basics of health and wellness give us as leaders.

Anyone else have a Wake Up practice?

"Alone, we can do so little; together, we can do so much." – Helen Keller

I am delighted to announce that I will serve as an advisor to the Global Fund within the Private Sector Advisory Group. 

The Global Fund is a worldwide partnership to defeat HIV, TB and malaria and ensure a healthier, safer, more equitable future for all. The fund raises and invests more than US$5 billion a year to fight the deadliest infectious diseases, challenge the injustice that fuels them, and strengthen health systems and pandemic preparedness in more than 100 of the hardest hit countries.

The Global Fund unites world leaders, communities, civil society, health workers and the private sector to find solutions that have the most impact, and  then take them to scale worldwide.

To achieve the greatest impact against the deadliest infectious diseases, the fund challenges power dynamics to ensure affected communities have an equal voice in the fight and an equal chance at a healthy future. 

This incredible opportunity allows me to contribute to an organization dedicated to fighting the world's most pressing health challenges and working towards a more equitable future.

I am honored to play a small role in this collective effort and look forward to collaborating with brilliant minds to drive impactful solutions.

Together, we can achieve a healthier, more equitable world. 🌍💪

column7:
This past week, we celebrated Founder’s Day here at Chick-fil-A, an annual tradition where we honor the legacy of our founder — my granddad — S. Truett Cathy.

So many of Granddad’s ideas that may have seemed small at the time have become a big part of his legacy.

For example, once while visiting a hotel, an employee responded to his thank you with a sincere “My pleasure.” Granddad decided he wanted every Guest in our Restaurants to feel the way he felt when he heard that response, and the rest is history. Every day, thousands of Chick-fil-A Team Members tell Guests “My pleasure” when they serve them, and it’s become part of an authentic Chick-fil-A experience.

Another example is from the late 1940s when Granddad learned one of his Team Members, Eddie White, needed help attending college. So, he placed an empty mayonnaise jar on the counter of his Dwarf Grill in Hapeville, GA, for customers and other Team Members to donate toward what became Eddie White’s college fund. Eddie went on to attend Morris Brown College and had a successful teaching career, eventually serving as assistant superintendent of schools in Clayton County, GA. This year, a record $26.4 million was awarded in Chick-fil-A Remarkable Futures scholarships, making a difference in the lives of more than 14,000 Team Members.

I think the most important part of Granddad’s legacy is the Corporate Purpose he and Chick-fil-A leaders adopted decades ago, which still guides us today: To glorify God by being a faithful steward of all that is entrusted to us. To have a positive influence on all who come in contact with Chick-fil-A. 

I miss my granddad, but reminders of his legacy are with us at Chick-fil-A, not just on Founder’s Day but every day.

Last week I traveled to Rome and the Vatican with Mayor Michelle Wu to participate in a climate change summit hosted by the Pontifical Academies of Sciences and Social Sciences. I was honored to meet Pope Francis and to thank him for his science-based commitment to end climate change. Meeting and reconnecting with friends from global cities, academics, and government officials was a source of inspiration--and a long follow-up list! It is so exciting to see Boston's progress on the Green New Deal hilighlited on the global stage. As Mayor Wu remarked, the community that gathered for this summit demonstrated the human energy that people from all walks of life are dedicating to the climate crisis. It was an honor to be a part of the team representing the City of Boston, as well as our tremendous Team Massachusetts. 

Much appreciation and admiration to Marcelo M Suarez-Orozco and Matt Fenlon for such a successful summit. Thank you to our hosts in the City of Rome, including edoardo zanchini, for showing us their beautiful city and exchanging climate change strategies at the local level.  Wonderful to connect with C40 Cities Mayors and staff too!

Both Matt and Danna have been highly impactful, collaborative leaders at Virginia Mason Franciscan Health for a number of years, and we are proud that they are taking the next steps in their careers within our system. The Village Board on Tuesday appointed Thomas Tilton to the position of Police Chief.

Chief Tilton served with the United States Secret Service for 26 years as a leader in law enforcement, security and investigative operations. He held various vital operational roles, overseeing and managing numerous large-scale operations.

Chief Tilton joined the Tinley Park Police Department in September 2021 as Deputy Police Chief of Administration and has been serving as Interim Police Chief since September.

Chief Tilton has served for more than 10 years as the Deputy Director of Operations for the Department of Emergency Management and Regional Security, overseeing tactical response operations within a critical agency comprised of 134 municipalities, 30 townships, 5.4 million residents and 945 square miles of territory.

Chief Tilton has various certifications from the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Schedule Board (ILETSB) as a Certified SWAT Operator, the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA) as a Certified Professional Emergency Manager, and the Illinois Tactical Officers Association (ITOA) as a Certified Tactical Patrol Officer. He has received numerous awards and recognitions for his outstanding achievements and service.

column7: Mother Nature is a beast! Remember, if you ever see a downed wire or pole, assume that it is energized, stay away and call 1-800-EDISON1 to report it.

It's clear that nursing in Taiwan is nothing like it is here, and they don't find it hard at all. The group consisted of two critical care nurses, one acute care nurse, and one neonatal ICU nurse. Learning from them and seeing their passion for their work was a pleasure. 

#Nursing #InternationalExchange #Healthcare

column7:
Every challenge we face in life presents an opportunity for growth and transformation. Whether it's a minor setback or a major crisis, each experience offers us the chance to learn something about ourselves, our abilities, and our resilience. By embracing these challenges with an open mind and a willingness to learn, we can turn them into valuable life lessons that help us to become stronger, more compassionate, and more adaptable individuals. So, the next time you find yourself facing a difficult situation, remember to look for the lessons it has to offer and use them to fuel your personal growth and development.

Today, President Biden welcomes President Ruto of Kenya for a State Visit and Dinner to celebrate and deepen ties between our two nations, marking years of official U.S.-Kenya partnership.  The two leaders’ agenda includes enhancing our partnership on clean energy and resilience, which includes deepening U.S.-Africa Nuclear Industry Cooperation. 

To further this goal, and as announced in the FACTSHEET, one of the deliverables is that the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) in partnership with Kenya and Ghana, plans to host the second installment of the U.S.-Africa Nuclear Energy Summit (USANES) on Industry Readiness in Nairobi, Kenya, in August 2024. Recognizing the historic relationship between the United States and Kenya, USANES 2024 envisions U.S. and African policymakers, technical experts, and industry leaders convening in Nairobi to address critical issues impacting industry readiness and the future of nuclear energy on the African continent.  The Summit comprises educational workshops, stakeholder engagement sessions, and multilateral discussions on topics from financing and workforce development to supply chain preparedness.

(more info: Office of Nuclear Energy, U.S. Department of Energy, Aleshia Duncan, Anushya Ramaswamy)

Just back from Lisbon, and wow, what a retreat! A vibrant mix of our firm's leaders from around the globe all gathered in one place. 
 
It was a whirlwind of insightful conversations, strategic planning, and a celebration of what makes AlixPartners truly exceptional.
 
Amidst the workshops and strategy sessions, there were plenty of moments to catch up with old friends, make new connections, and feel the global team's heart beat as one. 
 
Of course, as Francesco (pictured below) prepares to spread his wings and embark on his new venture, I had to snap a pic of what might be our last PMD retreat together. 
 
Thank you to the events team and everyone in Lisbon. Couldn’t be more excited of the future we're building together.

Layoffs have impacted a huge number of people, and I continue to see words of encouragement and support from the community. Kudos to everyone who's supporting each other at this time.

If you're looking to stay productive while finding your next career move, here's some tips to keep in mind:

1. Find a project you're passionate about and contribute to it 💡🧠💡 
We often lose sight of our creative ideas or projects we wanted to work on when we're full-time employees. Take the time now to pursue your passions and connect with others who share your interests.

2. Manage your time wisely ⌛⌛⌛ 
Balancing your time between projects, networking, and learning is critical. Don't aim to do it all at once. Use Sundays to set your goals and balance your time for the upcoming week.

3. Take care of your health 🏃‍♂️🏃‍♀️☀ 
Make time for walks to get Vitamin D and exercise regularly. Taking care of your mind and body is crucial for your progress. Being proactive about your health can help you stay focused and positive.

If you have more tips, pls share. #productivity #careeradvice #support #timemanagement #selfcare
